('6', 0, 1, 2, 42) 1. CIRCULAR FOR MEETING AT HOUSE OF COMMONS 1
('6', 0, 2, 3, 88) HOUSE OF COMMONS, November 5, 1906
('6', 0, 3, 4, 123) DEAR SIR, A meeting of the Liberal, Labour and Nationalist Members of this House will take place at 6 p.m.
('6', 0, 3, 5, 230) on Wednesday next, the 7th inst.
('6', 0, 3, 6, 263) in the Grand Committee Room, to hear the British Indian Deputation that has arrived from the Transvaal, in connection with the Ordinance passed by the Legislative Council of that Colony, termed the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance, and to pass a resolution.
('6', 0, 3, 7, 520) In the opinion of the Delegates, the Ordinance reduces the British Indian settlers of the Transvaal to a position much worse than they occupied under the Boer regime and even than that of the Kaffirs.
('6', 0, 3, 8, 721) They contend that the Ordinance in question is in contravention of promises repeatedly made by British Ministers and in conflict with British traditions.
('6', 0, 3, 9, 875) The undersigned trust that you will be good enough to attend the meeting.
('6', 0, 4, 10, 949) We are,
('6', 0, 5, 11, 957) Yours faithfully, HENRY COTTON R. LEHMANN H. COX J. M. ROBERTSON CHARLES W. DILKE A. H. SCOTT
('6', 0, 6, 12, 1051) CHARLES SWANN2 J. WARD
('6', 0, 7, 13, 1074) From a photostat of the typewritten office copy: S. N. 4482

('6', 5, 11, 15, 5598) 1 The address at the top would suggest that the letter was from Dadabhai Naoroji, but this copy was found among Gandhiji's papers.
('6', 5, 11, 16, 5729) Gandhiji's letter to him dated November 17 (vide “Letter to Dadabhai Naoroji”, 17 11 1906) shows that, during the Deputation's stay in England, Mr. Naoroji sent all papers received from South Africa to Gandhiji who returned them offering comment and explanation and sometimes suggesting courses of action.
('6', 5, 11, 17, 6035) It is thus very likely that Gandhiji drafted the letter because of his ready familiarity with the South African situation.

('6', 11, 0, 1, 12307) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 11, 1, 2, 12348) [ENCLOSURE] Precis of Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance, 1906 1
('6', 11, 2, 3, 12410) [LONDON,] November 2, 1906 DEFINITION: The term “Asiatic” shall mean any such person as is described in Article 1 of Law [3] of 1885. The term “Asiatic” under Law 3 of 1885 includes the so called coolies, Arabs, Malays, Mohammedan subjects of the Turkish Dominions.
('6', 11, 2, 4, 12676) This Ordinance however excepts the Malays from its operation.
('6', 11, 2, 5, 12738) Registration: Section 3 requires every lawfully resident Asiatic in the Transvaal to be registered, for which no charges shall be made, and in accordance with the section, an Asiatic lawfully resident is one who has received, or may receive, a permanent permit to enter and reside in the.
('6', 11, 2, 6, 13027) Transvaal, unless such permit is fraudulently obtained, or any Asiatic resident and actually in the Transvaal on the 31st day of May 1902. SECTION 4: Requires every such Asiatic to make an application for registration, such application to be made in the case of children under 16 years of age by their parents or guardians.
('6', 11, 2, 7, 13351) SECTION 5: Lays down that, if the application for registration is refused, the applicant shall be directed to leave the Colony, under the process described in the section.
('6', 11, 2, 8, 13523) SECTION 6: Says that any Asiatic who is the guardian of any Asiatic child under the age of eight years shall upon making application for registration on his own behalf supply such particulars and furnish such means of identification in respect of such child as may be prescribed by regulation, and if such guardian is himself registered, the particulars aforesaid which he has supplied shall be provisionally noted on the Register, and such guardian shall within one year make application for registration on such child’s behalf at the office of the Resident Magistrate of the district in which he himself resides.
('6', 11, 2, 9, 14138) The section then proceeds to lay down the procedure for the separate registration of such child after he has attained the age of eight years.
('6', 11, 3, 10, 14280) 1 This was prepared by Gandhiji to apprise sympathizers, particularly members of the introducing deputation, of the real scope and nature of the Ordinance.
('6', 12, 0, 1, 14436) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 13
('6', 12, 1, 2, 14479) SECTION 7: Deals further with the registration of children.
('6', 12, 1, 3, 14539) SECTION 8: Provides that any person who shall fail to make application for registration.
('6', 12, 1, 4, 14628) .either on his own behalf or as guardian shall be liable on conviction to a fine not excee ding One Hundred Pounds, and in default of payment to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a period not exceeding three months.
('6', 12, 1, 5, 14855) SECTION 9: Provides that every Asiatic of the age of 16 years and upwards entering or residing in the Transvaal shall upon demand made upon him by any member of the Police Force lawfully established in this Colony, or any other person authorized thereto by the Colonial Secretary, produce the certificate of registration 1 of which he is the lawful holder, and shall also on like demand supply such means of identification as may be prescribed by regulation.
('6', 12, 1, 6, 15314) In the case of children under 16 years, the guardians or parents have to produce a certificate and supply particulars of identification.
('6', 12, 1, 7, 15451) SECTION 10: Makes certificates of registration conclusive evidence as to the right of the lawful holder to remain in the Colony.
('6', 12, 1, 8, 15580) (N.B. To day every Asiatic in possession of his permit has such right by law.) SECTION[S] 11 & 12: Lay down the procedure for lost certificates.
('6', 12, 1, 9, 15725) SECTION 13: Provides that no Asiatic shall obtain a license to trade without production of certificate of registration.
('6', 12, 1, 10, 15845) SECTION 14: Makes the Registrar practically the arbiter as to the age of an Asiatic.
('6', 12, 1, 11, 15930) SECTION 15: Exempts declarations made for the purposes of the Ordinance from stamp duty.
('6', 12, 1, 12, 16019) SECTION 16: Imposes a fine of £500 or in default imprisonment with or without hard labour for a term not exceeding two years, or both fine and imprisonment, for the following acts:
('6', 12, 2, 13, 16200) (1) Any fraudulent or false statement or incitement to make such statement in connection with registration.
('6', 12, 3, 14, 16308) (2) Forgery of registration certificate.
('6', 12, 4, 15, 16349) 1 For the form of this certificate, vide appendix.
('6', 13, 0, 1, 16400) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 13, 1, 2, 16441) (3) Use of such certificate by a person not the lawful holder.
('6', 13, 1, 3, 16504) (4) Incitement to any person to use such certificate.
('6', 13, 2, 4, 16558) SECTION 17: Authorizes the issue of temporary permits, and authorizes the Lieutenant Governor at his discretion to order that any Asiatic in possession of a temporary permit “shall not during the currency of such permit be deemed to be a Coloured person for the purpose of the provision of the Liquor Ordinance”.
('6', 13, 3, 5, 16871) SECTION 18: Gives the Lieutenant Governor power to frame regulations under the Ordinance.
('6', 13, 4, 6, 16961) SECTION 19: Generally provides that any Asiatic failing to comply with any requirement of the Ordinance shall be liable to a fine not exceeding £100, or in default to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a period not exceeding three months.
('6', 13, 5, 7, 17210) The other Sections provide a heavy penalty for any Asiatic bringing without a permit a child under 16 years of age into the Colony, and among other things cancels [sic] such person’s permit and certificate of registration, and renders him liable to expulsion, and makes it lawful for the heirs of the late Aboo Baker Ahmed to hold a piece of land bought by the late Aboo Baker Ahmed before 1885, and left under his will to the heirs.
('6', 13, 6, 8, 17644) From a photostat of the typewritten office copy: S. N. 4447

('6', 18, 3, 4, 22798) THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO

('6', 18, 5, 6, 22859) HIS MAJESTY’S PRINCIPAL SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE COLONIES
('6', 18, 6, 7, 22919) COLONIAL OFFICE
('6', 18, 9, 8, 22935) I have the honour to acknowledge your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to my request for an interview with Lord Elgin on the position of British Indians in Natal.
('6', 18, 9, 9, 23107) I have no desire to open the whole position, but if His Lordship would be graciously pleased to grant me an interview, I shall be able to show the inner working of the Natal legislation.
('6', 18, 9, 10, 23294) I was privileged to come into very close contact with the late Sir John Robinson 1 and the late Mr. Harry Escombe, who were the joint authors of the Immigration Restriction Act and the Dealers' Licenses Act.
('6', 18, 9, 11, 23502) These two, and especially the latter, are the cause of very great and constant irritation.
('6', 18, 9, 12, 23593) Very serious injustice, in my humble opinion, has often been done in the administration of the Licenses Act.
('6', 18, 10, 13, 23702) I invite His Lordship's attention to the fact that even after the Act was passed, there was a confidential despatch from Mr. Chamberlain to the Natal Ministry as to the operation of the Act.
('6', 18, 10, 14, 23893) The despatch was partly published, and it stated that unless the municipal bodies exercised the arbitrary powers given to them in virtue of the Licenses Act in a reasonable manner, it might become necessary to amend the Act.
('6', 18, 10, 15, 24118) I am aware that His Lordship's intervention as to these Acts can only be diplomatic, and it is such intervention I would like to invoke.
('6', 18, 10, 16, 24255) The object of the interview is to the best of my ability to place the position so before His Lordship as to enlist His Lordship's active
('6', 18, 11, 17, 24392) 1 (1839 1903); first Prime Minister, and Colonial Secretary of Natal, 1893 7.
('6', 19, 0, 1, 24470) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 19, 1, 2, 24511) intervention so far as it may be consistent with the traditional policy of the Colonial Office.
('6', 19, 1, 3, 24607) The new Bill 1 introduced by Mr. Ralph Tatham in the Legislative Assembly makes it all the more imperative for me to approach His Lordship.
('6', 19, 1, 4, 24747) I regret exceedingly that the Authority referred to in my letter was not enclosed with it: it was an oversight, for which I beg to be excused.
('6', 19, 1, 5, 24890) I have now sent it through Mr. Ritch, the Secretary to the Transvaal Deputation.
('6', 19, 1, 6, 24971) As I have not kept a copy of the Authority, may I ask you to let me have one.
('6', 19, 2, 7, 25049) I have the honour to remain,
('6', 19, 4, 8, 25078) Your obedient servant, M. K. GANDHI

('6', 20, 6, 9, 26363) 26. MEETING AT HOUSE OF COMMONS 1
('6', 20, 7, 10, 26397) A meeting of more than a hundred Members of the House of Commons, drawn from the Liberal, Labour and Nationalist Parties, was addressed by Gandhiji and Mr. Ally in the Grand Committee Room of the House.
('6', 20, 8, 11, 26600) LONDON, November 7, 1906]
('6', 20, 9, 12, 26626) ...Mr. Gandhi said that in 1885 British Indians were described in documents
('6', 20, 10, 13, 26702) 1 Several members spoke.
('6', 20, 10, 14, 26727) Sir Henry Cotton, the Chairman of the meeting, said that, under this Ordinance, British Indians were placed under the surveillance of the police in a manner which could not be differentiated from the treatment given in England to prisoners who were released from jail.
('6', 20, 10, 15, 26996) Mr. Ally appealed in the name of Christianity and humanity for the support of British Members of Parliament in freeing Indians from a degrading law.
('6', 20, 10, 16, 27145) Sir Charles Dilke said that it was notorious that there was a great jealousy of Indians because they made such admirable shopkeepers and medical men.
('6', 20, 10, 17, 27295) Mr. Joseph Walton, Mr. Harold Cox and Mr. Higham supported a proposal to sign a memorial to the Prime Minister regarding the status of British Indians in the Transvaal.
('6', 20, 10, 18, 27464) Sir Henry Cotton summed up the feelings of the meeting by saying that the question had become one of Imperial importance and had thus been taken out of the realm of party politics.
('6', 20, 10, 19, 27645) A resolution supporting the objectives of the Deputation was then unanimously adopted.
('6', 21, 0, 1, 27732) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 21, 1, 2, 27773) which passed between the Republican Government and the British Government as ‘filthy vermin and persons without souls’.
('6', 21, 1, 3, 27893) They were then under great disabilities; they could not hold landed property, except in Locations that might be set apart for them for sanitary purposes, and they were required to register themselves and pay a fee to the Transvaal Government.
('6', 21, 1, 4, 28136) Lord Derby tried to mitigate their grievances, and Mr. Chamberlain afterwards wrote a strong despatch to the Boer Government about British Indians, whom he described as honourable men and an asset of great importance to the Transvaal.
('6', 21, 1, 5, 28371) The result of this was that British Indians went about the country as free citizens, and there was absolutely no restriction upon their movements.
('6', 21, 1, 6, 28518) Recently a new Ordinance had been passed and British Indian subjects were classed with Asiatics and were treated in a most degrading manner....

('6', 21, 6, 11, 28873) THE PETITION OF THE UNDERSIGNED, RESIDING IN THE UNITED KINGDOM, REPRESENTING WHOLESALE HOUSES IN SOUTH AFRICA
('6', 21, 7, 12, 28984) HUMBLY SHEWETH
('6', 21, 8, 13, 28999) That your Petitioners are all London wholesale Shipping Firms and Merchants, having branches in, or in connection with, South Africa.
('6', 21, 8, 14, 29133) Most of your Petitioners have come into direct contact with British Indian Merchants in South Africa, including the Transvaal.
('6', 21, 8, 15, 29260) From their experience of British Indian Merchants in the Transvaal your Petitioners are in a position to state that the British Indian Merchants in the Transvaal are on the whole an honest and honourable body of men, and their connection with them has always
('6', 21, 9, 16, 29519) 1 The petition was clearly drafted by Gandhiji.

('6', 22, 1, 2, 29673) been of a most satisfactory nature.

('6', 22, 1, 4, 29828) At the very least their presence there tends to the distinct benefit of the Transvaal community by reducing the cost of living expenses to those who can least afford to pay the exorbitantly high prices and profits demanded by the European firms.
('6', 22, 1, 5, 30074) Your Petitioners have read the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance, and in your Petitioners’ opinion the Ordinance will submit British Indians in the Transvaal to totally unnecessary indignity and hardship.
('6', 22, 1, 6, 30277) Your Petitioners desire to associate themselves entirely with the sentiments expressed in the Memorial submitted to His Excellency the Governor of the Transvaal by Mr. William Hosken and other notable European residents in the Transvaal in the month of April, 1903. 1
('6', 22, 2, 7, 30545) In your Petitioners’ humble opinion, while it is desirable that immigration of British Indians should be regulated in order to allay popular prejudice, they think that it should be along the Cape or Natal lines, and should not savour of class distinction.
('6', 22, 2, 8, 30801) Your Petitioners therefore pray that Your Lordship will be pleased to advise His Majesty to disallow the Ordinance above mentioned, or to grant such relief as will adequately protect the British Indians who have settled in the Transvaal.
('6', 22, 2, 9, 31039) And for this act of justice and mercy, your Petitioners shall ever pray, etc.

('6', 23, 1, 3, 31767) It is remarkable how the Delegates from the Transvaal have received support and sympathy from all quarters.
('6', 23, 1, 4, 31875) A most striking illustration perhaps was afforded by the meeting of the Liberal, Labour, and Nationalist Members of the House of Commons at the Grand Committee Room on Wednesday last under the chairmanship of Sir Henry Cotton, the Member for Nottingham East.
('6', 23, 1, 5, 32134) The attendance was fully one hundred.
('6', 23, 1, 6, 32172) The Members gave the Delegates a very sympathetic hearing, and many of them showed their active sympathy by making short speeches for or questioning the Delegates.
('6', 23, 1, 7, 32336) A resolution supporting the objects of the Delegation was unanimously adopted.
('6', 23, 1, 8, 32415) One of the Members even wanted to know why the Conservative Members had not been invited to the meeting.
('6', 23, 1, 9, 32520) Sir Charles Dilke, who has consistently championed the cause of British Indians in South Africa, immediately interposed that it was an oversight and that this was a question in which they could certainly secure Conservative co operation.
('6', 23, 1, 10, 32758) They and the Liberal Parliament always joined the the Conservatives in securing redress for their Indian fellow subjects in South Africa.
('6', 23, 1, 11, 32896) Mr. Scott, who was the organizer of the meeting, remarked that the only reason why the Circular Letter 1 was confined to the Liberal, Labour, and Nationalist Members was that the Government that was being approached by the Delegates was a Liberal Government, and it was considered only right that the meeting should take the form it did.
('6', 23, 1, 12, 33234) At the same time they would undoubtedly ask for and be willing to secure the co operation of Conservative Members.
('6', 23, 1, 13, 33349) Sir Henry Cotton added that on the deputation were represented very staunch Conservatives.
('6', 23, 1, 14, 33440) These proceedings take the question out of party politics, and as Sir Charles Dilke has often said, it becomes a question of Imperial importance.
('6', 23, 1, 15, 33586) These proceedings ought to strengthen the hands of Lord Elgin and encourage him to veto the Ordinance, or at least to appoint a commission on which the Delegates lay so much stress.
('6', 23, 1, 16, 33768) The Representation submitted to Lord Elgin exhaustively deals with the facts of the case, and shows clearly how unnecessary the legislation is, and how much harder it is than Law 3 of 1885. It is
('6', 23, 2, 17, 33964) 1 Vide “Circular for Meeting at House of Commons”, 5 11 1906.
('6', 24, 0, 1, 34026) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 25
('6', 24, 1, 2, 34069) undoubtedly not an amendment, but a new law, making class distinctions of a very offensive nature.
('6', 24, 1, 3, 34168) The prayer of the Delegates is very reasonable.
('6', 24, 1, 4, 34216) They ask Lord Elgin to sanction legislation along the Cape or Natal line[s], leaving it open to British Indian settlers to import assistants and such other men as may be required for attention to their businesses.
('6', 24, 1, 5, 34430) If such legislation be passed it would remove all fear of an unrestricted Asiatic influx.
('6', 24, 1, 6, 34520) There would then be no necessity for the espionage contemplated by the Ordinance.
('6', 24, 1, 7, 34602) That the lot of the British Indians is hard enough without any such legislation is shown by a recent prosecution of an Asiatic child 1
('6', 24, 2, 8, 34737) under eleven years of age for entering the Colony of the Transvaal in the company of his father.
('6', 24, 2, 9, 34834) We cannot do better than quote the words of the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Transvaal who quashed the conviction of the child:
('6', 24, 3, 10, 34975) The conviction is wholly bad.
('6', 24, 3, 11, 35005) Here is a child of between ten and eleven years of age, charged not with an ordinary Common Law offence, but with the offence of entering the Transvaal by means of a permit improperly obtained.
('6', 24, 3, 12, 35199) It does appear—at any rate, there is evidence on the record to show—that the thumb mark of this infant was pressed on a permit belonging to someone else.
('6', 24, 3, 13, 35353) But this child was not doli capax at all.
('6', 24, 3, 14, 35395) The child was put into the box, and said he did not know what a permit was, and had never seen one; and I dare say he was speaking the truth.
('6', 24, 3, 15, 35537) There can be no doubt that the conviction cannot be sustained for one moment.
('6', 24, 4, 16, 35615) The administrative order, of course, still remains.
('6', 24, 4, 17, 35667) The Magistrate has seriously ordered this infant to leave the Transvaal at the expiration of the term of imprisonment, or upon a certain date, whichever happens sooner.
('6', 24, 4, 18, 35836) If the child does not go away—and I do not suppose he can go away unless someone takes him—he will then, possibly, be brought up before the Magistrate as a criminal.
('6', 24, 4, 19, 36002) But I trust that course will not be taken by the authorities.
('6', 24, 4, 20, 36064) I cannot understand why this case was taken up at all.
('6', 24, 4, 21, 36119) It is a very important matter.
('6', 24, 4, 22, 36150) This child is an Indian; but the same would apply to any white child (not one of the exempted classes under the Ordinance) entering the Transvaal; and if it applies to a child of eleven, why not to a child in arms!
('6', 24, 4, 23, 36365) Surely it was never intended that such an administrative order should be made, in circumstances of this kind.
('6', 24, 4, 24, 36475) This legislation is sufficiently open to criticism without that.
('6', 24, 4, 25, 36540) If there is anything which can bring the administration of such a
('6', 24, 5, 26, 36606) 1 Mahomed Hafeji Moosa; Vide “Transvaal Permit Ordinance”, 29 9 1906.
('6', 25, 0, 1, 36676) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 25, 1, 2, 36717) law into ridicule and contempt it is administration conducted on the lines of this case.
('6', 25, 1, 3, 36806) I trust we shall hear nothing more about the administrative order.
('6', 25, 2, 4, 36873) We had only the other day an example of what The Rand Daily Mail described as “War on Women” 1 In the above case, we have an instance of what Indian Opinion describes to be “War on Infants”.
('6', 25, 2, 5, 37064) Cases such as these call for prompt amelioration, and not for greater severity.
('6', 25, 2, 6, 37144) The doctrine of relying on men on the spot will be carried to ridiculous extremes if Lord Elgin does not heed the representations made to him on behalf of British Indians in the Transvaal.
('6', 25, 2, 7, 37333) Very strong support is given to the delegation by a personal appeal 2 of five British Indians addressed to Lord Elgin in connection with the Ordinance.
('6', 25, 2, 8, 37485) They are all students from South Africa studying for the Bar or for Medicine, born or brought up in South Africa, and in their words, “South Africa is more our home than India.
('6', 25, 2, 9, 37662) Even our mother tongue is English, our parents having brought us up to speak that language from our infancy.
('6', 25, 2, 10, 37771) Three of us are Christians, one a Mahomedan, and one a Hindoo.” Are these men, after they have become barristers or doctors, on their return to South Africa, to be debarred from entering the Transvaal, or are they to carry “tickets of leave” as Sir Henry Cotton described the passes to be issued under the new Ordinance?
('6', 25, 2, 11, 38092) If such legislation is to be the vogue in the Colonies, it would be a mercy not to allow the British Indians to receive a liberal education in England at all, because a memory of the good times passed by them in England would only enhance the sting of humiliation to be undergone by them in Colonies which are British only in name and un British in conduct.

('6', 26, 8, 9, 39132) MY LORD,

('6', 26, 9, 11, 39256) The task before Mr. Ally and myself is, I know, exceedingly delicate and difficult, supported though we are by friends who have always helped us in our troubles, and representing different schools of politics, and who have come to give us the weight of their influence at considerable trouble to themselves, especially on a day like this.
('6', 26, 9, 12, 39595) Your Lordship is aware that there was a great Indian Mass Meeting held at which resolutions were adopted.
('6', 26, 9, 13, 39701) The text of these resolutions was cabled to Your Lordship 3 and in reply 4 Your Lordship was pleasedto send a cablegram informing the British Indian Asso ciation that Your Lordship had approved of the draft Ordinance in

('6', 27, 0, 1, 40504) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 27, 1, 2, 40545) that it gave some measure of relief to British Indians.
('6', 27, 1, 3, 40601) We, who are on the spot and to whom the Ordinance applies, think, with the greatest deference, that, instead of granting relief, it imposes on British Indians in the Transvaal hardships to which, so far as I am aware, there is no parallel in Colonial legislation.
('6', 27, 1, 4, 40865) The Ordinance assumes that every Indian is capable of passing his permit to someone else so that he may unlawfully enter the Colony.
('6', 27, 1, 5, 40998) It, therefore, violates the time honoured maxim that every one is to be presumed to be innocent until he is found to be guilty.
('6', 27, 1, 6, 41126) This Ordinance condemns every Indian as guilty and leaves no room for him even to show that he is innocent.
('6', 27, 1, 7, 41234) It has been called an amendment of Law 3 of 1885. With the greatest respect I submit that it is no amendment whatsoever of the Law, but that it is a totally new Ordinance accentuating colour prejudice in the most offensive manner.
('6', 27, 1, 8, 41465) The system of passes that the Ordinance introduces is unknown, so far as British Indians are concerned, in any other part of the British Dominions, and it undoubtedly reduces Indians to a level lower than that of the Kaffirs.
('6', 27, 1, 9, 41691) The reason for such legislation is said to be that there is a large unauthorized influx of British Indians and that the British Indian community or the British Indian Associa tion are making an attempt to introduce without authority a large number of Indians into the Colony; in other words, that the community is engaged in a criminal breach of the Peace Preservation Ordinance, and that it is in order to prevent such an attempt that the Ordinance has been passed.
('6', 27, 1, 10, 42158) It is, therefore, a measure of punishment.
('6', 27, 1, 11, 42201) One often hears of punitive measures being adopted in connection with communities some members of which have committed grave political crimes or severe breaches of the Common Law of the country.
('6', 27, 1, 12, 42396) In this instance, the whole community is to be punished in a degrading manner for a crime against a statute restrictive of the liberty of the subject which is misapplied to British Indians, and a crime which the community has stoutly repudiated.
('6', 27, 1, 13, 42642) Such, in the humble opinion of the Indian community, is the Ordinance about which we are approaching Your Lordship.
('6', 27, 1, 14, 42758) There are three things which are stated to be introduced into the Ordinance in the nature of relief to the British Indians—the remission of the £3 fee; but we have shown that there is no remission at all, as all who are at present in the Transvaal have paid the £3. The second is the authority which is given to the Government by the Ordinance to issue tem porary permits, but this again is no relief because it is superfluous.
('6', 28, 0, 1, 43186) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 29
('6', 28, 1, 2, 43229) Such authority has always existed and been exercised at the discretion of the Government: there are today British Indians holding temporary permits.
('6', 28, 1, 3, 43378) There is again the relief to holders of temporary permits from the operation of the Liquor Ordinance.
('6', 28, 1, 4, 43480) That relief the British Indians never asked for, and so far as it is applicable to them, it is interpreted as a wanton insult.
('6', 28, 2, 5, 43607) There is one thing that the Ordinance undoubtedly rectifies, and that is by restoring [it] to the heirs of the late Aboo Baker Ahmed who held land in his own name before 1885. This is individual in character, and I have no doubt that if the price the heirs have to pay for getting land which is theirs by right be the degradation of the whole Indian community of the Transvaal, I am sure that even the heirs themselves would not care to pay it, and the community will certainly never feel in any way thankful for such relief.
('6', 28, 2, 6, 44133) It will be a most surprising thing if, after repeated promises and pledges, an Ordinance of this nature is countenanced by Your Lordship.
('6', 28, 2, 7, 44271) I shall venture to quote extracts’ from Mr. Chamberlain’s despatches, also from those of Lord Milner and Mr. Lyttelton, to show what they intended to do after the war....
('6', 28, 3, 8, 44442) It is common knowledge that before the War the British Government used every effort possible that Law 3 of 1885 should be repealed.
('6', 28, 3, 9, 44574) The condition today is changed, but we had hoped that it would change for the better, seeing that there is no foreign government to deal with, but our own Government.
('6', 28, 3, 10, 44741) Unhappily, we are now in the position of strangers in what may be called our own land.
('6', 28, 3, 11, 44828) We have always endeavoured to conciliate prejudice and with that view we have made suggestions which have been adopted in the self governing Colonies.
('6', 28, 3, 12, 44979) Failing, however, the adoption of these suggestions, we have asked that a commission of enquiry may be appointed.
('6', 28, 3, 13, 45093) This is the time honoured British custom.
('6', 28, 3, 14, 45135) Whenever a new step has been taken, a royal commission has preceded it.
('6', 28, 3, 15, 45207) The latest instance, perhaps, is that of the Aliens Act in the United Kingdom.
('6', 28, 3, 16, 45286) Before any steps were taken, a commission investigated the charges made against the aliens, and into the question of the adequacy of the existing laws, and into the question as to what new laws were
('6', 28, 4, 17, 45485) 1 The extracts, which are not available, were presumably to be inserted here.

('6', 29, 1, 3, 45615) We have asked for a similar commission regarding the British Indians in the Transvaal.
('6', 29, 1, 4, 45702) We believe that we are entitled to this, in view of the very grave charges I have referred to.

('6', 30, 1, 2, 46690) 32. DEPUTATION TO LORD ELGIN 1
('6', 30, 2, 3, 46721) CONFIDENTIAL COLONIAL OFFICE, Thursday, November 8, 1906
('6', 30, 3, 4, 46778) PROCEEDINGS AT A DEPUTATION TO THE RT.
('6', 30, 3, 5, 46817) THE EARL OF ELGIN
('6', 30, 4, 6, 46835) ON BRITISH INDIAN SUBJECTS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('6', 30, 5, 7, 46878) The deputation consisted of the following gentlemen:
('6', 30, 6, 8, 46931) Lord Stanley of Alderley Mr. H. O. Ally } Mr Gandhi } Delegates from [the] Transvaal Sir Lepel Griffin, K.C.S.I. Mr. J. D. Rees, C.I.E., M.P. Sir George Birdwood, K.C.S.I. Sir Henry Cotton, K.C.S.I., M.P. Mr. Naoroji Sir M. Bhownaggree, K.C.I.E. Mr. Ameer Ali Mr. Harold Cox, M.P. Mr. Thornton, C.S.I.
('6', 30, 7, 9, 47233) THE EARL OF ELGIN: I should just like to say, gentlemen, that I made this interview a private one because I thought, from experience of other meetings of the same sort, we should be better able to discuss the matter friendly across the table without the presence of public reporters; at the same time, I am quite aware that the deputation wish to go into matters of some detail, and therefore I have made arrangements for a note to be taken so that anything which may be said shall be on record.
('6', 30, 8, 10, 47729) Then I should like to say one other word.
('6', 30, 8, 11, 47771) I recognize among the deputation some of those with whom I have had the pleasure of working in India, and I hope they have explained to the deputation, if it was necessary, that my sentiments would all be in favour of doing anything I could for the interests of British Indians.
('6', 30, 8, 12, 48050) (‘Hear!
('6', 30, 8, 13, 48058) Hear!’)
('6', 30, 9, 14, 48066) SIR LEPEL GRIFFIN: My Lord, what you have just said makes my duty in
('6', 30, 10, 15, 48135) 1 While our source is the minutes in Colonial Office records, incomplete versions are found in Gandhiji's typewritten office copy S. N. 4512 and also in The South African Blue Book, C. D. 3308.
('6', 31, 0, 1, 48329) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 31, 1, 2, 48370) introducing the Delegates more easy.
('6', 31, 1, 3, 48407) We are very much obliged to your Lordship for admitting this deputation of men who are all known to you as gentlemen connected with India, who have been most of them in India themselves, and are all interested in India, and we are very glad, without any question of party feeling—because all sides are represented in this deputation to introduce to you the Delegates from South Africa: Mr. Gandhi, who is, as your Lordship is aware, a barrister of the Inner Temple and a man who, in the late Boer war and in the late rising in Natal, has done most excellent work for the country in organizing ambulance corps and in other ways—he practises now in Johannesburg—and Mr. Ally, his colleague, who is the representative of the Mohammedan part of the Indian community in the Transvaal, a merchant of very good position and the founder, and I believe the Chairman, of the Islamic Association in the Transvaal.
('6', 31, 1, 4, 49310) To those gentlemen I propose to leave any details of the Ordinance which has now been passed and which we are about to ask His Majesty’s Government to veto.
('6', 31, 1, 5, 49467) But I would like to say a few words in explaining the matter now before the Colonial Office, and I shall take up the time of your Lordship only for a few minutes.
('6', 31, 2, 6, 49630) I have been asked to present this deputation principally, I fancy, because I happen to be the Chairman of the Council of the East India Association, of which your Lordship is a distinguished Vice President, but the question which the East India Association has so often urged upon successive Colonial Secretaries and Secretaries for India and Viceroys of India is not directly concerned in our presence here today.
('6', 31, 2, 7, 50045) The bed rock, as your Lordship is aware, of the East India Association’s protests [is] that all well conducted, loyal, and industrious British subjects, whatever their race or colour, should receive equal rights in all Colonies of the British Empire; that is the bed rock of justice which has always been refused in the past, but on which the East India Association, which is represented largely here today, begs to continue to rely and from which it must continue to make its protest.
('6', 31, 2, 8, 50531) That, my Lord, is not precisely the question which this deputation desires to put forward this afternoon; they are not making any of those large claims which we have before made; they only ask that a certain Ordinance applying to the Transvaal alone may not receive the sanction of His Majesty’s Government.
('6', 31, 3, 9, 50839) A few words only are necessary on this point.
('6', 31, 3, 10, 50885) During the Boer Government the British Indians were treated with considerable harshness, but their immigration into the Transvaal was not prohibited, and with the exception of a fee for a licence for adult traders, they were not interfered with.
('6', 31, 3, 11, 51131) But their position was an exceedingly uncomfortable one, and many protests were raised which, we understood, when the country fell into the hands of the English, would be redressed.
('6', 31, 3, 12, 51313) So far from being redressed, their position is made worse and the rules for registration and identification were made exceedingly more rigorous.
('6', 31, 3, 13, 51458) The Ordinance which has now been passed
('6', 32, 0, 1, 51498) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 33
('6', 32, 1, 2, 51541) makes, whatever people in South Africa may choose to say, their position infinitely worse and more degrading.
('6', 32, 1, 3, 51651) It may be said that in the Transvaal these rules are for the benefit of the Indians, but the toad under the harrow knows where the harrow grips him, and the Indians in the Transvaal consider that the new regulations of this Ordinance are a grievance and an insult which is almost too grievous to be borne; and I for one most strongly support their claim and their protest.
('6', 32, 2, 4, 52024) Under this Ordinance every one in the Transvaal is exposed to the most rigorous investigation; the impressions of his fingers are to be recorded on every pass; no one is allowed in—man, woman or child—without registration of so rigorous a character that has been unheard of in any civilized country within my recollection.
('6', 32, 2, 5, 52347) Under this regulation every Indian in the Transvaal, whether an adult male, whether a woman, or whether a child, and even babes in arms will be obliged to be registered under such conditions as ordinarily apply only to convicts in a civilized country; and evasion or ignorance or even forgetfulness on this point is punished by crushing fines, by imprisonment with hard labour, by expulsion, and by ruin.
('6', 32, 2, 6, 52752) You, my Lord, who have been Viceroy of India, and whose sympathy is with the country, must know that legislation of this sort is unheard of under the British flag; indeed, today in Europe, I may say without any exaggeration, that, with the exception of the Russian legislation against the Jews, there is no legislation comparable to this on the continent of Europe; and in England, if we wanted a similar case, we should have to go back to the time of the Plantagenets.
('6', 32, 3, 7, 53222) And against whom is this legislation directed?
('6', 32, 3, 8, 53269) Against the most orderly, honourable, industrious, temperate race in the world, people of our own stock and blood, with whom our own language has as a sister language been connected.
('6', 32, 3, 9, 53452) There is no occasion, in the presence of people connected with India, who know its history, to say what the Indian community is today; it is almost an insult to refer to it.
('6', 32, 4, 10, 53626) And by whom is this legislation instigated?
('6', 32, 4, 11, 53670) I am told, and I believe it, that it is not by the best part of the British community in the Transvaal, who are, I believe, in favour of giving all reasonable privileges to British Indian subjects; it is by the alien foreign population in the Transvaal who are perhaps to some extent inconvenienced by Indian traders who are so very much more temperate and industrious than themselves.
('6', 32, 4, 12, 54056) It does not come from the English.
('6', 32, 4, 13, 54091) The legislation is prompted, and the prejudice against the Indians is encouraged, by the aliens, by Russian Jews, by Syrians, by German Jews, by every class of aliens, the very off scourings of the international sewers of Europe.
('6', 32, 4, 14, 54321) The English residents, against whom I do not wish to say one word of criticism, are a part, in my mind, of the Transvaal, but the Transvaal is only a Colony by conquest, not by settlement, and it is the aliens who are opposed to this honourable Indian community.
('6', 33, 0, 1, 54584) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 33, 1, 2, 54625) My Lord, I do not wish to take up more of your time, but what I wish to say is that today we ask you, as representing His Majesty’s Government, and as we know your sympathies are with the Indians, over whom you have ruled with so much distinction, to procure the vetoing of this Ordinance.
('6', 33, 1, 3, 54915) No large questions are brought before you today by this deputation.
('6', 33, 1, 4, 54983) They are not asking for political rights; they are not asking for gratitude for their great and devoted services in the Transvaal war where so many of them lost their lives in their devotion to England, doing as courageous work as any one of the members of the armies which were sent by England, by Australia, or by Canada.
('6', 33, 1, 5, 55307) Those services have not been recognized; on the contrary, they have been ignored and further burdens have been placed upon them.
('6', 33, 1, 6, 55436) We ask for nothing today except the merest barest justice.
('6', 33, 1, 7, 55495) We ask that the whips which the Boers have inflicted upon us may not be changed into scorpions wielded by the British Government.
('6', 33, 2, 8, 55625) I would say in conclusion that we hope everything from the present
('6', 33, 3, 9, 55692) Government, and for this reason, that the grievances of the Chinese have received the
('6', 33, 4, 10, 55778) utmost sympathy at the hands of the Government, but, so far as this deputation is
('6', 33, 5, 11, 55860) concerned, the Chinese and other alien nations do not count.
('6', 33, 5, 12, 55921) We ask not for the
('6', 33, 6, 13, 55940) Chinese, but for our own fellow subjects, and we ask that justice, if not generosity,
('6', 33, 7, 14, 56026) may be dealt out to them and that your Lordship will save them from insult and
('6', 33, 8, 15, 56105) oppression.
('6', 33, 9, 16, 56117) It was at your Lordship’s request that this deputation was a small one; it might have been indefinitely extended.
('6', 33, 9, 17, 56231) This is a test case—a question of going forward or going back.
('6', 33, 9, 18, 56294) Your Lordship, as a past Viceroy of India, must know that the attention of the whole of India, 300 millions of Indians, is intent today upon the decision which will be given in this test case, and I beg your Lordship to think and to remember that, besides the Indians of Indian birth, against whom the insults of this Ordinance are directed, there are the whole body of Indian officials, to which I and most of the members of this deputation belong, who are insulted with the natives of India.
('6', 33, 9, 19, 56788) Is it to be supposed that we who have worked with, we who have governed this province of India under your Lordship and under your predecessors and successors, have been governing degraded creatures who are placed lower even than the Zulus and Russian Jews?
('6', 33, 9, 20, 57045) No, my Lord.
('6', 33, 9, 21, 57058) We trust to you to do what you can to defend the people whom you have governed so well.
('6', 33, 9, 22, 57146) And I will beg you to excuse any exciting warmth in my way of speaking, because I assure you that any warmth in my words is very much exceeded by the feeling of shame and resentment which fills my heart at the way in which the British Indians of the Transvaal are treated today by the settlers (I will not call them Colonists) of that country.
('6', 34, 0, 1, 57490) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 35
('6', 34, 1, 2, 57533) MR. GANDHI: Both Mr. Ally and I are very much obliged to your Lordship for giving us the opportunity of placing the British Indian position before you.
('6', 34, 1, 3, 57685) Supported though we are by distinguished Anglo Indian friends and others, I feel that the task before Mr. Ally and myself is very difficult, because your Lordship, in reply to the cablegram 1 sent to you through Lord Selborne, after the great British Indian mass meeting in Johannesburg, was pleased to inform the British Indian Association, that, although you would be pleased to give us every opportunity of stating our case, no good purpose was likely to be served as your Lordship had approved of the principle of the Ordinance, in that it gave some measure of relief to the British Indian community, though not as much as His Majesty’s Government would desire.
('6', 34, 1, 4, 58351) We who are the men on the spot and who are affected by the Ordinance in question have ventured to think otherwise.
('6', 34, 1, 5, 58466) We have felt that this Ordinance does not give us any relief whatsoever.
('6', 34, 1, 6, 58539) It is a measure which places British Indians in a far worse position than before and makes the lot of the British Indian well nigh intolerable.
('6', 34, 1, 7, 58683) Under the Ordinance the British Indian is assumed to be a criminal.
('6', 34, 1, 8, 58751) If a stranger, not knowing the circumstances of the Transvaal, were to read the Ordinance, he would have no hesitation in coming to the conclusion that an Ordinance of that nature which carries so many penalties and wounds the British Indian community on all sides, must only apply to thieves or a gang of robbers.
('6', 34, 1, 9, 59066) I venture, therefore, to think that, although Sir Lepel Griffin has used strong 2 language in connection with the Ordinance, he has not at all exaggerated, but every word of it is justified.
('6', 34, 1, 10, 59257) At the same time I beg to state that the Ordinance, as amended, does not apply to British Indian females.
('6', 34, 1, 11, 59363) The draft Ordinance undoubtedly applied to females also, but owing to the very strong protest made by the British Indian Association, and by Mr. Ally separately as Chairman of the Hamidia Islamic Society, pointing out the great violence that would have been done to female sanctity, if I may say so, the Ordinance was amended so as to take females out of its operation.
('6', 34, 1, 12, 59733) But it applies to all adult males and even to children, in that the parents or guardians have to take out registra tion certificates for their children or wards as the case may be.
('6', 34, 2, 13, 59914) 1 Vide “The Transvaal Ordinance”, 29 9 1906.
('6', 34, 3, 14, 59959) 2 The Original has “strange”.
('6', 35, 0, 1, 59989) 36 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 35, 1, 2, 60030) It is a fundamental maxim of the British law that every one is presumed to be innocent until he is found guilty, but the Ordinance reverses the process, and brands every Indian as guilty, and leaves no room for him to prove his innocence.
('6', 35, 1, 3, 60269) There is absolutely nothing proved against us and yet every British Indian, no matter what his status is, is to be condemned as guilty and not treated as an innocent man.
('6', 35, 1, 4, 60440) My Lord, an Ordinance of this nature [it] is not possible for British Indians to reconcile themselves to.
('6', 35, 1, 5, 60546) I do not know that such an Ordinance is applicable to free British subjects in any part of His Majesty’s Dominions.
('6', 35, 2, 6, 60662) Moreover, what the Transvaal thinks today the other Colonies think tomorrow.
('6', 35, 2, 7, 60739) When Lord Milner sprang his Bazaar Notice 1 on British Indians, the whole of South Africa rang with the Bazaar idea.
('6', 35, 2, 8, 60856) The term “Bazaar” is a misnomer; it has been really applied to Loca tions where trade is utterly impossible.
('6', 35, 2, 9, 60965) However, a proposal was seriously made, after a Bazaar Notice, by the then Mayor of Natal 2, Mr. Ellis Browne, that Indians should be relegated to Bazaars.
('6', 35, 2, 10, 61121) There is not the slightest reason why this Ordinance also, if it ever becomes law, should not be copied by the other parts of South Africa.
('6', 35, 2, 11, 61261) The position today in Natal is that even indentured Indians are not required to carry passes as contemplated by the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance; nor are there any penalties attached to the non carrying of passes as are defined in the Ordinance under discussion.
('6', 35, 2, 12, 61527) We have already shown in our humble representation that no relief has been granted by this Ordinance, because the remission of the £3 fee, referred to by Mr. Duncan, is quite illusory, because all we British Indians resident in the Transvaal who are obliged to pay £3 under Law 3 of 1885, and those who, under Lord Selborne’s promise, are likely to be allowed to re enter the Transvaal, have paid the £3 already.
('6', 35, 3, 13, 61940) The authority to issue temporary permits is also superfluous in that the Government have already exercised the power, and there are today in the Transvaal several Indians in possession of temporary permits.
('6', 35, 3, 14, 62147) They are liable to be expelled from the Colony on the expiry of their permits.
('6', 35, 4, 15, 62226) 1 Vide “The Transvaal Bazaars”, 19 11 1903.
('6', 35, 5, 16, 62270) 2 Mayor of Durban.
('6', 36, 0, 1, 62289) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 37
('6', 36, 1, 2, 62332) The relief under the Liquor Ordinance 1 is, British Indians feel, a wanton insult.
('6', 36, 1, 3, 62415) So much was this recognized by the local Government that they immediately assured the Indians that it was not intended for British Indians at all, but for somebody else.
('6', 36, 1, 4, 62585) We have no connection with anybody else, and we have always endeavoured to show that the British Indians ought to be treated as British subjects, and ought not to be included with the general body of Asiatics with respect to whom there may be a need for some restrictions which ought not to apply to British Indians as British subjects.
('6', 36, 2, 5, 62922) There remains one more statement that is in connection with the land owned by the late Aboobaker.
('6', 36, 2, 6, 63020) 2 That land should belong to the heirs by right, but under the interpretation reluctantly put upon it by the Supreme Court, that it is only individual in character and does not touch the community, the land cannot be transmitted to the heirs.
('6', 36, 2, 7, 63263) The Ordinance is intended to rectify the error, but, as I had the honour to represent the heirs, I ventured to think that even they would not consent to pay for getting this relief at the price, in the nature of this Ordinance, for British Indians; and certainly the Indian community can never exchange for the relief given to their heirs of the land of Aboobaker an Ordinance of this nature, which requires them to pay so great a price for what is really their own.
('6', 36, 2, 8, 63730) So that under the Ordinance in that respect again there is absolutely no relief.
('6', 36, 2, 9, 63811) As I said before, we shall be, under the Ordinance, branded as criminals.
('6', 36, 3, 10, 63885) My Lord, the existing regulation is severe enough.
('6', 36, 3, 11, 63936) I hold in my hands returns from the Court of the Magistrate at Volksrust.
('6', 36, 3, 12, 64010) Over 150 successful prosecutions of Indians attempting to enter the Transvaal have taken place during the years 1905 and 1906. All these prosecutions, I venture to say, are by no means just.
('6', 36, 3, 13, 64201) I venture to believe that if these prosecutions were gone into you would see that some of them were absolutely groundless.
('6', 36, 4, 14, 64324) So far as the question of identification is concerned the present laws are quite enough.
('6', 36, 4, 15, 64413) I produce to your Lordship the registration certificate held by me, and it will show how complete it is to establish identification.
('6', 36, 4, 16, 64546) The present law can hardly be called an amendment.
('6', 36, 4, 17, 64597) I produce before your Lordship a registration receipt held by my

('6', 37, 0, 1, 64712) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 37, 1, 2, 64753) colleague, Mr. Ally, from the Transvaal Government.
('6', 37, 1, 3, 64805) Your Lordship will see that it is merely a receipt for £3. The registration under the present Ordinance is of a different type.
('6', 37, 1, 4, 64933) When Lord Milner wished to enforce Law 3 of 1885 he suggested new registration.
('6', 37, 1, 5, 65013) We protested against it, but on his strong advice, as a voluntary act, we allowed ourselves to be newly registered, and hence the form produced before your Lordship.
('6', 37, 1, 6, 65179) At the time that registration was undertaken, Lord Milner stated emphatically that it was a measure once for all, and that it would form a complete title to residence by those who held such registration certificates.
('6', 37, 1, 7, 65396) Is all this now to be undone?
('6', 37, 1, 8, 65426) Your Lordship is doubtless aware of the Punia case 1, wherein a poor Indian woman, in company with her husband, was torn away from her husband, and was ordered by the magistrate to leave the country within seven hours.
('6', 37, 1, 9, 65645) Fortunately, relief was granted in the end, as the matter was taken up in time.
('6', 37, 1, 10, 65725) A boy under 11 years was also arrested and sentenced to pay a fine of £50 or to go to gaol for three months, and at the end of it to leave the country.
('6', 37, 1, 11, 65877) In this case again the Supreme Court has been able to grant justice.
('6', 37, 1, 12, 65946) The conviction was pronounced to be wholly bad, and Sir James Rose Innes stated that the Administration would bring itself to ridicule and contempt if such a policy was pursued.
('6', 37, 1, 13, 66124) 2 If the existing legislation is strong enough and severe enough to thus prosecute British Indians, is it not enough to keep out of the Colony British Indians who may attempt fraudulently to enter it?
('6', 37, 2, 14, 66325) It has been stated that the reason for passing the Ordinance is that there is an unauthorized influx of British Indians into the Transvaal on a wholesale scale, and that there is an attempt on the part of the Indian community to introduce Indians in such a manner.
('6', 37, 2, 15, 66590) The last charge has been, times without number, repudiated by the Indian community, and the makers of the charge have been challenged to prove their statement.
('6', 37, 2, 16, 66750) The first statement has also been denied.
('6', 37, 3, 17, 66792) I ought to mention one thing also, that is, the fourth resolution that was passed at the British Indian mass meeting.
('6', 37, 3, 18, 66910) 3 It was passed by the meeting solemnly, prayerfully, and in all humility, and the whole of that great meeting decided by that resolution that, if this Ordinance
('6', 37, 4, 19, 67072) 1 Vide “The Punia Case”, 29 9 1906. 2 ibid 3 ibid
('6', 38, 0, 1, 67122) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 39
('6', 38, 1, 2, 67165) ever came to be enforced, and we did not get relief, the British Indians, rather than submit to the great degradation involved in it, would go to gaol; such was the intensity of the feeling aroused by the Ordinance.
('6', 38, 1, 3, 67381) We have hitherto suffered much in the Transvaal and in other parts of South Africa, but the hardship has been tolerable; we have not considered it necessary to travel 6,000 miles to place the position before the Imperial Government.
('6', 38, 1, 4, 67614) But the straining point has been reached by the Ordinance, and we felt that we should in all humility exhaust every resource even to the extent of sending a Deputation to wait on your Lordship.
('6', 38, 2, 5, 67808) The least, therefore, that in my humble opinion is due to the British Indian community is to appoint a commission as suggested in the humble representation submitted to your Lordship.
('6', 38, 2, 6, 67992) It is a time honoured British custom that, whenever an important principle is involved, a commission is appointed before a step is taken.
('6', 38, 2, 7, 68130) The question of alien immigration into the United Kingdom is a parallel case.
('6', 38, 2, 8, 68208) Charges somewhat similar to the charges against the Indian community were made against the aliens who entered the United Kingdom.
('6', 38, 2, 9, 68338) There was also the question of the adequacy of the existing legislation and the necessity for further legislation; all these three points were referred to a commission before any step was taken.
('6', 38, 2, 10, 68533) I, therefore, venture to think that a commission should be appointed, and the whole question thrashed out before any drastic measures are taken.
('6', 38, 2, 11, 68678) I venture, therefore, to hope that your Lordship will see your way to grant this small measure of relief to the British Indian community.
('6', 38, 3, 12, 68816) MR. H. O. ALLY: My Lord, we are very much obliged to you for the patient hearing your Lordship is giving to the deputation.

('6', 45, 15, 24, 89685) restrictions on British citizens, and I do not go back from one single word.
('6', 45, 16, 25, 89762) have to recognize the fact that all over the world there are difficulties arising on the
('6', 45, 17, 26, 89851) part of white communities, and we have to reckon with them.
('6', 45, 17, 27, 89911) I do not say that they
('6', 45, 18, 28, 89934) ought always to succeed; they certainly ought not to succeed in points of detail which
('6', 45, 19, 29, 90021) would, in any way, involve oppression.
('6', 45, 19, 30, 90060) But the fact of there being that sentiment has
('6', 45, 20, 31, 90107) to be borne in mind when we have to deal with matters of this description.
('6', 45, 21, 32, 90182) I do not think I have much more to reply to.
('6', 45, 21, 33, 90227) Reference has been made to the proposition towards the end of the petition, that at any rate there might be a postponement for the examination of the subject by a commission.
('6', 45, 21, 34, 90402) That, no doubt, is an alternative which might be adopted; but I am not in a position today to say
('6', 46, 0, 1, 90500) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 47
('6', 46, 1, 2, 90543) whether that is so or not.
('6', 46, 1, 3, 90570) Indeed I think you will easily acknowledge that I paid you the best compliment when I did not endeavour to make up my mind until I had seen you, and heard what you have to say.
('6', 46, 1, 4, 90747) That is my position.
('6', 46, 1, 5, 90768) I have now heard what Mr. Gandhi had to say.
('6', 46, 1, 6, 90813) I hope he has put before me, as fully as he desired, what he has come so far to say.
('6', 46, 1, 7, 90898) I have heard the other gentlemen who have accompanied him.
('6', 46, 1, 8, 90957) I will give the best consideration to their representations, and I shall think it my duty to make up my mind with the full responsibility which I have to assume.
('6', 46, 2, 9, 91119) MR. GANDHI: May I make one statement, my Lord, for one minute?
('6', 46, 2, 10, 91182) I have listened with the very greatest attention, and with very great obligation, to your Lordship’s statement, but I must submit that the information placed before your Lordship on some points is not accurate, and I am in a position to refute that information by documentary evidence with regard to permits, as your Lordship used the term, in connection with the Ordinance of 1885, but this is not the occasion when I could do it.
('6', 46, 2, 11, 91614) But if your Lordship will ask us to wait upon you we: will do it.
('6', 46, 2, 12, 91680) But that just shows that nothing short of a commission would place our position accurately before your Lordship.
('6', 46, 3, 13, 91793) SIR LEPEL GRIFFIN: My Lord, I beg, on behalf of the deputation, to express our best thanks for the exceedingly kind and courteous way in which you have received us, and the patience with which you have listened to what we had to say.
('6', 46, 3, 14, 92027) We were assured before of your full sympathy in this matter, and knew it perfectly well.
('6', 46, 4, 15, 92116) (The deputation then withdrew.)

('6', 50, 1, 2, 96174) 38. LETTER TO SIR RICHARD SOLOMON
('6', 50, 2, 3, 96208) HOTEL CECIL, LONDON, November 8, 1906
('6', 50, 3, 4, 96246) SIR, We venture to address this informal letter to you on the strength of your having always been a friend of the Coloured people, using the term in its widest sense.
('6', 50, 3, 5, 96413) Lord Elgin seemed to think, as you also thought, that a commission of enquiry was due to us.
('6', 50, 3, 6, 96506) We venture respectfully to think that a word of approval from you of the idea of a commission would bring about, from our point of view, the desired result.
('6', 50, 3, 7, 96663) The Ordinance proceeds on the assumption that every Indian is capable of abusing his permit or registration.
('6', 50, 3, 8, 96772) From the statement made by Lord Elgin there is, in our humble opinion, no doubt that a great deal of inaccurate information has been placed before him.
('6', 50, 3, 9, 96924) We think that nothing short of an impartial commission of enquiry can remove all the doubts and misapprehension that exist.
('6', 50, 3, 10, 97048) May we appeal to you again for this small measure of justice, which it is in your power to grant.
('6', 50, 3, 11, 97146) Yours faithfully, [M. K. GANDHI H. O. ALLY] SIR RICHARD SOLOMON REFORM CLUB PALL MALL, W.

('6', 59, 4, 10, 109567) 50. DEPUTATION NOTES I
('6', 59, 5, 11, 109590) HOTEL CECIL, LONDON, November 9, 1906 1
('6', 59, 6, 12, 109630) INTERVIEW WITH LORD ELGIN
('6', 59, 7, 13, 109656) Though in order of time, the interview with Lord Elgin comes last, I shall deal with it first as it is very important.
('6', 59, 7, 14, 109775) We were accompanied by Sir Lepel Griffin, Lord Stanley of Alderley, Sir Muncherji Bhownaggree, Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji, Mr. Syed Ameer Ali, Mr. Harold Cox, Sir, Henry Cotton, Sir George Birdwood, Mr. J. D. Rees, Mr. Thornton and Mr. F. H. Brown 2. The deputation included members from all the parties.
('6', 59, 7, 15, 110074) 3 It is said that such a [strong] deputation has never before waited on Lord Elgin.
('6', 59, 7, 16, 110158) We all presented ourselves before Lord Elgin at 3 p.m.
('6', 59, 7, 17, 110213) on Thursday 4.
('6', 59, 8, 18, 110228) 1 The last paragraph of this item would suggest that this was completed on or after November 10, 1906; Vide “Letter to O. H. A. Johari”, 10 11 1906.
('6', 59, 9, 19, 110377) 2 F. H. Brown was not in the list, circulated by Gandhiji, of members who were to wait in deputation on Lord Elgin; vide “Deputation to Lord Elgin”,8 11 1906.
('6', 59, 10, 20, 110536) 3 The Conservative Party was not represented in the deputation although, according to Sir Henry Cotton the Transvaal Indian Deputation had the “complete sympathy” of individual Conservative Members; vide “Deputation to Lord Elgin”, 8 11 1906.
('6', 59, 11, 21, 110779) 4 November 8, 1906
('6', 60, 0, 1, 110798) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 61
('6', 60, 1, 2, 110841) Sir Lepel Griffin made a spirited speech and appealed to Lord Elgin to reject the Ordinance.
('6', 60, 1, 3, 110934) file said that the Ordinance was derogatory to Anglo Indians 1. One who read the Ordinance would think that those who ruled over such people 2 must be a worthless lot.
('6', 60, 1, 4, 111102) The Indians and the British both originated in Central Asia.
('6', 60, 1, 5, 111163) The Indians were very industrious, intelligent and honest.
('6', 60, 1, 6, 111222) Those who had seen India would never tolerate the refuse of Europe collected in the Transvaal tyrannizing over the Indians there.
('6', 60, 1, 7, 111352) Mr. Gandhi and Mr. Ally spoke after Sir Lepel.
('6', 60, 1, 8, 111399) Mr. Ally’s voice choked with emotion as he spoke.
('6', 60, 2, 9, 111449) Then Sir Henry Cotton made a powerful speech.
('6', 60, 2, 10, 111495) Quoting Lord Lansdowne, he said that the Members of the House of Commons also wanted that justice be done.
('6', 60, 2, 11, 111602) While Kruger used the whip, the British Government were scourging us with scorpion stings.
('6', 60, 2, 12, 111693) Sir Muncherji wanted to know what had happened to the commission which Mr. Lyttelton had promised him.
('6', 60, 2, 13, 111796) If Lord Elgin could do nothing more, the commission at any rate should be appointed.
('6', 60, 2, 14, 111881) Mr. Ameer Ali said that he had recently returned from India and that the whole country was unhappy over the sufferings of Indians in South Africa.
('6', 60, 3, 15, 112028) Mr. Dadabhai said that the British Government would stand disgraced if the oppression of Indians continued.
('6', 60, 4, 16, 112136) Mr. Rees said that this question was an all party one.
('6', 60, 5, 17, 112191) Mr. Cox said that, as an Englishman, he felt ashamed of the disabilities Indians in the Transvaal had to suffer.
('6', 60, 5, 18, 112304) In reply, Lord Elgin said that his own sympathy was bound to be with the Indians.
('6', 60, 5, 19, 112386) He had always wished well of the Indian people.
('6', 60, 5, 20, 112434) The officials of the Transvaal Government had stated that the Ordinance was not oppressive.
('6', 60, 5, 21, 112526) It was true in a sense that the remission of the £3 tax afforded, as Mr. Gandhi had pointed out, no relief in fact.
('6', 60, 5, 22, 112642) However, it was something of a gain that the legal stigma of the £3 tax had been removed.
('6', 60, 5, 23, 112732) There did not seem to be much objection to the giving of thumb impressions.
('6', 60, 5, 24, 112808) It was unlikely that the police would look into the passes every day and harass the people.
('6', 60, 5, 25, 112900) However, there was no need to emphasize all these matters.
('6', 60, 5, 26, 112959) Sir Lepel had said that the
('6', 60, 6, 27, 112987) 1 The British in India were also referred to as Anglo Indians.
('6', 60, 6, 28, 113050) 2 The reference is to the people to whom the Ordinance applied, namely, the British Indians.
('6', 61, 0, 1, 113143) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 61, 1, 2, 113184) British whites there were not very hostile to Indians.
('6', 61, 1, 3, 113239) But there were cablegrams from Krugersdorp and other places which expressed the hope that the Ordinance would receive Royal assent.
('6', 61, 1, 4, 113371) While he would not say anything about Mr. Gandhi or Mr. Ally, he might tell them that he had received cablegrams from some Indians expressing contrary opinions.
('6', 61, 1, 5, 113532) He added that all that was by way of information only.
('6', 61, 1, 6, 113587) He did not regard the demand for a commission as unreason able.
('6', 61, 1, 7, 113651) The matter deserved consideration, and he would reply after giving it sufficient thought.
('6', 61, 1, 8, 113741) Seeking permission to speak for a minute, Mr. Gandhi said that Lord Elgin’s information was not correct and that, if His Lordship gave them another appointment, the two Delegates would be able to prove this.
('6', 61, 1, 9, 113949) Whether or not a second meeting materializes, all this clearly shows that the appointment of a commission is absolutely necessary and that such complicated matters can be settled only through a commission.
('6', 61, 1, 10, 114155) It is hoped that, as a result of this Deputation, a commission will be appointed.
('6', 61, 2, 11, 114237) MEMBERS OF HOUSE OF COMMONS
('6', 61, 3, 12, 114265) As we thought it would be very appropriate and helpful if the Members of the House of Commons met and passed a resolution expressing sympathy, we called upon some Members and had a discussion with them.
('6', 61, 3, 13, 114468) In this matter we sought the help of Mr. Sootie 1
('6', 61, 4, 14, 114518) a Member of Parliament who is a friend of Mr. Polak’s father, and the meeting at last took place on Wednesday night.
('6', 61, 4, 15, 114635) Some half a dozen Members jointly issued a circular and invitations.
('6', 61, 4, 16, 114704) Messrs Gandhi and Ally spoke and then the meeting passed a resolution requesting Lord Elgin to accede to the demand of the Indian Deputation.
('6', 61, 4, 17, 114846) Many people think that the large meeting of Members of the House of Commons was the first of its kind in recent times.
('6', 61, 4, 18, 114965) This shows that our cause is being widely discussed.
('6', 61, 5, 19, 115018) MEETING WITH AMEER ALI
('6', 61, 6, 20, 115041) Both the members of the Deputation had a private interview with Mr. Ameer Ali, during which he expressed much sympathy for our

('6', 62, 1, 2, 115382) cause and also promised to write on it, if possible, for prominent papers here.
('6', 62, 1, 3, 115462) INTERVIEW WITH LORD HAMILTON Lord George Hamilton heard us patiently for half an hour.
('6', 62, 1, 4, 115549) It will be recalled that he was at one time the Secretary of State for India.
('6', 62, 1, 5, 115627) He has agreed to go into the question fully and do his best.
('6', 62, 1, 6, 115688) This matter is often discussed in South Africa and other papers.
('6', 62, 1, 7, 115753) South Africa also published an interview 1 with Mr. Gandhi on Mr. Tatham’s Bill.
('6', 62, 1, 8, 115834) The correspondent has given a correct report of the interview.
('6', 62, 1, 9, 115897) A copy of the petition submitted to Lord Elgin has been sent to every Member of Parliament with a courteous covering letter.
('6', 62, 1, 10, 116022) A letter 2 seeking an interview with Mr. Morley has been despatched today.
('6', 62, 1, 11, 116097) It will probably materialize next week.
('6', 62, 1, 12, 116137) The Deputa tion has still so much work to do that it will be very difficult for it to leave on November 24.
('6', 62, 2, 13, 116245) SOUTH AFRICAN STUDENTS IN ENGLAND
('6', 62, 3, 14, 116279) A petition has been specially sent to Lord Elgin by these students.
('6', 62, 3, 15, 116347) 3 In it they have asked to know what their own plight would be under the new law; but the petition covers the question of the rights of all the others as well.
('6', 62, 3, 16, 116507) If Lord Elgin should say that separate laws would be made for those who had gone to England, he would be insulting the others; if, on the other hand, he should say that they would not get the rights, it would be gross injustice.
('6', 62, 4, 17, 116736) NATAL QUESTION
('6', 62, 5, 18, 116751) The Deputation is not concerned with Natal affairs.
('6', 62, 5, 19, 116803) However, since Mr. Tatham’s Bill has been published and a cablegram about it has been received here, Mr. Gandhi has asked for a private interview with Lord Elgin.
('6', 62, 5, 20, 116966) 4 He has not yet given a definite reply, but has written saying that he will do so next week.

('6', 69, 6, 7, 125895) 60. LETTER TO “THE TIMES” 2
('6', 69, 7, 8, 125923) HOTEL CECIL, LONDON, November 12, 1906
('6', 69, 8, 9, 125962) THE EDITOR
('6', 69, 9, 10, 125973) THE TIMES PRINTING HOUSE SQUARE, E.C.
('6', 69, 10, 11, 126011) SIR, By your leading article in The Times of the 10th instant on the British Indian question in the Colonies, you have lifted it from the platform of parochialism to that of Imperialism.
('6', 69, 10, 12, 126198) For the present, however, we will be thankful if you will allow us to deal with the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance without touching the larger issue discussed by you.
('6', 69, 10, 13, 126366) You say:
('6', 69, 11, 14, 126375) It does not seem likely or desirable that a measure, which appears to be supported generally by the opinion of the people who are shortly to have power to make their own laws, should be refused the assent of the Crown.
('6', 69, 11, 15, 126594) We venture to take exception to your opinion for the following reasons:
('6', 69, 12, 16, 126666) 1. You admit that upon the merits of the particular controversy aroused by the Ordinance there is “at present hardly evidence
('6', 69, 13, 17, 126792) 1 Also quoted in “Letter to Sir Henry Cotton”, 12 11 1906, but the text varies slightly.
('6', 69, 13, 18, 126881) 2 This letter was not published in The Times.
('6', 70, 0, 1, 126927) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 71
('6', 70, 1, 2, 126970) enough to form judgement”.
('6', 70, 2, 3, 126997) 2. The Ordinance does not affect the broad question of Asiatic Immigration into the Transvaal, but it very materially alters to their prejudice the status of British Indians resident in the Colony.
('6', 70, 3, 4, 127195) 3 It is not “a purely temporary measure”; for, while it is true that Mr. Duncan stated that it was introduced without prejudice to further legislation, there was no question of the Ordinance itself being “a temporary measure”.
('6', 70, 3, 5, 127422) In its very nature it is not capable of being temporary, because it is intended to carry out once and for all, so it is said, registration of British Indians in the Transvaal, and to compel them to carry passes, euphemistically called registration certificates.
('6', 70, 4, 6, 127684) 4. Instead of preserving the status quo and relieving the Asiatic residents from “certain manifest grievances”, it reduces their status and removes not a single grievance.
('6', 70, 5, 7, 127856) 5. While the prejudice on the part of the general portion of the white community is admitted, the manner of giving effect to it is purely a creation of the Government and the Transvaal community is certainly not privy to the framing of the Ordinance.
('6', 70, 5, 8, 128107) Its plan is undoubtedly drastic, but honest.
('6', 70, 5, 9, 128152) If it had its own way, perhaps that portion of it which represents anti Asiatic agitation will pass legislation involving deportation of Indian residents in the Colony.
('6', 70, 5, 10, 128321) Such, in effect, it will be reme mbered, was the resolution passed by the so called National Convention.
('6', 70, 6, 11, 128426) 6. That the Transvaal is on the eve of getting Responsible Govern ment is an additional reason why, instead of the British Indian position being prejudiced by the Ordinance in question, it should be so commended to the incoming Government as to bear the Imperial stamp; that is to say, the status of British Indians should be levelled up to that enjoyed by British Indians at the Cape.
('6', 70, 7, 12, 128812) 7. There is absolutely no proof 1 justifying a dangerous departure from the traditions of Crown Colony Government in the shape of invidious class distinctions.
('6', 70, 8, 13, 128972) 1 Of a large unauthorized influx of Indians
('6', 71, 0, 1, 129016) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 71, 1, 2, 129057) 8. Involving, as the question does, Imperial considerations of the highest order, the Imperial Government should think twice before sanctioning panic legislation which underlies the Ordin ance.
('6', 71, 1, 3, 129251) The reasons we have above given for withholding the Royal sanction are also reasons showing why a commission should be appointed to go into the question, and to place such evidence before the public and the Government as is, on your own showing, at present lacking.
('6', 71, 1, 4, 129517) You, Sir, have rightly said that every Indian returning from the Transvaal to India returns a missionary to sow discontent.
('6', 71, 1, 5, 129641) We, who have the privilege of representing the community, can state that we have given only the most moderate expression to the sentiments of the thousands who attended the mass meeting referred to by you.
('6', 71, 1, 6, 129847) It is not possible for us to describe in words the bitterness which animated that meeting regarding the measure.
('6', 71, 1, 7, 129960) The lower the status of the Indian, the greater would be his hardship under the Ordinance.
('6', 71, 1, 8, 130051) The well to do Indian may by reason of his position be able to escape the grossest forms of oppression which must inevitably flow from the Ordinance.
('6', 71, 1, 9, 130201) Poor people were, under the registration effected by Lord Milner’s advice, dragged at four o’clock on a cold winter’s morning from their beds in Johannesburg, Heidelberg and Potchefstroom, and marched to the police station, or Asiatic Offices, as the case might be.
('6', 71, 1, 10, 130467) 1 It is they who under the Ordinance would be hustled by the Kaffir Police at every turn, and not the better class Indians.
('6', 71, 1, 11, 130591) They, therefore, feel the treatment more than we do, because to them their hardship is an ever present reality.
('6', 71, 1, 12, 130703) The Indian community has all along contended that there is no unauthorized influx on a wholesale scale, that there is no attempt by the community to countenance any such influx, that the present machinery is absolutely effective to check unauthorized entry and the documents already held by Indians are sufficient for purposes of identification.
('6', 71, 1, 13, 131049) If these statements are challenged, as they have been challenged, is it not at least in common fairness necessary to appoint a commission of enquiry [?]
('6', 71, 2, 14, 131202) We are etc., [M. K. GANDHI H. O. ALLY]
('6', 71, 3, 15, 131241) From a photostat of the typewritten office copy: S. N. 4543

('6', 83, 5, 9, 145943) CONSTITUTIONAL CLUB, [LONDON,] November 13, 1906
('6', 83, 6, 10, 145992) THE EDITOR THE TIMES [LONDON]
('6', 83, 8, 11, 146022) All thoughtful men must welcome your weighty leader on the Transvaal British Indian question which has recently come to the fore by reason of the visit of the Indian Deputation from the Transvaal.
('6', 83, 8, 12, 146219) I have carefully read and re read your remarks and I must confess that all that you have stated goes conclusively to show that Lord Elgin cannot possibly advise His Majesty to sanction the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance.
('6', 83, 8, 13, 146441) As Sir Lepel graphically put before Lord Elgin, “The toad under the harrow knows where and whether it is hurt!” The Ordinance which is supposed to relieve British Indians has given rise to the greatest irritation to the Indian community.
('6', 83, 8, 14, 146679) You will perhaps give me the credit for knowing fairly intimately the British
('6', 83, 9, 15, 146757) 1 This draft is by Gandhi.
('6', 83, 9, 16, 146784) Vide “Letter to Sir Muncherji Bhownaggree”, 12 11 1906. This letter did not appear in The Times
('6', 84, 0, 1, 146880) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 85
('6', 84, 1, 2, 146923) Indian question in South Africa which I have always considered to be one of the first class magnitude.
('6', 84, 1, 3, 147026) You, sir, have now very ably shown the Imperial importance of the question.
('6', 84, 1, 4, 147102) About a year ago, at a sitting of the Legislative Council of the Transvaal, Sir George Farrar suggested that a commission should be sent to the Transvaal to enquire into the whole position.
('6', 84, 1, 5, 147292) I immediately accepted the proposition and approached Mr. Lyttelton who, had he been still at the Colonial Office, 1 I doubt not, would have appointed a commission.
('6', 84, 1, 6, 147457) In view of the approaching Colonial Conference, it becomes doubly imperative that the Imperial Government should appoint such a commission so that the Conference may have reliable data before it to go upon.
('6', 84, 1, 7, 147664) There can be no conceivable objection from any quarter to the appointment of such a commission.
('6', 84, 1, 8, 147760) Not to prejudge the case it will be only reasonable to withhold the Royal sanction for the Ordinance in question, pending the report of any such commission that may be appointed.
('6', 84, 1, 9, 147939) I re echo your opinion regarding the terrible discontent that is being spread by British Indians from South Africa.
('6', 84, 1, 10, 148055) As you very properly say, it is not a question of political disabilities but one of inability to enjoy the ordinary rights of a British subject or even a human being in a civilized country.
('6', 84, 1, 11, 148245) If the Colonies persist in their policy of exclusion, they will force on the mother country for solution a very serious problem which the late Sir William Wilson Hunters 2
('6', 84, 2, 12, 148417) used to reiterate in your columns, namely, “Is India to remain a part of the British Dominions or not?” He who runs may read that England will find it difficult to hold India if her people, immediately they migrated to British Colonies, are to be insulted and degraded as if they belonged to barbarous race.
('6', 84, 3, 13, 148725) I am, etc.,
