('6', 90, 7, 14, 156106) [THE EDITOR
('6', 90, 8, 15, 156118) THE TIMES LONDON
('6', 90, 10, 16, 156135) Perhaps it is necessary for me to say a word about the“petition” from certain Indians regarding the British Indian Deputation from the Transvaal which was the subject matter of question and answer in Parliament as reported in your issue of yesterday’s date.
('6', 90, 10, 17, 156393) It is said
('6', 90, 11, 18, 156404) 1 This was not published in The Times.
('6', 91, 0, 1, 156443) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 91, 1, 2, 156484) therein that I do not possess any mandate, that I am a professional agitator and that my advocacy of the Indian cause has resulted in harm being done to the Indians.
('6', 91, 2, 3, 156650) The appointment of my colleague and myself was made unanimously at a public meeting.
('6', 91, 2, 4, 156735) We hold a document to that effect.
('6', 91, 3, 5, 156770) The mass meeting at Johannesburg which was convened by me as Secretary to the British Indian Association approved of the principle of the Delegation.
('6', 91, 3, 6, 156920) The first signatory 2 to this “petition” was present at the meeting and spoke strongly in support of all the principal resolutions.
('6', 91, 3, 7, 157052) He, moreover, offered himself as one of the delegates but was not accepted.
('6', 91, 3, 8, 157128) The “petition” is signed by two Indians.
('6', 91, 3, 9, 157169) It is necessary to distinguish the “petition” from a paper purporting to have been signed by 437 Indians and repudiating our mandate.
('6', 91, 3, 10, 157303) As to this, the following cable was received by the Delegates from Johannes burg on the 10th instant: “Have affidavits Godfrey obtained signat ures blank paper false pretences using name bias (code word for the British Indian Association, Transvaal) signatures now with drawn cabling (Lord) Elgin papers publish full report conference.” The foregoing cable was evidently sent on the telegra phic report of the interview sent by the Press correspondents.
('6', 91, 4, 11, 157757) The incident does not mean that the two signatories of the “petition” approve of the Asiatic Ordinance.
('6', 91, 4, 12, 157861) On the contrary, in their opinion evidently I am the mischievous cause of the legislation which they detest as much as the other Indians.
('6', 91, 4, 13, 157999) Their attitude resolves itself into personal objection to me and not into one of approval of the Ordinance.
('6', 91, 5, 14, 158107) As I have been allowed by the Colonial Office to see the “petition”— I know that the expression “professional agitator” means a paid agitator —I may then state that the thirteen years’ service rendered by me to my countrymen has been a labour of love and [a matter of the] keenest pleasure to me.
('6', 91, 6, 15, 158404) Opinions may differ as to the usefulness or otherwise of my services.
('6', 91, 6, 16, 158474) The late Sir John Robinson considered that they were not
('6', 91, 7, 17, 158531) 1 Vide ‘‘Interview to South Africa’’, 16 11 1906. 2 Dr. William Godfrey
('6', 92, 0, 1, 158603) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 93
('6', 92, 1, 2, 158646) useless.
('6', 92, 1, 3, 158655) 1 Mr. William Hosken 2 and others in the Transvaal also encourage me in the work I am trying to do, namely, to cement the relations between the European and the British Indian subjects in South Africa by removing all cause for misunderstanding.
('6', 92, 1, 4, 158900) The only reason for tendering this explanation is that the sacred mission which I have come here to discharge may not be prejudiced in the eyes of the public by leaving unchallenged the allegation in question.

('6', 93, 12, 15, 160129) I have just been talking to a valued friend 1 about the conversation we had yesterday.
('6', 93, 12, 16, 160216) He is a missionary belonging to the Arya Samaj of the Punjab.
('6', 93, 12, 17, 160278) The Samaj is to Hinduism what Protestantism is to Catholicism.
('6', 93, 12, 18, 160341) The missionary friend is under a vow of poverty and his talents are devoted to the work of education combined with religion.
('6', 93, 12, 19, 160466) He is an M.A. of Punjab University but in order to increase his usefulness he is staying in London and studying for the London M.A. I suggested to him that, if he could enter a quiet, nice English home, he would be able to see the real culture and beauty of English life which would be of immense use in his work.
('6', 93, 12, 20, 160780) At the same time he is to live as cheaply as possible.
('6', 93, 12, 21, 160835) Do you know a home that would take him without pecuniary consideration?

('6', 94, 8, 9, 161328) 92. LETTER TO W. T. STEAD
('6', 94, 9, 10, 161354) HOTEL CECIL, LONDON, November 16, 1906
('6', 94, 10, 11, 161393) DEAR SIR,
('6', 94, 11, 12, 161403) As you were good enough to show very great sympathy with the cause of British Indians in the Transvaal, may I suggest your using your influence with the Boer leaders in the Transvaal?
('6', 94, 11, 13, 161587) I feel certain that they did not share the same prejudice against British Indians as against the Kaffir races but as the prejudice against Kaffir races in a strong form was in existence in the Transvaal at the time when the British Indians immigrated there, the latter were immediately lumped together with the Kaffir races and described under the generic term “Coloured people”.
('6', 94, 11, 14, 161967) Gradually the Boer mind was habituated to this qualification and it refused to recognize the evident and sharp distinctions that undoubtedly exist between British Indians and the Kaffir races in South Africa.
('6', 94, 12, 15, 162176) If you were to place this position before them in your own graphic style and show to them that British Indians have an ancient civilization behind them, that they do not aspire to any“ political power in the Transvaal, that they are a mere handful, i.e., 13,000, and
('6', 95, 0, 1, 162443) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 95, 1, 2, 162484) that further immigration can easily be regulated without accentuating class difference, I have no doubt that some at least of the Boer leaders would listen to you and give effect to your suggestions.
('6', 95, 2, 3, 162684) The Indian community in the Transvaal will feel deeply grateful to you if you could see your way to influence the Boer mind in the direction I have ventured to suggest to you.
('6', 95, 3, 4, 162860) I remain,
('6', 95, 4, 5, 162870) Yours faithfully,
('6', 95, 5, 6, 162888) W. T. STEAD, ESQ.

('6', 99, 4, 5, 170146) 97. MEETING AT LONDON INDIAN SOCIETY 1
('6', 99, 5, 6, 170185) [After November 16, 1906]
('6', 99, 6, 7, 170211) At a well attended meeting of the London Indian Society, on the 3 rd November, at 84 and 85, Palace Chambers, Westminster, the Hon’ble Dadabhai Naoroji in the chair, Mr. James Godfrey of Natal, who is at present keeping his terms for the Bar and has passed his final examination, gave a paper under the above title 2. Below is given a condensation of the paper: Since my arrival here, I have had ample opportunities of studying these people and I hope to show you that there are very many valuable lessons to be learnt from them.
('6', 99, 6, 8, 170741) Let us examine and analyse them and see what qualities have made them what they are and what are the potent factors which are securing for them the universal triumph which seems to be growing larger and larger every day, and which must command the admiration of even their bitterest enemies.
('6', 99, 6, 9, 171033) I was led to make this examination myself owing to what I felt were unsatisfactory replies given to me by a large number of our countrymen when leaving this land for home.
('6', 99, 6, 10, 171205) Invariably I put them the question: “What has England taught
('6', 99, 7, 11, 171266) 1 This is a report of the meeting held on November 3, and was published in Indian Opinion as “specially contributed”.
('6', 99, 7, 12, 171384) It was written by Gandhiji; vide “Letter to H. S. L. Polak”, 16 11 1906.
('6', 99, 8, 13, 171457) 2 This item was published under the sub title, “The Englishman as I Find Him’’
('6', 100, 0, 1, 171536) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 101
('6', 100, 1, 2, 171580) you or what improvements have you in mind to suggest to your people when you return?” And to such questions I received the painful and saddening reply to the effect that they had been too much occupied with their immediate studies and occupations to devote any time to or concern themselves about the people or things surrounding them.
('6', 100, 1, 3, 171916) As to improvements at home, that is a question which affects local interests and, therefore, must necessarily need local considera tion, etc.
('6', 100, 1, 4, 172058) Now gentlemen, I put it to you that such replies are anything but satisfactory.
('6', 100, 1, 5, 172138) Whether this be the frame of mind of the majority who go back, I will not take upon myself the responsibility of stating.
('6', 100, 1, 6, 172260) I hope I shall be told I am mistaken.
('6', 100, 1, 7, 172298) Be that as it may, the knowledge of the fact of even one of us returning home in this mood of utter indifference and doubt, I feel, amply justifies a reference to the subject in a paper of this kind.
('6', 100, 1, 8, 172498) The Englishman abroad is one person and the Englishman at home is quite another.
('6', 100, 1, 9, 172579) In the first case he proves himself to be a veritable tyrant and a despot, but in the second case, i.e., in England, few will say that he is not a desirable person.
('6', 100, 2, 10, 172744) From this you will see, therefore, that we actually arrive in this country with more or less prejudiced views and ideas, and apparently some never seem to get beyond that stage, and can never see or appreciate any good in the Englishman.
('6', 100, 2, 11, 172982) We never seem to realize that we have come all the way from home in order to benefit ourselves and secure that experience and status which it is somewhat difficult for us to secure in our own land.
('6', 100, 2, 12, 173180) We come, not with the intention of merely qualifying in some particular profession, but of simultaneously gaining that wider experience of the world and its ways which can only be had by travelling in foreign countries.
('6', 100, 2, 13, 173400) We defeat the very object of our visit to this country if we do not carry away with us some of the multifarious benefits derived by our sojourn here.
('6', 100, 2, 14, 173550) We want, after our staying here, to go back with the very best that the place can give us...
('6', 100, 2, 15, 173643) If we don’t, the loss is ours and we are not doing our duty to ourselves, much less to our country.
('6', 100, 3, 16, 173743) The success of the Japanese is admitted on all hands to have been due chiefly to their having, for the last 40 years or more, sent out students and specialists for the express purpose of eliciting the best information, learning the newest and latest inventions and carrying back the cream of Europe’s learning, advancement and ideas of progress, all for the benefit of their country.
('6', 100, 3, 17, 174127) Mark you, they did not
('6', 101, 0, 1, 174150) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 101, 1, 2, 174192) only carry this knowledge and ideas back, but they actually applied them with a result and success which have astonished the whole world.
('6', 101, 1, 3, 174330) Let us try and reckon up some of their good points only and see if they are worth copying.
('6', 101, 1, 4, 174421) The bad points we leave aside.
('6', 101, 1, 5, 174452) Throughout their whole history, we find that they have displayed a remarkable spirit of love for freedom and independence.
('6', 101, 1, 6, 174575) Did they not have to fight for this bit of land which they now proudly call England?
('6', 101, 1, 7, 174660) Did they not have both internal and external foes and that through many centuries?
('6', 101, 1, 8, 174743) The wonderful genius of the race seems to have conspired with the strengthening influence of the place itself in securing a sure, certain and steady progress onward.
('6', 101, 1, 9, 174909) The great American writer, R. W. Emerson, says: ‘These Saxons are the hands of mankind.
('6', 101, 1, 10, 174997) They have the taste for toil, a distaste for pleasure or repose and the telescopic appreciation of distant gain.
('6', 101, 1, 11, 175110) They are the wealth makers and by dint of mental faculty which has its own conditions and terms.
('6', 101, 1, 12, 175207) The Saxon works after liking or only for himself and to set him at work and begin to draw his monstrous values out of barren Britain, all dishonour, fret and barrier must be removed and then his energies begin to play.’ We see then that the whole mind of the race, so to say, has been expanding proportionately.
('6', 101, 1, 13, 175519) They have persevered in it and kept up an even game.
('6', 101, 1, 14, 175572) The English game appears to be one of main force to main force, the planting of foot to foot, fairplay and open field, a rough tug without trick or dodging.
('6', 101, 1, 15, 175729) One cannot entertain any reasonable doubt of their ability and energy.
('6', 101, 1, 16, 175800) Just realize for one moment the nature of the lightly artificial construction of the whole fabric here.
('6', 101, 1, 17, 175904) The very climate and geography are in themselves matters which are contrary to such conditions as would enhance a natural existence.
('6', 101, 1, 18, 176037) Bacon says: ‘Rome was a state not subject to paradoxes, but England subsists by antagonisms and contradictions and is a perfect museum of anomalies.’ Is it not true, though it has been humorously said, that ‘no fruits ripen in England but a baked apple’, and, again, is it not equally true that no indigenous animal worth the mention has ever before flourished in this country in comparison with other countries?
('6', 101, 1, 19, 176450) Yet in spite of these natural difficulties they have, owing to their dogged perseverance, tact, zeal and energy, driven all before them and are now at the top of the tree.
('6', 101, 1, 20, 176622) There seems to be some secret
('6', 102, 0, 1, 176652) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 103
('6', 102, 1, 2, 176696) power which permeates the whole nation and makes for progress.
('6', 102, 1, 3, 176759) They have pride and affection for their race.
('6', 102, 1, 4, 176805) Do we not hear everyone of them boasting and priding himself on the fact of his being an Englishman?
('6', 102, 1, 5, 176906) Does he not flout it to your face at every turn that because he is an Englishman therefore he rules?
('6', 102, 1, 6, 177007) They have solidarity or responsibility and trust in each other.
('6', 102, 1, 7, 177071) It has been said of the Englishmen that ‘they embrace their cause with more tenacity than their lives’.
('6', 102, 1, 8, 177175) The paper was very well received.
('6', 102, 1, 9, 177209) Messrs B. J. Wadia, M.A., Parmeshwar Lall, M.A., J. Gowrieshanker, M.A., Nathuram, Dwarka Das and several other gentlemen who took part in the discussion congratulated the lecturer on his broad mindedness and theability with which he had written his paper.
('6', 102, 1, 10, 177466) Some of the speakers thought that Mr. Godfrey had over drawn the picture in favour of the Englishman, but Mr. Godfrey in his reply, whilst thanking the members for their sympathetic reception, said that he had purposely left out the other side of the Englishman’s character, but he wanted to place before the members of the Society what he conside red was best in his character and what was worthy ofimitation.
('6', 102, 1, 11, 177877) A vote of thanks to the lecturer and to the Chair brought the proceedings to a close.

('6', 103, 1, 5, 179193) He is a much travelled man and is the author of Malki Law, as also the Sayings of Mahomed.
('6', 103, 1, 6, 179284) He has made Pan Islamism his life work, and in his striking, though somewhat lengthy speech, he clearly showed that the object of Pan Islamism was to bring together under its fold the different sects of Mahomedans and carry on a peaceful propaganda of the faith of the Prophet with a view to promote universal brotherhood.
('6', 103, 1, 7, 179607) This Society, which was originally called the Anjuman e Islam, was founded in 1886 in London.

('6', 103, 1, 10, 179823) The following are the avowed objects of the Society:
('6', 103, 2, 11, 179876) (a) To promote the religious, social, moral and intellectual advancement of the Mussulman world.
('6', 103, 2, 12, 179973) (b) To afford a centre of social union to Muslims from all parts of the world.
('6', 103, 2, 13, 180052) (c) To promote brotherly feelings between Muslims, and to facilitate intercourse between them.
('6', 103, 2, 14, 180147) (d) To remove misconceptions prevailing among non Muslims regarding Islam and Mussulman.
('6', 103, 2, 15, 180236) (e) To render legitimate assistance to the best of its ability to any Muslim requiring it in any part of the world.
('6', 103, 2, 16, 180352) (f) To provide facilities for conducting religious ceremonies in non Muslim countries.
('6', 103, 2, 17, 180439) (g) To hold debates and lectures, and to read papers likely to further the interests of Islam.
('6', 103, 2, 18, 180534) (h) To collect subscriptions from all parts of the world in order to build a mosque in London, and to endow it, and to extend the burial ground for the Muslims in London.
('6', 103, 2, 19, 180705) Its members are ordinary, extraordinary and honorary.
('6', 103, 2, 20, 180759) The annual subscription for ordinary resident members is 10/6; non resident members pay only an entrance fee of 5/6.

('6', 104, 5, 7, 181194) QUESTION I
('6', 104, 6, 8, 181205) Has the Right Hon’ble the Colonial Secretary received a petition from Mr. Abdul Ganie, Chairman of the British Indian Association of the Transvaal, regarding the Vrededorp Stands Ordinance published in the Transvaal Government Gazette dated September 28 last?
('6', 104, 6, 9, 181465) Will His Lordship advise His Majesty, under the power reserved under the Letters Patent, to disallow the Ordinance, in that it imposes on British Indians and other Coloured people a restriction as to holding leases of or remaining in occupation of Stands in Vrededorp?
('6', 104, 6, 10, 181734) Is it not a fact that Vrededorp is contiguous to a Location called the Malay Location and inhabited largely by British Indians?
('6', 104, 6, 11, 181862) Is it not a fact that British Indians are already in occupation of several Stands in Vrededorp, that some of them have built substantial structures on some Stands and that they are carrying on their trade on such Stands?
('6', 104, 6, 12, 182083) Is it not also a fact that many British Indians resided in Vrededorp during the Dutch regime and that there was no objection taken to their presence during that time?

('6', 111, 4, 9, 191256) 109. DEPUTATION NOTES II
('6', 111, 5, 10, 191281) HOTEL CECIL, LONDON, November 17, 1906
('6', 111, 6, 11, 191320) INTERVIEWS WITH LEADERS: SYMPATHY AND PROMISE OF HELP
('6', 111, 7, 12, 191374) The last week has been very busy.
('6', 111, 7, 13, 191408) We have had not a moment’s leisure.
('6', 111, 7, 14, 191444) We saw Mr. Theodore Morison of Aligarh and the well known Mr. Stead of the Review of Reviews.
('6', 111, 7, 15, 191538) Mr. Stead has boldly come out to give us all the help he can.
('6', 111, 7, 16, 191600) He was therefore requested to write to the Boer leaders that they should not consider Indians as being on the same level as Kaffirs.
('6', 111, 8, 17, 191733) We also saw Miss Smith, a lady who contributes to the Punjabee and the Amrita Bazar Patrika.
('6', 111, 8, 18, 191826) Miss Winterbottom, the Secretary of the Union of Ethical Societies, has promised to render all possible help.
('6', 111, 9, 19, 191936) We had an interview on Transvaal and Natal matters with the Private Secretary to Lord Elgin.
('6', 111, 9, 20, 192029) We talked about many things, and we may hope for some satisfactory results.
('6', 111, 9, 21, 192105) From Mr. Churchill’s reply to Sir Henry Cotton it appears that, for the present at least, the Ordinance will not receive assent.
('6', 111, 9, 22, 192234) The Pan Islamic Society has made a representation to Lord Elgin, saying that the feelings of the Muslim community have been
('6', 111, 10, 23, 192358) 1 About how a report of the Deputation proceedings came to be published in The Times; vide “Letter to Sir Henry Cotton”, 10 11 1906.
('6', 111, 11, 24, 192491) 2 Vide “Letter to W. T. Stead”,16 11 1906.
('6', 111, 12, 25, 192534) 3 Vide “Letter to Miss F. Winterbottom”, 13 11 1906.
('6', 112, 0, 1, 192587) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 113
('6', 112, 1, 2, 192631) greatly hurt by the application of the Ordinance to Turkish Muslims, while the Christians and the Jews of Turkey have been excluded from its purview.
('6', 112, 1, 3, 192781) Thus, help is being received from all quarters.
('6', 112, 1, 4, 192829) Mr. Ally had an interview with Sir Richard Solomon and because of this too, we have some ground for hope.
('6', 112, 2, 5, 192935) GODFREY’S PETITION 1
('6', 112, 3, 6, 192956) There is no rose without thorns.
('6', 112, 3, 7, 192989) And these hopes have a thorn in the shape of Dr. Godfrey’s petition.
('6', 112, 3, 8, 193058) I am not depressed on this account.
('6', 112, 3, 9, 193094) Neither need it hurt our feelings.
('6', 112, 3, 10, 193129) We should not be angry with Dr. Godfrey.
('6', 112, 3, 11, 193170) He is a child and lacks understanding.
('6', 112, 3, 12, 193209) Often he is unaware of his own folly.
('6', 112, 3, 13, 193247) He deserves pity rather than scorn.
('6', 112, 3, 14, 193283) Lord Elgin’s secretary showed us his petition, in which he states that the Indian community has given no authority to Messrs Gandhi and Ally.
('6', 112, 3, 15, 193425) Mr. Gandhi was a paid agitator and had amassed money through that trade.
('6', 112, 3, 16, 193498) The whites of Durban had beaten him up in 1896 2
('6', 112, 4, 17, 193547) and driven him away.
('6', 112, 4, 18, 193568) His activities had resulted in great harm and created differences between the whites and the Coloured people.
('6', 112, 4, 19, 193678) One Mr. Abdool Gani was the Chairman [of the British Indian Associa tion] and he knew nothing [of all this].
('6', 112, 4, 20, 193787) Mr. Ally was a rebel who wanted to establish the authority of the Calif 3 in political matters also.
('6', 112, 4, 21, 193888) The petition bears the signatures of Dr. Godfrey and Mr. C. M. Pillay.
('6', 112, 4, 22, 193959) They also state that many persons did not sign the petition as they were afraid of the Association.
('6', 112, 4, 23, 194059) Besides the petition, there is a document which is said to have been signed by 437 Indians.
('6', 112, 4, 24, 194151) It says that Messrs Gandhi and Ally have no authority to act on behalf of the Indian community.
('6', 112, 4, 25, 194247) The best part of the petition is now known to the public as Sir Henry Cotton asked a question about it in Parliament.
('6', 112, 4, 26, 194365) As the question was raised by many, Sir Muncherji has addressed a letter [to The Times] on it, but this has not yet been published.
('6', 112, 4, 27, 194497) Mr. Gandhi, too, has written one.
('6', 112, 4, 28, 194531) And the two brothers of Dr. Godfrey who have been actively assisting the Deputation have also written to the Press.
('6', 112, 4, 29, 194647) When all these letters are published, it is expected that the storm will blow over.
('6', 112, 4, 30, 194731) It is necessary that all this news be published; it need not, however, cause any nervousness.

('6', 113, 1, 2, 194998) ARTICLES IN LONDON “TIMES” A formidable article appeared last Saturday in The Times.
('6', 113, 1, 3, 195083) A copy of it was despatched last week.
('6', 113, 1, 4, 195122) In the article written by Sir Roper Lethbridge also, it is stated that India is very unhappy because of the sufferings of the Indian community.
('6', 113, 1, 5, 195266) PERMANENT COMMITTEE The cablegram sanctioning the setting up of the permanent committee has been received.
('6', 113, 1, 6, 195373) Accordingly a room has been rented for a year; £40 will have to be paid as rent.
('6', 113, 1, 7, 195454) Sir Muncherji has helped a lot.
('6', 113, 1, 8, 195486) He will probably become the chairman of the committee.
('6', 113, 1, 9, 195541) Furniture worth £25 has been purchased.
('6', 113, 1, 10, 195581) It is proposed to give a thanksgiving dinner to all the gentlemen who have helped us, and to announce the formation of the committee on that occasion.
('6', 113, 1, 11, 195732) As the time is short, it remains to be seen how much of all this can be done.
('6', 113, 1, 12, 195810) Mr. Ritch will work as secretary of the committee.
('6', 113, 1, 13, 195861) As his financial position is not satisfactory, a nominal sum of £7.10.0 to £10 a month will have to be paid to him.
('6', 113, 1, 14, 195977) He will give all his time to the committee.
('6', 113, 1, 15, 196021) He is speaking on the 26th before the East India Association.
('6', 113, 1, 16, 196083) If possible, I shall give a summary 1 of his speech next week.
('6', 113, 1, 17, 196146) There is reason to hope that much of our work can be looked after by the committee.
('6', 113, 1, 18, 196230) It should receive help from all over South Africa.
('6', 113, 1, 19, 196281) Sir Muncherji has suggested that it may be named South Africa British Indian Vigilance Committee.

('6', 125, 1, 2, 209519) 129. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO LORD ELGIN
('6', 125, 2, 3, 209566) HOTEL CECIL, LONDON, W.C. 2, November 20, 1906
('6', 125, 3, 4, 209613) TO THE PRIVATE SECRETARY OF THE EARL OF ELGIN SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE COLONIES
('6', 125, 4, 5, 209695) COLONIAL OFFICE DOWNING STREET
('6', 125, 5, 6, 209726) DEAR SIR, With reference to the interview that Mr. Ally and I had with you and Mr. Just in connection with the “petition” received from Dr. Godfrey and another and the papers said to be signed by 437 Indians and in connection with matters arising out of His Lordship’s reply to the Deputation that waited on him on the 8th day of November, in accordance with your instructions, Mr. Ally and I submit herewith a written statement for submission to His Lordship.
('6', 125, 6, 7, 210187) I have the honour to be,
('6', 125, 8, 8, 210212) Your obedient servant, M. K. GANDHI Enclosure [ENCLODURE]
('6', 125, 9, 9, 210270) STATEMENT BY THE DELEGATES ON BEHALF OF THE BRITISH INDIANS
('6', 125, 10, 10, 210330) IN THE TRANSVAAL REGARDING THE “ PETITION” FROM DR.
('6', 125, 10, 11, 210382) WILLIAM GODFREY AND ANOTHER AND OTHER MATTERS
('6', 125, 11, 12, 210428) “ THE PETITION”
('6', 125, 12, 13, 210444) 1. The “petition” is signed by Dr. William Godfrey and C. M. Pillay both of whom are personally known to the Delegates.
('6', 125, 12, 14, 210564) 2. Petitioner William Godfrey is a doctor of Edinburgh University and is practising in Johannesburg.
('6', 125, 12, 15, 210665) 3. The petitioner C. M. Pillay is an interpreter of no standing.
('6', 125, 12, 16, 210730) He has been found to be the worse for liquor and may be described as a loafer.
('6', 126, 0, 1, 210809) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 127
('6', 126, 1, 2, 210853) 4. So far as the recollection of the Delegates serves rightly, the points made in the “petition” are as follows:
('6', 126, 2, 3, 210966) (a) Delegates have no mandate from the general body of Indians.
('6', 126, 3, 4, 211030) (b) Mr. Gandhi is a professional agitator who has made money out of his work.
('6', 126, 4, 5, 211108) (c) Mr. Gandhi has caused an estrangement between Europeans and Indians and his advocacy has resulted in harm to the community.
('6', 126, 5, 6, 211236) (d) He was mobbed at Durban by the European community.
('6', 126, 6, 7, 211291) (e) He is proprietor of Indian Opinion.
('6', 126, 7, 8, 211331) (f) Mr. Ally is Chairman and founder of a politico religious body which has as its object recognition of the Sultan as both the spiritual and political head of the Moslems.
('6', 126, 8, 9, 211504) (g) A Mr. Abdul Ganie is President of the British Indian Association.
('6', 126, 9, 10, 211574) (h) The petitioners have not been able to receive support for their contentions because of the intimidation on the part of the British Indian Association.
('6', 126, 10, 11, 211729) 5. As to (a), the Delegates enclose herewith letter 1 signed by the Chairman of the British Indian Association.
('6', 126, 10, 12, 211841) Their election was unanimous.
('6', 126, 10, 13, 211871) It took place at a meeting of the Association that was largely attended.
('6', 126, 10, 14, 211944) There was no protest sent to the Association although the election was before the public for a long time.
('6', 126, 11, 15, 212050) 6. As to (b), Mr. Gandhi has received no remuneration for his public work throughout his thirteen years’ career.
('6', 126, 11, 16, 212163) He has from time to time contributed to the funds of the Association.
('6', 126, 11, 17, 212233) The work has been purely a labour of love.
('6', 126, 11, 18, 212276) His Lordship is further referred to correspondence that took place in The Star of Johannesburg on the 25th October in refutation of a somewhat similar statement made by The Star on the 23rd October.
('6', 126, 12, 19, 212475) 7. As to (c), Mr. Gandhi is totally unaware of any estrangement having taken place between Europeans and Indians by reason of his
('6', 126, 13, 20, 212605) 1Vide “Interview to South Africa”, 16 11 1906, and also”Telegram to Transvaal Governor”, 9 30 1906.
('6', 127, 0, 1, 212705) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 127, 1, 2, 212747) advocacy; on the contrary, his supreme effort has been to bring about a reconciliation between the two communities, such being the avowed object of the Natal Indian Congress, of which he was the honorary Secretary and one of the founders, [and] of the British Indian Association of which he is the present Secretary.
('6', 127, 1, 3, 213064) On this point His Lordship is further referred to the following letter from the late Sir John Robinson, which is one among many received from distingu ished residents at the time of his departure for India in 1901:
('6', 127, 2, 4, 213279) I beg to thank you for your kind invitation to the meeting at the Congress Hall this evening (October 15, 1901).
('6', 127, 2, 5, 213392) It would have given me great pleasure to have been present on the occasion of so well earned a mark of respect to our able and distinguished fellow citizen, Mr. Gandhi, but unfortunately my state of health prevents my going out at night, and I am for the present debarred from taking part in any public function, so I must ask you to kindly excuse my inability to attend.Not the less heartily do I wish all success to this public recognition of the good work done and the many services rendered to the community by Mr. Gandhi.
('6', 127, 3, 6, 213919) The chief reason for his having organized the Indian Ambulance Corps at the time of the Boer War 2 and the Indian Stretcher[ Bearer] Corps at the time of the Native Rebellion, was to bring about such [re]conciliation, by showing that British Indians were not unworthy to be citizens of the Empire and were capable of recognizing their obligations if they also insisted on their rights.
('6', 127, 4, 7, 214305) 8. As to (d), it is true that Mr. Gandhi was mobbed on the 13th January, 1897 on his return from India on a misrepresentation about his advocacy of the Natal Indian cause in India.
('6', 127, 4, 8, 214486) Public apology was given to him on the 14th and when the whole of the position became known, the late Mr. Escombe invited him to see him and ever since that time he had the privilege of enjoying the late Mr. Escombe’s friendship.
('6', 127, 4, 9, 214716) The late Mr. Escombe at his request blessed the leaders of the Natal Indian Ambulance Corps and of his own accord gave them a tea party and made a very eulogistic and public spirited speech on the occasion.3 After the mobbing incident, he remained in Durban up to his return to India in 1901.
('6', 127, 5, 10, 215009) 1 Vide also “Notes”, 3 9 1900.
('6', 127, 6, 11, 215040) 2 ibid.
('6', 127, 6, 12, 215048) 3 ibid.
('6', 128, 0, 1, 215056) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 129
('6', 128, 1, 2, 215100) 9. As to (e), it is true that Mr. Gandhi is the real proprietor of Indian Opinion from which no profits are made and to which he has devoted the whole of his savings.
('6', 128, 1, 3, 215267) There are two Englishmen associated with him in that work and they and several Indians have, for the sake of the paper, reduced themselves to voluntary pauperism.
('6', 128, 1, 4, 215430) The paper is being run on Tolstoy’s and Ruskin’s lines.
('6', 128, 1, 5, 215486) Its publicly declared mission is to bring the two communities together and become an educative medium for the Indian community.
('6', 128, 2, 6, 215614) 10. As to (f) 1 , the terms in which Mr. Abdul Ganie has been spoken of are most derogatory and a product of ignorance.
('6', 128, 2, 7, 215734) He is the managing partner of one of the most flourishing firms of Indian merchants in South Africa.
('6', 128, 2, 8, 215835) Mr. Abdul Ganie has been the unchallen ged President of the Association since its inception.
('6', 128, 2, 9, 215928) He is a resident of the Transvaal of 25 years’ standing and has come in contact with most of the British officials including High Commissioners and is very well known and is respected by European merchants of standing.
('6', 128, 3, 10, 216147) 11. As to (g) 2 , Mr. Ally’s whole life in South Africa, that is to say a period of twenty three years, has been devoted to the service of the Empire.
('6', 128, 3, 11, 216298) He had the honour of coming in personal touch with Sir Richard Solomon, the late Lord Loch, the late Lord Rosemead, Dr. Jamieson, Sir Gordon Sprigg, Sir James Sievright and the present officials in the Transvaal.
('6', 128, 3, 12, 216511) He was asked by the Cape Government, at the time of the Malay discontent; regarding the position of a burial ground, to quell the discontent which he was successful in doing and for which he was thanked by the Government.
('6', 128, 3, 13, 216733) This was in 1885; He has had the honour often to speak—being a voter himself at the Cape—on public platforms in support of the British Party candidate as opposed to Bond candidates.
('6', 128, 3, 14, 216915) His free services were utilized by the Uitlander Committee for receiving signatures to the petition that was forwarded to the late Queen in connection with the Uitlander grievances.
('6', 128, 4, 15, 217097) It is untrue that the Hamidia Islamic Society, of which he is the Founder and President, has as its object recognition of the Sultan as the political head of the Moslem world.
('6', 128, 4, 16, 217273) It is formed essentially to help poor Moslems, to defray the expenses of the burials of poor
('6', 128, 5, 17, 217366) 1 This should really be “(g)”.
('6', 128, 5, 18, 217397) Vide summary of petition in para 4, “Letter to Private Secretary to Lord Elgin”, 20 11 1906. 2 This should be “ (f) “.
('6', 129, 0, 1, 217516) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 129, 1, 2, 217558) Moslems, to do among them the work of social regeneration and to remove their special hardships.
('6', 129, 1, 3, 217655) Sir Richard Solomon, whom Mr. Ally saw on Friday last, has kindly consented that his name might be mentioned to His Lordship as guarantee of his intense loyalty and devotion to the Empire, if such be needed.
('6', 129, 1, 4, 217863) 12. As to (h), the allegation of intimidation is devoid of foundation.
('6', 129, 1, 5, 217934) Poor people, who would be the greatest sufferers under the Ordinance, do not require the slightest encouragement to make an effort for their deliverance from the impending calamity, for such it undoubtedly is to them.
('6', 129, 1, 6, 218152) The Delegates respectfully claim to be the most moderate exponents of the sentiments of over 10,000 Indians in the Colony of the Transvaal.
('6', 129, 1, 7, 218292) It is not possible to give His Lordship an adequate notion of the bitter feeling engendered by the Ordinance.
('6', 129, 1, 8, 218402) Many Europeans, including a government official, were present at the great Mass Meeting, which resolved, without a dissentient voice, to send a deputation.
('6', 129, 1, 9, 218558) The visitors fully realized the depth of feeling to which the community was moved.
('6', 129, 1, 10, 218641) His Lordship is referred for a description of the meeting to The Star, The Leader and The Rand Daily Mail which published fairly full reports of the meeting.
('6', 129, 2, 11, 218799) SUGGESTED EXPLANATION OF PETITIONER’S CONDUCT 13. Dr. Godfrey is a hot headed youth, without any experience of practical life in the world.
('6', 129, 2, 12, 218939) He only finished his studies over two years ago.
('6', 129, 2, 13, 218988) He has never before, except in connection with the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance, come forward to do public work.
('6', 129, 2, 14, 219104) He himself attended the Mass Meeting and spoke on the principal resolutions, including the resolutions condemning the Ordinance, appointing a commission and advocating going to gaol in preference to the submission to the carrying of passes.
('6', 129, 2, 15, 219345) When the time came for selecting the delegates, he came forward as a candidate but was not selected.
('6', 129, 2, 16, 219446) He sent a telegram at Cape Town wishing success to Mr. Ally and has given him a note of introduction to his wife’s parents in Edinburgh, which reads as follows:
('6', 129, 3, 17, 219607) This is to introduce to you one of our best of friends Mr. H. O. Ally.
('6', 129, 3, 18, 219678) He is leaving here to fight the Indian cause and after his battles he will no doubt take a trip to Scotland.
('6', 129, 3, 19, 219787) He will wire by what train he will be coming up and on what date.
('6', 129, 3, 20, 219853) By religion he is an Islam and as such I will write you in detail
('6', 130, 0, 1, 219919) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 131
('6', 130, 1, 2, 219963) as to the modes of their living especially as regards to their food and I hope (after my next week’s letters) you will make him as happy and cheery as you can during his stay in Edinburgh.
('6', 130, 1, 3, 220152) Don’t forget to let him have a sight of the glorious F. Bridge and our ain little wee lael home at Tynecastle Terrace.
('6', 130, 1, 4, 220271) John I have no doubt will know Mr. Ally well.
('6', 130, 1, 5, 220317) It is the same who gave him the confetti before he left.
('6', 130, 2, 6, 220374) Yours aff [ectionately,] (signed ) WILLIAM
('6', 130, 3, 7, 220417) The original is hereto attached for His Lordship’s inspection.
('6', 130, 3, 8, 220480) He was for a long time one of Mr. Gandhi’s clients and he was associated with Mr. Gandhi in nursing the plague patients in 1904 and at the time did very valuable work for the relief of the patients.
('6', 130, 3, 9, 220679) The only way therefore his conduct can be explained is to ascribe it to his hot headedness.
('6', 130, 3, 10, 220771) The disappointment in this connection seems to have unhinged his mind.
('6', 130, 3, 11, 220842) That appears to be the most charitable constru ction to place upon his conduct, otherwise his strong condemnation of the Ordinance, his strong recommendation to Mr. Ally, would be inconsistent with the despatch of the petition.
('6', 130, 3, 12, 221070) From the following cablegram received by the Delegates and already sent to His Lordship, 1 it would appear that 437 Indian signatures taken on a separate document have been received on false pretences:
('6', 130, 4, 13, 221272) Have affidavits Godfrey obtained signatures blank paper false pretences using

('6', 130, 7, 16, 221488) 14. The Delegates have been obliged painfully and reluctantly to make the above statements, not in the slightest degree with the intention of injuring Dr. Godfrey or his associate and if they have been obliged to say anything regarding themselves, it is from a sense of paramount duty they owe to their countrymen, whose interests they have the honour to represent.
('6', 130, 7, 17, 221854) As the personal element has been introduced here by the “petition” and in Johannesburg by The Star, it has become necessary to show respectfully to His Lordship that, so far as the personal element is to count in the controversy, the position held by the Delegates, in their humble opinion, would weigh, after the most searching examination in favour of the community.
('6', 130, 8, 18, 222223) 1 Vide “Letter to Private Secretary to Lord Elgin”, 12 11 1906.
('6', 131, 0, 1, 222287) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 131, 1, 2, 222329) would very much rather that the whole of the Ordinance were examined on its merits and they would therefore respectfully proceed to dwell upon some of the points that arise from His Lordship’s reply to the Deputation.
('6', 131, 2, 3, 222547) LORD ELGIN’S REPLY: NO PERMIT UNDER LAW 3 OF 1885
('6', 131, 3, 4, 222597) 15. His Lordship is under the impression that there were permits under the Law 3 of 1885 during the Boer regime and that the Boer administration was lax in the administration of the permit law.
('6', 131, 3, 5, 222791) The Delegates respectfully venture to state that the Boer law did not require any permits at all.
('6', 131, 3, 6, 222889) The receipts given for £3 therefore were not inaccurate.
('6', 131, 3, 7, 222946) They were not permits authorizing entry or residence.
('6', 131, 3, 8, 223000) There was no restriction on immigration contemplated by Law 3 of 1885, as the law itself shows.
('6', 131, 3, 9, 223096) There was therefore no question of identification
('6', 131, 4, 10, 223146) The permits came into vogue only after the introduction of the Peace Preservation Ordinance of the British regime.
('6', 131, 5, 11, 223261) This distinction is very material in order to show that the Asiatic Ordinance, now for consideration before His Lordship, is not an amendment but a new law.
('6', 131, 5, 12, 223418) It does not make accurate that which was inaccurate under the Boer regime.
('6', 131, 5, 13, 223493) It creates a new disability.
('6', 131, 6, 14, 223522) VOLUNTARY THUMB MARKS
('6', 131, 7, 15, 223544) 16. It is respectfully submitted that the voluntary act of the Indian community in putting thumb marks on permits and registra tion certificates was performed gracefully to please Lord Milner and to avoid legislation compelling such performance.
('6', 131, 7, 16, 223790) It is therefore hardly fair to use the act as a precedent against the community.
('6', 131, 8, 17, 223871) NEW REGISTRATION
('6', 131, 9, 18, 223888) 17. The statement that new registration will give a final and indefeasible title to those who are registered is again, in the humble opinion of the Delegates, not in consonance with facts.
('6', 131, 9, 19, 224077) The title of those who hold permits is today indefeasible in law.
('6', 131, 9, 20, 224143) The new Ordinance would actually cancel that title and not give it.
('6', 131, 9, 21, 224211) After dispossessing the community of what it already possesses, it will restore a new title of doubtful value circumscribed by galling require ments and penalties.
('6', 131, 9, 22, 224375) It will, therefore, restore to the community only a part of what will be taken away from it.
('6', 132, 0, 1, 224468) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 133
('6', 132, 1, 2, 224512) INSPECTION
('6', 132, 2, 3, 224523) 18. Under the new Ordinance, it is possible to carry on a daily inspection.
('6', 132, 2, 4, 224599) The assurance given to His Lordship, that the inspection will be yearly, is beside the mark.
('6', 132, 2, 5, 224692) There is no guarantee of the same executive authority remaining in office.
('6', 132, 2, 6, 224767) The experience of the community almost invariably has been that arbitrary power given to the executive in South Africa has been arbitrarily and almost fully exercised against British Indians.
('6', 132, 2, 7, 224959) When a restrictive law is passed against a community labouring under popular prejudice, the executive has been powerless to resist popular demand for full enforcement of restrictions.
('6', 132, 2, 8, 225143) This has happened even with the present executive in respect of Law 3 of 1885 and Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('6', 132, 2, 9, 225255) So much has this been the case that the Indian community has had to go to the Supreme Court in order to resist the attempt of the executive to read into the above laws meanings they are not ordinarily capable of bearing.
('6', 132, 4, 10, 225476) 19. It is for the Indian community a matter almost of life and death.
('6', 132, 4, 11, 225546) It is respectfully urged that the matter can only be properly sifted by a judicial commission.
('6', 132, 4, 12, 225641) If His Lordship is not satisfied as to the full justice of the Indian contention, it is submitted that the decision should be suspended pending the inquiry of a commission.

('6', 139, 0, 1, 232448) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 139, 1, 2, 232490) 141. DEPUTATION TO MORLEY
('6', 139, 2, 3, 232516) The following is a report of the interview between Mr. Morley, Secretary of State for India, and the deputation representing Brittish Indians in South Africa:
('6', 139, 3, 4, 232675) [LONDON, November 22, 1906]
('6', 139, 4, 5, 232703) SIR LEPEL GRIFFIN: I have the honour, sir, to head this deputation today in order to present to you two Delegates from South Africa, Mr. Gandhi and Mr. Ally.
('6', 139, 5, 6, 232861) I would like to say with reference to Mr. Gandhi and a somewhat silly petition which has been sent from South Africa against him and his mission that this was the work of some mischievous schoolboy, and every one who knows Mr. Gandhi, or has been associated with his work for many years, as I have been, knows his single hearted devotion to this particular cause and that without any personal motive or any reward.
('6', 139, 5, 7, 233276) His methods and his motives have been altogether disinterested—to this I can pledge myself.
('6', 139, 6, 8, 233368) One thing that I think I may say without presumption is this.
('6', 139, 6, 9, 233430) No one knows better than you, sir, how strong the feeling of India is on this point.
('6', 139, 6, 10, 233515) It has been brought before the India Office and the Colonial Office by successive Viceroys and Indian Secretaries; and Colonial Secretaries themselves have, in reply to the memorials which I have had the honour myself to submit to them, expressed quite as warm sympathy with the grievances of the British Indians in South Africa as Indian Viceroys or Indian Secretaries at home.
('6', 139, 6, 11, 233894) That point does not require any elaboration: The position between England and her Colonies seems to me very much like that which is now existing between the Central Government of the United States and the State of California, and that position will become aggravated in many parts of the world.
('6', 139, 6, 12, 234189) (‘Hear!
('6', 139, 6, 13, 234197) Hear!’) The difficulty of the case is, of Corsica, exceedingly great.
('6', 139, 6, 14, 234267) You have two opposite positions, one represented by the clear and somewhat crude position, which nevertheless has a dignified and a worthy basis—that every British subject under the English flag should be free in his person and to carry on everywhere, without interruption, honourably any occupation he may see fit to undertake.
('6', 139, 6, 15, 234596) (‘Hear!
('6', 139, 6, 16, 234604) Hear!’) That applies, sir, to the whole Empire, and it is met on the opposite side by the position, which opposes reduction of the wages of labour—so far as white people are concerned, of course, the desire, and the proper desire is that the rate of wages should rise.
('6', 139, 6, 17, 234873) The introduction of a very industrious, temperate class, who can live on very little, tends to lower the rate of earnings of white people who cannot live on so small a sum.
('6', 139, 6, 18, 235046) These are the two opposite poles, and they have to be connected peaceably by some bridge which we ask you, sir, to try and build.
('6', 140, 0, 1, 235176) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 141
('6', 140, 1, 2, 235220) And I would also say, sir, that for two reasons you are the one person who can
('6', 140, 2, 3, 235299) satisfy the claims of this exceedingly complicated case.
('6', 140, 2, 4, 235356) In the first place, you hold
('6', 140, 3, 5, 235385) the keys which shut and which unloose as Secretary of State for India.
('6', 140, 4, 6, 235456) Let me explain in one word.
('6', 140, 4, 7, 235484) Take Natal, for example.
('6', 140, 4, 8, 235509) I have more than once,
('6', 140, 5, 9, 235532) as Chairman of the East India Association, sent petitions to the Secretary of State for
('6', 140, 6, 10, 235620) India, urging that no indentured coolies be allowed to go to Natal until the status of
('6', 140, 7, 11, 235707) their fellow subjects in South Africa is altered.
('6', 140, 7, 12, 235757) Natal cannot get on without the
('6', 140, 8, 13, 235789) Indians, and yet it persecutes them: and it persecuted them in old days much worse
('6', 140, 9, 14, 235872) than the Transvaal did: and their position is no better now, although Natal requires
('6', 140, 10, 15, 235957) Indian coolies every year more and more because English colonists cannot do the
('6', 140, 11, 16, 236037) field work themselves.
('6', 140, 11, 17, 236060) These are not countries which Englishmen can ever colonize.
('6', 140, 12, 18, 236120) That, sir, is all that I think it is necessary to say, but I shall make a final
('6', 140, 13, 19, 236200) personal appeal to you by saying that the other reason why I think you of all men are
('6', 140, 14, 20, 236286) the one who can settle this question is that one of the classics you have given to the
('6', 140, 15, 21, 236373) English people is a work 1 on compromise, in which I have very little doubt that the
('6', 140, 16, 22, 236458) key to this exceedingly complicated question will be found.
('6', 140, 17, 23, 236518) MR. GANDHI: On behalf of my colleague, Mr. Ally and myself, I beg to tender you our respectful thanks for giving to us an opportu nity of placing our position before you, sir.
('6', 140, 17, 24, 236694) But I do not make any apology for trespassing upon your most valuable time, because I think, sir, that we have a right to come to you, our responsible advocate and trustee, whenever we find our interests are in danger.
('6', 140, 17, 25, 236913) The Asiatic Ordinance was, as Sir Lepel Griffin has said, approved by Lord Elgin, I believe, under a misapprehension.
('6', 140, 17, 26, 237031) The Ordinance, in my humble opinion, departs from the Colonial policy hitherto follo wed in connection with Colonial legislation.
('6', 140, 17, 27, 237161) In my humble opinion it is without any justification whatever in that it draws, with reference to free immigrants, a colour line against which Colonial Secretaries as well as Indian Secretaries have repeatedly protested, and protested with success.
('6', 140, 17, 28, 237410) The Ordinance has been described by one of the South African colonists as one which will make us go about the streets with dog’s collars, and an indignant Indian at one of the meetings said that the treatment which would be meted out to us would be that, not of the colonial dog because he is a household pet, but of the Indian dog,
('6', 140, 18, 29, 237743) 1 The reference is to Morley's essay, On Compromise.
('6', 141, 0, 1, 237796) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 141, 1, 2, 237838) which is a vile dog.
('6', 141, 1, 3, 237859) I know that that was the bitterness of feeling that was engendered throughout the great mass of my community.
('6', 141, 1, 4, 237969) I cannot help saying, sir, that the feeling that was given vent to by the great meeting at Krugersdorp was fully justified by the experience of British Indians over and over again throughout the Transvaal as well as other parts of South Africa The reasons given for the introduction of the Ordinance have been stated in an inspired article in The Star as well as by Mr. Duncan, viz., that there is an unauthorized influx of Asiatics or British Indians into the Transvaal, and that the British Indian community is countenancing and encouraging such Asiatic influx.
('6', 141, 1, 5, 238533) I think, sir, that that charge, or both of the charges, can be proved to be absolutely false.
('6', 141, 1, 6, 238627) When they talk of an unauthorized influx, they mean that the British Indians enter the Transvaal without any permits, evading the police, and entering surreptitiously in defiance of the Peace Preservation Ordinance, which should regulate the entry of all, but which really regulates the entry of British Indians into the Transvaal.

('6', 142, 1, 3, 240486) I have been studying the history of restrictive legislation throughout South Africa—at any rate, during the last thirteen years—and I well remember that in 1894 Lord Ripon vetoed the Disenfranchising Bill because it applied to Asiatics alone.
('6', 142, 1, 4, 240729) Mr. Chamberlain disapproved of a draft bill that was submitted in 1897 in connection with a restriction on British Indians.

('6', 142, 1, 6, 241177) But, sir, in the Transvaal —also only last year, I believe it was, or in 1904—the Legislative Council passed the Native Land Tenure Bill, and I think it was passed without a single dissentient; but there was no hesitation whatsoever on the part of Mr. Lyttelton to veto the Land Tenure Bill.

('6', 142, 1, 8, 241769) It only meant Natives who held landed property; but even that was considered by Mr. Lyttelton as being too strong, and he had no hesitation in vetoing that legislation.

('6', 149, 10, 19, 262462) Lord Elgin told you when you saw him that he had sent any number of despatches to this Office—on the way to the Colonial Office, I presume—making the same protest.
('6', 149, 10, 20, 262626) Lord Curzon, the last Viceroy, carried on a tremendous battle.
('6', 149, 10, 21, 262689) (‘Hear!
('6', 149, 10, 22, 262697) Hear!’) I was this morning turning over his speeches, trying to see what he had said or done, and he gives in one of the speeches—his seventh Budget Speech—an account of his attempted dealings with the Government of Natal—in the year 1903, I think.
('6', 149, 10, 23, 262946) This is what he says.
('6', 149, 10, 24, 262968) It is very short, so I venture to read it.
('6', 149, 10, 25, 263011) ‘We stipulated for the eventual abolition of a tax of £3 a head which had been imposed on such persons for leave to reside; we stipulated for the amendment of an Act placing traders, of however old a standing, under the power of local corporations, who had absolute authority to refuse licenses to trade; we stipulated for the removal of Indians from another Act, under which they were classed with barbarous races; and for the provision of a summary remedy for free Indians, that is to say, Indians who had served their indenture, and had become free Indians, who might be wrongfully arrested on the ground that they were coolies under indenture or prohibited immigrants’.
('6', 149, 10, 26, 263685) That was Lord Curzon’s position dealing with the Government of Natal in 1903. What did the Government of Natal say?
('6', 149, 10, 27, 263801) ‘In reply,’ says Lord Curzon, ‘we were given to understand that there was no prospect of obtaining the consent of the local legislature to these conditions, and the negotiations were dropped.’ It would surely be unwise, and I do not think Sir Lepel Griffin would recommend me to put myself (if I had the authority) in a position of that sort, or that I should write to Lord Elgin a communication which would urge him to put himself into the same position with reference to the new Transvaal Government, when it comes into existence as Lord Curzon was placed in by the established Government of Natal.
('6', 150, 0, 1, 264402) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 151
('6', 150, 1, 2, 264446) As I understand from Mr. Gandhi—and I was delighted to hear it, and perhaps a little surprised, but delighted—the feeling on the part of the white colonists towards the Indians who are now, and have been for some time, resident in the Transvaal is not bad, but rather good than otherwise.
('6', 150, 2, 3, 264735) MR. GANDHI: The feeling is bad enough, but it is restricted to the petty store keepers.
('6', 150, 2, 4, 264823) It is they who agitate, and they who inflame the popular prejudice.
('6', 150, 3, 5, 264891) MR. MORLEY: I understand that, but we must, after all, look at this thing fairly.
('6', 150, 3, 6, 264973) It is not very unnatural that a small white store keeper should be very happy if he could so far prevail upon the prejudices of the people as to induce those who are in authority to keep out his formidable competitors, because, of course, we know quite well—it is no secret—that it is not merely prejudice of colour; it is not a prejudice of racial inferiority, because that would be absurd when there are, as we know, Indians in the Transvaal, pursuing professions and so forth, who are not only not inferior but greatly superior in many of the elements that make a civilized being to many of those who are not excluded from the Transvaal.
('6', 150, 3, 7, 265614) (‘Hear!
('6', 150, 3, 8, 265622) Hear!’)...
('6', 150, 4, 9, 265633) ...If a foreign power were to impose these disabilities upon fellow subjects of ours, I think the Foreign Office would be set in motion to represent such a proceeding as an unfriendly act.
('6', 150, 4, 10, 265822) (‘Hear!
('6', 150, 4, 11, 265830) Hear!’) It is a disagreeable truth, but we ought to face these things: that there is no doubt we can more effectively remonstrate with foreign powers than we can in some circumstances with our own kinsfolk.
('6', 150, 4, 12, 266037) (‘Shame!’) But this is carrying me into a very wide field indeed.
('6', 150, 4, 13, 266103) Lord Stanley, I think, rather tempted me into these speculations.
('6', 150, 4, 14, 266169) If there is any feeling in India, that, after all, is the only thing that I can do any good by endeavouring to convey.
('6', 150, 4, 15, 266288) Whatever can be done by way of energetic expression of opinion, of energetic protest, when the time comes, against these harsh and humiliating indignities, you may feel perfectly sure, and they may feel perfectly sure, that this Office will not be at all slack in backing the Colonial Office in any representations that they may wish to make, or possibly even in going a little in front.
('6', 150, 4, 16, 266676) (‘Hear!
('6', 150, 4, 17, 266684) Hear!’) Nobody occupying my position could do anything less than promise you, which I do with the greatest sincerity, not only the sympathy of which somebody has spoken today, but as much support as I find myself able to give, now that I am in possession of the general views which you, gentlemen, have so ably laid before me.
('6', 150, 4, 18, 267011) (Applause.)
('6', 150, 5, 19, 267023) SIR LEPEL GRIFFIN: .
('6', 150, 5, 20, 267044) Mr. Morley, I beg on behalf of the deputation to express our best thanks for the very kind and sympathetic manner in which you have 1istened to us for so long, and for the answer which you have given to us.
('6', 150, 5, 21, 267251) The deputation then withdrew.

('6', 151, 1, 2, 267373) 142. LETTER TO “SOUTH AFRICA”
('6', 151, 2, 3, 267403) [HOTEL CECIL, LONDON,] November 22, 1906 THE EDITOR SOUTH AFRICA [LONDON]
('6', 151, 3, 4, 267477) SIR, You have laid the British Indian Deputation under deep obligation by your opening your columns for a discussion of the British Indian position in the Transvaal and, in the words of Lord Milner, it is such discussion alone which would bring us nearer to a proper solution.
('6', 151, 3, 5, 267754) In your leaderette, however, you have done less than justice to the British Indian community by imputing to it a desire forthe franchise and for an Asiatic invasion of the Transvaal.
('6', 151, 3, 6, 267937) May I state that the community has never desired any political power in the Transvaal or an invasion of it by British Indians, and it is for that reason that it has accepted legislation along the Cape or the Natal model, which restricts the immigration of British Indians (except those who enjoy a status) without insulting them.
('6', 151, 3, 7, 268267) The community has also accepted the principle of the control of all new trade licences, subject to appeal to the Supreme Court, by local boards or municipalities.
('6', 151, 3, 8, 268430) The objection to the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance is taken not because the Ordinance is restrictive of immigration, but because it is restrictive of the ordinary civil liberty of the British Indians who are today domiciled in the Transvaal.
('6', 151, 3, 9, 268674) It is not the present Ordinance which would restrict Indian immigration; as you are aware, the Peace Preservation Ordinance has been misapplied for effecting that purpose.
('6', 151, 3, 10, 268846) You say that Indians cannot be treated better than natives of South Africa.
('6', 151, 3, 11, 268922) Without entering into a discussion of the proposition, may I inform you that they are being treated worse than the Natives, in that, whereas Natives can become owners of landed property in any part of the Transvaal, Indians cannot own it at all.
('6', 151, 5, 12, 269168) Yours etc., M. K. GANDHI South Africa, 24 11 1906

('6', 154, 6, 6, 271885) 147. DEPUTATION NOTES III
('6', 154, 7, 7, 271911) HOTEL CECIL, LONDON, November 23, 1906
('6', 154, 8, 8, 271950) This is our last week here.
('6', 154, 8, 9, 271978) We had hoped to leave on November 24. But we have been obliged to stay on in order to complete the work regarding the Committee and do whatever is necessary after the interview with Mr. Morley.
('6', 154, 8, 10, 272172) Now we have fixed the date of our departure for December 1.
('6', 154, 9, 11, 272232) MORE PROMISES OF HELP
('6', 154, 10, 12, 272254) During the current week, we met Lord Milner, Mr. Lyttelton, Lord Reay, Sir Raymond West and others.
('6', 154, 10, 13, 272354) Everyone has shown much sympathy and offered to work for us.
('6', 154, 10, 14, 272415) It is not possible to say what the outcome of all this will be.
('6', 154, 11, 15, 272479) INTERVIEW WITH SECRETARY OF STATE FOR INDIA
('6', 154, 12, 16, 272523) The deputation met Mr. Morley, the Secretary of State for India, on Thursday at 12.20 p.m.
('6', 154, 12, 17, 272614) Those present were Sir Lepel Griffin, Lord Stanley of Alderley, Sir Charles Dilke, Sir Charles Schwann, Sir William Wedderburn, Sir Henry Cotton, Sir Muncherji Bhownaggree, Dr. Rutherford, Mr. Harold Cox, Mr. A. H. Scott, Mr. Lynch, Mr. F. H. Brown, Mr. J. D. Rees, Mr. Thornton, Mr. Arathoon, Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji, Mr. T. J. Bennett, Mr. Theodore Morison and Mr. Ritch.

('6', 154, 12, 19, 273034) Sir Lepel Griffin, Lord Stanley, Mr. Cox and Sir Muncherji spoke at length.
('6', 154, 12, 20, 273110) Lord Stanley
('6', 155, 0, 1, 273123) 156 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 155, 1, 2, 273165) went so far as to demand sweet deeds in place of sweet words.
('6', 155, 1, 3, 273227) Messrs Ally and Gandhi 1 said whatever was required on the occasion.
('6', 155, 2, 4, 273296) MORLEY’S SPEECH
('6', 155, 3, 5, 273312) Mr. Morley gave a long reply in which he said:
('6', 155, 4, 6, 273359) I am glad to have met the deputation.
('6', 155, 4, 7, 273397) For I desire to be familiarized fully with the condition of the country for whose administration I am responsible to Parliament.
('6', 155, 4, 8, 273526) Moreover, the problem placed before me today has a very close bearing on the good government of India.
('6', 155, 4, 9, 273629) That the feelings of the people of India are excited on account of the disabilities imposed upon Indians in South Africa is a serious matter.
('6', 155, 4, 10, 273771) Indians returning to their native land from South Africa carry with them the story of the indignities to which they are subjected, and the result is that people are greatly agitated.
('6', 155, 4, 11, 273954) People in India must be thinking that the Government lack either the will or the power to prevent oppression in South Africa.
('6', 155, 4, 12, 274080) In either case, it is harmful.
('6', 155, 4, 13, 274111) I believe the resistance offered by Mr. Chamberlain in 1901, in the interests of Indians, deserves praise.
('6', 155, 4, 14, 274218) The first thing that has been brought to the notice of the new Government is that a bar sinister has been placed upon Indians in some Colonies.
('6', 155, 4, 15, 274362) Men in authority do not like to be told about moral principles.
('6', 155, 4, 16, 274426) But I am glad that Lord Stanley has spoken of moral principles.
('6', 155, 4, 17, 274490) The views expressed by Lord Stanley may be held by some to be old fashioned, but I for one share them entirely.
('6', 155, 4, 18, 274602) Unfortunately, we have not a white sheet of paper to write upon.
('6', 155, 4, 19, 274667) We must face the facts as they are and then act, as far as possible, in accordance with moral principle.
('6', 155, 4, 20, 274772) Now, let us see what the India Office can do.
('6', 155, 4, 21, 274818) It has been recognized by Sir Lepel Griffin that the minister primarily concerned is Lord Elgin.
('6', 155, 4, 22, 274915) Sir Muncherji asks me to demand that a commission be appointed.
('6', 155, 4, 23, 274979) But a serious difficulty in the way is that in May next the Transvaal will be under responsible government.
('6', 155, 4, 24, 275087) Now it would be a serious matter if a conflict arises between the [policies of the] new government and
('6', 155, 5, 25, 275190) 1 In his Gujarati despatches Gandhiji often refers to himself both in the first person and by name.
('6', 156, 0, 1, 275290) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 157
('6', 156, 1, 2, 275334) the commission’s recommendations.
('6', 156, 1, 3, 275368) I do not believe that such a commission will solve the question.
('6', 156, 1, 4, 275433) I have been in Parliament for many years but I do not remember any commission which has solved any question.
('6', 156, 1, 5, 275542) And the question regarding the Transvaal is not likely to be solved by the appointment of a commission.
('6', 156, 1, 6, 275646) It will quite probably mean a collision with the newly organized government at the very outset of its career.
('6', 156, 1, 7, 275756) The plain fact is that we cannot dictate to the self governing colonies.
('6', 156, 1, 8, 275829) We can plead, we can argue, we can press for the application of our principles.
('6', 156, 1, 9, 275909) Whether at the Colonial Conference [next year] or in his despatches, Lord Elgin will, doubtless, advance strong arguments and make recommendations.
('6', 156, 1, 10, 276057) Viceroy after Viceroy has written on the matter.
('6', 156, 1, 11, 276106) Lord Curzon had written very strongly.
('6', 156, 1, 12, 276145) He had made many recommendations about Natal but Natal paid no heed to his words.
('6', 156, 1, 13, 276227) It remains to be seen whether the Transvaal will listen to the requests of Lord Elgin.
('6', 156, 1, 14, 276314) I am glad to know that there are many whites in the Transvaal who are not against Indians.
('6', 156, 1, 15, 276405) I can well understand the small white shopkeepers opposing them.
('6', 156, 1, 16, 276470) I can even understand Indians [already in the country] opposing [further immigration of Indians].
('6', 156, 1, 17, 276568) 1 But what I cannot understand is the prejudice felt by the whites against mere dark skin.
('6', 156, 1, 18, 276659) I know that there are in the Transvaal many [Indians] who are superior to the whites.
('6', 156, 1, 19, 276745) How can these then be tyrannized over?
('6', 156, 1, 20, 276784) Just as Lord Lansdowne’s feelings were hurt by the treatment meted out to Indians, my blood too boils at their sufferings.
('6', 156, 1, 21, 276907) But it must be remembered that we cannot remonstrate as effectively with the Colonies as we can with foreign powers.
('6', 156, 1, 22, 277024) But I have been tempted into a digression by the remarks of Lord Stanley.
('6', 156, 1, 23, 277098) All I can now say is that it is my duty to do all I can.
('6', 156, 1, 24, 277155) The India Office will not fail to make strong representations as frequently as may be necessary.
('6', 156, 1, 25, 277252) I can definitely assure you that I shall not be slack in supporting the Colonial Office and, possibly, going ahead of it.
('6', 156, 2, 26, 277374) 1 This statement is not found in the official minutes of Morley's speech; Vide “Deputation to Morley”, 22 11 1906
('6', 157, 0, 1, 277488) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 157, 1, 2, 277530) MORE INTERVIEWS AND SYMPATHY
('6', 157, 2, 3, 277559) Though Mr. Morley has made such a strong speech, I do not yet expect that the Ordinance will be refused assent.
('6', 157, 2, 4, 277671) Strong despatches seem to have been received from the Transvaal.
('6', 157, 2, 5, 277736) I feel also that the rulers here think in their heart of hearts that we are an inferior race and there is no harm in piling up endless burdens on us.
('6', 157, 2, 6, 277886) Today we saw Mr. Lyttelton and also Sir Raymond West 1, an ex Chief Justice of the Bombay High Court.
('6', 157, 2, 7, 277988) They appeared to be of much the same view.
('6', 157, 2, 8, 278031) They felt much sympathy, but they also indicated that we would get no redress until we acquired strength like the whites.
('6', 157, 2, 9, 278153) They are afraid of the colonies, not because they are white, but because they are powerful.
('6', 157, 2, 10, 278245) If this is a true reading of the situation, we should realize that our salvation lies in our own hands.
('6', 157, 3, 11, 278349) OUR DELIVERANCE
('6', 157, 4, 12, 278365) While we are on this subject, the case of Miss Milne deserves to be noted.
('6', 157, 4, 13, 278440) Miss Milne, a suffragette, began making a speech in front of the Houses of Parliament.
('6', 157, 4, 14, 278527) The police attempted to stop her, but she persisted.
('6', 157, 4, 15, 278580) She was then arrested and prosecuted.
('6', 157, 4, 16, 278618) The Magistrate sentenced her to pay a fine of 10s or imprisonment for seven days.
('6', 157, 4, 17, 278700) The brave lady preferred to go to gaol.
('6', 157, 4, 18, 278740) This will be our last letter from England.
('6', 157, 4, 19, 278783) Hence I would appeal to all and say that, just as Miss Milne preferred going to gaol, so must every Transvaal Indian, taking it that the Ordinance will receive Royal assent.
('6', 157, 4, 20, 278957) There is no doubt that the Fourth Resolution contains the key to the Indians’ deliverance.
('6', 157, 4, 21, 279048) If the Resolution is acted upon, there should be no anxiety, whether or not the Ordinance receives the assent.

('6', 159, 2, 5, 280760) 150. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO LORD ELGIN 1
('6', 159, 3, 6, 280809) [HOTEL CECIL, LONDON,] November 24, 1906
('6', 159, 4, 7, 280850) TO THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO THE RIGHT HON’BLE THE EARL OF ELGIN HIS MAJESTY’S PRINCIPAL SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE COLONIES DOWNING STREET LONDON DEAR SIR, I have seen Mr. Churchill’s reply on the Vrededorp Stands ordinance in answer to Sir Henry Cotton’s question 2. In my
('6', 159, 5, 8, 281124) 1 This letter along with Sir Henry Cotton's question and Churchill's answer (footnote 2 below) was reproduced in Indian Opinion, 22 12 1906. 2 On November 22, 1906, Sir Henry Cotton had asked the Under Secretary of State for the Colonies in the House of Commons whether his attention had been drawn to Clauses 5, 8 and 9 of the Second Schedule of the Vrededorp Stands Ordinance Of 1906, under which the residence of British Indians, other than domestic servants, was prohibited within that area affected by the Ordinance; and whether, looking to the fact that the Ordinance did not come into effect until it had been assented to by the Crown, and that, for several years past, both under the Boer Government and at present, British Indians had been allowed to occupy land within this area under grants given by the bur ghers of Vre dedor p, and were still residing in this area, and had erected substantial structures thereon, the Secretary of State would advise His Majesty to disallow the Ordinance.
('6', 159, 5, 9, 282126) MR. CHURCHILL: My attention has been drawn to the provision referred to.
('6', 159, 5, 10, 282199) This land was originally granted to poor burghers—that is, to white men onlt, and on condition of personal occupation.
('6', 159, 5, 11, 282318) The Ordinance, therefore, merely perpetuates the legal conditions which were in existence before annexation, and in defiance of which certain Indians have, I understand, acquired some Stands and erected tin shanties.
('6', 159, 5, 12, 282535) I may add that it is very desirable to keep the white and Coloured quarters apart, as the practice of allowing European, Asiatic, and Native families to live side by side in mixed community is fraught with many evils, and is, in Lord Selborne’s opinion, injurious to the social well being of all three.
('6', 159, 5, 13, 282838) The whole question is, however, still under consideration.
('6', 160, 0, 1, 282897) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 161
('6', 160, 1, 2, 282941) humble opinion the answer is based on a misapprehension of the real state of affairs.
('6', 160, 2, 3, 283027) The act of granting Vrededorp to the poor Dutch burghers for personal occupation was accompanied by occupation of Vrededorp by persons other than the grantees irrespective of race or colour.
('6', 160, 2, 4, 283218) As for instance, many non Dutch white people occupied Stands in Vrededorp from the original grantees with the knowledge of the Boer Government.
('6', 160, 3, 5, 283362) The Ordinance does not perpetuate the legal conditions which were in existence before annexation, because the legal condition before annexation was that the grantees had only squatters’ rights.
('6', 160, 3, 6, 283556) The Ordinance now gives to them a permanent tenure with power to them to transfer their leases to whomsoever they choose save and except Asiatics so that the legal condition of personal occupation is now being changed into that of transferable leases.
('6', 160, 4, 7, 283808) I venture to protest against the statement that Indians acquired rights in Vrededorp in defiance of legal conditions.
('6', 160, 4, 8, 283926) They acquired rights in Vrededorp in the same manner that those who were not poor burghers did.
('6', 160, 4, 9, 284022) Nor is it true that Indians have erected shanties in Vrededorp.
('6', 160, 4, 10, 284086) In my humble opinion, class considered, what are descri bed as shanties are superior to many of the buildings in Vrededorp.
('6', 160, 5, 11, 284210) If the doctrine of the desirability of keeping the white and the Coloured quarters apart is sound, I fear that there will be an end to British Indian residence in the Transvaal with any degree of self respect.
('6', 160, 5, 12, 284420) The logical conclusion of such a doctrine will be a system of Locations which can only result in ruination to hundreds of law abiding and respectable Indians.
('6', 160, 6, 13, 284579) One is appalled by the inaccurate information that is placed before His Lordship in connection with matters Indian and it is extremely painful that legislation that is otherwise without the slightest justification is justifiedon statements that are inaccurate or misleading.
('6', 160, 7, 14, 284854) In venturing to offer the above remarks, no reflection is cast on Lord Selborne but it is respectfully submitted that Lord Selborne himself receives misleading information, as is painfully apparent to those who are on the spot and know the inner working of
('6', 161, 0, 1, 285111) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 161, 1, 2, 285153) the administration.

('6', 163, 7, 10, 288916) THE CONSTITUTION
('6', 163, 8, 11, 288933) NAME The Committee shall be called SOUTH AFRICA BRITISH INDIAN COMMITTEE.
('6', 163, 8, 12, 289007) OBJECT The Committee is established for the purpose of (a) concentrating and giving continuity to the efforts to secure fair and just treatment to British Indian settlers in South Africa of those friends who have heretofore exerted themselves to that end in Parliament and in other ways;
('6', 163, 9, 13, 289295) 1 Copies of the draft constitution were later sent to the others mentioned in the list.
('6', 164, 0, 1, 289383) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 165
('6', 164, 1, 2, 289427) (b) and of helping the Imperial Government to arrive at a proper solution of this difficult problem.
('6', 164, 1, 3, 289528) RULES 1. There shall be no subscription for membership of the Committee and members shall not be personally liable for any expenses incurred in the name of the Committee.
('6', 164, 1, 4, 289699) 2. The Committee shall consist of a President, Vice Presidents and members.
('6', 164, 1, 5, 289775) 3. There shall be a sub Committee of not more than six members besides Chairman and Secretary, who shall be ex officio members of such Committee.
('6', 164, 1, 6, 289921) 4. The sub Committee shall meet every week on...at...
('6', 164, 1, 7, 289975) 5. ....members shall form a quorum.
('6', 164, 1, 8, 290011) 6. As to any matters touching which no provision is made in the foregoing rules, the ordinary rules of meetings shall apply.
('6', 164, 1, 9, 290136) 7. The above rules are subject to change at the discretion of the sub Committee.
