('6', 169, 5, 14, 298088) 160. SPEECH AT EAST INDIA ASSOCIATION
('6', 169, 6, 15, 298126) At a meeting 1 of the East India Association at Caxton Hall, London, L. W. Ritch read a paper entitled “The Burden of the British Indians in South Africa”.
('6', 169, 6, 16, 298282) Gandhiji opened the discussion that
('6', 169, 7, 17, 298318) 1 For a report, vide “Ritch's Speech at East India Association”, before 18 12 1906.
('6', 170, 0, 1, 298402) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 171
('6', 170, 1, 2, 298446) followed.
('6', 170, 1, 3, 298456) November 26, 1906
('6', 170, 2, 4, 298474) Mr. Gandhi said that after what had been said by the lecturer it was unnecessary to say anything further with reference to the object of the mission with which he had been entrusted, but it would be ungrateful on his part if he did not take the opportunity of expressing his deep gratitude to the East India Association and its secretary, Mr. G. W. Arathoon, for the advocacy which the Indian cause in South Africa had received.
('6', 170, 2, 5, 298903) There was one thing which all should bear in mind, namely, that whatever difficulties they were undergoing in South Africa were being undergone in the name of the English people [sic], more particularly in the Transvaal.
('6', 170, 2, 6, 299124) The Ordinance which had brought them to England had been introduced in the name of the King.
('6', 170, 3, 7, 299217) For the first time in Colonial history, a precedent had been set by a Crown Colony of legislation which branded a class of people simply because they wore a coloured skin.
('6', 170, 3, 8, 299389) Was India to be retained, or was India to be lost simply because Colonial sentiment had to be consulted?
('6', 170, 3, 9, 299494) What was the proportion of the white population to the Indian?
('6', 170, 4, 10, 299557) Mr. Ritch had said, the Asiatics in the Transvaal were but a drop in the Ocean —13,000 as against 285,000 white men.
('6', 170, 4, 11, 299674) They were simply struggling for peace, for contentment and self respect in that Colony.
('6', 170, 4, 12, 299762) Nearly all of them entered the Colony before the war.
('6', 170, 4, 13, 299816) Today they were merely asking for the civil rights which ought to be granted to everybody who was a subject under the British Crown, and yet under the Ordinance they were to be treated differently to other British subjects.
('6', 170, 4, 14, 300040) Was that kind of legislation to be sanctioned in the name of the British nation?
('6', 170, 4, 15, 300121) (Applause.)...
('6', 170, 5, 16, 300136) The Journal of the East India Association, January 1907

('6', 172, 1, 2, 301753) 163. LETTER TO LORD HARRIS 1
('6', 172, 2, 3, 301782) [HOTEL CECIL, LONDON,] November 27, 1906
('6', 172, 3, 4, 301823) MY LORD, Mr. Ally and I have arrived, as perhaps Your Lordship is aware, as a Deputation on behalf of the British Indian community in the Transvaal.
('6', 172, 3, 5, 301972) We have waited on Lord Elgin and Mr. Morley who have given sympathetic answers with reference to our mission but we also feel that any representations that they may make in our behalf require to be considerably strengthened.
('6', 172, 3, 6, 302197) Moreover, the support that we have received from all parties has been exceptionally warm.
('6', 172, 3, 7, 302287) We are most anxious to make as much use as possible of it in our future struggle.
('6', 172, 3, 8, 302369) We have further been instructed by the British Indians in South Africa to form a committee, so that the work now being done may be continued.
('6', 172, 3, 9, 302511) We enclose herewith copy of the constitution.
('6', 172, 3, 10, 302557) We have approached the Right Hon’ble Lord Reay with a view to his acceptance of the Presidentship of the Committee and we believe that, if you could see your way to lend the weight of your influence to the Committee by accepting a Vice Presidentship, he will accept the Presidentship and Your Lordship will lay the Indian community in South Africa under deep obligation to you.

('6', 175, 6, 15, 307457) [HOTEL CECIL, LONDON,] November 27, 1906
('6', 175, 7, 16, 307498) TO THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO MR. WINSTON CHURCHILL
('6', 175, 8, 17, 307548) DEAR SIR, In accordance with the desire expressed by Mr. Winston Churchill, we beg to enclose herewith three statements 1,on single
('6', 175, 9, 18, 307680) 1 Only one of the three enclosures, viz., “Objections to the Vrededorp Stands Ordinance”, is available and reproduced here.
('6', 176, 0, 1, 307804) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 177
('6', 176, 1, 2, 307848) sheets of paper, showing the view of the British Indian community, first, on the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance, secondly, on the Vrededorp Stands Ordinance, and thirdly, on the general question.
('6', 176, 2, 3, 308045) We remain,
('6', 176, 3, 4, 308056) Dear Sir,
('6', 176, 4, 5, 308066) Yours faithfully, 3 enclosures
('6', 176, 5, 6, 308097) From the typewritten office copy: S. N. 4653
('6', 176, 6, 7, 308142) [ENCLOSURE]
('6', 176, 7, 8, 308154) OBJECTIONS TO THE VREDEDORP STANDS ORDINANCE 1. The Ordinance if sanctioned will be a precedent for the inclusion of class disqualifying clauses in leases in other townships in Johannesburg or the Transvaal and would therefore go beyond the Law 3 of 1885 in restricting British Indian rights.
('6', 176, 7, 9, 308447) 2. British Indians with the knowledge of the Boer Government occupied and built upon Stands in Vrededorp just as many other Europeans did who were not the original burghers who received, from the late President Kruger, squatters’ rights on the Stands.
('6', 176, 7, 10, 308699) 3. Vrededorp is contiguous to the Malay Location, which is inhabited by a very large number of British Indians.
('6', 176, 7, 11, 308811) 4. The Ordinance does not perpetuate the legal condition that was in existence before the war but it gives permanent rights to the original burghers with the power to sublet.
('6', 176, 7, 12, 308986) Under this power, Europeans who were not burghers would be able to retain the rights granted to them by the burghers whereas British Indians will be dispossessed without the slightest justification.
('6', 176, 7, 13, 309185) 5. Premises built by British Indians are not shanties but substantial structures as good as most other buildings.
('6', 176, 7, 14, 309299) 6. If the Ordinance is sanctioned, it will be the first instance of a recognition by an Imperial Government of the right of a municipality to curtail the residential rights of British Indians in any part of the Transvaal which, under a Supreme Court judgment, British Indians are entitled to.
('6', 176, 7, 15, 309592) It will indirectly create a system of Locations which otherwise the Imperial Government, it is presumed, would never sanction.
('6', 176, 8, 16, 309719) From a photostat of the typewritten office copy: S.N. 4636

('6', 180, 1, 2, 312734) 175. SPEECH AT LONDON FAREWELL 1
('6', 180, 2, 3, 312767) The following is a report of Gandhiji’s speech at the farewell breakfast given at Hotel Cecil by the Delegates from the Transvaal to friends and sympathizers:
('6', 180, 3, 4, 312926) [HOTEL CECIL, LONDON, November 29, 1906]
('6', 180, 4, 5, 312967) Sir Muncherji, My Lord and Gentlemen, before I begin to express our thanks for your attendance here and to those gentlemen who have not been able to attend this morning, I shall take the opportunity of reading some of the letters 2 which have been received in connection with the invitations.
('6', 180, 4, 6, 313260) The task before my colleagues and myself today is an exceedingly pleasant one to thank you all who have honoured us by your presence, and also to thank those gentlemen who could not be with us this morning.
('6', 180, 4, 7, 313467) Mr. Ally and I, when we came to the end of our mission, thought that the least we could do, as representing the 13,000 British Indians in the Transvaal, was to adopt this tangible method of showing our gratitude.
('6', 180, 4, 8, 313680) The support we have received throughout our stay in England has been very encouraging.
('6', 180, 4, 9, 313767) We have received it from all parties ever since the beginning of our campaign against the deprivation of our civil rights as citizens in this mighty Empire.
('6', 180, 4, 10, 313924) We have appealed to all parties, and all parties have invariably extended their help to us.
('6', 180, 4, 11, 314016) For this we cannot be too grateful, and I think it but right especially to mention the name of the late Sir William Wilson Hunter.
('6', 180, 4, 12, 314147) As far back as 1893, Sir W. W. Hunter received one of the circulars sent out to him from South Africa, and he it was, I think, who first understood the national importance of this question, and ever since that time down to the date of his death, he was always busy
('6', 180, 5, 13, 314412) 1 This function was specially reported for Indian Opinion.
('6', 180, 5, 14, 314471) Among those present were Lord Reay, Sir William Bull, M.P., A. H. Scott, M.P., Sir George Birdwood, Sir Frederick Fryer, Sir Raymond West, Sir M. M. Bhownaggree, Ameer Ali, Theodore Morison, Dr. Josiah Oldfield, Dr. E. P. S. Counsel, C. W. Arathoon, J. H. L. Polak, L. W. Ritch, G. V. Godfrey, J. W. Godfrey, A. Cartwright, F. H. Brown, H. E. A. Cotton, A. H. Gool, T. Ruthnum Pather, S. M. Manga and J. M. Robertson.
('6', 180, 5, 15, 314889) 2 Gandhiji read out letters of good wishes from Sir William Markby, Sir Roper Lethbridge and Sir Charles Schwann.
('6', 180, 5, 16, 315003) He also mentioned similar latters from Sir Henry Cotton, Sir William Wedderburn, T. J. Bennett, Harold Cox and others.
('6', 181, 0, 1, 315122) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 181, 1, 2, 315164) doing something or other to assist the cause of British Indians in South Africa.
('6', 181, 1, 3, 315245) In the columns of The Times and otherwise, he always advocated our cause, and I had a letter from Lady Hunter saying that, even at the time of his death, he had a long contribution in preparation in connection with this matter.
('6', 181, 1, 4, 315473) In 1896, when I was in Calcutta, the late Mr. Saunders also came to the assistance of our cause, as also did The Times of India, which paper has always advocated the cause of the British Indians in South Africa.
('6', 181, 1, 5, 315685) Coming nearer, the East India Association has helped us, and the British Committee of the Indian National Congress has given us valuable assistance.
('6', 181, 1, 6, 315834) It is a matter of regret to both Mr. Ally and myself that we have had to issue this invitation just at the time the “Grand Old Man” of India, Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji, is leaving this country for the forthcoming session of the Congress.
('6', 181, 1, 7, 316067) To him also we owe a debt of gratitude.
('6', 181, 1, 8, 316107) As I have said, we have appealed to all parties in the House of Commons, and all have helped us.
('6', 181, 1, 9, 316204) I must not fail to mention especially the name of Mr. Scott, who has helped us most sympatheti cally and most energetically in connection with our grievances, and now I come to the name of Sir Mancherji Bhownaggree.
('6', 181, 1, 10, 316420) For the last 12 years, he has persistently and with unflagging zeal been advocating the cause of British Indians in South Africa.
('6', 181, 1, 11, 316550) All have helped, but Sir Mancherji has made this cause his own.
('6', 181, 1, 12, 316614) Sir Mancherji has worked as if he were actuated by the same strong convictions and feelings as we ourselves.
('6', 181, 1, 13, 316723) He has felt as no other man has the national importance of the issues involved.
('6', 181, 1, 14, 316803) In the House of Commons, outside the House, in his correspondence, he has always helped and counselled us as to how we were to go to work, and words cannot express our gratitude to him for all he has done for us in South Africa.
('6', 181, 1, 15, 317032) The difficulties in our path have, perhaps, whether this Ordinance be passed or not, only just commenced.
('6', 181, 1, 16, 317138) We, therefore, hope that the support, which all our friends here have hitherto afforded us, will be maintained, because, even if the Ordinance is disallowed—as there is some hope it will be— there is still a great deal to be done in regard to the general question.
('6', 181, 1, 17, 317403) There is again the Vrededorp Ordinance.
('6', 181, 1, 18, 317443) There is, too, the Natal Municipal Corporations Bill.
('6', 181, 1, 19, 317497) Whatever is done in the Transvaal is likely to be done by the other Colonies.
('6', 181, 1, 20, 317575) Ours has been a policy of the strictest moderation.
('6', 181, 1, 21, 317627) We have always claimed that we have been able to enter into the feelings of our opponents (if one may use that term) in South Africa, and although we have examined the whole question from their standpoint and have always endeavoured to convince those
('6', 182, 0, 1, 317878) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 183
('6', 182, 1, 2, 317922) who are prejudiced against us of our desire to be moderate, we have still to ask you to extend your support to us in our struggle, and it is for this reason that we have been authorized by the British Indians in South Africa to organize and inaugurate such a committee as will always watch over our interests.
('6', 182, 1, 3, 318232) The work that has been so well and ably performed here by our supporters will have been frittered away if it be not now concentrated and continued by means of such an organization as thisCommittee.
('6', 182, 1, 4, 318430) As most of you gentlemen have received copies of the circular 1 , I will only recapitulate the objects of the Committee.
('6', 182, 1, 5, 318551) You will notice that it is merely a provisional draft.
('6', 182, 1, 6, 318606) These are the ideas as they strike us, and we hope that you will consider them, and help us by your counsels.
('6', 182, 1, 7, 318716) All whose names are printed on the draft have kindly consented to become members of the Committee, and it now only remains for me to ask you kindly to consider the draft constitution, and to formally inaugurate it, if you think that the step we have ventured to take is acceptable to you.
('6', 182, 1, 8, 319005) I cannot better illustrate the gravity of the position in which we are placed in the Transvaal than by pointing to the young British Indians who are here today.
('6', 182, 1, 9, 319166) They are more your hosts than guests.
('6', 182, 1, 10, 319204) They are Indian students who belong to South Africa, that is to say, South Africa is more their home than India itself.
('6', 182, 1, 11, 319324) They are studying here, but I have no doubt they are looking forward to their return to South Africa with considerable anxiety and apprehension, because they will have to share the same fate as the thirteen thousand British Indians in the Transvaal, and in fact all the British Indians in South Africa.
('6', 182, 1, 12, 319627) Here, in England, they will become barristers or doctors, but there, in South Africa, they may not even be able to cross the border of the Transvaal.
('6', 182, 1, 13, 319777) Indian Opinion, 29 12 1906

('6', 186, 1, 2, 323702) 182. LETTER TO J. H. POLAK
('6', 186, 2, 3, 323729) [HOTEL CECIL, LONDON,] November 29, 1906
('6', 186, 3, 4, 323770) DEAR MR. POLAK, After all, I think that Ruthnum should, at least for the present, go to the Van Weenen’s.
('6', 186, 3, 5, 323876) The Bedford County School won’t havehim by reason of his being overage.
('6', 186, 3, 6, 323948) I have had no time to look up any other institution.
('6', 186, 3, 7, 324001) He must leave India House at the earliest opportunity.
('6', 186, 3, 8, 324056) If therefore the Van Weenen’s are prepared still to accept him, will you kindly arrange so that Ruthnum can leave for Westcliffe on Monday?
('6', 186, 3, 9, 324196) I would like Miss Weenen to give him all the education she is capable of giving him.
('6', 186, 3, 10, 324281) Perhaps she can also secure a private tutor or admission for him to a school or class in Westcliffe.
('6', 186, 3, 11, 324382) Under the above proposal, Ruthnum Pather need not take out a railway season ticket as he would be going to town only six days every term.
('6', 186, 3, 12, 324520) I would like Miss Weenen to treat him as a member of the family, to be perfectly frank and open with him and never to hesitate to point out to Ruthnum his defects either in speech, in manner or in mode of living.
('6', 186, 3, 13, 324733) He should in short be treated as a very young lad and receive loving supervision.
('6', 186, 3, 14, 324815) He has in him the making[s] of a very good man if at the impressionable time of his life he receives proper handling.
('6', 186, 3, 15, 324933) You may, if you like, pass on this letter to Miss Van Weenen.
('6', 186, 3, 16, 324995) I am, yours sincerely,

('6', 187, 12, 12, 325710) November 30, 1906
('6', 187, 14, 13, 325728) TO THE EDITOR THE TIMES [LONDON]
('6', 187, 16, 14, 325761) On the eve of the departure of the Indian Deputation from the
('6', 187, 17, 15, 325823) Transvaal, may we trespass upon your courtesy to allow us to offer our thanks to the many supporters of the British Indian cause who have rendered us their valuable assistance in putting our case before the Imperial Government and the British public.
('6', 187, 17, 16, 326074) The unfailing cour tesy we have experienced from gentlemen representing different shades of opinion, from all parties, and from the Press has been a source of keenest satisfaction to us and has inspired us with a new hope.
('6', 187, 17, 17, 326297) Our brief stay in London has prevented us from personally waiting on all whom we should have liked to meet.
('6', 187, 17, 18, 326405) We have, however, received support and sympathy even from them.
('6', 187, 17, 19, 326469) The lesson we have drawn from the above is that we may rely upon the British sense of fair play and justice and that the cause we have the honour to espouse is absolutely just.
('6', 187, 17, 20, 326646) May we restate it in a few words We ask for no political power in the Transvaal.
('6', 187, 17, 21, 326727) We do not strive for unrestricted immigration of British Indians, but we do respectfully and emphatically claim the ordinary rights of citizenship forthose who are
('6', 187, 18, 22, 326891) 1 This was sent to other papers also and published in South Africa, 1 12 1906;
('6', 187, 19, 23, 326970) was later reproduced in India, 7 12 1906, and in Indian Opinion, 29 12 1906. with a few verbal variations.
('6', 187, 20, 24, 327077) 2 The letter published in South Africa is dated November 29.
('6', 188, 0, 1, 327138) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 189
('6', 188, 1, 2, 327182) already in the country namely, free dom of ownership of land, freedom of locomotion, freedom of trade, subject to such requirements as may be necessary in the interests of the community as a whole.
('6', 188, 1, 3, 327380) In short, the British Indians in the Transvaal claim the right to live in the Transvaal with self respect and dignity.
('6', 188, 1, 4, 327499) The Indian community protests against any class distinction being made, and it has exerted itself against the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance, because it violates in the most brutal manner the principles above laid down.
('6', 188, 1, 5, 327720) In our humble opinion we feel that if we cannot secure for our countrymen, whom we have the honour to represent, the above measure of recognition, the term “British Indian” becomes an empty platitude and“Empire” ceases to have any meaning for the British Indian.
('6', 188, 1, 6, 327983) In coming to England and laying our case before the Home Govern ment, we have no desire to offer violent opposition to the European Colonists in the Transvaal.
('6', 188, 1, 7, 328143) Ours is wholly a defensive attitude.
('6', 188, 1, 8, 328180) When the local Govern ment, in the name of the people of the Transvaal, sends to the Imperial Government for assent a piece of offensive legislation 1 to protect and accentuate colour prejudice, we are obliged, in self defence, to lay before the same Government the Indian side of the question.
('6', 188, 1, 9, 328475) We are anxious and willing to work out our own salvation by our conduct, and by showing to the Colonists that their interests are also our interests and that our goal is the common advancement of them and us.
('6', 188, 1, 10, 328684) We cannot do this if we do not get breathing time, by reason of the anti Indian prejudice of the few being crystallized into and receiving the hallmark of legislation under the King’s Sign Manual.

('6', 189, 1, 2, 329068) 185. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO LORD ELGIN
('6', 189, 2, 3, 329115) UNION CASTLE LINE, R. M. S. BRITON, SOUTHAMPTON DOCKS, December 1, 1906
('6', 189, 3, 4, 329187) TO THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO THE SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE COLONIES LONDON]
('6', 189, 4, 5, 329263) DEAR SIR, I have been so much over worked night and day that I have not been able before now to submit my promised statement 1 on Natal to His Lordship.
('6', 189, 4, 6, 329416) I allowed it to be crowded out as Mr. Tatham’s Bill was rejected by the Natal Parliament.
('6', 189, 4, 7, 329506) I have now forwarded to Mr. Ritch, the Secretary of the South Africa British Indian Committee, my statement and asked him to have it typed and then present the original with a typed copy to you for submission to Lord Elgin.
('6', 189, 4, 8, 329730) I duly received your letter with enclosures for which I thank you.
('6', 189, 5, 9, 329797) I remain,
('6', 189, 6, 10, 329807) Yours faithfully, M. K. GANDHI
('6', 189, 7, 11, 329838) From a photostat of the original: C. O. 179, Vol. 239/Ind.
('6', 189, 8, 12, 329897) 1 Vide enclosure.
('6', 190, 0, 1, 329915) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 191
('6', 190, 1, 2, 329958) [ENCLOSURE]
('6', 190, 2, 3, 329970) STATEMENT REGARDING BRITISH INDIAN POSITION IN NATAL1
('6', 190, 3, 4, 330024) 1. I shall venture to deal with only the most important and pressing portion of the question.
('6', 190, 4, 5, 330118) THE IMMIGRATION ACT 2. Under this Act an undoubted injustice is done to British Indian merchants in that they are not allowed to import confidential clerks or domestic servants.
('6', 190, 4, 6, 330296) 3. The result is that a monopoly is created among the few clerks and servants.
('6', 190, 4, 7, 330375) 4. Nor is it possible to command a large supply of confidential clerks from those who are already domiciled in the Colony.
('6', 190, 4, 8, 330498) 5. Confidential clerks as a rule and domestic servants invariably lack ability to satisfy the educational test under the Immigration Act.
('6', 190, 4, 9, 330636) 6. It is not contended that such men should be allowed to possess rights of domicile but it is respectfully submitted that they ought to be allowed to enter the Colony to reside therein temporarily subject to guarantee being given that, at the end of their service with their masters, they should quit the Colony.
('6', 190, 5, 10, 330950) DEALERS’ LICENSES ACT 7. This Act has caused and continues to cause the gravest mischief.
('6', 190, 5, 11, 331040) British Indian merchants are totally at the mercy of the licensing officers whose decisions are not capable of being reviewed by the Supreme Court.
('6', 190, 5, 12, 331188) 8. Under this Act most respectable Indian merchants of long standing have been deprived of their licences to trade i.e., of their vested rights.
('6', 190, 5, 13, 331333) This happened in the case of Messrs Dada Osman and Hoondamal.
('6', 190, 5, 14, 331395) 9. At one time an arbitrary use of their power by the licensing officers created a scandal.
('6', 190, 5, 15, 331487) Mr. Chamberlain sent a strong despatch and the then ministry in Natal addressed a circular letter 2 to the municipalities of Natal that, unless they exercised reasonably, moderately and with due regard for vested rights, the power given to them, the Act would have to be amended so as to restore the inherent jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.
('6', 190, 6, 16, 331831) 1 This was forwarded by L. W. Ritch to the Private Secretary to Lord Elgin on December 4. 2 Vide “Petition to Natal Governor”, 31 7 1899.
('6', 191, 0, 1, 331969) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 191, 1, 2, 332011) 10. It is submitted that the right of the Supreme Court to review the decisions of licensing officers should be restored at the earliest opportunity unless the Indian traders are to lose all they have in the Colony.
('6', 191, 1, 3, 332227) 11. The late Mr. Escombe in his latter days deplored the deprivation of the right of approaching the Supreme Court in appeal against decisions of licensing officers.
('6', 191, 2, 4, 332393) MUNICIPALITIES BILL 12. The attempt to deprive the Indian ratepayers of the right to exercise the municipal franchise is held to be totally unjustifiable and wantonly insulting.
('6', 191, 2, 5, 332571) 13. It is debatable whether India possesses representative institutions founded on the Parliamentary franchise.
('6', 191, 2, 6, 332683) But it is not open to question as to the municipal franchise.
('6', 191, 2, 7, 332745) 14. Both the late Sir John Robinson and the late Mr. Escombe said emphatically that the Indian community ought not to be deprived of the municipal franchise.
('6', 191, 3, 8, 332903) 15. The moral effect of sanctioning such legislation will be very serious and the Indians will be further degraded in the estimation of the Colonists.
('6', 191, 4, 9, 333054) CONCLUSION 16. It now only remains for me to add that regarding Natal the remedy is absolutely in the hands of the Imperial Government.
('6', 191, 4, 10, 333190) [The] prosperity of Natal is dependent on a continuance of indentured labour from India.
('6', 191, 4, 11, 333279) Natal cannot be allowed to draw upon India for a supply of indentured labour when she refuses to treat the resident Indian population with justice and decency.
('6', 191, 4, 12, 333439) M. K. GANDHI
('6', 191, 5, 13, 333452) From a photostat of the original: C. O. 179, Vol. 239/Misc.
('6', 191, 6, 14, 333512) 1 Vide “What is a Collie”, 21 5 1904.

('6', 192, 1, 2, 333593) 186. LETTER TO PROFESSOR GOKHALE
('6', 192, 2, 3, 333626) R. M. S. BRITON, December 3, 1906
('6', 192, 3, 4, 333660) DEAR PROF.
('6', 192, 3, 5, 333671) GOKHALE, I am on way back to Johannesburg.
('6', 192, 3, 6, 333714) I wrote to you from London.
('6', 192, 3, 7, 333742) 1 Sir Muncherji suggests that there should be in India a separate South Africa British Indian Committee in the same way as in London.
('6', 192, 3, 8, 333876) By this time you probably know all about the London Committee.
('6', 192, 3, 9, 333939) If a committee were formed in India, I have no doubt all parties would unite.
('6', 192, 3, 10, 334017) Mr. Bennett told me that Mr. Fraser of The Times [of India] would help willingly.
('6', 192, 3, 11, 334099) Many members of the Chamber of Commerce too may unite and the Aga Khan will certainly do so.
('6', 192, 3, 12, 334192) If some such organisation be formed, it will do most effective work.
('6', 192, 3, 13, 334261) The importance of the question was fully realized by everyone in London.
('6', 192, 3, 14, 334334) I am aware that Sir Pherozeshaw 2 does not see eye to eye with us in this matter but I venture to think that he is mistaken.
('6', 192, 3, 15, 334459) Anyhow if a committee were formed, even if it did not do much good, it could not do harm.
('6', 192, 3, 16, 334549) In order to have a committee you certainly need some local man with an accurate knowledge of the position in South Africa.
('6', 192, 3, 17, 334672) As to that I can make no suggestion.
('6', 192, 4, 18, 334709) I remain,
('6', 192, 5, 19, 334719) Yours truly, M. K. GANDHI [PS.] Please write to me Box 6522, Johannesburg.

('6', 192, 7, 21, 334858) 187. RITCH’S SPEECH AT EAST INDIA ASSOCIATION3
('6', 192, 8, 22, 334905) [Before December 18, 1906] A paper on “The Burden of British Indians in South Africa” was read by Mr. L. W. Ritch at the Caxton Hall on November 26
('6', 192, 9, 23, 335053) 1 This letter has not been traced.
('6', 192, 9, 24, 335088) 2 Sir Pherozeshah Mehta 3 This was drafted by Gandhiji on board the ship; vide following item, “Deputation Notes IV”, before 18 12 1906.
('6', 193, 0, 1, 335225) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 193, 1, 2, 335267) last, under the auspices of the East India Association.
('6', 193, 1, 3, 335323) Sir Mun cherjee Bhownaggree was in the chair.
('6', 193, 1, 4, 335369) Among those present were Lord Reay, Sir Raymond West, Sir Frederick Tyler, Sir George Birdwood Mr. Cotton, Mr. Bennett, Mr. Brown, Mr. Morison and Mr. Arathoon.
('6', 193, 1, 5, 335530) Professor Parmanand and Mr. Mukerjee were among the Indians present.
('6', 193, 1, 6, 335599) The speech described in detail the condition [of Indians] all over South Africa.
('6', 193, 1, 7, 335680) As most of the points made by Mr. Ritch are already known to the readers of this journal, I shall not summarize the speech here.
('6', 193, 1, 8, 335809) After Mr. Ritch had read his paper, the chairman called upon Messrs Gandhi and Ally to speak on the subject.
('6', 193, 1, 9, 335918) Mr. Gandhi acknowledged with gratitude the help rendered by the East India Association to the cause of British Indians in South Africa and warned the assembly that, if the new act were passed, the responsibility would lie squarely on every Englishman.
('6', 193, 1, 10, 336170) For, whatever laws were enacted in South Africa they were made in the name of the King Emperor.
('6', 193, 1, 11, 336266) If therefore the British people were at all inclined to do justice to the three hundred millions in India, they should ensure that the hardships of Indians in the Colonies were ended.
('6', 193, 1, 12, 336450) Mr. Ally spoke next and supported Mr. Gandhi’s argument.
('6', 193, 1, 13, 336507) He pointed out that alien peoples such as Armenians were free to enter the Transvaal, while the Indians were subjected to various kinds of disabili ties.
('6', 193, 1, 14, 336661) This should happen no more.
('6', 193, 1, 15, 336689) Sir Raymond West said that, listening to Mr. Ritch’s speech and the information given by the Delegates, he felt ashamed.
('6', 193, 1, 16, 336810) Was the duty of England over once self government had been granted to the Colony?
('6', 193, 1, 17, 336892) If that were so, the term “Imperial race” ceased to have meaning and should no more be used.
('6', 193, 1, 18, 336985) Self government for a Colony did not give it the right to trample upon the non whites.
('6', 193, 1, 19, 337072) The Indians had a good cause, and with patience they were bound to get their grievances redressed.
('6', 193, 1, 20, 337171) Mr. Thornton pleaded strongly for justice being done to Indians in the Transvaal.
('6', 193, 1, 21, 337253) He said that nothing could be more modest than the demands put forward by them, and they admitted of no dispute.
('6', 193, 1, 22, 337366) Mr. Nusserwanjee Cooper, Editor of The Parsee Chronicle, said that he had travelled in British Guiana and had found the Indians there quite happy.
('6', 193, 1, 23, 337513) They enjoyed all the rights and many of them had risen to high positions.
('6', 193, 1, 24, 337587) The Indians in South Africa should have the same rights and privileges.
('6', 193, 1, 25, 337659) That they had to suffer hardships was gross
('6', 194, 0, 1, 337703) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 195
('6', 194, 1, 2, 337746) injustice.
('6', 194, 1, 3, 337757) Mr. Wise, a planter from Ceylon, took exception to Mr. Ritch’s censure of indentured labour.
('6', 194, 1, 4, 337850) They went there of their own free will, and it was not for others to say anything about it.
('6', 194, 1, 5, 337942) Mr. Wise was followed by Mr. Martin Wood, Sir Leslie Probyn and others.
('6', 194, 1, 6, 338014) Replying to questions, Mr. Ritch said that, if one had to choose between doing the right thing by the Indians and losing the Colonies, it would be any day better to let the Colonies go.
('6', 194, 1, 7, 338200) But to deny justice to the Indians would be a matter of shame to the British people.
('6', 194, 1, 8, 338285) Winding up the discussion, Sir Muncherji said that he had been thinking of the problem for many years and that he could not stand the hardships imposed upon the Indians in South Africa.
('6', 194, 1, 9, 338471) Sir Raymond West had counselled patience, but he himself held there was no longer any room for patience.
('6', 194, 1, 10, 338576) Where was the scope for patience when Indians were actually being deprived of their rights?
('6', 194, 1, 11, 338668) Before the meeting dispersed, a resolution expressing sympathy with the British Indians in South Africa was moved by Miss Winterbottom, the Secretary of the Union of Ethical Societies, and was passed.
('6', 194, 1, 12, 338869) With a vote of thanks to Mr. Ritch, the proceedings came to a close.

('6', 194, 3, 16, 339189) The last week will abide in our memory for ever.
('6', 194, 3, 17, 339238) Every moment strengthened our confidence that the mission on which the Delegates went to England would succeed.
('6', 194, 4, 18, 339350) SECOND MEETING OF M. P’S.

('6', 194, 5, 20, 339447) They thought that, if the Royal assent were given to the Ordinance, England’s prestige would suffer.
('6', 194, 5, 21, 339548) They therefore decided to hold another meeting.

('6', 195, 1, 4, 339812) The meeting took place on Monday; and the Members resolved to wait upon the Prime Minister and speak to him about the Ordinance.
('6', 195, 1, 5, 339941) A committee was appointed and it met Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman.
('6', 195, 1, 6, 340008) The Prime Minister said that he did not approve of the Ordinance, and that he would speak to Lord Elgin on the matter.
('6', 195, 1, 7, 340127) This provided the first reason for entertaining the hope of which we have spoken.
('6', 195, 2, 8, 340209) INTERVIEW WITH CHURCHILL We met Mr. Winston Churchill at the time fixed by him.
('6', 195, 2, 9, 340289) He spoke nicely.
('6', 195, 2, 10, 340306) He asked both of us whether we were not afraid of res ponsible government in case the Ordinance were refused assent.
('6', 195, 2, 11, 340423) What if a worse act were to be passed by the new Government?
('6', 195, 2, 12, 340484) We replied that we could not imagine an act worse than the present Ordinance, 1
('6', 195, 3, 13, 340564) and that we had asked for refusal of assent leaving the future to take care of itself.
('6', 195, 3, 14, 340651) He then asked us to send him a brief note, covering, say, a foolscap sheet, of all that we had to say on this Ordinance, on the Vrededorp Stands Ordinance’ and on the question as a whole.
('6', 195, 3, 15, 340839) He would read and consider it.
('6', 195, 3, 16, 340870) Mr. Ally then reminded him that he was the same person who had been present at the Point to receive Mr. Churchill on his return from the war 2. And it was with the same Mr. Churchill that he now pleaded for redress on behalf of the Indian community.
('6', 195, 3, 17, 341120) Mr. Churchill smiled, patted Mr. Ally on the back and said that he would do all he could.
('6', 195, 3, 18, 341210) This answer added to our hopes.
('6', 195, 3, 19, 341242) The brief account asked for by Mr. Churchill has already been sent to him.
('6', 195, 4, 20, 341317) INTERVIEW TO “THE DAILY NEWS” The name of the Editor is Gardiner.
('6', 195, 4, 21, 341383) When we repeated the whole story for his benefit, he promised to write strongly on the subject, and a poignant article was published the following day.
('6', 195, 5, 22, 341535) PARTY TO WELL WISHERS The Delegates may be said to have done the last bit of their work on the 29th.

('6', 195, 5, 24, 341711) At the breakfast, the idea of the Committee was [formally] put forward.
('6', 195, 5, 25, 341783) A fairly large number of persons was present.
('6', 195, 5, 26, 341829) Lord Reay made a very good and powerful speech.
('6', 195, 5, 27, 341877) There were also other effective speeches.
('6', 195, 5, 28, 341919) But as I intend

('6', 196, 2, 3, 342185) DELEGATES’ FAREWELL LETTER
('6', 196, 3, 4, 342212) The Delegates have sent a letter 1 of thanks to the Press.
('6', 196, 3, 5, 342271) They have said that the Indian community did not want to fight against the Colony, but wished to solve its problems amicably.
('6', 196, 3, 6, 342397) When a blow was directed against the community, it had to use a shield to ward it off.
('6', 196, 3, 7, 342484) The community would, as far as possible, act with due deference to the views of the colonists.
('6', 196, 3, 8, 342579) But at the same time, it would demand that there should be no detraction from the normal rights to which every citizen was entitled.

('6', 199, 4, 11, 349163) 193. CABLE TO S.A.B.I. COMMITTEE
('6', 199, 5, 12, 349196) [JOHANNESBURG,] December 29, 1906
('6', 199, 6, 13, 349230) TO SOUTH AFRICA BRITISH INDIAN COMMITTEE 28, QUEEN ANNE’S CHAMBERS, S.W. [LONDON]
('6', 199, 7, 14, 349312) PLEASE MOVE GOVERNMENT REGARDING ORDINANCE.
('6', 199, 8, 15, 349356) DEPURITION1
('6', 199, 9, 16, 349368) Colonial Office Records: C. 0. 291, Vol. 291/Misc.
('6', 199, 10, 17, 349419) 194. A RETROSPECT
('6', 199, 11, 18, 349437) It has been our practice, during Christmas every year, to take stock of the position of Indians in South Africa.
('6', 199, 11, 19, 349550) On this occasion we are glad to be able to inform our readers of the success achieved by the Deputation in the matter of the Transvaal Ordinance, which is the most important event of the year.
('6', 199, 11, 20, 349743) As a result of Lord Elgin with holding assent to the Ordinance, it is not only the Transvaal Indians
('6', 199, 12, 21, 349844) 1 The Colonial Office Records show that this was the code word used by Gandhiji as Secretary of the Transvaal British Indian Association.
('6', 200, 0, 1, 349982) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 201
('6', 200, 1, 2, 350025) who have benefited, but the entire Indian community in South Africa.
('6', 200, 1, 3, 350094) The community has gone one step forward.
('6', 200, 1, 4, 350135) The main reason for withholding sanction was, we believe, saving the Indian community from a stigma which the Ordinance was certain to have put on it.
('6', 200, 1, 5, 350286) This means that the Imperial Government will not sanction any law that will apply to the Indians but not to the whites.
('6', 200, 1, 6, 350406) If we are right in assuming this, the Vrededorp Stands Ordinance, which prohibits Indians from holding any leases of Stands in Vrede dorp, should also be refused sanction.
('6', 200, 1, 7, 350578) And the Natal Municipalities Franchise Bill should also be treated likewise.
('6', 200, 1, 8, 350655) The Natal Mercury has, however, drawn a distinction and based on it the demand that, while the Transvaal is still a Crown Colony and so open to interference from the Imperial Government in its legislation, Natal is a self governing Colony and that the Imperial Government should not interfere in its affairs.
('6', 200, 1, 9, 350964) This argument is fallacious; for there is a clause in the Constitution of Natal which requires that all class legislation passed by the Natal parliament should have the approval of theImperial Government before it becomes law.
('6', 200, 1, 10, 351191) If therefore this clause is not a mere show piece but meant really to protect the Indian community, the argument of The Natal Mercury is not valid.
('6', 200, 1, 11, 351339) There is therefore every reason to expect that the Natal Bill too will be vetoed.
('6', 200, 2, 12, 351421) [From Gujarati]
('6', 200, 3, 13, 351437) Indian Opinion, 29 12 1906
('6', 200, 4, 14, 351464) 195. OPPRESSION IN THE CAPE
('6', 200, 5, 15, 351492) It has come to our notice that, under the Cape Immigration Act, the Cape Indians, while taking out an immigration certificate or permit, furnish their photograph, pay a fee of £1 and, on occasion, give their right and left thumb impressions as well.
('6', 200, 5, 16, 351742) We have also come to know that this has gone on for some time past.
('6', 200, 5, 17, 351810) We are deeply grieved to learn this.
('6', 200, 5, 18, 351847) It not only makes the Indians hang their heads in shame, but, if not stopped, it will have repercussions elsewhere and will harm the cause of the entire Indian community in South Africa.
('6', 200, 5, 19, 352034) It is quite easy to remedy this evil.
('6', 200, 5, 20, 352072) For, as we understand it, it is not done under any properly enacted law; it is the immigration officer who, in consultation with a few Indians, has introduced this system of taking photographs.
('6', 200, 5, 21, 352266) If, therefore, Indians meet the immigration officer, immediate redress may be possible.
('6', 200, 5, 22, 352354) We are anxious to learn that
('6', 201, 0, 1, 352383) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 201, 1, 2, 352425) effective measures have been taken in this regard without the least delay.
('6', 201, 1, 3, 352500) At one time the Asiatic Officer had introduced a similar regulation in the Transvaal; but it had to be repealed when the Indian community opposed it.
('6', 201, 1, 4, 352650) Moreover, it is found that these certificates will be valid for one year only.
('6', 201, 1, 5, 352729) There is absolutely no reason why they should be so limited.
('6', 201, 1, 6, 352790) To a man who has no knowledge of English but is a resident of the Cape, a permanent certificate should be issued stating that he has a right to return to the Cape.
('6', 201, 1, 7, 352954) We are not prisoners released on parole that our certificates of freedom can be cancelled if we fail to return within a given period.
('6', 201, 1, 8, 353088) The situation in the Cape is believed to be better than that elsewhere.
('6', 201, 1, 9, 353160) We appeal to the Cape leaders to keep up that position by their diligence.
('6', 201, 2, 10, 353235) [From Gujarati]
('6', 201, 3, 11, 353251) Indian Opinion, 29 12 1906

('6', 202, 0, 1, 354412) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 203
('6', 202, 1, 2, 354455) 197. SPEECH AT DINNER
('6', 202, 2, 3, 354477) On Wednesday, January 2, 1907, a dinner was given in honour of Gandhiji and Ally by Messrs M. C. Comroodeen & Co.
('6', 202, 2, 4, 354591) at their premises in Grey Street, Durban.
('6', 202, 2, 5, 354633) The Manager of the firm spoke on the occasion and Gandhiji and Ally replied.
('6', 202, 2, 6, 354710) The following is a combined report of their speeches:
('6', 202, 3, 7, 354764) [DURBAN, January 2, 1907]
('6', 202, 4, 8, 354790) Messrs Gandhi and Ally each replied, and narrated their work in London.
('6', 202, 4, 9, 354862) During their stay, short as it was, they came in contact with all classes of men from the humblest politician to the highest, including the Premier, and none of them on hearing the case put in such a reasonable light, grudged them their support, no matter what party he belonged to.
('6', 202, 4, 10, 355145) To give some idea, the Delegates stated that 5,000 penny stamps were used for their work in London.
('6', 202, 4, 11, 355245) The Committee that had been formed to watch their affairs was composed of highly influential men, to whom they entrusted their case in South Africa.
('6', 202, 4, 12, 355394) Strong and sincere promises of help had been given by Members of both the Houses of Parliament, who were convinced of the moderation of their demand, and the conciliatory spirit of their case.
('6', 202, 4, 13, 355587) When the Ordinance was introduced, it was passed so hurriedly that all the protests were disregarded, and yet they did not seek any outside interference.
('6', 202, 4, 14, 355741) They took the right course, and the right had prevailed.
('6', 202, 4, 15, 355798) They had high hopes from the work of theCommittee.
('6', 202, 4, 16, 355849) The great organ of public opinion, The Times, in London, had opened its columns to discuss their case, and when the position was explicitly explained and understood, there was only one reply, and that was that their grievance was just, modest, and reasonable to any right thinking human being.
('6', 202, 4, 17, 356143) When they left the English shore, they had strong hopes that redress would not be denied to them: and when, after some days, they reached Madeira they had a cable to say that the Ordinance had been disallowed.
('6', 202, 4, 18, 356353) The Delegates asked the audience to conform to all their responsibilities as citizens, and they had every hope from British justice.
('6', 202, 4, 19, 356486) The struggle had only just begun, but they did not despair of the future.
('6', 202, 5, 20, 356560) The Natal Mercury, 4 1 1907
('6', 202, 6, 21, 356588) 198. REPLY TO MAHOMEDAN ASSOCIATION’S ADDRESS

('6', 203, 0, 1, 356847) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 203, 1, 2, 356889) [DURBAN , January 3, 1907]
('6', 203, 2, 3, 356916) A number of associations have been founded recently.

('6', 203, 2, 7, 357158) Also we shall gain much strength and influence if the various associations co operate with one another.

('6', 203, 2, 22, 358363) He is never away from me.
('6', 203, 2, 23, 358389) May you also act in this faith.
('6', 203, 2, 24, 358421) Believe that God is near you and always follow the truth.
('6', 203, 2, 25, 358479) This is all I ask of you.

('6', 203, 4, 27, 358521) Indian Opinion, 12 1 1907
('6', 203, 5, 28, 358547) 199. SPEECH AT DURBAN RECEPTION
('6', 203, 6, 29, 358579) An address was presented to Gandhiji and Ally by the Mahomedan Association at the Indian Theatre in Victoria Street on Thursday, January 3, 1907. In reply to the address and speeches by Dawad Mahomed, Dada Abdulla and others, Gandhiji and Allyspoke.
('6', 203, 6, 30, 358829) The following is a combined report of their speeches:
('6', 204, 0, 1, 358883) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 205
('6', 204, 1, 2, 358926) [DURBAN, January 3, 1907]
('6', 204, 2, 3, 358952) The Delegates spoke, each in their turn, on broad politics, further giving the audience a review of their hard work in England.
('6', 204, 2, 4, 359080) They acknowledged the sterling services and important counsels given to them by Sir M. M. Bhownaggree, who placed his immense influence and long experience at their disposal, as did Mr. Ameer Ali, ex judge of the Calcutta Supreme Court.
('6', 204, 2, 5, 359317) The importance of India as a precious possession of the British Empire, with its 300,000,000 people who form a third part of the King Emperor’s subjects, played a great part in their success.
('6', 204, 2, 6, 359509) The English audience was, at several meetings, asked whether they would allow the South African colonists to ill treat undeservedly the sons of India, who fought their wars in China, South Africa, Somaliland, Soudan, and the frontiers of India; the people whose loyalty could be gauged by remembering that a handful of white soldiers (about 78,000) was sufficient to guard the 300 millions of fellow subjects in India, and whether they would like the representatives of the 13,000 British Indians of the Transvaal when they went back to India, to tell their kith and kin that the great Emperor who ruled this vast Empire was unable to save them from undue humiliation in South Africa at the hands of narrow minded white colonists?
('6', 204, 2, 7, 360240) The instant reply of the enthusiastic audiences was strongly in the negative.
('6', 204, 3, 8, 360318) Messrs Gandhi and Ally convinced the Indian audience that they had returned with a confident conviction from England that any reasonable and just grievance, when laid with moderation before the English rulers at Home, would not go unredressed; and, in conclusion, asked the members of the community to conform to all the laws and by laws of the Government whether just or unjust, and make themselves good citizens, as in them lay their own salvation.
('6', 204, 3, 9, 360769) They must convince their white neighbours that their presence in South Africa was not unbeneficial to the Colony, and they must work side by side with European colonists, who should always be honoured as the predominant race.
('6', 204, 3, 10, 360995) The Natal Mercury, 8 1 1907
('6', 204, 4, 11, 361023) 200. REPORT OF SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION
('6', 204, 5, 12, 361066) In his annual report recently published, the Superintendent of Education in Natal has said that whatever education is given [to Indians] is provided by the Government at its own expense and that the Indian community does nothing in the matter.
('6', 204, 5, 13, 361310) The charge is partly, though not entirely, justified.
('6', 204, 5, 14, 361364) Besides running a Madressa at Umgeni and one or two other private schools, the Indian community makes small occasional contributions towards the education of
('6', 205, 0, 1, 361522) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 205, 1, 2, 361564) Indians.
('6', 205, 1, 3, 361573) Hence we cannot admit the charge of the Superintendent in the form in which he has made it.
('6', 205, 1, 4, 361665) But it will have to be admitted by every Indian to his shame that the charge is on the whole justified.
('6', 205, 1, 5, 361769) Even in the Madressa there is plenty of scope for improvement if only we have the enthusiasm.
('6', 205, 1, 6, 361863) We are firmly of the view that, just as there should be provision in every Madressa for the teaching of Arabic, so should there be provision for secular or practical education, that is, for the teaching of English and Gujarati or any other Indian language.
('6', 205, 1, 7, 362120) Moreover, whatever teaching there is in Arabic is mostly parrot like; in other words, it is learning by rote withoutunderstanding the meaning.
('6', 205, 1, 8, 362263) On this point, we would advise our Muslim brethren to consider the example of Egypt.
('6', 205, 1, 9, 362348) There education is imparted inArabic from childhood, but with comprehension of the meaning, so that all people can speak Arabic and understand what they read from the earliest age.
('6', 205, 1, 10, 362529) This is also true of other education in the Egyptian Madressa.
('6', 205, 1, 11, 362592) If this reform is carried out in every Indian Madressa, many Muslim children will receive some education without difficulty.
('6', 205, 1, 12, 362717) In this matter we cannot but confess that the leaders of thecommunity have remained backward.
('6', 205, 1, 13, 362811) Apart from the Madressa, there is so little by way of other facilities, and the Indian community has been so careless that we must admit whatever charge is made against us on this count.
('6', 205, 1, 14, 362998) It does not become us to pass on the blame to others by saying that the Govern ment does nothing for education.
('6', 205, 1, 15, 363110) It is as much our duty as that of the Government to provide for education.
('6', 205, 1, 16, 363185) If the Government fails in its duty, that is no reason for us to follow suit.
('6', 205, 1, 17, 363263) On the contrary, if the Government does nothing for education, the responsibility of the Indian community becomes all the greater.
('6', 205, 1, 18, 363394) We are therefore constra ined to say that the above charge is quite justified.
('6', 205, 1, 19, 363473) We know that it is easy to be critical but difficult to suggest remedies and apply them.
('6', 205, 1, 20, 363562) But we shall be able to take a step forward only if we admit that we have been guilty.
('6', 205, 1, 21, 363649) Three things are necessary for meeting the problem.
('6', 205, 1, 22, 363701) The first thing is buildings and equipment.

('6', 212, 1, 10, 378318) A Society 1 has been founded which has shown, after an investigat ion of all religions, that not only do all of them teach morality but they are based for the most part on; ethical principles; that it is one’s duty to obey the laws of ethics whether or not one professes a religion; and that men who would not obey them could do no good either to themselves or to others, in this world or the next.

('6', 213, 3, 9, 380130) The different sciences show us the world as it is.
('6', 213, 3, 10, 380181) Ethics tells us what it ought to be.
('6', 213, 3, 11, 380218) It enables man to know how he should act.

('6', 213, 3, 18, 380959) Similarly, an ethical idea is useless so long as it is not followed by suitable action.
('6', 213, 3, 19, 381047) There are many who memorize moral precepts and preach sermons, but they neither practise them nor do they mean to do so.
('6', 213, 3, 20, 381168) There are some who believe that moral principles are not intended to be practised in this world; they are meant for the other world—the world which lies beyond death.
('6', 213, 3, 21, 381335) A great thinker has said, “If you wish to attain perfection, you must begin from this very day to live according to the laws of morality at any cost.” We need not be scared away by such thoughts; on the contrary we should be glad to live up to them, considering our responsibility in the matter.
('6', 213, 3, 22, 381631) “Certainly, cousin,” said the gallant Earl of Pembroke, on coming up to the Earl of Derby before Aubercoche and finding the battle already won, “you have neither been courteous nor behaved honour ably to fight my enemies without waiting for me, seeing that you had sent for me”.
('6', 213, 3, 23, 381910) Only when there is such readiness to accept moral responsibility will men tread the path of virtue.
('6', 213, 3, 24, 382010) God is omnipotent, He is perfect.
('6', 213, 3, 25, 382044) There are no limits to His mercy, to His goodness and to His justice.
('6', 213, 3, 26, 382114) If this is so, how can we, His bond slaves, stray at all from the moral path?

('6', 214, 1, 3, 382311) However, those committing a breach of morality have only themselves to blame.
('6', 214, 1, 4, 382389) In the path of morality there is no such thing as reward for moral behaviour.
('6', 214, 1, 5, 382467) If a man does some good deed, he does not do it to win applause, he does it because he must.
('6', 214, 1, 6, 382560) For him doing good is but a higher kind of food, if one may compare food and goodness.
('6', 214, 1, 7, 382647) And if someone should give him an opportunity to do a good deed, he would feel grateful just as a starving man would be grateful to the giver of food and bless him.

('6', 214, 1, 9, 382910) It does mean that we should become a little more diligent, a little better educated, a little cleaner and neater, etc.

('6', 216, 1, 2, 385392) 211. LETTER TO “THE OUTLOOK”
('6', 216, 2, 3, 385421) [JOHANNESBURG Before January 12, 1907]
('6', 216, 3, 4, 385460) [TO THE EDITOR
('6', 216, 4, 5, 385475) THE OUTLOOK
('6', 216, 5, 6, 385487) SIR,] May I congratulate you on having recognized by your exhaustive leader on “British Indians in the Transvaal” in your issue of November 24 the Imperial importance of the question?
('6', 216, 5, 7, 385671) And may I, at the same time, point out that you have, in justifying the anti Indian policy of the Europeans, done, no doubt unconsciously, an injustice to British Indians in a twofold manner?
('6', 216, 5, 8, 385863) First, in my humble opinion, you have missed the central question.
('6', 216, 5, 9, 385930) You seem to think that Indians on the one hand demand an open door for an unrestricted influx of their countrymen, and that the white colonists on the other, from an instinct of self preservation, demand that the door should be tightly closed.
('6', 216, 5, 10, 386174) Such, however, is not the case.
('6', 216, 5, 11, 386206) Indians ask for the ordinary civil rights enjoyed by all human beings, except criminals, in any civilized state.
('6', 216, 5, 12, 386319) They admit the principle of restriction of further immi gration of their brethren along the lines even as adopted by Aust ralia, but they say, with Mr. Chamberlain that they may not be restricted solely because theyare British Indians.
('6', 216, 5, 13, 386555) If Imperia lism has any meaning, how can any exception be taken to a position such as above?
('6', 216, 5, 14, 386648) I have no doubt that you, sir, will admit that even a self governing colony, so long as it chooses to remain a part of the Empire, may not go so far as to degrade and ill treat those whom it finds settled within its borders on assumption of self governing powers.
('6', 216, 5, 15, 386912) Secondly, you talk of the necessity of sacrifice of a “principle of logic” (as you are pleased to term it) to the principle of “high expediency”.
('6', 216, 5, 16, 387058) To me, it is not logic so much as morality you would sacrifice on the altar of expediency; but assuming that a logical or a moral principle may be so sacrificed, what is “higher expediency”?
('6', 216, 5, 17, 387249) It is a wanton wounding of the susceptibilities of a finely strung and highly loyal community like the millions of India, or a firm refusal on the part of the Imperial watchdog sitting, inLord Milner’s language,
('6', 217, 0, 1, 387461) 218 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 217, 1, 2, 387503) on the watch tower, and sweeping the whole horizon before him to protect an unreasoning and unreasonable colour prejudice.
('6', 217, 1, 3, 387626) You incidentally mention the Treaty of Vereeniging 1. May I draw your attention to the fact that, even if the term “Native” as used there were to include British Indians, it merely suspends a considera tion of the granting of the political franchise to the “Natives” until after the establishment of responsible government in the Colony.
('6', 217, 1, 4, 387964) British Indians have, however, in unmistakable language stated that they do not aspire, at any rate at the present stage, to political power.
('6', 217, 2, 5, 388106) Indian Opinion, 12 1 1907
('6', 217, 4, 6, 388132) Yours, etc., M. K. GANDHI
('6', 217, 5, 7, 388158) 212. QUINN’S SPEECH
('6', 217, 6, 8, 388178) Mr. Quinn’s speech, as reported by our Johannesburg correspondent, 2 deserves attention.
('6', 217, 6, 9, 388267) It shows that the white population is altogether in the dark about our conditions.
('6', 217, 6, 10, 388350) Mr. Quinn believes that (1) the Asiatic Ordinance would have prevented the entry of Indians without permits; (2) there are many Indians who have entered the country without permits; (3) the Transvaal law would also have served to check Indian trade.
('6', 217, 6, 11, 388600) All these statements are incorrect.
('6', 217, 6, 12, 388636) The Transvaal Ordinance which has been disallowed would not have prevented the entry of permitless Indians.
('6', 217, 6, 13, 388744) The only law that can prevent the entry of such persons is the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('6', 217, 6, 14, 388837) Also it is not true that many Indians enter without permits.
('6', 217, 6, 15, 388898) Recent cases show that people are effectively prevented from doing so.
('6', 217, 6, 16, 388969) Furthermore, every one knows that the Asiatic Ordinance had no bearing on Indian trade.
('6', 217, 6, 17, 389057) All the same, it should be borne in mind that harm is done to the whole Indian community to the extent that some try to enter without permits or with forged ones.
('6', 217, 6, 18, 389220) Those engaged in such activities should desist from them.
('6', 217, 6, 19, 389278) Above all, leading Indians should do all they can to remove this
('6', 217, 7, 20, 389343) 1 Signed between the Boers and the British Government in 1902, it brought the Transvaal and the Orange River Colony under British rule.

('6', 219, 1, 2, 391343) 214. JAPAN AND AMERICA
('6', 219, 2, 3, 391366) The quarrel between Japan and America still continues.
('6', 219, 2, 4, 391421) California has a large Japanese population, which has made much progress by dint of its intelligence and skill.
('6', 219, 2, 5, 391533) There are many Japanese boys in American schools.
('6', 219, 2, 6, 391583) The white population there cannot bear this.
('6', 219, 2, 7, 391628) Japan is putting up a hard fight over this issue.
('6', 219, 2, 8, 391678) So far, there has been no solution.
('6', 219, 2, 9, 391714) President Roosevelt is in a difficult situation.
('6', 219, 2, 10, 391763) On the one hand, a brave people like the Japanese is being insulted.
('6', 219, 2, 11, 391832) On the other, those among the white population who would not mind America being involved in a war refuse to listen to Roosevelt’s advice and do not allow Japanese boys to enter the schools.
('6', 219, 2, 12, 392022) It is an impossible situation.
('6', 219, 2, 13, 392053) America is not in a position even to fight.
('6', 219, 2, 14, 392097) The Japanese Navy is very much stronger than the American, and only recently it proved its mettle.
('6', 219, 2, 15, 392196) In a situation such as this, England too has to weigh matters carefully.
('6', 219, 2, 16, 392269) While the Japanese are friends of the English, the Ameri cans are their cousins.
('6', 219, 2, 17, 392350) Whom should England support?
('6', 219, 2, 18, 392379) It is believ ed that war can be averted only if England intervenes effectively.

('6', 220, 4, 14, 394497) 216. ETHICAL RELIGION II
('6', 220, 5, 15, 394522) CHAPTER II: IDEAL MORALITY
('6', 220, 6, 16, 394549) The current views of morality are not of a very high order.
('6', 220, 6, 17, 394609) Some believe that morality is not something quite essential.
('6', 220, 6, 18, 394670) Others think that there is no relation between religion and morality.
('6', 220, 6, 19, 394740) But an examination of the world’s religions shows that, without morality, religion cannot subsist.
('6', 220, 6, 20, 394839) True morality covers religion for the most part.
('6', 220, 6, 21, 394888) Anyone who observes the laws of morality for their own sake and not for any selfish end can be regarded as religious.
('6', 220, 6, 22, 395006) There are men in Russia who dedicate their lives to the good of their country.
('6', 220, 6, 23, 395085) Such men are truly moral.
('6', 220, 6, 24, 395111) A man like Jeremy Bentham, who discovered many good principles for English legislation, tried very hard to spread education among the English and took a prominent part in improving the condition of prisoners, may be regarded as truly moral.
('6', 220, 6, 25, 395352) Besides, it is a rule of ideal morality that it is not enough to
('6', 221, 0, 1, 395417) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 221, 1, 2, 395459) follow the trodden path.
('6', 221, 1, 3, 395484) We ought to follow the path which we know to be true, whether it is familiar or unfamiliar to us.
('6', 221, 1, 4, 395582) In other words, when we know a particular path to be the right one, we should set out on it without fear.
('6', 221, 1, 5, 395688) We can progress only if we observe the laws of morality in this way.
('6', 221, 1, 6, 395757) That is why true morality, true civilization and true progress are always to be found together.
('6', 221, 1, 7, 395853) If we examine our desires, we shall see that we do not wish for what we have already.
('6', 221, 1, 8, 395939) We always value more that which we do not have.
('6', 221, 1, 9, 395987) But desires are of two kinds: one is the pursuit of mere self interest.To attempt to fulfil this kind of desire is immoral.
('6', 221, 1, 10, 396111) The other impels us constantly to improve ourselves and to do good to others.
('6', 221, 1, 11, 396189) We should never become overweening with any amount of good that we may do.
('6', 221, 1, 12, 396264) It is not for us to evaluate it, but rather should we have perpetual longing to become better and do more good.
('6', 221, 1, 13, 396376) True morality consists in our effort to realize such longing.
('6', 221, 1, 14, 396438) If we have no home or family of our own, that is nothing to be ashamed of.
('6', 221, 1, 15, 396513) But if we have a home and abuse it, or own a business and practise fraud, we stray from the path of morality.
('6', 221, 1, 16, 396623) Morality consists in doing what we ought to do.
('6', 221, 1, 17, 396671) We can prove the need of morality through a few illustrations.
('6', 221, 1, 18, 396734) Destruction has been the lot of peoples or families in which the seeds of immorality, such as disunity and untruth, were found.
('6', 221, 1, 19, 396862) To take an example from trade and business, we do not come across a single person who will say that truth should not be followed.
('6', 221, 1, 20, 396992) The effect of justice and goodness is not felt from outside; these qualities in here in us.
('6', 221, 1, 21, 397084) Four hundred years ago, much injustice and untruth prevailed in Europe, so that people could not rest in peace even for a moment.
('6', 221, 1, 22, 397214) The cause of this state of affairs was that people had no morality.
('6', 221, 1, 23, 397282) If we take out the essence of all moral laws, we shall find that the attempt to do good to mankind is the highest morality.
('6', 221, 1, 24, 397406) If we open the treasure house of morality with this key, we shall find in it all the other principles.
('6', 221, 1, 25, 397509) At the end of each of these articles, we print select poems bearing on morality from Gujarati or Urdu poets in the hope that all our readers will benefit from them and will also commit them to memory.
('6', 221, 1, 26, 397710) We begin with an extract 1 from Mr. Malbari’s 2 book, Adami Ane Teni Duniya.
('6', 221, 2, 27, 397787) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 12 1 1907
('6', 221, 3, 28, 397829) 1 Not reproduced here 2 B. M. Malbari, Gujarati poet and social reformer.
('6', 221, 3, 29, 397903) The title of the book is Man and His World

('6', 227, 8, 25, 409466) 224. ETHICAL RELIGION III
('6', 227, 9, 26, 409492) CHAPTER III: WHAT IS MORAL ACTION?
('6', 227, 10, 27, 409527) When can it be said that a particular action is moral?
('6', 227, 10, 28, 409582) In asking this question, the intention is not to contrast moral with immoral actions, but to consider many of our everyday actions against which nothing can be said from the conventional standpoint and which some
('6', 227, 11, 29, 409795) 1 Vide ‘‘Japan and America’’, 12 1 1907.
('6', 228, 0, 1, 409836) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 229
('6', 228, 1, 2, 409879) regard as moral.
('6', 228, 1, 3, 409896) Most of our actions are probably non moral; they do not necessarily involve morality.
('6', 228, 1, 4, 409982) For the most part we act according to the prevailing conventions.
('6', 228, 1, 5, 410048) Such conventional behavi our is often necessary.
('6', 228, 1, 6, 410097) If no such rules are observed, anarchy would be the result, and society—social intercourse—would come to an end.
('6', 228, 1, 7, 410210) Still the mere observance of custom and usage cannot properly be called morality.
('6', 228, 1, 8, 410292) A moral act must be our own act: it must spring from our own will.
('6', 228, 1, 9, 410359) If we act mechanically, there is no moral content in our act.
('6', 228, 1, 10, 410421) Such action would be moral, if we think it proper to act like a machine and do so.
('6', 228, 1, 11, 410504) For in doing so, we use our discrimination.
('6', 228, 1, 12, 410548) We should bear in mind the distinction between acting mechanically and acting inten tionally.
('6', 228, 1, 13, 410642) It may be moral of a king to pardon a culprit.
('6', 228, 1, 14, 410689) But the messenger bearing the order of pardon plays only a mechanical part in the king’s moral act.
('6', 228, 1, 15, 410789) But if the messenger were to bear the king’s order, considering it to be his duty, his action would be a moral one.
('6', 228, 1, 16, 410905) How can a man understand morality who does not use his own intelligence and power of thought, but lets himself be swept along like a log of wood by a current?
('6', 228, 1, 17, 411064) Sometimes a man defies convention and acts on his own with a view to [doing] absolute good.
('6', 228, 1, 18, 411156) Such a great hero was Wendell Phillips 1. Addressing an assembly of people, he once said, “Till you learn to form your own opinions and express them, I do not care much what you think of me.” Thus when we all care only for what our conscience says, then alone can we be regarded to have stepped on to the moral road.
('6', 228, 1, 19, 411473) We shall not reach this stage, as long as we do not believe—and experience the belief—that God within us, the God of all, is the ever present witness to all our acts.
('6', 228, 1, 20, 411640) It is not enough that an act done by us is in itself good; it should have been done with the intention to do good.
('6', 228, 1, 21, 411755) That is to say, whether an act is moral or otherwise depends upon the intention of the doer.
('6', 228, 1, 22, 411848) Two men may have done exactly the same thing; but the act of one may be moral, and that of the other the contrary.
('6', 228, 1, 23, 411963) Take, for instance, a man who out of great pity feeds the poor and another who does the same, but with the motive of winning prestige or with some such selfish end.
('6', 228, 1, 24, 412128) Though the action is the same, the act of the one is moral and that of the other non moral.
('6', 228, 1, 25, 412220) The reader here ought to remember the distinction between the two words, non moral and immoral.
('6', 228, 1, 26, 412316) It may be that we do not always see good results flowing from a moral act.
('6', 228, 1, 27, 412391) While thinking of morality, all that we need to see is that the act is
('6', 228, 2, 28, 412462) 1 (1811 84); American orator, social reformer and abolitionist
('6', 229, 0, 1, 412525) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 229, 1, 2, 412567) good and is done with a good intention.
('6', 229, 1, 3, 412607) The result of an action is not within our control.
('6', 229, 1, 4, 412658) God alone is the giver of fruit.
('6', 229, 1, 5, 412691) Historians have called Emperor Alexander “great”.
('6', 229, 1, 6, 412741) Wherever he went [in the course of his conquests,] he took the Greek language and Greek culture, arts and manners, and today we enjoy the benefits of Greek civilization.
('6', 229, 1, 7, 412911) But the intention of Alexander behind all this was only conquest and renown.
('6', 229, 1, 8, 412988) Who can therefore say that his actions were moral?
('6', 229, 1, 9, 413039) It was all right that he was termed “great”, but moral he cannot be called.
('6', 229, 1, 10, 413115) These reflections prove that it is not enough for a moral act to have been done with a good intention, but it should have been done without compulsion.
('6', 229, 1, 11, 413267) There is no morality whatever in my act, if I rise early out of the fear that, if I am late for my office, I may lose my situation.
('6', 229, 1, 12, 413399) Similarly there is no morality in my living a simple and unpretentious life if I have not the means to live otherwise.
('6', 229, 1, 13, 413518) But plain, simple living would be moral if, though wealthy, I think of all the want and misery in the world about me—and feel that Iought to live a plain, simple life and not one of ease and luxury.
('6', 229, 1, 14, 413717) Like wise it is only selfish, and not moral, of an employer to sympathize with his employees or to pay them higher wages lest they leave him.
('6', 229, 1, 15, 413859) It would be moral if the employer wished well of them and treated them kindly realizing how he owed his prosperity to them.
('6', 229, 1, 16, 413983) This means that for an act to be moral it has to be free from fear and compulsion.
('6', 229, 1, 17, 414066) When the peasants rose in revolt and with bloodshot eyes went to King Richard II of England demanding their rights, he granted them the rights under his own seal and signature.
('6', 229, 1, 18, 414243) But when the danger was over, he forced them to surrender the letters.
('6', 229, 1, 19, 414314) It would be a mistake for anyone to say that King Richard’s first act was moral and the second immoral.
('6', 229, 1, 20, 414418) For his first act was done only out of fear and had not an iota of morality about it.
('6', 229, 1, 21, 414504) Just as a moral action should be free from fear or compulsion so should there be no self interest behind it.
('6', 229, 1, 22, 414613) This is not to say that actions prompted by self interest are all worthless, but only that to call them moral would detract from the [dignity of the] moral idea.
('6', 229, 1, 23, 414775) That honesty cannot long endure which is practised in the belief that it is the best policy.
('6', 229, 1, 24, 414868) As Shakespeare says, love born out of the profit motive is no love.
('6', 229, 2, 25, 414936) 1 “Love is not love, When it is mingled with respects that stand Aloof from the entire point.”
('6', 230, 0, 1, 415031) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 231
('6', 230, 1, 2, 415074) Just as an action prompted by the motive of material gain here on earth is non moral, so also another done for considerations of comfort and personal happiness in another world is non moral.
('6', 230, 1, 3, 415265) That action is moral which is done only for the sake of doing good.
('6', 230, 1, 4, 415333) A great Christian, St. Francis Xavier, passionately prayed that his mind might always remain pure.
('6', 230, 1, 5, 415432) 1 For him devotion to God was not for enjoying a higher seat after death.
('6', 230, 1, 6, 415506) He prayed because it was man’s duty to pray.
('6', 230, 1, 7, 415551) The great Saint Theresa wished to have a torch in her right hand and a vessel of water in her left, so that with the one she might burn the glories of heaven and with the other extinguish the fires of hell, and men might learn to serve God from love alone— without fear of hell and without temptation of heavenly bliss.
('6', 230, 1, 8, 415871) To preserve morality thus demands a brave man prepared to face even death.
('6', 230, 1, 9, 415946) It is cowardice to be true to friends and to break faith with enemies.
('6', 230, 1, 10, 416017) Those who do good out of fear and haltingly have no moral virtue.
('6', 230, 1, 11, 416083) Henry Clay, known for his kind liness, sacrificed his convic tions to his ambition.
('6', 230, 1, 12, 416167) Daniel Webster 2, for all his great intellect and his sense of the heroic and the sublime, once sold his intellectualintegrity for a price.
('6', 230, 1, 13, 416307) By a single mean act he wiped out all his good deeds.
('6', 230, 1, 14, 416361) This shows how difficult it is to judge the morality of a man’s action because we cannot penetrate the depths of his mind.
('6', 230, 1, 15, 416484) We have also the answer to the question raised at the outset in this chapter: what is a moral action?
('6', 230, 1, 16, 416586) Inciden tally, we also saw which kind of men could live up to that morality.
('6', 230, 2, 17, 416663) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 19 1 1907
