('6', 235, 4, 12, 426032) 228. A MARE’S NEST
('6', 235, 5, 13, 426051) The Natal Advertiser has published what purports to be a report of an Indian meeting held in order to consider certain complaints against the Natal Indian Congress and to form a new body.
('6', 235, 5, 14, 426239) We notice, from our Johannesburg correspondence, that the contents of the precious report were telegraphed to the Johannesburg Star, in extenso.
('6', 235, 5, 15, 426384) It evidently appears as if the wish was father to the thought, and that some “good natured” people would rather see a quarrel between different sections of the Indian community.
('6', 235, 5, 16, 426562) We may, therefore, assure these friends that such a quarrel is not possible, because there can be no backbone to it.
('6', 235, 5, 17, 426679) It is worthy of note that it is not stated in the inspired report where the meeting took place, who convened it, who attended it, and when it was held.
('6', 235, 5, 18, 426831) We have, however, taken the trouble to inquire about it, and we find that some such meeting did take place at a private house.
('6', 235, 5, 19, 426958) But the whole aspect is changed when the facts are known.
('6', 235, 5, 20, 427016) The meeting discussed the question of founding a political institution apart from the Congress, but little encouragement was given by the speakers to this proposal, and the weight of opinion did not favour it.
('6', 235, 5, 21, 427226) We think the following letter, addressed to The Advertiser by Mr. V. Lawrence, Chairman of the meeting, places the matter in its true light:
('6', 235, 6, 22, 427367) Sir, In your second edition of the 17th instant, there appears on page 5 what purports to be the report of a meeting of the Colonial Hindus and Christianized Indians that took place on Tuesday night last, headed “Natal Hindus, Dissatisfaction with the Natal Indian Congress, Representation Desired”.
('6', 235, 6, 23, 427667) As chairman of that meeting, I must most emphatically refute many of the statements therein.
('6', 235, 6, 24, 427760) The object of that meeting was to form a very influential and representative committee to approach the Natal Indian
('6', 236, 0, 1, 427876) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 237
('6', 236, 1, 2, 427919) Congress, which is recognized by the Imperial and Colonial Governments as the representative institution of the Indian community in Natal, to make it a more representative body than it is at present.
('6', 236, 1, 3, 428119) It is not true that it was pointed out during the discussion that the association of the Colonial Indian and Hindu community with the Mohammadan merchants was derogatory to the good opinion of the European section of the country in regard to the former.It was not only the idea, but the first and foremost object of the meeting was, and all the discussion that night was directed to achieve that object, to unite with, and not to dissociate from, the Natal Indian Congress, to obtain redress for the disabilities that are and may be heaped upon the Indian community.
('6', 236, 2, 4, 428686) It is not correct that minor matters were then discussed and the meeting broke up without any definite decision being come to.
('6', 236, 2, 5, 428813) The meeting dispersed after the election of a thoroughly representative committee of all classes of the Indian community to approach the Natal Indian Congress, and I was deputed to interview the President and the Secretaries of the Congress, and ascertain from them what day, time and place will suit the Congress to hear the views of the committee.
('6', 236, 2, 6, 429163) We have neither desire nor intention to work against either the Congress or the Europeans, but to unite with the Congress in creating a better understanding between the European and Indian communities.
('6', 236, 2, 7, 429365) We are glad to notice that the prominent Hindus of Durban met together on Sunday for the purpose of repudiating the statements made in the newspaper report.
('6', 236, 2, 8, 429522) Mr. Sanghavi, the Chairman of this meeting, said that perfect amity and concord existed between the different sections of the Indian community, irrespective of caste, creed or religion.
('6', 236, 2, 9, 429708) If, however, there are any young Indians, besides the person that concocted The Advertiser report, who feel aggrieved at not being able to figure prominently in the work of the Congress, we strongly advise them to steer clear of any movement that would bring about discord between the different sections of the community.
('6', 236, 2, 10, 430030) It may be well to examine the origin of the Natal Indian Congress 1. It was established when a general attack on the Indian community on the part of some European colonists was commenced.
('6', 236, 2, 11, 430218) The trustees of the Congress include two Hindus, one of them a Tamil gentleman, and on the Congress membership are scores of Hindus and Christians belonging to different presidencies of India.
('6', 236, 2, 12, 430411) Its objects are
('6', 236, 3, 13, 430427) 1 Founded in 1894; vide “Petition to Natal Legislative Assembly”, 28 6 1894: Deputation to Natal Premier”, 29 6 1894, “Memorial to J. Chamberlain”, 11 8 1895 and “The Second Report of the Natal Indian Congress”, post 11 10 1899.
('6', 237, 0, 1, 430656) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 237, 1, 2, 430698) all embracing, and if the attention paid to the Tamil community is to count for anything, it is but simple truth to state that, during the first few years of the Congress existence, it was largely occupied with matters more especially concerning that community.

('6', 238, 3, 6, 433588) 230. NATAL LICENSING ACT
('6', 238, 4, 7, 433613) At the beginning of each year Indians in Natal go through a period of acute anxiety.
('6', 238, 4, 8, 433698) All traders, big and small remain in suspense for they are not sure whether they will get [renewed] licences.
('6', 238, 4, 9, 433808) This time, it seems, preparations are afoot for greater harassment [of Indians].
('6', 238, 4, 10, 433889) LADYSMITH In Ladysmith notice has been given to all traders that they will not get their licences next year.
('6', 238, 4, 11, 433998) Some have been refused lice nces even for the current year for the alleged reason that they do not know how to keep accounts in English.
('6', 238, 5, 12, 434135) TONGAAT
('6', 238, 6, 13, 434143) In Tongaat licences have been refused to many Indians, the reasons given being lack of cleanliness and the unsatisfactory condition of accounts.
('6', 238, 7, 14, 434288) ELSEWHERE
('6', 238, 8, 15, 434298) Meetings are held all over the Colony where Europeans pass resolutions to the effect that no licences should be issued to Indian traders.
('6', 238, 8, 16, 434436) There is no immediate danger, as a result of these resolutions, of licences being withheld in all places.
('6', 238, 8, 17, 434542) There is no doubt, however, that, if steps are not taken from now on, it will be too late afterwards.
('6', 238, 9, 18, 434644) REMEDIAL MEASURES Let us consider what measures can be taken.
('6', 238, 9, 19, 434706) It is quite necessary that those who have been refused licences should file appeals with the Licensing Board.
('6', 238, 9, 20, 434816) Such appeals cost very little.

('6', 240, 2, 3, 437297) MEASURES CONCERNING OURSELVES Let us now consider measures in so far as they concern us.
('6', 240, 2, 4, 437386) In this fight we must know for certain whether or not we are at fault.
('6', 240, 2, 5, 437457) He who cannot see his own fault is doomed.
('6', 240, 2, 6, 437500) [On the other hand,] that we may suffer even when there is nothing that can be said against us is contrary to experience.
('6', 240, 2, 7, 437622) It is our duty to offer resistance by legitimate, constitutional means; it is also our duty to think of our own faults.
('6', 240, 2, 8, 437742) In relation to the law, we are at fault on three points: (1) lack of cleanliness; (2) the bad state of account books; and (3) the location of residence and shop in the same premises.
('6', 240, 3, 9, 437925) LACK OF CLEANLINESS In regard to lack of cleanliness, we must confess that, though we are not as bad as Europeans make us out to be, the charge is by and large justified.
('6', 240, 3, 10, 438096) The phrase “lack of cleanliness” covers both the general appearance of the house and one’s personal appearance.
('6', 240, 4, 11, 438208) CONDITION OF SHOP Very often the shop is found to be in a slovenly condition.
('6', 240, 4, 12, 438286) The backyard is full of slush and dirt.
('6', 240, 4, 13, 438326) Even the interior of the shop is sometimes dirty, and we are content that our shops should look like hovels.
('6', 240, 4, 14, 438435) All this must change.
('6', 240, 4, 15, 438457) It will be wise to give up all hope of carrying on trade anyhow, as we do in India, without giving much thought to the condition of the shop.
('6', 240, 4, 16, 438599) If we cannot maintain our shop in as good a condition as the Europeans of better standing do, we do not deserve to be in trade.
('6', 240, 4, 17, 438727) When they see our huts adjoining their well kept shops, and see the same things being sold in our huts as in theirs, they are bound to feel a grudge against us.

('6', 240, 4, 19, 438971) No doubt they do, but we must never forget that, if we follow their example, we shall lose our case.
('6', 240, 4, 20, 439072) We should not be surprised if they even expect more from us, for, after all?
('6', 240, 4, 21, 439149) we belong to a different community.

('6', 243, 4, 8, 444618) 232. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('6', 243, 5, 9, 444643) SELF GOVERNMENT IN THE TRANSVAAL
('6', 243, 6, 10, 444676) Lord Selborne has been re appointed Governor of the Transvaal under the new Constitution.
('6', 243, 6, 11, 444766) The post of Lieutenant Governor has now been abolished altogether.
('6', 243, 6, 12, 444833) Those desiring to contest the election to the new parliament will file their nomination papers with the respective magistrates on February 9. People will go to the polls on the 20th.
('6', 243, 7, 13, 445016) WHAT IS RESPONSIBLE GOVERNMENT?
('6', 243, 8, 14, 445048) It will not be out of place here to explain the significance of the change now introduced in the Transvaal.
('6', 243, 8, 15, 445156) In the British Empire, there are three types of territories outside Great Britain, viz., self governing colonies, Crown colonies and dependencies.
('6', 243, 8, 16, 445303) India is among the dependencies.
('6', 243, 8, 17, 445336) Crown colonies includeMauritius,Ceylon, etc.
('6', 243, 8, 18, 445381) Natal, Canada, Australia, etc., are among the self governing colonies.
('6', 243, 8, 19, 445452) In a Crown colony there is generally a legislative body either elected by the people or nominated by the government.
('6', 243, 8, 20, 445569) Officials are appointed only by the government, the legislature has no con trol over them and they are in no way responsible to the members.
('6', 243, 8, 21, 445710) All laws are regarded as having been enacted by the government.
('6', 243, 8, 22, 445774) Self government is said to have been conferred on a people when power is transferred to it and it acquires the authority to appoint officers, levy taxes and enact laws.
('6', 243, 8, 23, 445943) The British control over self governing colonies is very slight.
('6', 243, 8, 24, 446008) Their legislation requires Royal assent, but if the Crown should refuse the assent, there is always the probability that these countries may declare their independence.
('6', 243, 8, 25, 446177) Many experienced politicians believe that self governing colonies will become independent in a few years.
('6', 243, 8, 26, 446283) Till recently the Transvaal was a Crown Colony, but it has now become self governing.
('6', 243, 8, 27, 446369) Under it the
('6', 244, 0, 1, 446382) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 245
('6', 244, 1, 2, 446425) members elected by the people can question the doings of the officials; it is therefore also called responsible government.

('6', 246, 1, 2, 450516) 233. ETHICAL RELIGION IV
('6', 246, 2, 3, 450541) CHAPTER IV: IS THERE A HIGHER LAW?
('6', 246, 3, 4, 450576) We constantly pronounce judgements upon the value of actions.
('6', 246, 3, 5, 450638) Some actions satisfy us and others do not.
('6', 246, 3, 6, 450681) Whether a certain act is good or bad does not depend upon whether it is beneficial or harmful to us.
('6', 246, 3, 7, 450782) In judging it, we adopt quite a different standard.
('6', 246, 3, 8, 450834) We have in our minds certain ideas and on the basis of those we judge the acts of others.
('6', 246, 3, 9, 450924) Whether any wrong done by one to another affects us or not, we do feel it to be wrong.
('6', 246, 3, 10, 451011) Sometimes we have a trace of sympathy for the wrongdoer; but despite that sympathy, we feel no hesitation at all in pronouncing his act to be wrong.
('6', 246, 3, 11, 451160) It may be that at times our judgement is found to be mistaken.
('6', 246, 3, 12, 451223) We cannot always fathom a man’s motives, and may thus judge him wrongly.
('6', 246, 3, 13, 451296) Neverth eless, we find no difficulty in judging an act in so far as the intention is known.
('6', 246, 3, 14, 451388) Even if our personal interests are sometimes served by wrong actions, we do feel inwardly that they are wrong.
('6', 246, 3, 15, 451499) Thus it is established that the rightness or wrongness of an act does not depend upon a man’s self interest.
('6', 246, 3, 16, 451608) Nor does it depend upon his wishes.
('6', 246, 3, 17, 451644) There is a difference between morality and sympathy.
('6', 246, 3, 18, 451697) Out of sympathy for the child we wish to give it a certain thing, but if the thing is harmful to the child, we hold it immoral to give it.
('6', 246, 3, 19, 451836) It is doubtless good to show sympathy but, unrestricted by moral considerations, it turns into poison.
('6', 246, 3, 20, 451939) We see also that moral laws are immutable.
('6', 246, 3, 21, 451982) Opinions change, but not morality.
('6', 246, 3, 22, 452017) When our eyes are open, we see the sun; when they are closed, it is not seen.
('6', 246, 3, 23, 452095) The change here has been in our sense of sight, not in the fact of the sun’s existence.
('6', 246, 3, 24, 452183) The same holds true of moral laws.
('6', 246, 3, 25, 452218) It is probable that in a state of ignorance we do not know what is moral; but once the eye of knowledge is opened, there is no difficulty in knowing it.
('6', 246, 3, 26, 452371) Men rarely care to see single mindedly the right or wrong of things; often prompted by personal considerations, they mistakenly describe the immoral as moral.
('6', 246, 3, 27, 452530) The time is yet to come when men, freeing themselves from self regarding considerations, will concentrate their attention on the ideas of morality alone.
('6', 246, 3, 28, 452684) Moral culture is still in its mere infancy; it is as science was before the birth of a Bacon or a Darwin.
('6', 246, 3, 29, 452790) Men were eager to know what the truth was.
('6', 246, 3, 30, 452833) Instead of inquiring into morality, they have been hitherto engaged in
('6', 247, 0, 1, 452904) 248 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 247, 1, 2, 452946) discovering laws of nature—the laws of the earth’s motion, etc.
('6', 247, 1, 3, 453010) Where do we find the disinterested student of mora lity, patient and painstaking, who, setting aside his earlier superstitious notions, devotes his life to seeking only the ideal good?
('6', 247, 1, 4, 453195) When men become as eager to explore the world of moral ideas as they are now to explore the realms of nature, we shall be able to bring together the various conceptions of morality.
('6', 247, 1, 5, 453377) It is unlikely that, on ideas of morality, there will be the same divergence of opinion as exists among men on matters of science.
('6', 247, 1, 6, 453508) However, we may not for a time arrive at unanimity of opinion regarding moral laws.
('6', 247, 1, 7, 453592) This does not, however, mean that it is impossible to distinguish between right and wrong.
('6', 247, 1, 8, 453683) We thus see that, independent of and apart from men’s wishes and opinions, there is something like a moral standard which we may call moral law.
('6', 247, 1, 9, 453828) If there are laws of the state, why may not there be a moral law too?
('6', 247, 1, 10, 453898) It does not matter if that law is not committed to writing by man, and indeed it need not be.
('6', 247, 1, 11, 453992) If we grant or hold that the moral law exists, it is incumbent on us to obey it, just as we ought to obey the law of the state.
('6', 247, 1, 12, 454120) A moral law is distinct from and better than the laws of the state or those of business.
('6', 247, 1, 13, 454209) One may ask, “How does it matter if I do not obey the laws of business and remain poor?
('6', 247, 1, 14, 454297) Or if I disobey the laws of the state and incur the ruler’s displea sure?” But it will never do —either for me or anyone else — to say, “What does it matter whether I tell a lie or tell the truth?” There is thus a great difference between moral laws and temporal laws.
('6', 247, 1, 15, 454566) For morality dwells in our hearts.
('6', 247, 1, 16, 454601) Even a man practising immorality would admit that he has been immoral.
('6', 247, 1, 17, 454672) A wrong can never become right.
('6', 247, 1, 18, 454704) Even where a people is vile, though men may not observe the moral law, they would make a pretence of doing so; they thus are obliged to admit that moral laws ought to be observed.
('6', 247, 1, 19, 454884) Such is the greatness of morality.
('6', 247, 1, 20, 454919) It cares not for custom nor for public opinion.
('6', 247, 1, 21, 454967) To a moral man, public opinion or custom is binding only so long as it is in harmony with the moral law.
('6', 247, 1, 22, 455072) Where does this moral law come from?
('6', 247, 1, 23, 455109) This law is not laid down by the state, for different laws are found in different states.
('6', 247, 1, 24, 455199) Many men were opposed to the morality which Socrates observed in his day.
('6', 247, 1, 25, 455273) Even so the world admits that the morality he observed has remained, and shall remain, morality for ever.
('6', 247, 1, 26, 455379) Robert Browning says, ‘If ever Satan proclaimed the law of hatred and untruth in the world, even then
('6', 248, 0, 1, 455481) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 249
('6', 248, 1, 2, 455524) justice, goodness and truth will continue to be divine.” 1 One may conclude from this that the moral law is supreme and divine.
('6', 248, 1, 3, 455652) Such a law no people or individual can violate to the end of time.
('6', 248, 1, 4, 455719) As has been said, even as the dangerous storm ultimately passes, immoral men must meet their destruction.
('6', 248, 2, 5, 455825) No sooner did the cup of sin in Assyria and Babylon become full than it broke.
('6', 248, 2, 6, 455904) When Rome trod the path of immorality, none of her great men could save her.
('6', 248, 2, 7, 455981) The ancient Greeks were an accom plished people, still all their art and philosophy could not continue in their immorality for long.
('6', 248, 2, 8, 456114) The French Revolution was but an insurrec tion against immorality.
('6', 248, 2, 9, 456181) The same was the case with America.
('6', 248, 2, 10, 456217) The good Wendell Phillips used to say that immorality even if enthroned will not endure.
('6', 248, 2, 11, 456306) This mysterious moral law brings prosperity to the man who observes it: it sustains the family that obeys it, and the community which lives by it ever flourishes.
('6', 248, 2, 12, 456469) Freedom, peace and happiness are the lot of the nation that lets itself be ruled by this highest law.
('6', 248, 3, 13, 456571) [From Gujarati]
('6', 248, 4, 14, 456587) Indian Opinion, 26 1 1907
('6', 248, 5, 15, 456613) 1 ...justice, good, and truth were still Divine, if, by some demon's will, Hatred and wrong had been proclaimed Law through the worlds, and right misnamed.

('6', 255, 5, 16, 468839) 240. INDIANS IN THE TRANSVAAL
('6', 255, 6, 17, 468869) We invite the attention of every Indian to the speech by Sir Richard Solomon translated into Gujarati by our Johannesburg correspondent.
('6', 255, 6, 18, 469006) 1 When Sir Richard makes a public speech, we should know that it is not for electioneering purposes only.
('6', 255, 6, 19, 469112) He has just returned from England.
('6', 255, 6, 20, 469147) He has met officials in the Colonial Office in London, and he is a favourite of theirs.
('6', 255, 6, 21, 469235) Through him, the Liberal Government desires to unite the Dutch and the English.
('6', 255, 6, 22, 469315) It is necessary, therefore, to look upon whatever Sir Richard says at this juncture as important.
('6', 255, 6, 23, 469413) Sir Richard says that the Asiatic Ordinance will have to be reintroduced in the new parliament, and that the Imperial Government will not reject an act passed by it.
('6', 255, 6, 24, 469579) Not only would Sir Richard have such a law passed, but, according to his line of thinking, no new Indian should beallowed to enter and settle in the Transvaal.
('6', 255, 6, 25, 469739) Sir Richard does not therefore like the Natal or the Cape immigration laws.
('6', 255, 6, 26, 469815) He would have the Orange River Colony law 2 enacted in the Transvaal.
('6', 255, 6, 27, 469885) This means that, if the reins of government were to pass into the hands of Sir Richard, Indians would face very hard times indeed.
('6', 255, 6, 28, 470016) What are we to do in this situation?
('6', 255, 6, 29, 470053) We have only one answer.
('6', 255, 6, 30, 470078) We have hailed the refusal of assent to the Asiatic Ordinance as a victory.
('6', 255, 6, 31, 470154) But true victory will come only when we show our strength.
('6', 255, 7, 32, 470213) 1 Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 2 2 1907. 2 Under the law an Indian could enter the Orange River Colony “only as a domestic servant”.
('6', 256, 0, 1, 470345) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 257
('6', 256, 1, 2, 470388) certain that the Asiatic Ordinance will be re introduced.
('6', 256, 1, 3, 470446) When that happens, there should be only one thought in the mind of every Indian: never to accept such a law.
('6', 256, 1, 4, 470555) And, if it is enforced, he will rather go to gaol than carry a pass like a Kaffir.
('6', 256, 1, 5, 470638) True victory will be won only when the entire Indian community courageously marches to the gaol—when the time comes—and stays there as if it were a palace.

('6', 257, 0, 1, 472186) 258 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 257, 1, 2, 472228) 243. NAUSEA
('6', 257, 2, 3, 472240) Generally speaking, every person has an aversion to something or the other.
('6', 257, 2, 4, 472316) To some the sight of blood or pus is nauseating, to others the smell of kerosene.
('6', 257, 2, 5, 472398) Similarly, an Englishman is averse to certain things.
('6', 257, 2, 6, 472452) Of these aversions some are desirable, but others are carried too far.
('6', 257, 2, 7, 472523) None the less, it is a fact that people do have these aversions.
('6', 257, 2, 8, 472588) Trivial as some of these may seem, we should know what they are.
('6', 257, 2, 9, 472653) It often happens that, starting from trifles, people go on to big quarrels.
('6', 257, 2, 10, 472729) Because of trifles the whites sometimes cause havoc.
('6', 257, 2, 11, 472782) We know of an instance in which a white man kicked an Indian simply because the latter happened to break wind.
('6', 257, 2, 12, 472893) Once Mr. Miller, a Magistrate of the Amlazi Court, was so sickened at the sight of an Indian witness hiccuping that he could stand it no longer and asked the Indian to stop.
('6', 257, 2, 13, 473067) Once an Indian and some Europeans were at dinner table.
('6', 257, 2, 14, 473123) During the meal the Indian started belching.
('6', 257, 2, 15, 473168) An English lady at the table almost fainted and could not eat at all that day.
('6', 257, 2, 16, 473247) We can see from these instances how necessary it is for us always to show consideration for the feelings of others.
('6', 257, 2, 17, 473363) Also, while we live in this country, we should so behave that the whites’ prejudices against us are weakened.
('6', 257, 2, 18, 473473) With this end in view, we list below some of the causes of their prejudice and appeal to all Indians to overcome them.
('6', 257, 3, 19, 473592) SOME DON’TS
('6', 257, 4, 20, 473604) 1. Avoid, as far as possible, blowing your nose or spitting on swept or paved walks or in the presence of others.
('6', 257, 5, 21, 473718) On hygienic grounds also, this rule is worth observing.
('6', 257, 5, 22, 473774) Doctors say that sometimes serious diseases are caused by contact with the nasal or oral discharge of another.
('6', 257, 5, 23, 473885) Dr. Murison has said that we often spread tuberculosis through our habit of spitting anywhere.
('6', 257, 5, 24, 473980) Both these things should be done into a spittoon while at home, and into a handkerchief while out, and, as far as possible, in privacy.
('6', 257, 6, 25, 474116) 2. One should not belch, hiccup, break wind, or scratch oneself in the presence of others.
('6', 257, 7, 26, 474207) These [maxims] are useful for correct social behaviour.
('6', 257, 7, 27, 474263) By practice one can learn to check one’s instinct to do any of these things.
('6', 257, 8, 28, 474340) 3. If you want to cough, do so holding your handkerchief
('6', 258, 0, 1, 474397) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 259
('6', 258, 1, 2, 474440) against the mouth.
('6', 258, 2, 3, 474459) If one’s spittle gets blown on to others, it annoys them and if one has any disease, the spittle carries it to them.
('6', 258, 3, 4, 474576) 4. Even after a bath, in many men, some dirt remains in the ears or under the nails.
('6', 258, 3, 5, 474661) It is necessary to pare one’s nails and keep them as well as the ears clean.
('6', 258, 4, 6, 474738) 5. Those who do not grow a regular beard should, if necessary, shave every day.
('6', 258, 4, 7, 474818) An unshaven face is a sign of laziness or stinginess.
('6', 258, 5, 8, 474872) 6. One should not let mucus accumulate in the corners of the eyes.
('6', 258, 5, 9, 474939) One who allows this to happen is considered slothful and a sleepyhead.
('6', 258, 6, 10, 475010) 7. Every act of cleaning the body should be done in privacy.
('6', 258, 7, 11, 475071) 8. The turban or cap and the shoes should be clean.
('6', 258, 7, 12, 475123) The life of the shoes is prolonged by cleaning and polishing.
('6', 258, 8, 13, 475185) 9. Those who chew betel leaf and nut should do so at fixed hours, as with other kinds of food so as to avoid giving the impression that we are eating all the time.
('6', 258, 8, 14, 475349) Those who chew tobacco have a lot to think about.
('6', 258, 8, 15, 475399) They disfigure every spot by spitting.
('6', 258, 8, 16, 475438) Addicts to tobacco, as the Gujarati proverb goes, spoil the corner of the house where they chew tobacco, the whole house if they smoke and their clothes if they take snuff.
('6', 258, 9, 17, 475611) These are rules for personal cleanliness.
('6', 258, 9, 18, 475653) Later we shall write of those relating to the home and its environs.
('6', 258, 10, 19, 475722) [From Gujarati]
('6', 258, 11, 20, 475738) Indian Opinion, 2 2 1907
('6', 258, 12, 21, 475763) 244. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('6', 258, 13, 22, 475788) SIR RICHARD SOLOMON’S SPEECH
('6', 258, 14, 23, 475817) I have already written of Sir Richard Solomon’s election speech 1
('6', 258, 15, 24, 475883) at Pretoria on January 21 and said I would give, in translation, his ideas on Coloured persons.
('6', 258, 15, 25, 475979) I do so today.
('6', 258, 16, 26, 475994) 1 Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 26 1 1907 and “Indians in the Transvaal”, 2 2 1907.
('6', 259, 0, 1, 476076) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 259, 1, 2, 476118) ASIATIC ORDINANCE Now I come to the question of Asiatics, which is related to that of the Kaffirs.
('6', 259, 1, 3, 476217) Most of the Asiatics in this territory are Indians who have entered lawfully and secured their rights in a similar fashion.
('6', 259, 1, 4, 476341) There are also those who have entered by breaking the law.
('6', 259, 1, 5, 476400) Let them be punished for that.
('6', 259, 1, 6, 476431) (Applause.) But the lawful immigrants are entitled to justice as well as to recognition, and they should get them.
('6', 259, 1, 7, 476546) They should not be deprived of rights lawfully acquired.
('6', 259, 1, 8, 476603) It is therefore necessary to maintain a complete register of the lawful immigrants.
('6', 259, 1, 9, 476687) Moreover registration is necessary not only to protect the interests of those who are here by virtue of their legal right, but also to prevent the immigration of those who may in future be prohibited.
('6', 259, 1, 10, 476888) With this end in view a law was passed by the Legislative Council, but it failed to receive the assent of the Imperial Government, as the Indian community raised unreasonable objections to it.
('6', 259, 1, 11, 477081) This is quite understandable for the Imperial Government has a great responsibility in relation to India.
('6', 259, 1, 12, 477187) As long, therefore, as the reins of power in this Colony are in the hands of the Imperial Government, it is clear that they will not assent to such an act.
('6', 259, 2, 13, 477343) “PASS LAW AGAIN”
('6', 259, 3, 14, 477360) But we can [now] pass a law similar to the previous one.
('6', 259, 3, 15, 477417) I am sure the Imperial Government will give their consent to a similar bill passed by a self governing colony.
('6', 259, 4, 16, 477528) OTHER ACTS
('6', 259, 5, 17, 477539) Some may ask what should be done about Indian immigration in the future.
('6', 259, 5, 18, 477612) The English traders in this Colony hold that the Indians, who have a different way of life and who enter into unfair competition with them, should be prohibited from entering and trading in the Transvaal.
('6', 259, 5, 19, 477817) They are afraid that they will be ruined by the immigration of such men.
('6', 259, 5, 20, 477890) I sympathize with this line of thinking.
('6', 259, 5, 21, 477931) Hence I believe that the parliament of this Colony should, as early as possible, enact a measure to restrict Indian immigration.
('6', 259, 5, 22, 478060) The model for such a law is to be had in the Cape or Natal.
('6', 259, 6, 23, 478120) ARE NOT CAPE AND NATAL LAWS ENOUGH?
('6', 259, 7, 24, 478156) I have given much thought to this question; and I think
('6', 260, 0, 1, 478212) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 261
('6', 260, 1, 2, 478255) that, if we adopt the laws of the Cape Colony and Natal, the immigration of ordinary coolies will discontinue, but the immigration of those whom you really wish to keep out, namely, the traders, will not stop.
('6', 260, 1, 3, 478465) If, therefore, we adopt the Cape or the Natal Act, we shall have to add to it the further provision that the immigrant Asiatic cannot carry on trade.
('6', 260, 2, 4, 478615) SIR RICHARD’S REMEDY
('6', 260, 3, 5, 478636) I wish to speak frankly on this question.
('6', 260, 3, 6, 478678) Personally I would prefer it that Indians were not allowed to come into the Colony at all.
('6', 260, 3, 7, 478769) A concession may be made in favour of only those coming on a short visit.
('6', 260, 3, 8, 478843) It is much better not to allow any Indians to come in rather than allow them in and then to suppress them, leading to a clash between the local and the Imperial Governments.
('6', 260, 3, 9, 479017) I am therefore of the view that we should pass an act similar to the one in force in the Orange River Colony.
('6', 260, 3, 10, 479127) It was enacted before the Boer War and the Imperial Government did not oppose it.
('6', 260, 3, 11, 479209) In passing the measure we should provide for the continued stay of lawful immigrants and the protection of the rights acquired by them.
('6', 260, 4, 12, 479345) JOHANNESBURG CHAMBER OF COMMERCE
('6', 260, 5, 13, 479378) The Johannesburg Chamber has issued a statement giving the causes of the starvation now prevalent in Johannesburg.
('6', 260, 5, 14, 479493) Competition from the Indian trader is mentioned as one of them.
('6', 260, 5, 15, 479557) In his speech 1 a few months ago, Mr. Quinn had shown that it was no use blaming the Indian trader.
('6', 260, 5, 16, 479657) But the Chamber’s sole business at present is to rouse public opinion against Indians as much as possible.
('6', 260, 6, 17, 479764) INDIANS GOING TO DELAGOA BAY
('6', 260, 7, 18, 479793) News having been received of the ill treatment of Indians going from the Transvaal to Delagoa Bay, an inquiry was made of the Portuguese Consul.
('6', 260, 7, 19, 479938) In his reply he says that no further disability has been imposed; that, if any regulations were framed recently, they have not been published in the Gazette, and that an Indian going from the Transvaal has no difficulty.
('6', 260, 7, 20, 480159) The hardship brought to our notice was that Indians from the Transvaal were detained at the border if they did
('6', 260, 8, 21, 480270) 1 Vide “Quinn's Speech”, 12 1 1907 and “Johannesburg Letter”, 12 1 1907. There is, however; no reference to this point made by Quinn in Gandhiji's summaries of his speech.
('6', 261, 0, 1, 480442) 262 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 261, 1, 2, 480484) not hold a pass for Delagoa Bay similar to the Natal pass.
('6', 261, 1, 3, 480543) Further correspondence with the Consul is going on, and another detailed letter from him is expected.
('6', 261, 2, 4, 480645) EAST INDIA ASSOCIATION
('6', 261, 3, 5, 480668) The Transvaal Leader today publishes a cable from England reporting the annual meeting of the East India Association presided over by Sir Raymond West.
('6', 261, 3, 6, 480820) A speaker at the meeting pointed out that Indians suffered no hardships in places like Jamaica, because the whites there belonged to good families and were respectable people.
('6', 261, 3, 7, 480996) In those places a considerable income could be earned by good, capable Indians, free from any bad habits.
('6', 261, 3, 8, 481102) Commenting on this, Sir Raymond West said that there could be no comparison between Jamaica and South Africa, for the whites in South Africa were hostile to the Indians because they suffered from Indian competition.
('6', 261, 3, 9, 481318) Sir Raymond concluded by saying that one of the remedies for Indian hardships in South Africa was that every Indian should receive adequate education.
('6', 261, 3, 10, 481469) Sir Raymond means to suggest that, if we are educated, the displeasure of the whites may lessen, for in that case we should be copying their way of life.
('6', 261, 4, 11, 481623) [From Gujarati]
('6', 261, 5, 12, 481639) Indian Opinion, 2 2 1907
('6', 261, 6, 13, 481664) 245. ETHICAL RELIGION–V
('6', 261, 7, 14, 481688) CHAPTER V: MORALITY AS A RELIGION
('6', 261, 8, 15, 481722) The subject of this chapter may strike one as strange.
('6', 261, 8, 16, 481777) The common idea is that morality and religion are distinct things; still this chapter seeks to consider morality as a religion.
('6', 261, 8, 17, 481905) Some readers may think the writer guilty of confusion.
('6', 261, 8, 18, 481960) That reproach may come from two sides— from those who regard religion as more than morality, and from others who think that, where there is morality, there is no need for religion.
('6', 261, 8, 19, 482141) Yet the author’s intention is to show their close relationship.
('6', 261, 8, 20, 482205) The societies spreading ethical religion or religious ethics believe in religion through morality.
('6', 261, 8, 21, 482304) The common idea, it may be admitted, is that there may be morality without religion and religion without morality.
('6', 261, 8, 22, 482419) One comes across many men of immoral conduct who claim to be religious in
('6', 262, 0, 1, 482493) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 263
('6', 262, 1, 2, 482536) spite of the sinful acts they commit.
('6', 262, 1, 3, 482574) On the other hand, there are moral men like the late Mr. Bradlaugh, who are proud to call themselves atheists and would run away from the name of religion.
('6', 262, 1, 4, 482730) Those who hold either of these views are mistaken.
('6', 262, 1, 5, 482781) Those who hold the first view are not only mistaken, but also dangerous as they practise immorality under the guise of religion.
('6', 262, 1, 6, 482910) In this chapter, there fore, we shall show that, considered intellectually and scientifically, religion and morality are united and should be so united.
('6', 262, 1, 7, 483063) Morality was in the beginning simply the customary conduct of a community, settled ways of acting that men living together naturally fell into.
('6', 262, 1, 8, 483207) By a natural process the good customs tended to survive and the bad ones to die out, since, if the bad ones did not die out, they would weaken the community and lead to its extinction.
('6', 262, 1, 9, 483392) Even today we see this process at work.
('6', 262, 1, 10, 483432) It is neither morality nor religion if people observe good customs more or less unthinkingly.
('6', 262, 1, 11, 483526) However, most of what passes for morality in the world today consists, as pointed out above, of good customs.
('6', 262, 1, 12, 483636) Moreover, men often have a merely superficial idea of religion.
('6', 262, 1, 13, 483700) Sometimes men believe in religion only as a means to ward off dangers that threaten them.
('6', 262, 1, 14, 483790) It would be a mistake to dignify actions as religious where they are performed out of a love that springs from fear.
('6', 262, 1, 15, 483907) But at long last a time does come when men begin to tread the path of morality consciously, deliberately with a determined will, regardless of gain or loss, of life or death, without turning to look back, ready to sacrifice themselves.
('6', 262, 1, 16, 484143) Then can they be said to have been permeated with true morality.
('6', 262, 1, 17, 484208) How can such morality subsist except with the support of religion?
('6', 262, 1, 18, 484275) One tells oneself, “If by doing a little harm to another, I can secure my personal interest, why should I not do that little harm?” The profit derived from doing harm is no profit, but a positive loss [to the doer].
('6', 262, 1, 19, 484491) How shall this unpalatable dose go down one’s throat?
('6', 262, 1, 20, 484545) Ostensibly in Germany’s interest, Bismarck perpetrated dreadful deeds.
('6', 262, 1, 21, 484616) Where then was his education?
('6', 262, 1, 22, 484646) Where did those maxims of morality disappear which, at other times, he used to mouth before school children?
('6', 262, 1, 23, 484755) Obviously, a reply to all these questions can be given.
('6', 262, 1, 24, 484811) The reason why he could not keep up his morality in the face of these difficulties was that his morality was not grounded in religion.
('6', 262, 1, 25, 484946) So long as the seed of morality is not watered by religion, it cannot
('6', 263, 0, 1, 485016) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 263, 1, 2, 485058) sprout.
('6', 263, 1, 3, 485066) Without water it withers and ultimately perishes.
('6', 263, 1, 4, 485116) Thus it will be seen that true or ideal morality ought to include true religion.
('6', 263, 1, 5, 485197) To put the same thought differently, morality cannot be observed without religion.
('6', 263, 1, 6, 485280) That is to say, morality should be observed as a religion.
('6', 263, 1, 7, 485339) Furthermore, it is seen that the rules of morality, laid down in the world’s great religions, are largely the same.
('6', 263, 1, 8, 485455) The founders of thereligions have also explained that morality is the basis of religion.
('6', 263, 1, 9, 485544) If a foundation is removed, the superstructure falls to the ground; similarly if morality is destroyed, religion which is built on it comes crashing down.
('6', 263, 1, 10, 485699) The author adds that there is nothing wrong in calling morality a religion.
('6', 263, 1, 11, 485775) Dr. Coit in his prayer says, “I shall have no other God except righteousness.” On reflection, we shall realize that God will not help us and answer our impassioned prayer for help, if we utter His name, while having a dagger concealed under our arm.
('6', 263, 1, 12, 486025) Let us take two men, one who believes in the existence of God, yet breaks all His Commandments; and another who, though not acknowledging God by name, worships Him through his deeds and obeys His laws, recognizing in the divine laws, their Maker.
('6', 263, 1, 13, 486272) Which of the two men shall we call a man of religion and morality?
('6', 263, 1, 14, 486339) Without a moment’s thought, one would emphatically reply that the second man alone is to be considered religious and moral.

('6', 266, 1, 2, 490730) 248. ETHICAL RELIGION–VI
('6', 266, 2, 3, 490755) [Before February 5, 1907] 1
('6', 266, 3, 4, 490783) CHAPTER VI: RELIGIOUS MORALITY OR MORAL RELIGION
('6', 266, 4, 5, 490832) DARWIN’S VIEWS ON ETHICS
('6', 266, 5, 6, 490857) Before summarizing this chapter, it is necessary to give an account first of Darwin himself.
('6', 266, 5, 7, 490950) Darwin was a great Englishman of the last century who made great scientific discoveries.
('6', 266, 5, 8, 491039) His memory andhis power of observation were amazing.
('6', 266, 5, 9, 491092) He has written some books which deserve to be read and pondered.
('6', 266, 5, 10, 491157) With a mass of evidence and arguments, he has shown how man came into being; how he has evolved from a particular kind of monkey.
('6', 266, 5, 11, 491287) After a large number of experiments and much sifting of evidence, he realized that there was not much difference between the anatomy of man and that of the ape.
('6', 266, 5, 12, 491448) Whether this conclusion is correct or not has not much to do with ethics.
('6', 266, 5, 13, 491522) Besides this, Darwin has also shown how ideas of morality affect mankind.
('6', 266, 5, 14, 491596) And as many scholars have faith in Darwin’s writings, our author has dealt with his views in Chapter VI.
('6', 266, 6, 15, 491701) CHAPTER VI
('6', 266, 7, 16, 491712) It is noble voluntarily to do what is good and right.
('6', 266, 7, 17, 491766) The true sign of man’s nobility is the fact that, instead of being driven about like a cloud before the wind, he stands firm and can do, and in fact does, what he deems proper.
('6', 266, 7, 18, 491943) Nevertheless, we ought to know the direction in which our environment disposes our instincts.
('6', 266, 7, 19, 492037) We know that we are not in every way masters of our own life; there are conditions outside of us to which we have to adjust ourselves.
('6', 266, 7, 20, 492172) For instance, in a country where Himalayan cold prevails, we have to put on adequate clothing, whether we like it or not, in order to keep the body warm.
('6', 266, 7, 21, 492326) That is, we have to act with prudence.
('6', 266, 7, 22, 492365) The question now arises: does the influence of environment lead us to be moral?
('6', 266, 7, 23, 492445) Or can it be that the forces that surround us are indifferent to morality?
('6', 266, 7, 24, 492520) At this point it becomes necessary to consider Darwin’s views.
('6', 266, 7, 25, 492583) Though Darwin did not write as a moral philosopher, he has shown
('6', 266, 8, 26, 492648) 1 Vide the following item.
('6', 267, 0, 1, 492675) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 267, 1, 2, 492717) how close the connection is between morality and environment.
('6', 267, 1, 3, 492779) Those who think that morality is unimportant and that physical strength and mental capacity are the only things that matter should read Darwin.
('6', 267, 1, 4, 492923) According to him, there is an instinct of self preservation in men as in other creatures.
('6', 267, 1, 5, 493013) He also says that those who survive the struggle for existence may be regarded as successful, that is, those who are unfit tend to extinction, but that the issue of the struggle does not depend on mere physical force.
('6', 267, 1, 6, 493231) Comparing man with the bear or the buffalo, we find that, in physical strength, the bear and the buffalo are superior to him; in a tussle he will surely be worsted.
('6', 267, 1, 7, 493396) Nonetheless he is their superior by virtue of his intelligence.
('6', 267, 1, 8, 493460) Similarly we can compare different races of men.
('6', 267, 1, 9, 493509) In war it is not the side with the largest numbers or with the hardiest soldiers that wins, but the side with the ablest generals and the best strategy, though its soldiers may be fewer or less hardy.
('6', 267, 1, 10, 493710) In these examples we see the superiority of intelligence.
('6', 267, 1, 11, 493768) But Darwin shows further that moral strength is even superior to physical and intellectual strength; and we can see in various ways thata man who has moral qualities lasts longer than one who is devoid of them.
('6', 267, 1, 12, 493979) Some hold that Darwin taught that strength is enough; that is, those who are physically strong ultimately survive.
('6', 267, 1, 13, 494094) Superficial thinkers may believe that morality is of no use.
('6', 267, 1, 14, 494155) But this is not Darwin’s view at all.
('6', 267, 1, 15, 494193) We find from the evidence of the early history of man that races without morality have completely disappeared.
('6', 267, 1, 16, 494304) The people of Sodom and Gomorrah were extremely immoral and they are now therefore completely extinct.
('6', 267, 1, 17, 494407) We can see even today how races without morality are steadily declining.
('6', 267, 1, 18, 494480) Let us now take some simple illustrations and see how at least common morality is necessary for sustaining the human race.
('6', 267, 1, 19, 494603) A peaceful disposition is one element of morality.
('6', 267, 1, 20, 494654) At first sight it may appear that people with a violent disposition rise in life; but a little reflection will show that, when the sword of violence falls, it may be on one’s own neck.
('6', 267, 1, 21, 494839) Freedom from bad habits forms another element of morality.
('6', 267, 1, 22, 494898) Statistics have proved that, at the age of thirty, intemperate persons in England are not likely to live beyond another thirteen or fourteen years, while the teetotaller’s expectation of life is seventy years.
('6', 267, 1, 23, 495108) Yet another element of morality is chastity.
('6', 267, 1, 24, 495153) Darwin has shown that profligate persons die early.
('6', 267, 1, 25, 495205) They have no children, or if they have any, they are weak.
('6', 267, 1, 26, 495264) The profligate become feeble of mind, and
('6', 268, 0, 1, 495306) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 269
('6', 268, 1, 2, 495349) in course of time look like idiots.
('6', 268, 1, 3, 495385) If we consider the morals of various communities, we find the same state of affairs.
('6', 268, 1, 4, 495470) Among the Andaman islanders the husband looks after his wife only until their child is weaned and begins to move about, and he then abandons her.
('6', 268, 1, 5, 495616) That is, they do not have the quality of altruism, and utter selfishness prevails.
('6', 268, 1, 6, 495699) The result is that the race is gradually dying out.
('6', 268, 1, 7, 495751) Darwin shows that the altruistic instinct is present, to some extent, even in animals: timid birds display strength in defending their young.
('6', 268, 1, 8, 495893) This shows that, if there had been no selflessness among animals, we should have in the world scarcely any life other than grass and poisonous flora.
('6', 268, 1, 9, 496043) The main distinction between man and other animals is that man is more selfless than the animals.
('6', 268, 1, 10, 496141) He has sacrificed his life for others in proportion to his strength, that is, for his offspring, for his family, his community and his country.
('6', 268, 1, 11, 496285) Darwin clearly shows that moral strength is supreme.
('6', 268, 1, 12, 496338) The ancient Greeks had greater intelligence than the Europeans of today, but when the former gave up morality, their intelligence became their enemy, and no trace of them remains today.
('6', 268, 1, 13, 496524) Nations are sustained neither by wealth nor by armies, but by righteousness alone.
('6', 268, 1, 14, 496607) It is the duty of man to bear this truth in mind and practise altruism, which is the highest form of morality.
('6', 268, 2, 15, 496718) [From Gujarati]

('6', 269, 4, 14, 498306) 250. LETTER TO TOWN CLERK
('6', 269, 5, 15, 498332) JOHANNESBURG, February 6, 1907
('6', 269, 7, 16, 498363) THE TOWN CLERK P. O. BOX 1047 JOHANNESBURG
('6', 269, 9, 17, 498406) The Committee of the British Indian Association has seen the draft of the by laws for licensing and regulating Asiatic tea rooms or eating houses.
('6', 269, 9, 18, 498553) My Committee respectfully submits the following for
('6', 269, 10, 19, 498605) 1 This address was presented on February 6, 1907 and the function reported in Indian Opinion, 9 2 1907.
('6', 270, 0, 1, 498709) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 271
('6', 270, 1, 2, 498752) the Council’s consideration, in connection with the by laws.
('6', 270, 1, 3, 498813) It appears that the necessity for the by laws has arisen on account of the large, indentured Chinese population and the catering for that population which has been undertaken by various persons.
('6', 270, 1, 4, 499008) But, under the definition of the term, “Asiatic tea room or eating house” is evidently included any place where Asiatics are catered for, and it would, therefore, include the small British Indian restaurants which are conducted in Johannesburg.
('6', 270, 1, 5, 499253) They are very few, and have very few visitors, the British Indian population being all permanently resident, and not requiring any houses for feeding it.
('6', 270, 1, 6, 499407) My Committee, therefore, ventures to suggest that the definition should not include those of British Indians.
('6', 270, 1, 7, 499517) At the same time, my Committee has no desire to protect the few small British Indian restaurants in Johannesburg from inspection with regard to sanitation, etc., but, in the humble opinion of my Committee, the ordinary public health by laws are sufficient for the purpose.
('6', 270, 1, 8, 499790) In the humble opinion of my Committee, the procedure laid down for making application for a tea room or an eating house licence is cumbersome and costly, and could only be justified if there were large remunerative establishments.
('6', 270, 1, 9, 500021) The fee fixed for the annual licence, too, in my Committee’s humble opinion, is almost prohibitive, and is greater than the fee charged for either European restaurants or Kaffir eating houses, the fee for the former being £7.10.0 only and for the latter £5. Moreover, the definition of an “Asiatic eating house” includes a tea room.
('6', 270, 1, 10, 500354) Therefore, whilst a general tea room carries with it a licence of £3, an Asiatic tea room will require a licence fee of £10; and the fee of £2 for transfer of licences is, in my Committee’s humble opinion, a heavy charge.
('6', 270, 1, 11, 500576) My Committee, therefore, ventures to trust that the Town Council will be pleased to favourably consider the objections herein raised to the proposed by laws.
('6', 270, 2, 12, 500734) I have the honour to be,
('6', 270, 4, 13, 500759) Your obedient servant,

('6', 279, 4, 9, 518126) 257. THE DEFEAT OF “THE ADVERTISER”'1
('6', 279, 5, 10, 518164) The meeting of Indian leaders with the editor of The Natal Advertiser has yielded good results.
('6', 279, 5, 11, 518260) The Natal Advertiser has written at length pointing out the fancied contradictions between our writings, the work done by Messrs Gandhi and Ally and the facts as stated by the leaders of the Indian community.
('6', 279, 5, 12, 518469) It has further pointed out that even men like Sir Lepel Griffin are prepared to grant all rights to Indians and to allow any number of them to emigrate to South Africa.
('6', 279, 5, 13, 518638) It is obvious that all this writing is of no value whatever.
('6', 279, 5, 14, 518699) But instead of acknowledging its defeat, The Advertiser has tried to keep up the facade.
('6', 279, 5, 15, 518788) Leaving aside The Advertiser article under review, it is easy to see that the paper holds the view that big traders should have no difficulties, that problems arising from the Immigration Act should be solved and a just attitude adopted towards the Indian community.
('6', 279, 5, 16, 519055) If The Advertiser continues this policy, both the newspapers of Durban will, it may reasonably be expected, be somewhat friendly to the Indian community and not attack it outright.
('6', 279, 5, 17, 519236) Much good can result if a similar arrangement can be arrived at with the Maritzburg papers also.
('6', 279, 6, 18, 519333) 1 A deputation of leading Durban Indians met the editor of The Natal Advertiser following a critical editorial by the paper on the Imperial Government's reaction to the British Indian Deputation.
('6', 279, 6, 19, 519529) This was, however, followed by a more conciliatory article addressed to Indians and entitled “A True Agitation and a False”, which said, “Let us, at all events, understand one another.”

('6', 282, 1, 2, 523894) 260. ETHICAL RELIGION–VII
('6', 282, 2, 3, 523920) CHAPTER VII: SOCIAL IDEAL
('6', 282, 3, 4, 523946) t is sometimes said that all morality involves social relations.
('6', 282, 4, 5, 524011) This is well said; for instance, if the judge has a proper sense of justice, men who go to court obtain satisfaction.
('6', 282, 4, 6, 524129) Similarly love, kindness, generosity and other qualities can be manifested only in relation to others.
('6', 282, 4, 7, 524232) The force of loyalty can be demonstrated only in our relations with one another.
('6', 282, 4, 8, 524313) Of patriotism, nothing need be said.
('6', 282, 4, 9, 524350) Truly speaking, there is no aspect of morality the benefit of which accrues to the practitioner alone.
('6', 282, 4, 10, 524453) Sometimes it is said that truthfulness and other virtues have nothing to do with the other person and are entirely personal.
('6', 282, 4, 11, 524578) But we must admit that by telling the truth we prevent harm to another, just as by telling a lie and deceiving a person we do him an injury.
('6', 282, 5, 12, 524719) In the same way, when a man disapproves of certain laws or
('6', 282, 6, 13, 524778) customs and withdraws from society, even then his acts affect society.
('6', 282, 6, 14, 524849) Such a man lives in a world of ideals.
('6', 282, 6, 15, 524888) He does not worry that the world of his ideals is not yet born.
('6', 282, 6, 16, 524952) For him the mere thought that the prevailing standard is not good enough is sufficient to impel him to resist it.
('6', 282, 6, 17, 525066) He will constantly try to change other people’s way of life to his own.
('6', 282, 6, 18, 525138) This is how prophets have caused the world’s wheels to change their course.
('6', 282, 7, 19, 525214) So long as man remains selfish and does not care for the hap 
('6', 282, 8, 20, 525276) piness of others, he is no better than an animal and perhaps worse.
('6', 282, 8, 21, 525344) His superiority to the animal is seen only when we find him caring for his family.
('6', 282, 8, 22, 525427) He is still more human, that is, much higher than the animal, when he extends his concept of the family to include his country or community as well.
('6', 282, 8, 23, 525576) He climbs still higher in the scale when he comes to regard the human race as his family.
('6', 282, 8, 24, 525666) A man is an animal or imperfect [as a human being] to the extent that he falls behind in his service to humanity.
('6', 282, 8, 25, 525780) If I feel my wife’s injury or that of my community, yet have no sympathy for anyone outside the circle, it is clear that I do not have any feeling for humanity as such; but I have, simply out of selfishness or a sense of discrimination, a certain feeling for my wife, my children or the community which I hold as my own.
('6', 282, 9, 26, 526101) That is to say, we have neither practised nor known ethical
('6', 282, 10, 27, 526161) religion so long as we do not feel sympathy for every human being.
('6', 282, 10, 28, 526228) Now we know that the higher morality must be comprehensive; it must embrace all men.
('6', 282, 10, 29, 526313) Considering our relation to mankind, every man has a claim over us, as it is our duty always to serve him.
('6', 282, 10, 30, 526420) We should act on
('6', 283, 0, 1, 526437) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 283, 1, 2, 526479) the assumption that we have no claim on others.
('6', 283, 1, 3, 526527) He is merely ignorant who would here argue that the man acting in this manner will be trampled in the world’s scramble.
('6', 283, 1, 4, 526647) For it is a universal experience that God always saves the man who whole heartedly devotes himself to the service of others.
('6', 283, 1, 5, 526772) According to this moral standard all men are equal.
('6', 283, 1, 6, 526824) This is not to be interpreted to mean equality of position and function for all.
('6', 283, 1, 7, 526905) It only means that, if I hold a high place, I also have the ability to shoulder its duties and responsibilities.
('6', 283, 1, 8, 527018) I should not therefore lose my head and believe that men with smaller responsibilities are my inferiors.
('6', 283, 1, 9, 527123) Equality depends on the state of our mind, and until our mind reaches that state, we shall remain backward.
('6', 283, 1, 10, 527231) According to this moral standard no nation can rule another for selfish ends.
('6', 283, 1, 11, 527309) It is immoral of the American people to reduce the aborigines to an inferior status and run the government.
('6', 283, 1, 12, 527417) A civilized race coming into contact with a savage one owes it to the latter to raise it to its own level.
('6', 283, 1, 13, 527524) The same standard rules that the king is the servant and not the master of his people and that the officers are not there to enjoy power but to make the people happy.
('6', 283, 1, 14, 527691) If the people in a democratic state are selfish, that state comes to no good.
('6', 283, 1, 15, 527769) Moreover, according to this law, the stronger members of a state or community have to protect, not oppress, the weaker ones.
('6', 283, 1, 16, 527894) Under such a government there can be no starvation; nor can there be excessive accumulation of riches; for we can never be happy while we see our neighbours languishing in misery.
('6', 283, 1, 17, 528074) The man following this high moral standard will never amass wealth.
('6', 283, 1, 18, 528142) He who would be moral need not be scared away by the thought that few follow this ideal morality; for he is master of his morality, not of its results.
('6', 283, 1, 19, 528294) He will be considered guilty if he does not practise morality; but nobody will find fault with him if his immoral behaviour has no consequences for society.
('6', 283, 1, 20, 528451) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 16 2 1907
('6', 283, 2, 21, 528493) 261. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('6', 283, 3, 22, 528518) NEW PARLIAMENT There has been a great deal of hustle over the new parliament of the Transvaal, which is to have 58 members, 38 of whom will represent the Johannesburg area.
('6', 283, 3, 23, 528691) The nominations of candidates were filed on Saturday, the 9th.
('6', 283, 3, 24, 528754) This issue of Indian Opinion will be in the hands of readers by the 16th or the 18th.
('6', 283, 3, 25, 528840) The election will take place on
('6', 284, 0, 1, 528872) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 285
('6', 284, 1, 2, 528916) Wednesday, the 20th.
('6', 284, 1, 3, 528937) The names of successful candidates will be known on the 21st.
('6', 284, 1, 4, 528999) It is therefore hoped that these names will be available to our readers in the next issue.
('6', 284, 1, 5, 529090) THE PARTIES In all there are five parties: Progressive (i.e.
('6', 284, 1, 6, 529151) mine owners), Hetvolk, (i.e., the Dutch), Nationalist, Independent, and Labour.
('6', 284, 1, 7, 529231) Only two of these are parties in the real sense.
('6', 284, 1, 8, 529280) The Nationalist Party, it may be said, has been formed for those who might be scared by the names, Progressive and Hetvolk.
('6', 284, 1, 9, 529404) It is widely believed that the Hetvolk and Nationalist Parties will fare well and that, between them, they will secure a majority of the seats.
('6', 284, 1, 10, 529548) Many look upon the Progressive Party with disfavour.
('6', 284, 1, 11, 529601) The leaders of the Hetvolks are General Botha and General Smuts, those of the Nationalists Sir Richard Solomon and Mr. Wyburg and of the Progressives Sir Percy Fitzpatrick, Sir George Farrar, Mr. Hosken, etc.
('6', 284, 1, 12, 529810) and others.
('6', 284, 1, 13, 529822) The real tussle that is going on is between Sir Richard Solomon and Sir Percy Fitzpatrick.
('6', 284, 1, 14, 529913) They are both candidates from Pretoria.
('6', 284, 1, 15, 529953) It is difficult to say which of the two will win.
('6', 284, 1, 16, 530003) Sir Richard’s views about the Chinese and theKaffirs havingundergone a change, he is being looked upon by many with scorn.
('6', 284, 1, 17, 530126) He was ready to bring the Chinese into the Colony, but now says that his views in the matter have changed.
('6', 284, 1, 18, 530233) Formerly, he used to say that the Kaffirs should get their legitimate rights; now he would approve whatever the other members propose to do about them.
('6', 284, 1, 19, 530385) An analysis shows that there are 35 Hetvolk, 29 Progressive, 32 Independent, 15 Nationalist and 12 Labour candidates.
('6', 284, 1, 20, 530503) Five of the Hetvolk candidates have already been elected unopposed.
('6', 284, 1, 21, 530571) The Indian community, it appears, stands neither to lose nor to gain whichever party comes to power, for members of both the parties have already expressed themselves against the Indians.
('6', 284, 1, 22, 530759) PERMIT OFFICE An article has been published in The Transvaal Advertiser which clearly appears to have been inspired by the Permit Office.
('6', 284, 1, 23, 530897) It says that the Indian community causes the Permit Office much trouble, that the failure of the Ordinance to receive assent has increased the work of that office, that Indians enter without permits from hundreds of places, that they bring in their children without permits and employ them in the stores, and that the decisions of the Supreme Court have moreover created numerous obstacles in the working of the existing law.
('6', 284, 1, 24, 531323) The Advertiser has thus tried to incite the people so as to ensure in advance that the new parliament passes the Ordinance again.
('6', 285, 0, 1, 531453) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 285, 1, 2, 531495) The statements are obviously false.
('6', 285, 1, 3, 531531) Instead of the Permit Office being put to trouble, it is that office which gives trouble.
('6', 285, 1, 4, 531621) The hardships caused by the law are increasing instead of decreasing; and the Supreme Court steps in only when the Permit Office transgresses all limits.
('6', 285, 1, 5, 531775) It is not enough that we know all this.
('6', 285, 1, 6, 531815) Knowing this, we ought to adopt remedies for these ills.
('6', 285, 1, 7, 531872) The measures that need to be taken have already been indicated in Indian Opinion.
('6', 285, 1, 8, 531954) But the greatest, the ultimate, remedy is going to gaol; and so long as that is not forg otten, no harm can befall [us].
('6', 285, 1, 9, 532075) The adoption of this remedy will also require a good deal of money.
('6', 285, 1, 10, 532143) The British Indian Association and all other bodies should take quick and effective measures in this regard.
('6', 285, 1, 11, 532252) MIDDELBURG LOCATION News has now been received from Middelburg about the Location there.
('6', 285, 1, 12, 532341) Acting on it, the Association has written to the Town Clerk asking him why the notices have been issued.
('6', 285, 1, 13, 532446) Further action in the matter will be taken after a reply has been received.
('6', 285, 1, 14, 532522) COOVADIA’S CASE Mr. Coovadia, a well known merchant of Johannesburg, who is the Treasurer of the British Indian Association, was on his way to Johannesburg with his 16 year old son.
('6', 285, 1, 15, 532704) The boy was forced to detrain at Volksrust because he did not have a permit.
('6', 285, 1, 16, 532781) Earlier when a permit was applied for, it was refused, and Captain Fowle had given the assurance that there would be no difficulty at all.
('6', 285, 1, 17, 532920) Though Mr. Coovadia had this letter with him, the boy was nevertheless asked to detrain.Medical evidence indicated that the boy was eighteen years old, whereupon the Magistrate refused to release him.
('6', 285, 1, 18, 533121) A written representation was made to Mr. Chamney who declined to intervene.
('6', 285, 1, 19, 533197) Last Monday, the case came up for hearing at Volksrust, when the Magistrate refused to send it up to Johannes burg for recording evidence.
('6', 285, 1, 20, 533336) It will now therefore be heard next Monday.
('6', 285, 1, 21, 533380) In the end, of course, the boy will be let off.
('6', 285, 1, 22, 533428) But think of the trouble and expense Mr. Coovadia will have to go through before obtaining justice in such a trifling matter!
('6', 285, 1, 23, 533554) When a permit was applied for, it was said that it could not be issuedas the boy was under sixteen.
('6', 285, 1, 24, 533654) 1 And for want of a permit one has to undergo all this expense.
('6', 285, 1, 25, 533718) When a well known man has to suffer these hardships, what about the poor?
('6', 285, 2, 26, 533792) 1 The original reads: “If a permit had been applied for, it would have been said that it could not be given as the boy was under sixteen years.” Gandhiji, however, mentions earlier that a perrnit was in fact refused.

('6', 287, 0, 1, 535869) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 287, 1, 2, 535911) 263. WHEN WOMEN ARE MANLY, WILL MEN BE EFFEMINATE?
('6', 287, 2, 3, 535962) This question is suggested by some cablegrams received from England last week.
('6', 287, 2, 4, 536041) While English women do manly deeds, shall we, though men, behave like women?
('6', 287, 2, 5, 536118) This is no matter for fun, but a grave one indeed.
('6', 287, 2, 6, 536169) Let us see how.
('6', 287, 2, 7, 536185) The women of England have no franchise.
('6', 287, 2, 8, 536225) They are fighting for it without minding people’s ridicule.
('6', 287, 2, 9, 536285) A few days ago a procession of eight hundred women marched to the Houses of Parliament.
('6', 287, 2, 10, 536373) then the police stopped the crowd, some brave women tried to force their way into the House.
('6', 287, 2, 11, 536466) These women do not belong to the working class.
('6', 287, 2, 12, 536514) One of them is a sister of General French 1, and over Sixty years old.
('6', 287, 2, 13, 536585) Another, Miss Pankhurst, is the daughter of a well known wealthy Englishman.
('6', 287, 2, 14, 536662) Both are women of learning.
('6', 287, 2, 15, 536690) There were many such women in this crowd of eight hundred.
('6', 287, 2, 16, 536749) Of those who forced their way in, prominent ladies like General French’s sister were arrested andprosecuted.
('6', 287, 2, 17, 536858) The Magistrate sentenced them to fines ranging from £1 to £2, or to imprisonment for varying periods.
('6', 287, 2, 18, 536960) Such sentences have been passed on 49 women, and each one of them, instead of paying up the pittance of a fine, has courted imprisonment.
('6', 287, 2, 19, 537098) The aged sister of General French is also among them.
('6', 287, 2, 20, 537152) We believe these women have behaved in a manly way.
('6', 287, 2, 21, 537204) Now let us look at our own house.
('6', 287, 2, 22, 537238) Lord Selborne and Sir Richard Solomon say that the Asiatic Ordinance should be [re ]enacted.
('6', 287, 2, 23, 537331) Perhaps that will be done in a month or two.
('6', 287, 2, 24, 537376) Will Indians go to gaol if that happens?
('6', 287, 2, 25, 537417) We think men cry for fear of imprisonment when they are caught while using a false permit, but not while committing the offence.
('6', 287, 2, 26, 537546) This we regard as unmanly.
('6', 287, 2, 27, 537573) Now when people are wrongfully treated as criminals and asked to give their finger prints, will they quietly give them or will they go to gaol?
('6', 287, 2, 28, 537717) If they give their finger prints and suffer dishonour, we shall regard them as doubly unmanly.
('6', 287, 2, 29, 537812) Hence we ask: will Indian men be effeminate?
('6', 287, 2, 30, 537857) Or will they emulate the manliness shown by English women and.
('6', 287, 2, 31, 537920) wake up?
('6', 287, 2, 32, 537929) Will they choose to find happiness in prison taking it to be a palace, or will they submit to oppression when the Transvaal Government starts it?
('6', 287, 2, 33, 538075) In a few days our mettle will be tested.
('6', 287, 3, 34, 538116) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 23 2 1907
('6', 287, 4, 35, 538158) 1 Field Marshal Sir John French, (1852 1925); served in the South African War and was later Commander in Chief of British Forces in France during World WarI.
('6', 288, 0, 1, 538316) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 289
('6', 288, 1, 2, 538360) 264. LADYSMITH LICENCES
('6', 288, 2, 3, 538384) To return to the subject of the Ladysmith licences, we should examine how much of the blame lies with us.
('6', 288, 2, 4, 538490) We have repeatedly written on this matter in our English columns.
('6', 288, 2, 5, 538556) A question has been asked in the House of Commons on the subject at the instance of the [South Africa British Indian] Committee, but it would be better if we made a search nearer home.
('6', 288, 2, 6, 538741) It came out in the course of the judgement on the appeal that the account books had been written up newly or only occasionally and were got written by a man for an annual fee of £8. The Natal Witness has severely criticized these practices and approved the action of the Ladysmith Board.
('6', 288, 2, 7, 539029) We must think over all this.
('6', 288, 2, 8, 539058) It is essential to maintain regular accounts.
('6', 288, 2, 9, 539104) It is unnecessary for every trader to employ a separate accountant; what is necessary is that the accounts must be written up regularly so that no one can say a word against them.
('6', 288, 2, 10, 539284) It is also possible to have the accounts written by an English accountant or through a lawyer, where a competent Indian accountant is not available.
('6', 288, 2, 11, 539433) We shall never succeed unless we give up some of our stingy ways.
('6', 288, 3, 12, 539499) [From Gujarati]
('6', 288, 4, 13, 539515) Indian Opinion, 23 2 1907
('6', 288, 5, 14, 539541) 265. CAPE IMMIGRATION ACT Cables have appeared in the Press saying that the [Imperial] Government have assented to the new Cape Immigration Act and that it will soon come into force.
('6', 288, 5, 15, 539724) The main difference is that, while formerly all Indians anywhere in South Africa were allowed to enter the Cape, now only the old Indian residents will be allowed in.
('6', 288, 5, 16, 539891) There are other changes besides.
('6', 288, 5, 17, 539924) We believe that the remissness of the Cape Indian leaders is partly responsible for these changes.
('6', 288, 5, 18, 540023) It was quite likely that, even if there had been a strenuous struggle, the Indians would have lost the case, but then we would at least have done our duty.
('6', 288, 5, 19, 540179) Again, for a struggle, the Cape offers advantages not found elsewhere.
('6', 288, 5, 20, 540250) But the Cape Indians do not avail themselves of these advantages.

('6', 290, 1, 2, 542203) 268. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('6', 290, 2, 3, 542228) FIVE PERMIT CASES
('6', 290, 3, 4, 542246) The case of Mr. Coovadia’s son was heard by the Magistrate of Volksrust on Friday the 15th.
('6', 290, 3, 5, 542338) 1 Mr. Gandhi appeared for Mr. Coovadia.
('6', 290, 3, 6, 542378) Giving Evidence, Constable MacGregor stated that boys under fourteen were allowed to enter without a permit, that permits were demanded of boys of fourteen and over, and that if they failed to produce them, they were arrested.
('6', 290, 4, 7, 542605) Mr. James Codie deposed that one could not say that Captain Fowle’s decisions were always acceptable to the present Registrar.
('6', 290, 4, 8, 542732) On being shown Captain Fowle’s letter about Mr. Coovadia’s son, he stated that the letter could not be treated as a permit and Mr. Chamney would not consider it as binding.
('6', 290, 4, 9, 542905) On being severely cross examined, he admitted that Mr. Chamney should accept every thing that had been done by Captain Fowle as Permit Officer.
('6', 290, 4, 10, 543049) Mr. Amod Saleji Coovadia 2 giving evidence about his nephew’s age said that he was a student at Johannesburg in 1903. Mr. Coovadia corroborated this testimony.
('6', 290, 4, 11, 543209) Dr. Hick gave evidence about the boy’s age, and Mrs Gandhi produced Captain Fowle’s letters that were with him.
('6', 290, 4, 12, 543321) The boy himself gave evidence to show that he had some knowledge of English.
('6', 290, 4, 13, 543398) Here the hearing [of the evidence] was over.
('6', 290, 4, 14, 543443) The Magistrate then heard the arguments on both sides and acquitted the boy.
('6', 290, 5, 15, 543520) After this the cases of four Indians were heard.
('6', 290, 5, 16, 543569) They were alleged to have entered with other people’s permits.
('6', 290, 5, 17, 543632) Their names were Kika Parsad, Naga Bhana, Ambu Vallabh Soni and Mirzakhan.
('6', 290, 5, 18, 543707) Three of them admitted that they had bought permits from others in Bombay on payment of Rs. 90 for each.
('6', 290, 5, 19, 543812) The fourth man pleaded not guilty.
('6', 290, 5, 20, 543847) All the four were sentenced to a fine of £40 or four month’s imprisonment.
('6', 290, 6, 21, 543922) Mr. Coovadia’s case shows that persons with genuine case sometimes obtain justice, after spending a lot of money.
('6', 290, 6, 22, 544036) This is so mainly because of the false cases that are taken to the courts.
('6', 290, 6, 23, 544111) It can be
('6', 290, 7, 24, 544121) 1 Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 16 2 1907.
('6', 290, 8, 25, 544162) 2 Brother of Ebrahim Saleji Coovadia

('6', 291, 1, 2, 544241) seen from the four cases heard on the same day that those who sell permits only get people into trouble by practising deceit and fraud.

('6', 291, 1, 4, 544482) By such deeds they do harm to the whole community and are responsible for the enactment of rigorous laws.
('6', 291, 2, 5, 544588) ASIATIC BLUE BOOK
('6', 291, 3, 6, 544606) Lord Elgin has published in England the complete history of the Asiatic Ordinance.
('6', 291, 3, 7, 544689) Long cables about it have been received by all the three newspapers here.
('6', 291, 3, 8, 544763) Among these, Lord Selborne’s statement, in particular, deserves to be noted by the Indian community.
('6', 291, 3, 9, 544864) He severely criticizes Lord Elgin’s decision.
('6', 291, 3, 10, 544910) He says that, in granting the Indian plea, Lord Elgin has broken [Lord Selborne’s] promise which he had made at Potchefstroom about not allowing fresh Indian immigrants till responsible government had been set up.
('6', 291, 3, 11, 545124) This complaint of His Excellency is unjustified.
('6', 291, 3, 12, 545173) For, the immigration of new Indians apart, even old residents have difficulty in re entering the Colony and, if they succeed at all, it is after many months.
('6', 291, 3, 13, 545331) He says further that many Indians continue to enter without permits.
('6', 291, 3, 14, 545400) Even this statement should be regarded as improper, as the Indian community has repeatedly suggested to Lord Selborne the appointment of an inquiry commission to substantiate this.
('6', 291, 3, 15, 545581) Lord Seiborne’s bitter remarks only show one thing: the Indian community has to put up a fight not merely against the Whites, but also against the Governor himself who, instead of remaining impartial, has turned against the Indians.
