('6', 292, 0, 1, 546286) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 293
('6', 292, 1, 2, 546330) 269. ETHICAL RELIGION–VIII
('6', 292, 2, 3, 546357) CHAPTER VIII: PERSONAL MORALITY
('6', 292, 3, 4, 546389) ‘I am responsible for this,’ or ‘This is my duty’: this is a moving and wonderful thought.
('6', 292, 3, 5, 546480) A mysterious, resounding voice seems to say, ‘To thee, individually, O man, is given this task.
('6', 292, 3, 6, 546576) Whether defeat or victory, both belong to thee.
('6', 292, 3, 7, 546624) Thou art what no one else in the world is, for nowhere has nature created two similar objects.
('6', 292, 3, 8, 546719) Thou hast a duty which no one else in the world can do, and if thou dost not do it that loss will stand debited to thee in the world’s balance sheet.’ ‘What is that duty I owe to myself?’ Someone may quote the verse:
('6', 292, 4, 9, 546936) Call not man God, for man is not God,
('6', 292, 5, 10, 546974) Yet man is not distinct from God’s glory,
('6', 292, 6, 11, 547016) And answer, ‘My duty is to rest secure in the belief that I am a ray of God’s light.’ Another may answer that the duty is to have sympathy and fraternal regard for others.
('6', 292, 6, 12, 547188) A third may answer that it is to revere parents, care for one’s wife and children, and acquit oneself well with brother, sister or friend.
('6', 292, 6, 13, 547327) Alongside of all these virtues, it is also a part of my duty to respect myself even as I respect others.
('6', 292, 6, 14, 547432) As long as I do not understand myself, how shall I understand others?
('6', 292, 6, 15, 547502) And how shall I respect one whom I do not know?
('6', 292, 6, 16, 547550) Many hold the view that the obligation of proper conduct arises [only] in relation to others and that, in the absence of contact with others, one may do just as one pleases.
('6', 292, 6, 17, 547724) He who holds this view does not know what he says.
('6', 292, 6, 18, 547775) In this world none can, with impunity, act as he pleases.
('6', 292, 6, 19, 547833) Let us now see what our duty is to ourselves.
('6', 292, 6, 20, 547879) Let us take, first, our private habits which are unknown to all but ourselves.
('6', 292, 6, 21, 547958) We are responsible for them since they affect our character; but this is not all.
('6', 292, 6, 22, 548040) We are responsible for them also because they affect others.
('6', 292, 6, 23, 548101) Every person ought to control his own impulses, and keep his soul as well as body clean.
('6', 292, 6, 24, 548190) ‘Tell me,’ says a great man, ‘what a man’s private habits are and I shall tell you what he is or will be’.
('6', 292, 6, 25, 548297) We should therefore control all our appetites, so that we do not drink or eat to excess.
('6', 292, 6, 26, 548386) Else we shall lose our strength and our good name.
('6', 292, 6, 27, 548437) Worldly success never comes to him who does not abstain from sensual pleasures and does
('6', 293, 0, 1, 548525) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 293, 1, 2, 548567) not thus save his body, mind, intellect and soul.
('6', 293, 1, 3, 548617) Arguing along these lines and keeping one’s instincts pure, one should further consider how to put them to use.
('6', 293, 1, 4, 548729) One ought to have a fixed aim in life.
('6', 293, 1, 5, 548768) If we do not discover our life’s purpose, and keep steadily to the course, we shall be swept along like a rudderless ship on the high seas; we shall falter on the [moral] path.
('6', 293, 1, 6, 548945) Man’s highest duty in life is to serve mankind and take his share in bettering its condition.
('6', 293, 1, 7, 549039) This is true worship—true prayer.
('6', 293, 1, 8, 549073) He is a godly man who does God’s work.
('6', 293, 1, 9, 549112) Hypocrites and cheats going about invoking God’s name are legion.
('6', 293, 1, 10, 549178) Because a parrot utters the name of God, no one would call it godly.
('6', 293, 1, 11, 549247) Contribution to an ideal order of human life is something everyone can aim at.
('6', 293, 1, 12, 549326) With this aim in view the mother may legitima tely rear her child, the lawyer may pursue his profession, the merchant may carry on his business or trade and the working man may labour.
('6', 293, 1, 13, 549511) A person with that fixed aim would never deviate from the path of morality, for if he did, he could not fulfil his aim of uplifting mankind.
('6', 293, 1, 14, 549652) Let us consider the matter in some detail.
('6', 293, 1, 15, 549695) We ought constantly to examine whether our way of life tends to improve human life or to worsen it.
('6', 293, 1, 16, 549795) Thus the merchant should ask himself whether, in transacting a business, he is cheating himself or another.
('6', 293, 1, 17, 549903) The lawyer and the physician, acting according to this standard, will give more thought to their client or patient than to their fees.
('6', 293, 1, 18, 550038) The mother in rearing her child would proceed very cautiously lest she should spoil the child out of misguided love or some selfish interest.
('6', 293, 1, 19, 550180) The worker too would be guided by these considerations and do his duty.
('6', 293, 1, 20, 550252) The result of all this would be that, if the worker fulfils his function in conformity with the moral ideal, he would be deemed better and higher than the wealthy merchant, physician or lawyer who lives without any discipline.
('6', 293, 1, 21, 550479) The worker would be the true coin and those selfish men, even though more intelligent or wealthy, would be counterfeit.
('6', 293, 1, 22, 550599) This further shows that any man, whatever his place in life, has the power to fulfil this aim.
('6', 293, 1, 23, 550694) A man’s value depends upon his way of life, not his status.
('6', 293, 1, 24, 550754) One’s way of life is not to be judged by one’s visible outward actions, but by one’s inner leanings.
('6', 293, 1, 25, 550855) For instance, if of two men, one gives a dollar to a poor person to rid himself of his presence and the other half a dollar but with love and out of compassion for the man, obviously, the one who gave half a dollar is
('6', 294, 0, 1, 551073) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 295
('6', 294, 1, 2, 551117) truly moral, while the other who gave a dollar, the sinner.
('6', 294, 1, 3, 551177) To sum up, he alone is religious, he alone is happy and he alone is wealthy, who is sincere in himself, bears no malice, exploits no one and always acts with a pure mind.
('6', 294, 1, 4, 551348) Such men alone can serve mankind.
('6', 294, 1, 5, 551382) How can a damp matchstick kindle a log of wood?
('6', 294, 1, 6, 551430) How can a man who does rot practise morality teach it to another?
('6', 294, 1, 7, 551496) How can a sinking man save another from drowning?
('6', 294, 1, 8, 551546) The man who lives a moral life never raises the question as to how to serve the world, for he is never in doubt.
('6', 294, 1, 9, 551659) Mathew Arnold says of a friend:
('6', 294, 2, 10, 551691) I saw him sensitive in frame,
('6', 294, 3, 11, 551721) I knew his spirits low,
('6', 294, 4, 12, 551745) And wished him health, success, and fame—
('6', 294, 5, 13, 551787) I do not wish it now.
('6', 294, 6, 14, 551809) For these are all their own reward,
('6', 294, 7, 15, 551845) And leave no good behind:
('6', 294, 8, 16, 551871) They try us—oftenest make us hard,
('6', 294, 9, 17, 551906) Less modest, pure, and kind.
('6', 294, 10, 18, 551935) Time was when Arnold wished his friend health, success and fame.
('6', 294, 10, 19, 552000) But he did not so wish now, because his friend’s happiness or misery did not depend on their presence or absence; he therefore only wished that his morality might ever endure.
('6', 294, 10, 20, 552176) Emerson says, “Adversity is the prosperity of the great.” Both the money and the fame belonging to the base are a misery to them and to the world.

('6', 298, 2, 6, 559218) In this matter, The Natal Mercury has commented strongly in our favour.

('6', 298, 2, 12, 559548) 1 He had a very anxious time before he got his licence.
('6', 298, 2, 13, 559604) And then, it was not out of a sense of justice that the Town Council gave it to him; but under pressure.
('6', 298, 2, 14, 559709) For, as soon as the case of Mr. Goga’s licence concluded, there came up the case of a poor Indian, Benne by name.

('6', 298, 2, 25, 560648) The Congress is working hard.

('6', 299, 1, 2, 561352) 273. CAPE IMMIGRATION ACT
('6', 299, 2, 3, 561378) A new Immigration Act has been passed in the Cape, which, in our opinion, is much worse than the one in Natal.
('6', 299, 2, 4, 561489) For the present, we reproduce here only its worst features.
('6', 299, 2, 5, 561549) If an Indian not knowing English leaves the Cape without a permit, he cannot return even if he has been a resident.
('6', 299, 2, 6, 561665) That means that an Indian who does not know English will have to take out a permit each time he goes out and pay a fee of £1. Such a permit will be issued for a limited period only.
('6', 299, 2, 7, 561847) One cannot therefore have a permanent certificate.
('6', 299, 2, 8, 561898) Moreover, according to the Gezette in which the Act is published, a person applying for such a certificate will have to produce his photograph and other tokens of identity.
('6', 299, 2, 9, 562071) The clause requiring a permit is not relaxable because it is a part of the Act, and the Act has already received the assent of Lord Elgin.
('6', 299, 2, 10, 562210) The matter of the photograph, however, falls within the discretion of the Governor.
('6', 299, 2, 11, 562294) It is a local regulation, which can be amended from time to time.
('6', 299, 2, 12, 562360) We would advise the leaders of the Cape to fight out the question of the photograph without losing time.
('6', 299, 2, 13, 562465) It was a mistake that they allowed the Act to be passed in the first place.
('6', 299, 2, 14, 562541) But we will regard it as a major crime if the clause requiring a photograph remains.
('6', 299, 2, 15, 562626) If this practice is established in the Cape, it will have repercussions elsewhere, and offend religious sentiment.
('6', 299, 2, 16, 562741) We hope the leaders of the Cape will lose no time in taking up this matter.
('6', 299, 2, 17, 562817) We print elsewhere a translation of the main portions of the Act.

('6', 301, 1, 2, 565075) 276. VREDEDORP ORDINANCE
('6', 301, 2, 3, 565100) We publish in this issue some photographs bearing on the Ordnance.
('6', 301, 2, 4, 565167) They will show that what Mr. Churchill has described as shanties are not shanties at all but magnificent buildings.
('6', 301, 2, 5, 565283) It was necessary to bring out this supplement [of photographs] because with these we could convince Lord Elgin that all the information sent to him from here should not be accepted as true.
('6', 301, 2, 6, 565473) Especially when the information relates to the Indians, it is hardly ever likely to be true, because the European officials here are found to share the anti Indian prejudices that the other Whites have.
('6', 301, 2, 7, 565676) Lord Selborne may have no knowledge of the condition of Indian houses in Vrededorp, and we cannot therefore blame him.
('6', 301, 2, 8, 565795) It is the officers below who do all the harm.
('6', 301, 2, 9, 565841) In this issue we also publish a table which will show that the loss suffered by the Indian community in Vrededorp amounts to £19,000. The table will lend much support to the agitation being conducted in London that Indians should be compensated for this loss.

('6', 301, 5, 12, 566142) 277. NEW IMMIGRATION ACT IN THE CAPE
('6', 301, 6, 13, 566179) The new Immigration Act was published in the Cape Government Gazette of February 15. The following is a translation of the clauses relating to Indians:
('6', 301, 7, 14, 566331) PROHIBITED IMMIGRANTS
('6', 301, 8, 15, 566353) A person coming under any of the clauses below will be considered a “prohibited immigrant” and will not be allowed to enter: (1) a person who is unable, owing to insufficient education, to write out and sign, in the characters of any European language, an application to the satisfaction of the [Immigration] Officer; (2) a person who has no means of livelihood; (3) a person convicted of
('6', 302, 0, 1, 566742) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 303
('6', 302, 1, 2, 566786) he abo ve cla uses wil l not , how ever, app ly to the fol lowin g imm igran ts: ( I ) a per son who has ren dered sat isfac tory ser vice in [Hi s Maj esty’s] vol untar y for ces; (2) the wif e, and child under the age of ixteen years, of any person eligible to immigrate into the Colony; (3) persons born in South Africa and persons of European birth domiciled in South Africa; (4) any Asiatic lawfully resident in the Colony and returning to it in accordance with the terms and conditions of a permit taken and authorizing him to be absent temporarily.
('6', 302, 1, 3, 567342) EXAMINATION ON LANDING Every person landing at any port in the Colony shall be required to satisfy the Immigration Officer that he is not a prohibited immigrant and that he is exempted from the provisions of the Act.
('6', 302, 1, 4, 567559) Under this regulation every one who lands in the Cape Colony, save a minor under sixteen and a wife accompanying her husband, will have to fill in a printed form.
('6', 302, 1, 5, 567722) Those who do not fill in this form or those who, notwithstanding their having filled it in, are found to be [prohibited] immigrants, shall be liable to detention.
('6', 302, 1, 6, 567885) However, if a person wants to prove his right of landing, he will be given every reasonable facility to do so.
('6', 302, 1, 7, 567996) TEMPORARY PERMITS Temporary permits will be issued to those who wish to enter in order to tranship or to reside temporarily in it for a reasonably necessary purpose on payment of a fee of £1 and of a reasonable sum to be deposited as security.
('6', 302, 1, 8, 568240) The deposit shall bc refunded to the holder of the permit if he returns within the period for which the permit is issued.
('6', 302, 1, 9, 568362) However, if a permit holder overstays, he will forfeit his deposit and he may be arrested and prosecuted.
('6', 302, 1, 10, 568468) Any permit holder who gives a false or misleading address shall be liable to forfeit his permit and to prosecution.
('6', 302, 1, 11, 568584) The Chief Immigration Officer will have the power to issue a permit for three weeks and the Minister concerned the power to issue one for three months.
('6', 302, 1, 12, 568736) PHOTOGRAPHIC PERMITS Asiatics lawfully resident in the Colony can take out these permits.
('6', 302, 1, 13, 568826) The period for which they are available and the port at which the holder shall disembark on return to the Colony will be stated in these permits.
('6', 302, 1, 14, 568972) A fee of £1 will be charged for a permit; every permit shall contain a photograph of the holder and such particulars and marks as may be necessary for purposes of identification.

('6', 303, 0, 1, 569192) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 303, 1, 2, 569234) 278. HIS MAJESTY AMIR HABIBULLAH AT ALIGARH COLLEGE
('6', 303, 2, 3, 569286) His Majesty the Amir visited Aligarh College on January 16, and he was welcomed with great honours.
('6', 303, 2, 4, 569386) We give here a translation from The Times of India of his address to the students of that College on the occasion.
('6', 303, 3, 5, 569501) SHIYA AND SUNNI
('6', 303, 4, 6, 569517) You are young.
('6', 303, 4, 7, 569532) Please listen to me.
('6', 303, 4, 8, 569553) Some people may have told you that I am a fanatic Sunni.
('6', 303, 4, 9, 569610) But does it mean that because I am a Sunni I am a fanatic?
('6', 303, 4, 10, 569669) I shall ask you a question: Will those of you who are Shiyas show greater regard to Hindus than to Sunnis?
('6', 303, 4, 11, 569776) Will you then believe that I, who am a Sunni, will prefer Hindus to Shiyas?
('6', 303, 4, 12, 569852) You must have read in the newspapers that, on Bakr Id, I prevented the killing of cows in Delhi lest it should hurt the feelings of Hindus.
('6', 303, 4, 13, 569992) If such is my regard for the Hindus, do you believe that I shall have less for the Shiyas?
('6', 303, 4, 14, 570083) I beg of you to give up from today the notion that I am a fanatic Sunni.
('6', 303, 4, 15, 570156) In Afghanistan my subjects include sunnis, Shiyas, Hindus and Jews.
('6', 303, 4, 16, 570224) I allow them all full religious freedom.
('6', 303, 4, 17, 570265) Do you call this fanaticism?
('6', 303, 4, 18, 570294) But one thing I must say: I cannot allow Shiyas to show disrespect to the three Khalifas.
('6', 303, 4, 19, 570384) If people think it fanatical of me to prevent Shiyas from showing such disrespect, well, I am a fanatic.
('6', 303, 5, 20, 570489) EDUCATION
('6', 303, 6, 21, 570499) Many people have spoken against the Aligarh College.
('6', 303, 6, 22, 570552) I have therefore come to find out the truth for myself.
('6', 303, 6, 23, 570608) I am thankful to the Government of India for letting Muslims assemble in such numbers to meet me and for giving me this opportunity to address you.
('6', 303, 6, 24, 570756) When I questioned the students of Aligarh College today, I was glad to find them well informed on religious matters.
('6', 303, 6, 25, 570873) I shall therefore be able to silence those who have been speaking against the College.
('6', 303, 7, 26, 570960) WESTERN EDUCATION
('6', 303, 8, 27, 570978) I would never say that you should not receive western education.
('6', 303, 8, 28, 571043) On the contrary, I would advise you—and I would say this twice
('6', 304, 0, 1, 571106) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 305
('6', 304, 1, 2, 571150) over—to exert yourselves to the utmost to receive that education.
('6', 304, 1, 3, 571216) But before you do that you must have education in Islam.
('6', 304, 1, 4, 571273) I have started the Habibia College in Afghanistan.
('6', 304, 1, 5, 571324) There I have allowed western education to be imparted in order that the students may grow up to be whole Muslims.
('6', 304, 1, 6, 571438) I found the students whom I examined today to be very well educated in religion.
('6', 304, 2, 7, 571519) DONATION TO COLLEGE
('6', 304, 3, 8, 571539) I am very sorry that, in view of the heavy expenditure I have to incur on education in my own country, I cannot help the Aligarh College as much as I should like to.
('6', 304, 3, 9, 571705) For the present, I shall give the College Rs. 500 every month.
('6', 304, 3, 10, 571768) It is my advice that those whom I examined today should be sent abroad for extensive travel.
('6', 304, 3, 11, 571861) They will prove successful in the future.
('6', 304, 3, 12, 571903) In addition to the Rs. 500 a month, I now donate Rs. 20,000 to the College.
('6', 304, 4, 13, 571979) WELCOME AT GWALIOR
('6', 304, 5, 14, 571998) After being honoured at Aligarh College His Majesty the Amir went to Gwalior where he was received with much pomp and ceremony.
('6', 304, 5, 15, 572126) He was Maharaja Scindia’s guest and stayed in his palace.

('6', 308, 5, 19, 578510) 283. “ULTRA VIRES”
('6', 308, 6, 20, 578529) In the Natal Government Gazette for the 19th February last is published a notice which requires appellants under the Dealers’ Licenses Act to deposit a sum of £12.10.0 to cover the travelling expenses of the members of the Board of Council sitting as a Court of Appeal.
('6', 308, 6, 21, 578799) As it is the unfortunate Indians who have to appeal as a rule, or rather go through the farce of an appeal, this fresh imposition makes their lot harder still and makes attainment of justice prohibitive.
('6', 308, 6, 22, 579003) We are perilously near to being asked next time to pay the travelling expenses of judges.
('6', 308, 6, 23, 579093) The rule, however, it seems to us, is clearly ultra vires.
('6', 308, 6, 24, 579152) The section which authorizes the Government to frame
('6', 308, 7, 25, 579205) 1 Here, in the original, part of a line is missing.
('6', 309, 0, 1, 579257) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 309, 1, 2, 579299) regulations empowers them to regulate procedure and to create fresh burdens of an arbitrary nature.
('6', 309, 1, 3, 579399) We trust the Natal Indian Congress will promptly protest against this rule 1 and in the meanwhile we can safely say that appellants need not deposit the sum required under the notice in question.
('6', 309, 1, 4, 579595) Indeed, if we are correctly informed in the recent appeals no such deposits were required or made.
('6', 309, 2, 5, 579694) Indian Opinion, 9 3 1907
('6', 309, 3, 6, 579719) 284. THOSE FINGER IMPRESSIONS
('6', 309, 4, 7, 579749) Our Johannesburg correspondent draws attention to a very serious state of affairs, if true.
('6', 309, 4, 8, 579841) It appears that, in spite of the disallowance or suspension of the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance, the Asiatic Department has been proceeding as if the Ordinance had been allowed.
('6', 309, 4, 9, 580022) It appears that the authorities have been inspecting permits and registration certificates held by British Indians, and at the same time, taking their ten finger prints.
('6', 309, 4, 10, 580192) There appears to be no justification for this high handed action.
('6', 309, 4, 11, 580258) We have nothing to say against the examination of permits and registration certificates— indeed, we consider it to be a proper thing, and the only remedy for weeding out of the Colony those British Indians or Asiatics who may have entered it without permits.
('6', 309, 4, 12, 580517) But examination is one thing, and, under its cover, to call upon British Indians to give their finger impressions distinctly another.
('6', 309, 4, 13, 580651) The British Indians have consented to give their thumb prints as a matter of grace and conciliation.
('6', 309, 4, 14, 580752) The authorities should be satisfied therewith.
('6', 309, 4, 15, 580799) Mr. Henry has shown that thumb prints are, when properly taken, an invaluable test of identification.
('6', 309, 4, 16, 580901) It is, therefore, a gratuitous insult to offer to the community to take their finger impressions.
('6', 309, 4, 17, 580999) We congratulate the British Indian Association on having moved so promptly in the matter.
('6', 309, 4, 18, 581089) Our correspondent informs us also that the British Indian Association has circularized all the sub committees warning them
('6', 309, 5, 19, 581212) 1 The Congress wrote to the Colonial Secretary requesting the withdrawal of the notice but the request was not acceded to.
('6', 309, 5, 20, 581335) Vide “The Dealers' Licenses Act”, 30 3 1907.
('6', 310, 0, 1, 581380) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 311
('6', 310, 1, 2, 581424) against giving finger impressions, and informing them that there is absolutely no law justifying such a degrading procedure.

('6', 310, 3, 4, 581574) 285. LETTER TO “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER”
('6', 310, 4, 5, 581612) [JOHANNESBURG, March 9, 1907]
('6', 310, 5, 6, 581642) [TO THE EDITOR
('6', 310, 6, 7, 581657) THE TRANSVAAL LEADER JOHANNESBURG
('6', 310, 7, 8, 581691) SIR,] Your leading article entitled “Who Rules This Colony?” appearing in today’s issue contains a strange series of illogical inferences drawn from an analysis of the Blue book recently published on the British Indian question in the Transvaal.
('6', 310, 7, 9, 581937) One of these specially needs refutation.
('6', 310, 7, 10, 581978) You state that those British Indians who are here should not be indiscriminately admitted to those political rights and privileges they do not enjoy in their own country.
('6', 310, 7, 11, 582149) My Association has several times pointed out in your columns that the British Indian community of the Transvaal has no intention whatever of claiming, and in fact does not claim, any political rights and privileges at all in this Colony.
('6', 310, 7, 12, 582387) British Indians simply demand the most elementary of civil rights, which is an entirely different matter.
('6', 310, 7, 13, 582493) I trust that you will take an early opportunity of correcting the mis statement of facts above referred to.
('6', 310, 8, 14, 582601) [I am, etc., ABDUL GANI CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION] Indian Opinion, 16 3 1907
('6', 310, 9, 15, 582689) 1 For the substance of the circular, however, Vide “Telegram to Registrar of Asiatics”, 5 3 1907.
('6', 311, 0, 1, 582787) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 311, 1, 2, 582829) 286. ENGLISH LIBERALITY
('6', 311, 2, 3, 582853) We have often had to write about the oppression we suffer at the hands of Englishmen.
('6', 311, 2, 4, 582939) We are very glad now to have an occasion for speaking well of them while thinking of the coming restoration of Dutch rule in the Transvaal.
('6', 311, 2, 5, 583079) The defeat of the Dutch in the war proved English tenacity.
('6', 311, 2, 6, 583139) The British, even when thrown flat on the ground, do not accept defeat, call it a virtue or a failing.
('6', 311, 2, 7, 583242) Once the war started, they alone knew how to win it.
('6', 311, 2, 8, 583295) The British saw, during the war, that the Dutch were not a people to be easily beaten; they too would not accept defeat.
('6', 311, 2, 9, 583416) In defeat, the Dutch had truly won.
('6', 311, 2, 10, 583452) Had they not been just a handful, they could never have been defeated.
('6', 311, 2, 11, 583523) That was the impression they made on the British.
('6', 311, 2, 12, 583573) Moreover, the British were shrewd enough to see that, in declaring war on the Dutch, they were themselves mainly at fault.
('6', 311, 2, 13, 583696) The party which had declared and fought the war was defeated at the last election.
('6', 311, 2, 14, 583779) The Liberals won and they decided to hand over the reins of Government to the Dutch.
('6', 311, 2, 15, 583864) As a result, General Botha and his colleagues have formed the Transvaal Ministry.
('6', 311, 2, 16, 583946) Though they are now British subjects in the Transvaal, they are quite free.
('6', 311, 2, 17, 584022) They will now be able to take into the public services as many Dutchmen as they wish.
('6', 311, 2, 18, 584108) The air is thick with talk of helping the poor among the Dutch.
('6', 311, 2, 19, 584172) And the Dutch language has today gained in prestige by fifty per cent.
('6', 311, 2, 20, 584243) The Dutch are now to be seen in every town and village as before.
('6', 311, 2, 21, 584309) They are flushed with enthusiasm and are again in high spirits.
('6', 311, 2, 22, 584373) No matter what the Dutch have done to us, we ought to congratulate them, considering that they deserve what they have gained.
('6', 311, 2, 23, 584499) This [attitude] is an outstanding illustration of English liberality.
('6', 311, 2, 24, 584569) It is a matter of joy for us that we are associated with such a people.
('6', 311, 2, 25, 584641) We have a lesson to learn from this.
('6', 311, 2, 26, 584678) Why do the Dutch and the British both hate us?

('6', 314, 5, 12, 589873) Mr. James Godfrey who went to England for his education has now returned a barrister at law.

('6', 314, 5, 16, 590240) They have used all their property to give their sons and daughters a very good education.

('6', 314, 5, 18, 590459) All of us admit the pressing need for education, but we are slow in acting on the belief.

('6', 314, 5, 20, 590656) Education is just a means.
('6', 314, 5, 21, 590683) If it is not accompanied by truthfulness, firmness, patience and other virtues, it remains sterile, and sometimes does harm instead of good.

('6', 315, 2, 3, 591264) PERMIT LAW
('6', 315, 3, 4, 591275) The authorities seem to have begun the examination of permits in every town.
('6', 315, 3, 5, 591352) Not only were the permits of Rustenburg Indians examined, but the police made them give their finger prints also.
('6', 315, 3, 6, 591466) After the finger prints had been taken, the Rustenburg Indians referred the matter to the Association and were told that none of them should have given finger prints.
('6', 315, 3, 7, 591633) The giving of finger prints has done no good.
('6', 315, 3, 8, 591679) It is likely that the authorities will cite this instance of some Indians who gave finger prints and argue that the Indian community had no objection to giving finger prints.
('6', 315, 3, 9, 591854) The British Indian Association has written letters to every town saying that the permits and the registers may both be produced for inspection on demand; that the authorities may be assisted in their work of scrutiny and all information required by them supplied; that thumb impressions may be given if required, but that any further demand may be unequivocally refused and the Association informed that the authorities demand finger prints.
('6', 315, 3, 10, 592296) All Indians must bear these four points in mind.
('6', 315, 3, 11, 592345) A telegram 1 has been sent to the Government saying that the people regard it an outrage that finger prints should have been taken at Rustenburg.
('6', 315, 3, 12, 592491) The question has been asked on whose orders the prints were taken and whether or not the practice would be discontinued.
('6', 315, 3, 13, 592612) The Transvaal Indians should take care that they do not get caught in the net that the authorities spread for them.
('6', 315, 3, 14, 592728) In reply to the Association’s telegram, the authorities have inquired whether the objection is only to giving the impressions of all the fingers or if it extends to the thumb impression also.
('6', 315, 3, 15, 592920) In its reply 2
('6', 315, 4, 16, 592935) the Association has stated that, in accordance with the understanding with Lord Milner, it has no objection to Indians giving the thumb impression for obtaining permits.
('6', 315, 4, 17, 593105) The Association intends to assist the Government in the scrutiny of permits, but cannot agree about the giving of the ten fingerprints as this needlessly humiliates the Indian community.
('6', 315, 5, 18, 593292) 1 Vide “Telegram to Registrar of Asiatics”, 2 3 1907. 2 Vide “Telegram to Registrar of Asiatics”, 5 3 1907.

('6', 316, 1, 2, 593444) TRANSVAAL PERMITS
('6', 316, 2, 3, 593462) Last week I wrote about the notice regarding persons staying in the Transvaal without permits, 1 In answer to an enquiry by the British Indian Association, Mr. Chamney has replied that those persons in the Transvaal who hold the old Dutch certificates will have permits issued to them up to March 31, and that all those who continue to live in the Transvaal after that date without permits will be prosecuted.
('6', 316, 2, 4, 593872) From this it is not to be inferred that a permit will necessarily be issued to anyone who holds the Dutch certificate.
('6', 316, 2, 5, 593991) These persons will have to produce evidence to the effect that the Dutch certificate belongs to the holder, and the holder was in the Transvaal immediately before the outbreak of the war and left the Colony because of it.
('6', 316, 2, 6, 594213) Every Indian resident in the Transvaal who possesses such evidence should take out a permit as soon as practicable.
('6', 316, 2, 7, 594329) But it should be remembered that, unless the applicant is granted a permit, he is not to surrender his register.

('6', 318, 1, 2, 597548) 292. THE MASS MEETING
('6', 318, 2, 3, 597570) The Natal Indians met on Monday 1 night in large numbers to consider the question of traders’ licences and the municipal franchise.
('6', 318, 2, 4, 597702) The meeting seems to have been the largest on record.
('6', 318, 2, 5, 597756) The Advertiser calls it “a record gathering, both in regard to the size of the audience and its enthusiasm”.
('6', 318, 2, 6, 597865) Delegates attended from all parts of the Colony and perfect unanimity prevailed.
('6', 318, 2, 7, 597946) We congratulate the indefatigable Secretaries of the Congress on the admirable manner in which they organized the meeting.
('6', 318, 2, 8, 598069) The studiously moderate address of the chairman of the meeting and the array of facts presented by him should disarm all opposition.
('6', 318, 2, 9, 598202) Nothing could be fairer than the compromise offered by him on the intricate trading question.
('6', 318, 2, 10, 598296) Indeed Mr. Dawad Mahomed showed that he claimed for the Indian traders nothing more than what the reasonably minded colonists have admitted they are entitled to at the very least.
('6', 318, 2, 11, 598476) The first resolution 2 adopted by the meeting put in a concrete form the grievance of the community regarding the Licenses Act.
('6', 318, 2, 12, 598604) There can be no doubt that nothing less than an amendment of the present Act will satisfactorily meet the difficulty.
('6', 318, 2, 13, 598722) The second resolution 3 was the outcome of the recent licensing cases.
('6', 318, 2, 14, 598793) The contention of the Indian community is that, if with the possession of the municipal franchise by the Indian community, Indians have laboured under gross injustice at the hands of the municipal bodies, how much worse must the position become if the community is deprived of the municipal franchise.
('6', 318, 2, 15, 599095) The meeting, therefore, emphasized the necessity for protecting British Indian rate payers of Natal against the attempt to deprive them of the right to elect municipal councillors.
('6', 318, 3, 16, 599276) 1 March 11 2 The first resolution protested against the manner of enforcement of the Dealers' Licenses Act and requested the intervention of the local and Imperial Governments; it further demanded that the Act should be “so changed as to safeguard vested rights”.
('6', 318, 3, 17, 599540) 3 The second resolution requested the Imperial Government to “safeguard the right of British Indian rate payers to vote at the municipal elections”.
('6', 318, 3, 18, 599689) The Natal Manicipal Bill proposed the disfranchisement of British Indians at municipal elections.
('6', 319, 0, 1, 599787) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 319, 1, 2, 599829) The two resolutions form a complete answer to the Colonial Patriotic Unionand show how necessary it is for the heads of the two communities to meet together and evolve a workable compromise.
('6', 319, 1, 3, 600020) Let us hope that Mr. Poynton, who we believe is a moderate man, will consider our proposal and win the esteem of the colonists by paving the way to a real settlement of the thorny question of Indian immigration and Indian competition.
('6', 319, 2, 4, 600255) Indian Opinion, 16 3 1907
('6', 319, 3, 5, 600281) 293. LORD SELBORNE’S DESPATCH
('6', 319, 4, 6, 600311) Lord Selborne’s despatch to Lord Elgin on the anti Asiatic Ordinance of the Transvaal has now been received.
('6', 319, 4, 7, 600420) We regret to have to say that, in spite of His Excellency’s usual fairness, he has throughout the despatch shown himself as a partisan rather than an unprejudiced administrator and representative of the Sovereign.
('6', 319, 5, 8, 600634) We will deal for the present with the alleged influx of unauthorized Asiatics into the Transvaal.
('6', 319, 5, 9, 600732) We must unhesitatingly say that His Excellency has not produced a particle of evidence in support of the statement so repeatedly challenged by the Indian community of the Transvaal.
('6', 319, 5, 10, 600914) The evidence referred to by Lord Selborne is the report made by Mr. Burgess as to his examination of Indian passengers at the Coast.
('6', 319, 5, 11, 601047) It shows at best nothing more than that some Indians attempt to enter the Transvaal on permits not their own, and that such attempt is successfully arrested in its progress, even before Indians making the attempt have reached the Transvaal border.
('6', 319, 5, 12, 601295) Now the attempt on the part of individual Indians to effect an entry into the Transvaal without lawful authority has never been denied.
('6', 319, 5, 13, 601431) There is, however, no warrant for the inference, based on such attempts, that there is any successful entry.
('6', 319, 5, 14, 601540) As to the allegation of “an organised agency trafficking in permits”, there is not a tittle of evidence produced beyond undisclosed circumstances which have come to his (the Coast Agent’s) knowledge.
('6', 319, 5, 15, 601740) It is now the clear duty of the British Indian Association to call for the production of the evidence on which the statement is founded.
('6', 319, 5, 16, 601877) Till then, the case for the introduction of the Ordinance remains “unproven”.
('6', 319, 5, 17, 601955) Notwithstanding the fact, we find The Transvaal Leader basing an inflammatory article on Lord Selborne’s despatch.
('6', 319, 5, 18, 602070) The Leader
('6', 320, 0, 1, 602081) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 321
('6', 320, 1, 2, 602125) gravely asks whether British Indians are to rule South Africa or the white men.
('6', 320, 1, 3, 602205) And all this because Lord Elgin has dared to do justice in the teeth of official opposition.
('6', 320, 1, 4, 602298) The Leader then goes on furiously to urge that any such attempt on the part of British Indians to rule South Africa should be resisted, if need be, by the shedding of blood.
('6', 320, 1, 5, 602472) We may, however, assure The Leader that no such heroic measures will be necessary, seeing that British Indians have no ambition to rule.
('6', 320, 1, 6, 602609) We would ask our contemporary to peruse the statement 1 presented by the Deputation to Lord Elgin and we promise that it will show why it was that Lord Elgin vetoed the Ordinance.
('6', 320, 2, 7, 602789) Indian Opinion, 16 3 1907

('6', 321, 5, 11, 604997) 296. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('6', 321, 6, 12, 605022) ORDINANCE BLUE BOOK
('6', 321, 7, 13, 605042) The Blue book containing the correspondence that passed between Lord Selborne and Lord Elgin regarding the Ordinance has now been received.
('6', 321, 7, 14, 605182) It shows that Lord Elgin, who had heard only one side of the case, had at first approved the Ordinance, but his eyes were opened after he had heard the Deputation that visited England, and then he refused it [Royal] assent.
('6', 321, 7, 15, 605406) Lord Selborne, however, sticks to his earlier position and says in his reply that his hands have been weakened by Lord Elgin listening to the Deputation.
('6', 321, 7, 16, 605560) Among the reasons for passing the Ordinance, Lord Selborne mentions many Indians entering without permits.
('6', 321, 7, 17, 605667) In support he quotes the report of Mr. Burgess, which says that he had personally seen several Indians holding false permits and that some had even erased the thumb impressions on them.
('6', 321, 7, 18, 605853) Even if some of these statements are true, it only shows that people are not able to enter wrongfully and that those attempting to do so can in fact be stopped.
('6', 321, 7, 19, 606014) There are some more points worth noticing in Lord Selborne’s letter, which we shall see later.
('6', 321, 7, 20, 606109) Commenting on this Blue book, The Leader and The Star say

('6', 325, 3, 6, 611819) 301. THE MALAY LOCATION
('6', 325, 4, 7, 611843) The Johannesburg Town Council, as will be seen from our news columns, will very shortly receive title to the Malay Location.
('6', 325, 4, 8, 611968) One of the conditions of the grant will be that the Town Council will have to compensate the inhabitants for the buildings erected by them and to find other Stands in lieu of those now occupied.
('6', 325, 4, 9, 612163) At first sight, the provision seems to be equitable.
('6', 325, 4, 10, 612216) But further consideration will reveal the fact that compensation does not include any payment in respect of the tenure or loss of rents, and so far as the present intentions of the Council are known, the giving of Stands means removal to Klipspruit.
('6', 325, 4, 11, 612466) Stand holders in the Malay Location, though, strictly speaking, only monthly squatters, were, up to the outbreak of war, at least as safe in their possession of Stands as the burghers of Vrededorp who occupied the Stands precisely on the same terms as the residents of the Malay Location.
('6', 325, 4, 12, 612755) When, therefore, we compare the handsome treatment meted out to the burghers with the treatment that is likely to be the lot of the residents of the Malay Location under the Government grant, we realize fully what the possession of a brown skin means.
('6', 325, 4, 13, 613007) If the Coloured people cannot show a legal title to anything they enjoyed during the Boer regime, their equitable right, no matter how strong, receives short shrift under the changed conditions.
('6', 325, 4, 14, 613202) Will Lord Selborne once more maintain that the change from the Republican to the British flag necessitates a partial robbery of the rights of the residents of the Malay Location?
('6', 325, 4, 15, 613381) For the paltry compensation that the Stand holders will receive for the buildings can ill repay them for years of undisturbed occupation which enables many a holder to derive a handsome income from rents paid by sub tenants and which is their means of livelihood.
('6', 325, 4, 16, 613645) And to add force to our argument, let us for the hundredth time recall the fact that every attempt made by the late President Kruger to remove the inhabitants of the Location not
('6', 325, 5, 17, 613824) 1 Fourth Resolution; “The Mass Meeting”, 11 9 1906.
('6', 326, 0, 1, 613876) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 327
('6', 326, 1, 2, 613920) thirteen miles from Johannesburg, but five miles, was successfully resisted by their late advocates, the representatives of the British Crown in the Transvaal.

('6', 326, 3, 4, 614106) 302. SOUTH AFRICA BRITISH INDIAN COMMITTEE
('6', 326, 4, 5, 614149) We suggest that all our readers carefully read Mr. Ritch’s letter this week.
('6', 326, 4, 6, 614226) The work done by him, and through him by the British Committee, has been invaluable.
('6', 326, 4, 7, 614311) He has been working with great enthusiasm and tact.
('6', 326, 4, 8, 614363) We shall owe it to Mr. Ritch and the South Africa British Indian Committee if the Natal Municipal Bill is dropped, if the Vrededorp Indians receive compensation and if relief is secured at last from the oppressive Natal Licenses Act.
('6', 326, 4, 9, 614597) Mr. Ritch will not be able to work without the Committee, and without Mr. Ritch, the Committee cannot do much.
('6', 326, 4, 10, 614708) There is at present no one in London who can replace Mr. Ritch for vigilance and ability.
('6', 326, 4, 11, 614798) Sir Muncherji and our other well wishers do all they can to help us but not much can be done unless there is an able Secretary to bring them all together and to work under their guidance.
('6', 326, 4, 12, 614986) Almost weekly we see from Reuter’s cables that the Committee is active.
('6', 326, 4, 13, 615058) Last week the news was received that, in pursuance of the resolution passed at the mass meeting [in Durban], the Committee had written strongly to Lord Elgin.
('6', 326, 4, 14, 615217) This week we find that a debate was initiated by Lord Ampthill in the House of Lords.
('6', 326, 4, 15, 615303) The report and cablegrams printed elsewhere in this issue will show that, in the House of Commons too, questions were asked and answered about our grievances.
('6', 326, 4, 16, 615462) We owe all this to the efforts of the Committee and Mr. Ritch.
('6', 326, 4, 17, 615525) It is clear that they have been making considerable effort.
('6', 326, 4, 18, 615585) How is the Committee to continue and do more work?
('6', 326, 4, 19, 615636) Mr. Ritch has himself supplied the answer.
('6', 326, 4, 20, 615679) He writes that £250 a year will not suffice.
('6', 326, 4, 21, 615724) We have published elsewhere the accounts submitted by him showing how the money is spent.
('6', 326, 4, 22, 615814) Mr. Ritch had been drawing £25 per quarter, but the Committee has permitted him to draw £45, as £25 was not enough to meet even the deficit in his domestic budget.
('6', 326, 4, 23, 615978) What is paid to Mr. Ritch is not a salary.
('6', 326, 4, 24, 616021) The market value of his work cannot be less than £30 a month.
('6', 326, 4, 25, 616083) He does not seek money nor does he work for it.
('6', 326, 4, 26, 616131) He works because he feels [for the Indians in South Africa].
('6', 326, 4, 27, 616192) If his condition permitted it, he would not accept even a penny.
('6', 327, 0, 1, 616257) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 327, 1, 2, 616299) Among the Committee’s expenses we see payments of £180 to Mr. Ritch, £50 to a paid employee and £50 as rent for the office.
('6', 327, 1, 3, 616423) Thus salaries and rent took away £280, leaving £20, which was too little to meet the Committee’s other expenses.
('6', 327, 1, 4, 616536) Even after we remit £50, the balance of the promised £300, the expenses will not be fully met.
('6', 327, 1, 5, 616631) The Anti Indian Law Fund Committee has resolved to send £100 more.
('6', 327, 1, 6, 616698) But we feel that it is absolutely necessary to spend up to £500 in England.
('6', 327, 1, 7, 616774) Expenses on this scale will, it appears, have to be maintained over two or three years.
('6', 327, 1, 8, 616862) If compensation is paid to the Vrededorp Indians, we can recover more than £500 from that [amount] alone.
('6', 327, 1, 9, 616968) Our expenses in England will be repaid a hundred times over if our traders can survive in Natal.
('6', 327, 1, 10, 617065) The attack on the inhabitants of the Malay Location continues.
('6', 327, 1, 11, 617128) If they can be successfully defended, that also will be a good return.
('6', 327, 1, 12, 617199) We therefore specifically appeal to all our readers to make the requisite effort to maintain the Committee.
('6', 327, 1, 13, 617307) The Natal Indian Congress has contributed £125. Out of the £50 yet to be sent, the Congress should pay £25 And just as the Transvaal has decided to contribute an additional £100, so must Natal too.
('6', 327, 1, 14, 617505) That is the duty of the Congress.
('6', 327, 1, 15, 617539) The Committee will be able to do its best only if money is remitted in this manner.
('6', 327, 1, 16, 617623) At present there is little likelihood of any help coming from the Cape, though efforts are being made.
('6', 327, 1, 17, 617726) Our request to the Indians in the Cape is that, if it is not possible for them to send a collective contribution, individuals may send us whatever they can.
('6', 327, 1, 18, 617883) We shall pass on the money, as from them, to the Committee.
('6', 327, 1, 19, 617943) Even if the Cape Indians consider their own position relatively safe, they should share in their countrymen’s adversities elsewhere.

('6', 328, 4, 17, 619809) 304. MALARIA AND DUTY OF INDIANS
('6', 328, 5, 18, 619842) Malaria is taking a heavy toll in the neighbourhood of Durban.
('6', 328, 5, 19, 619905) It is said that nearly three hundred Indians have been buried on the other side of Umgeni.
('6', 328, 5, 20, 619996) The Corporation has started distributing quinine free of charge.
('6', 328, 5, 21, 620061) One philanthropic European has undertaken to supply medicine to all patients.
('6', 328, 5, 22, 620139) Many Indians have availed themselves of his offer.
('6', 328, 5, 23, 620190) At this juncture the Indian community should not lag behind.
('6', 328, 5, 24, 620251) We think it necessary that the leaders should come out, and go from place to place making inquiries about the victims of the disease and also arrange for their treatment.
('6', 328, 5, 25, 620422) People should be persuaded to maintain cleanliness and not let water stagnate in the vicinity.
('6', 328, 5, 26, 620517) The Congress should write to Dr. Murison for help.
('6', 328, 5, 27, 620568) We believe that it is
('6', 329, 0, 1, 620590) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 329, 1, 2, 620632) the duty of Dr. Nanji to come forward at this time and give medical aid to patients.
('6', 329, 1, 3, 620717) If he does so, Indians will have much relief and he will be able to do them a lot of good.
('6', 329, 1, 4, 620808) For the guidance of those who wish to help, we make the following suggestions: 1. simple food for the patient; 2. quinine as prescribed by the physician; 3. ensuring proper bowel movement; 4. removing vegetation, if any, from the neighbourhood; 5. draining of swamps, if any; 6. advising people to use mosquito nets where possible; 7. the avoidance of overcrowding; 8. cleanliness of latrines, and night soil to be covered with dry earth or ash.
('6', 329, 1, 5, 621254) These suggestions are very easy to carry out.
('6', 329, 1, 6, 621300) It has been found that a malarious region becomes free from disease as soon as the land in the neighbourhood is drained.

('6', 329, 4, 9, 621463) 305. PERMIT DEPARTMENT
('6', 329, 5, 10, 621486) The report of the Volksrust permit case which we print elsewhere is worth reading.
('6', 329, 5, 11, 621569) The case of Shaikh Inas also brings out many things.
('6', 329, 5, 12, 621622) It is interesting to know how far Mr. Burgess interferes in Durban.
('6', 329, 5, 13, 621690) Not only does he examine those without permits but even others who have them.
('6', 329, 5, 14, 621768) It is quite evident that this procedure is improper.
('6', 329, 5, 15, 621821) For earlier when the person concerned appeared in court, the magistrate found his case in order, held his permit to be valid and acquitted him.
('6', 329, 5, 16, 621965) Yet Lord Selborne relies on Mr. Burgess’s report and has made out that many persons come in with forged permits or none at all.
('6', 329, 5, 17, 622093) The case of Abdul Rehman is equally important.
('6', 329, 5, 18, 622140) He will produce witnesses who know him, and thus have himself acquitted.
('6', 329, 5, 19, 622213) But he would not have been able to come in either, if Mr. Burgess had had his way.

('6', 330, 0, 1, 622643) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 331
('6', 330, 1, 2, 622687) 306. HISTORY OF ISLAM
('6', 330, 2, 3, 622709) The Spectator is one of the famous journals published in Britain today.
('6', 330, 2, 4, 622781) Prince Tiano is a great Italian writer and has studied Eastern languages.
('6', 330, 2, 5, 622855) At present he is writing a history of Islam and intends to publish it in twelve parts.
('6', 330, 2, 6, 622942) The first part has already been published.
('6', 330, 2, 7, 622985) It is priced at £.1.12.0 and runs into 740 pages of a large size.
('6', 330, 2, 8, 623051) A review of this book has appeared in The Spectator of December 22, of which we give a summary below: Prince Tiano gives in the first part the history of the first six years of the Prophet’s life, in which we see the Prophet as a statesman, law maker and general.
('6', 330, 2, 9, 623315) His power was growing from day to day.
('6', 330, 2, 10, 623354) The Jews opposed him strongly, but the Prophet broke their power.
('6', 330, 2, 11, 623420) Though there was not much pomp and splendour about him, his power was very great.
('6', 330, 2, 12, 623502) What he did, no other religious teacher has done.
('6', 330, 2, 13, 623552) He started preaching after the age of forty.
('6', 330, 2, 14, 623597) His was not a struggle for self interest, but for the good of others.
('6', 330, 2, 15, 623667) At the time of his death he was the head of a theocratic state.
('6', 330, 2, 16, 623731) He established a religion which came to enjoy world wide allegiance, thanks to his greatness and sense of justice.
('6', 330, 2, 17, 623846) He gave the Arabs a practical knowledge of world affairs, which they had lacked.
('6', 330, 2, 18, 623927) He moulded them into a single people and made them doughty fighters.
('6', 330, 2, 19, 623996) He ruled over different peoples; and today, though Muslims live under different governments, they believe in one God and His Prophet and maintain fraternal relations with others of the same faith.
('6', 330, 2, 20, 624193) What the nature of this brotherhood is and what the Muslim community can do in the modern world has to be considered whenever we think of the pan Islamic movement.
('6', 330, 2, 21, 624357) The foregoing is just a summary.
('6', 330, 2, 22, 624390) We have omitted a considerable portion which is critical.
('6', 330, 2, 23, 624448) But we would advise those who know English to read the whole article.
('6', 330, 3, 24, 624518) [From Gujarati]
('6', 330, 4, 25, 624534) Indian Opinion, 23 3 1907

('6', 332, 1, 2, 626330) DELAGOA BAY RAILWAY
('6', 332, 2, 3, 626350) There has been a serious accident on the Delagoa Bay Railway.
('6', 332, 2, 4, 626412) Many passengers lost their lives in a landslide.
('6', 332, 2, 5, 626461) One of them was Dr. Jameson, a former Minister for Lands.
('6', 332, 2, 6, 626519) He retired when the new Ministry was formed, and was proceeding to England.
('6', 332, 2, 7, 626595) True to the saying “Man proposes, but God disposes”, Dr. Jameson died in this accident before reaching England.
('6', 332, 2, 8, 626707) His body was taken back to Pretoria and buried there.
('6', 332, 2, 9, 626761) ON THE ACCIDENT
('6', 332, 3, 10, 626777) The accident gives rise to many reflections.
('6', 332, 3, 11, 626822) Others died besides Dr. Jameson.
('6', 332, 3, 12, 626855) Some were injured.
('6', 332, 3, 13, 626874) Again, two hundred lives were lost when a French man of war was wrecked near Toulon.
('6', 332, 3, 14, 626959) Incidents such as these are constantly taking place but, intoxicated with this world of affairs, we see nothing.
('6', 332, 3, 15, 627072) As children, we read [in Gujarati]
('6', 332, 4, 16, 627107) Know, O Man, know thy mind And be afraid of death.
('6', 332, 4, 17, 627158) Beware of the destined hour To ashes thou shalt turn.
('6', 332, 4, 18, 627212) We live on in the world as if we had come here with a charter of immortality; and as the Gujarati proverb goes, we go on killing buffaloes for shoe laces.
('6', 332, 4, 19, 627367) But if we reflect seriously and look at things calmly, we realize that all is done in vain which is not done for others’ good.
('6', 332, 4, 20, 627494) If every minute, hour and day given to us is spent in good deeds, in patriotic service and in maintaining truth, we shall have nothing to fear even when death strikes us down.
('6', 332, 4, 21, 627670) Only a person who risks his life can fetch pearls from the depths of the sea.
('6', 332, 4, 22, 627748) Similarly, from the ocean of life we have to seek out tasks precious like pearls.
('6', 332, 4, 23, 627830) He alone who does not care for his life can do this.
('6', 332, 4, 24, 627883) If our actions are effeminate, we cannot remain manly.
('6', 332, 4, 25, 627938) Lord Selborne has made a biting remark that we are base and in the face of the least danger we think of bribing the officials.
('6', 332, 4, 26, 628065) We can refute this charge only if we have true spirit within us.
('6', 332, 5, 27, 628130) GIVING OF FINGER PRINTS
('6', 332, 6, 28, 628154) That this was started at Rustenburg I have already mentioned.
('6', 332, 7, 29, 628216) Now the Association has received a letter from the Rustenburg
('6', 332, 8, 30, 628278) 1 Vide ‘‘Johannesburg Letter’’, 9 3 1907.
('6', 333, 0, 1, 628320) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 333, 1, 2, 628362) Committee saying that the paper on which the finger prints of some people were obtained at the instance of the Committee has been burnt.
('6', 333, 1, 3, 628499) For this Rustenburg deserves our congratulations.
('6', 333, 1, 4, 628549) Indians in other places should heed this warning and not give the ten finger impressions under any circumstances.
('6', 333, 2, 5, 628663) VREDEDORP ORDINANCE
('6', 333, 3, 6, 628683) It has been suggested by the Johannesburg municipality that the Vrededorp Ordinance may be put into effect from July 1. Meanwhile, the South Africa British Indian Committee has been active about obtaining compensation.
('6', 333, 4, 7, 628902) MALAY LOCATION On the subject of handing over the Malay Location to the Johannesburg Town Council, the Government have written that, as soon as it agrees to certain conditions, it will be granted a permanent lease.
('6', 333, 4, 8, 629117) One of the conditions is that, should the Council evict the residents of the Malay Location, it should provide suitable Stands elsewhere for the evicted and also pay compensation, as determined by a tribunal, for buildings already erected by them in the Location.
('6', 333, 4, 9, 629381) This means that the inhabitants of the Malay Location will not be compensated for their right to the Stands which, for many years now, they have believed to be theirs; only the present value of the structures will be paid.
('6', 333, 4, 10, 629604) That is to say, the payment will vary from £50 to £150. The Malay Location Committee should start an agitation from today.
('6', 333, 4, 11, 629727) It is probable that the agreement between the Government and the Council will soon be signed.
('6', 333, 5, 12, 629821) PERMITS
('6', 333, 6, 13, 629829) Only a few days now remain for those persons who are now resident in the Transvaal, hold old registers but had left the territory just before the war, to apply for new permits.
('6', 333, 6, 14, 630006) It should be remembered that, after March 31, no applications will be entertained.

('6', 337, 1, 2, 634331) 313. RESOLUTIONS AT TRANSVAAL INDIAN MASS MEETING1
('6', 337, 2, 3, 634382) [JOHANNESBURG, March 29, 1907] [Resolution 1] 2 This meeting of British Indians, convened under the auspices of the British Indian Association, hereby respectfully protests against the passage of the Asiatic Law Amendment Bill by the new Transvaal Parliament, in that the Bill is unnecessary and degrading to the British Indian community.
('6', 337, 2, 4, 634721) [Resolution 2] 3 This meeting of British Indians convened under the auspices of the British Indian Association denies the allegation of illegal influx of British Indians on a wholesale scale, and, in order to satisfy the Government and popular prejudice, offers to submit to voluntary regis tration, as was done by the community in 1904 under Lord Milner’s advice, and in the manner sketched in the Chairman’s speech thus practically fulfilling all the requirements of the Bill without its offensive character.
('6', 337, 2, 5, 635232) [Resolution 3] 4 In the event of the humble proposal embodied in Resolution 2 not being accepted by the local Government, this meeting hereby requests full Imperial protection by reason of the fact that British Indians have no voice in the choice of the legislators, and represent a very small and weak minority.
('6', 337, 2, 6, 635545) [Resolution 4] 5 That the Chairman be, and is, hereby authorized to submit the resolutions passed by this meeting of British Indians, by wire or cable, to the local Government and to the Right Hon’ble the Secretary of State for the Colonies, Right Hon’ble the Secretary of State for India, and His Excellency the Governor General of India.
('6', 337, 3, 7, 635885) Indian Opinion, 6 4 1907

('6', 338, 1, 2, 636329) 314. THE DEALERS’ LICENSES ACT
('6', 338, 2, 3, 636360) The reply 1 of the Natal Government to the Natal Indian Congress regarding the imposition of a heavy fee against a rule under the Dealers’ Licenses Act is very unsatisfactory, except in so far as the reply shows an anxiety on the part of the Government to justify its action; but the analogy given from the Liquor Licences and the Road Boards Act is entirely misleading.
('6', 338, 2, 4, 636731) The Liquor Licences Ordinance and laws are naturally and always restrictive to trade in liquor.
('6', 338, 2, 5, 636827) The policy of the legislature, therefore, naturally is to put as many obstacles as possible in the way of those licences being multiplied.
('6', 338, 2, 6, 636966) It may be retorted, it is true, that such is also the policy of the Dealers’ Licenses Act so far as Indians are concerned, but we think that the Government could hardly take up such a position.
('6', 338, 2, 7, 637160) The hardship created by the Act is great enough in that absolute discretion as to the granting of licences rests with the Appellate Boards.
('6', 338, 2, 8, 637300) To impose a heavy penalty, for the fee of £12 10s is nothing less, would be, practically, to bar even an approach to these Boards.
('6', 338, 2, 9, 637431) The analogy of the Road Boards also cannot hold good, because the interests involved are of a totally different nature.
('6', 338, 2, 10, 637551) They regulate special rights and do not create social disabilities, whereas the Dealers’ Licenses Act specifically restricts a natural right, which has hitherto been considered to be a vested right.
('6', 338, 2, 11, 637750) We undoubtedly think that it is the duty of the Congress to pursue the matter, until the imposition shall have been removed.
('6', 338, 3, 12, 637875) Indian Opinion, 30 3 1907
('6', 338, 4, 13, 637901) 315. TRANSVAAL ASIATIC ORDINANCE
('6', 338, 5, 14, 637934) The Transvaal Indians are again confronted with the same situation that they faced during September last.
('6', 338, 5, 15, 638040) Today every one is watching to see what they will do next.
('6', 338, 6, 16, 638099) 1 The Government in its reply had said: “The rule requiring appellants under Act 18 of 1897 to deposit £12 is a proper one, and within the authority given by the Act.
('6', 338, 6, 17, 638266) I may say that the rule is similar to others passed in connection with similar acts.
('6', 338, 6, 18, 638351) It is almost identical with one of the rules under the Liquor Act; and, under the Road Boards Act, 1901, a deposit of £15 to £25 is similarly required to be made.”
('6', 339, 0, 1, 638515) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 339, 1, 2, 638557) All Indians will be guided by what the Transvaal Indians do.
('6', 339, 1, 3, 638618) What happens in the Transvaal may well happen all over South Africa.
('6', 339, 2, 4, 638687) “NOTHING VENTURE, NOTHING HAVE”
('6', 339, 3, 5, 638719) According to the saying, “Nothing venture, nothing have,” if the Transvaal Indians do not rigidly adhere to the resolution on going to gaol, they will lose everything.
('6', 339, 3, 6, 638887) Not only they, but other South African Indians also will lose their rights.
('6', 339, 3, 7, 638963) If the Indian community in the Transvaal does not carry out the resolution in regard to going to gaol, it will be eating its own words.
('6', 339, 3, 8, 639099) The Europeans will laugh at the Indians.
('6', 339, 3, 9, 639140) They will think us timid and cowardly and take it that we shall endure any burden imposed on us.
('6', 339, 3, 10, 639237) No one will put any faith in our word, whether written or spoken.
('6', 339, 4, 11, 639303) IF BILL IS PASSED
('6', 339, 5, 12, 639321) If this Bill is passed, the Transvaal Government will soon draft other bills, and the Indian community will of its own lose its rights one after another.
('6', 339, 5, 13, 639475) The laws which obtain in the Orange River Colony will be enacted in the Transvaal also and later in all the other places.
('6', 339, 5, 14, 639597) There is already talk today of relegating all the traders to Bazaars, of sending people to Klipspruit thirteen miles away from the Malay Location, and entirely abolishing the right of Indians to own land outside a Location.
('6', 339, 5, 15, 639821) If, therefore, the Indian community abandons the resolution on courting imprisonment, we believe that it will be impossible to get redress in any of the matters.
('6', 339, 5, 16, 639983) If we lose our reputation this time, we shall never recover it.
('6', 339, 5, 17, 640047) It is our belief that there is nothing worse than withdrawing a threat once held out.
('6', 339, 6, 18, 640133) OTHER REASONS FOR OPPOSING ORDINANCE
('6', 339, 7, 19, 640170) These are listed below: 1. Under the Ordinance all (existing) permits will be withdrawn and new ones issued after fresh inquiry.
('6', 339, 7, 20, 640299) 2. These permits will have to be produced before a Kaffir or any other constable.
('6', 339, 7, 21, 640381) 3. Licences will not be issued to those who do not produce the permits.
('6', 339, 7, 22, 640453) 4. Even when the permit is produced, the police have the right to
('6', 340, 0, 1, 640519) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 341
('6', 340, 1, 2, 640563) lock up a man for the night.
('6', 340, 1, 3, 640592) 5. Even a child of eight years will have to be registered by its parents, and its identification marks noted.
('6', 340, 1, 4, 640702) 6. It is not the people with forged permits or without permits who will have to face this harassment, since they will have left the Transvaal.
('6', 340, 1, 5, 640845) It is the others with valid permits who will have to go through it all.
('6', 340, 1, 6, 640917) 7. All the officers have said that the new permits will carry the impressions of all the ten digits.
('6', 340, 1, 7, 641018) 8. There is a great difference between giving our thumb impressions in the past and the same provision under the new law.
('6', 340, 1, 8, 641140) So far, the thumb impression was given voluntarily, now it is made compulsory under the law.
('6', 340, 1, 9, 641233) 9. Hitherto the giving of thumb impressions was not a statutory requirement, so that it had no consequences elsewhere, but now under the new law, it will have consequences everywhere.
('6', 340, 1, 10, 641417) 10. If a stranger reads this Ordinance, he will only get the impression that those to whom it applies must be thieves, bandits or traitors.
('6', 340, 1, 11, 641557) 11. The clauses of the Ordinance are such that these can only apply to criminals.
('6', 340, 2, 12, 641639) 12. The reason advanced for the Ordinance is also of the same nature: the leaders of the Indian community secure entry for Indians into the Transvaal under false pretexts—which means that the leaders are criminals.
('6', 340, 2, 13, 641854) 13. The Ordinance raises the question whether the Indian community has any status at all.
('6', 340, 3, 14, 641944) 14. If the Indian community submits to this Ordinance, the result will be that Indians like Sir Muncherji Bhownaggree who may enter the Transvaal will also be required to take out permits with finger prints.
('6', 340, 3, 15, 642152) The responsibility for this will rest on the Transvaal Indians.
('6', 340, 3, 16, 642216) 15. The Ordinance applies only to Asiatics, and not to Cape Boys, Kaffirs, or Malays.
('6', 340, 3, 17, 642302) That means that all these three communities will laugh at the Indians.
('6', 340, 3, 18, 642373) Supposing an Indian marries a Malay.
('6', 340, 3, 19, 642410) No one will be able to ask the Malay to produce a pass, but everywhere the Kaffir police will accost the Indian and demand, “Your pass,
('6', 341, 0, 1, 642546) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 341, 1, 2, 642588) please!” This means that the status of the Indian will be lower than that of his Malay wife.
('6', 341, 1, 3, 642681) Other such reasons can also be given.
('6', 341, 1, 4, 642719) Yeaders should deeply ponder over the foregoing reasons and consider whether it is not better to go to gaol than to suffer such indignity.
('6', 341, 1, 5, 642858) To take out a pass under the Ordinance is, we believe, like permanent imprisonment.
('6', 341, 1, 6, 642942) In comparison with that, there is nothing wrong in going to gaol for a few days or months.
('6', 341, 1, 7, 643033) On the contrary, besides bringing in some gain, it will redound to our credit.
('6', 341, 1, 8, 643112) The other permanent imprisonment will cause us loss and discredit.
('6', 341, 1, 9, 643179) It must be remembered that the resolution about courting imprisonment has already been passed by the Indian community and announced to the whole world.
('6', 341, 1, 10, 643331) If the Ordinance was not acceptable in December, how can it be so now?
('6', 341, 1, 11, 643402) As far as that Ordinance is concerned, the pledge about going to gaol must stand for ever.
('6', 341, 1, 12, 643493) We request the Indian community to bear all this in mind and to adhere firmly to the resolution on courting imprisonment.
('6', 341, 1, 13, 643615) And we pray to God to give us the courage to renew that pledge.
('6', 341, 2, 14, 643679) BRAVE WOMEN OF BRITAIN
('6', 341, 3, 15, 643702) We still receive cables from Britain regarding the struggle by some brave women.
('6', 341, 3, 16, 643783) All of them go to gaol instead of paying fines.
('6', 341, 3, 17, 643831) Though they have not won their rights so far, they have not lost heart.
('6', 341, 3, 18, 643903) Instead, they believe that even though they themselves may not get the rights, their daughters will get them as a result of their struggle.
('6', 341, 3, 19, 644043) Now about this resolution on gaol going, no one must argue that he will go to gaol only if all the other Indians do so.
('6', 341, 3, 20, 644163) It is the man with courage who will have to go to gaol.
('6', 341, 3, 21, 644219) We have to follow the example of the women referred to above.
('6', 341, 3, 22, 644281) They go to gaol, though they are very few in number, and thus draw the attention of the world to their cause.
('6', 341, 3, 23, 644391) We earnestly request all our readers to have this article imprinted on their mind, and to act with great deliberation.
('6', 341, 4, 24, 644510) [From Gujarati]
('6', 341, 5, 25, 644526) Indian Opinion, 30 3 1907
('6', 342, 0, 1, 644552) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 343
('6', 342, 1, 2, 644596) 316. DUTY OF CAPE AND NATAL [INDIANS]
('6', 342, 2, 3, 644634) At this juncture, it is the duty of Indians in the Cape and Natal to hold meetings expressing sympathy with the Transvaal Indians.
('6', 342, 2, 4, 644765) They should, moreover, pass resolutions and send them to the Imperial Government.
('6', 342, 2, 5, 644847) It will also bc a good thing if Indians from every village and town were to pass resolutions and write to the Government respectfully saying that the law is oppressive and should be withdrawn.
('6', 342, 2, 6, 645040) It may be remembered that cablegrams in support of the Transvaal Ordinance were sent to Lord Elgin by whites from every town.
('6', 342, 2, 7, 645166) Everywhere the speeches should be reasonable and good tempered.
('6', 342, 3, 8, 645230) [From Gujarati]
('6', 342, 4, 9, 645246) Indian Opinion, 30 3 1907
('6', 342, 5, 10, 645272) 317. INDIANS GOING TO LOBITO BAY
('6', 342, 6, 11, 645305) An Englishman named Stone intends to take Indian labourers to a place called Lobito Bay in Portuguese Africa a thousand miles to the north of the Cape.
('6', 342, 6, 12, 645457) He wants to take Indians there to work on the railway which a British company is constructing.
('6', 342, 6, 13, 645552) The question has arisen if the Indian community should encourage this proposal.
('6', 342, 6, 14, 645632) The President of the Durban Sanitary Association has published certain facts which indicate that the arrangements made by Mr. Stone in Durban for the Indians are altogether bad.
('6', 342, 6, 15, 645810) The building that he has rented for them is small and insanitary.
('6', 342, 6, 16, 645876) If this is true, we should consider whether Indian labourers are likely to gain anything by going to Lobito Bay.
('6', 342, 6, 17, 645989) Mr. Stone has also received the permission of the Government of India.
('6', 342, 6, 18, 646060) He therefore stands in no need of help from the Indian community.
('6', 342, 6, 19, 646126) But the above instance should make us realize that the Indian community cannot give its consent to such proposals.
('6', 342, 6, 20, 646241) If need be, it can even register its opposition.
('6', 342, 6, 21, 646290) We hear that the climate of Lobito Bay is pleasant.
('6', 342, 6, 22, 646342) It is therefore probable that the Indian labourers will be happy there.
('6', 342, 6, 23, 646414) Much will depend upon whether the foremen who will accompany them are good men or not.
('6', 342, 7, 24, 646501) [From Gujarati]

('6', 343, 1, 2, 646585) 318. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('6', 343, 2, 3, 646610) ASIATIC ORDINANCE
('6', 343, 3, 4, 646628) In just two days the new Transvaal parliament passed the Ordinance exactly as it stood in September last.
('6', 343, 3, 5, 646734) On the 20th the Ordinance was introduced in the Assembly, and the same day, within two hours, it went through all the three readings and was immediately sent to the Legislative Council, where, at the instance of Mr. Martin, it was postponed to the 22nd so that Members could have time to study it.
('6', 343, 3, 6, 647032) 1 But this was merely a pretence.
('6', 343, 3, 7, 647066) How were the Members to digest it in one night?
('6', 343, 3, 8, 647114) The Legislative Council passed it on the 22nd.
('6', 343, 4, 9, 647161) TELEGRAM FROM ASSOCIATION
('6', 343, 5, 10, 647187) No one ever dreamt that the Bill would be passed in this manner.
('6', 343, 5, 11, 647252) When the Association came to know of it, it immediately sent a telegram to the Council to the following effect:
('6', 343, 6, 12, 647364) The Association finds with great sorrow that the Asiatic Bill has already been passed in the Assembly and is likely to pass through the Council today.
('6', 343, 6, 13, 647515) The Association humbly requests that, until the Association’s plea in the matter has been heard, further consideration of the Bill may be postponed.
('6', 343, 6, 14, 647664) The Association begs to remind Your Honour that the function of the Council is to protect the interests of those who do not have the franchise.
('6', 343, 6, 15, 647808) The Indian community is loyal, but is without the right to vote.
('6', 343, 6, 16, 647873) The Association does not at all admit the charge that there is a mass infiltration into the Transvaal by Indians.
('6', 343, 6, 17, 647987) All adult Indians possess permits bearing names and identification marks.
('6', 343, 6, 18, 648061) Those who are without permits can even now be deported.
('6', 343, 6, 19, 648117) It is our request that at the least a commission should be appointed to inquire into the allegation.
('6', 343, 6, 20, 648218) We feel that the Bill is oppressive and uncalled for.
('6', 343, 6, 21, 648272) The Association requests redress at the hands of the Council.
('6', 343, 7, 22, 648334) This telegram was read out before the Council, but without any result.
('6', 343, 7, 23, 648405) Now the Bill has been sent to Lord Elgin for approval.
('6', 343, 8, 24, 648460) Satyagraha in South Africa, Ch. XV where Gandhiji says that the Bill was rushed through all its stages in a single sitting on March 21, 1907.
('6', 344, 0, 1, 648602) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 345
('6', 344, 1, 2, 648646) SPEECHES ON BILL
('6', 344, 2, 3, 648663) The Colonial Secretary, Mr. Smuts, said that the whole white population of the Transvaal was of one mind in the matter.
('6', 344, 2, 4, 648783) Indians should be stopped from coming in.
('6', 344, 2, 5, 648825) They come in in large numbers.
('6', 344, 2, 6, 648856) The Dutch Government attempted to prevent them, and this led to the [Boer] War.
('6', 344, 2, 7, 648936) The Bill that had been presented that day had come up before the former Council.
('6', 344, 2, 8, 649017) Its aim was just to have every Indian registered.
('6', 344, 2, 9, 649067) Law 3 of 1885 was defective, and its drawbacks would be removed in the new Bill.
('6', 344, 2, 10, 649148) The Imperial Government had vetoed the Bill because it was passed by the former Council.
('6', 344, 2, 11, 649237) They were now in a position to show that they were unanimous in passing it.
('6', 344, 2, 12, 649313) Further legislation would be necessary after that Bill had become law; but they would have to look into the matter later.
('6', 344, 2, 13, 649435) For the time being it was necessary for them to know who had the right to live in the Colony.
('6', 344, 2, 14, 649529) For these reasons the Bill must be passed the very same day.
('6', 344, 2, 15, 649590) Dr. Krautze supported the motion.
('6', 344, 2, 16, 649624) Mr. Owen Jones said that all the municipalities demanded such an Act.
('6', 344, 2, 17, 649694) It was absolutely essential to protect the whites.
('6', 344, 2, 18, 649745) Mr. Loveday congratulated the Government on its promptness in bringing up the Bill.
('6', 344, 2, 19, 649829) Mr. Jacobs said that all farmers wanted the Indians driven out.
('6', 344, 2, 20, 649893) If the Indians were not sent back, they might even dispossess the farmers.
('6', 344, 2, 21, 649968) The whites could settle in the Transvaal, but not in India.
('6', 344, 2, 22, 650028) The Indians should not therefore leave their own country.
('6', 344, 2, 23, 650086) General Choke Burger supported the Bill and so did Sir Percy Fitzpatrick.
('6', 344, 2, 24, 650160) The Bill was thus passed, and then sent up to the Council.
('6', 344, 3, 25, 650219) IN THE COUNCIL
('6', 344, 4, 26, 650234) Mr. Curtis said that the Bill must be passed, but that the Council should have a night to consider it, lest anyone in England should think that the Council passed it without due consideration.
('6', 344, 4, 27, 650427) The Bill was absolutely necessary.
('6', 344, 4, 28, 650462) From his experience he could say that every month a hundred Indians entered the Transvaal without permits.
('6', 344, 4, 29, 650569) If, therefore, South Africa was to remain in the hands of the whites, the Bill had to be passed.
('6', 344, 4, 30, 650666) Mr. Martin said that traders and all others had asked for such a Bill and that it should be passed.
('6', 344, 4, 31, 650766) Mr. Roy congratulated [the Government] on bringing forward the Bill.
('6', 344, 4, 32, 650835) Mr. Purchas said that the Bill was reasonable and that the Indian contention was not fair.
('6', 345, 0, 1, 650926) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 345, 1, 2, 650968) Indians were concerned only with their own interests.
('6', 345, 1, 3, 651022) They did not consider the other side and their English friends were unaware of conditions here.
('6', 345, 2, 4, 651118) PRESS COMMENTS
('6', 345, 3, 5, 651133) The Leader, The Daily Mail and The Star make the following comments.
('6', 345, 3, 6, 651202) According to The Leader, Lord Elgin had now no alternative but to give his approval to the Bill.
('6', 345, 3, 7, 651299) However, in vetoing the former Bill, he had raised a big issue.
('6', 345, 3, 8, 651363) It was difficult to see how he could now approve the present Bill.
('6', 345, 3, 9, 651430) In the opinion of The Rand Daily Mail, the Bill was necessary to prevent Indian infiltration.
('6', 345, 3, 10, 651524) It was well therefore that it had been passed.
('6', 345, 3, 11, 651571) Those who remained in the Transvaal, however, should be able to live a decent life.
('6', 345, 3, 12, 651655) The Star says that Sir Richard Solomon had brought the news that the Bill would receive Royal assent in it was passed by the new parliament.
('6', 345, 3, 13, 651796) The Bill must therefore be passed now.
('6', 345, 4, 14, 651835) COMMENTS IN ENGLAND
('6', 345, 5, 15, 651855) The Times says that the Transvaal parliament has made a serious mistake in passing the Bill.
('6', 345, 5, 16, 651948) It did not think of the difficulties of the Imperial Government.
('6', 345, 5, 17, 652013) The Conservative Globe also says that the Bill should not be approved.
('6', 345, 5, 18, 652084) The Tribune thinks that it was improper that the Bill should have been passed.
('6', 345, 5, 19, 652163) But now that General Botha was visiting England, Lord Elgin should be able to find a way out.
('6', 345, 6, 20, 652257) OUR COMMITTEE VIGILANT
('6', 345, 7, 21, 652280) Cables from England show that our Committee there has started a movement in Parliament against the Bill.
('6', 345, 7, 22, 652385) Furthermore, a joint meeting of the Committee and the East India Association will take place at Caxton Hall on April 9.
('6', 345, 8, 23, 652505) ASSOCIATION MEETING
