('6', 345, 9, 26, 652743) At both the meetings, it was solemnly resolved after due consideration to adhere to the Resolution

('6', 348, 7, 10, 656494) Indian Opinion, 6 4 1907
('6', 348, 8, 11, 656519) 322. A WAY OUT OF DIFFICULTY
('6', 348, 9, 12, 656548) The Indian Mass Meeting, held the other day at Johannesburg, shows the earnestness with which British Indians in the Transvaal are fighting an uphill battle.
('6', 348, 9, 13, 656706) The central point of the proceedings was undoubtedly the Second Resolution, which embodied the eminently reasonable suggestion made by Mr. Abdool Gani, the Chairman of the Meeting and President of the British Indian Association.
('6', 348, 9, 14, 656935) If the Transvaal Government have any desire whatsoever to conciliate British Indians and to look at the situation from all points of view, they will accept the proposal without the slightest hesitation.
('6', 348, 9, 15, 657138) With statesmanlike moderation, British Indians have offered voluntarily to be re registered; they have offered to exchange the double documents they now hold for another document to be mutually approved; and although there is no legislative compulsion, they have agreed to submit to certain restrictions which the Government have considered to be necessary.
('6', 348, 9, 16, 657496) The Second Resolution is at once an earnest of the bona fides of the Indian community, and a way out of a delicate and difficult position.
('6', 348, 9, 17, 657635) We should be very much surprised if it were not a fact that the Transvaal Ministry is not pining for a tussle with the Imperial Government.
('6', 348, 9, 18, 657775) It should be thankful to take up the Indian suggestions, nor need Indians be at all frightened over the Resolution.
('6', 349, 0, 1, 657891) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 349, 1, 2, 657933) Whilst it undoubtedly exposes them once more to irksome procedure, in view of the prejudice existing in the Colony, it is necessary for them to undergo it.
('6', 349, 1, 3, 658089) The step taken voluntarily will redound to the eternal credit of the community, and it will pave the way for a reasonable settlement of the whole Indian question.
('6', 349, 1, 4, 658252) Moreover, the more the Indian community yields in a dignified manner, the more secure becomes its position in the event of the obnoxious Bill receiving the Royal sanction, and it being necessary for the community to enforce the Fourth Resolution of last September.
('6', 349, 1, 5, 658517) The Natal Advertiser has taken us to task for, as it terms it, “deliberately inciting the Transvaal British Indians to passive resistance”.
('6', 349, 1, 6, 658657) It is impossible for The Advertiser to enter into the feelings that actuate British Indians.
('6', 349, 1, 7, 658750) It is not a question of martyrdom, nor is it a question of offering resistance for the sake of it.
('6', 349, 1, 8, 658849) We have no hesitation in saying that to a loyal and law abiding community, passive resistance, as the proposed going to gaol has been termed for want of a better word, is a recognized method of obtaining redress; as a matter of fact, the going to gaol is a legal method of submission to law.
('6', 349, 1, 9, 659141) There are four things provided in the Bill: one is to submit to registration; secondly in its absence, to leave the country; thirdly, in the absence of either, to pay a fine if the option is reserved; lastly and fourthly, in the absence of any of the last three, to suffer imprisonment.
('6', 349, 1, 10, 659428) We cannot conceive that there is anything wrong for a British Indian to accept the last remedy, if he considers that registration is worse than gaol.
('6', 349, 1, 11, 659578) It is undoubtedly true that the last method is an extreme step justifiable under exceptional circumstances.
('6', 349, 1, 12, 659686) Whether or not a particular state creates such circumstances is a matter of opinion, and the prudence of a community is measured by its capacity for finding out the real state operating to justify that method.
('6', 349, 1, 13, 659896) If, then, all the moderate propositions submitted by the British Indians in the Transvaal fail to carry weight, and if the Imperial Government abdicate their function of protecting the weak against the strong, we re affirm our opinion that for the Indian community to be considered a self respecting body, no other course is left open, but with quiet courage and resignation, to prefer gaol to submission to the insult offered by the Bill.
('6', 349, 2, 14, 660336) Indian Opinion, 6 4 1907
('6', 350, 0, 1, 660361) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 351
('6', 350, 1, 2, 660405) 323. SUGGESTION TO OUR TRANSVAAL READERS
('6', 350, 2, 3, 660446) This number of Indian Opinion is in our view a very important one.
('6', 350, 2, 4, 660513) It carries a report of the Transvaal meeting 1 which every one should read carefully.
('6', 350, 2, 5, 660599) But it is especially necessary to get as many whites as possible to read the English report and to draw their attention to the Second Resolution in particular.
('6', 350, 2, 6, 660759) If they read it in the right spirit, we are sure they will support the suggestion contained therein.
('6', 350, 2, 7, 660860) If this should happen, the Bill would not come into force.
('6', 350, 2, 8, 660919) We therefore suggest that each reader order as many copies of this number as possible and distribute them among the whites and request them to read it.
('6', 350, 2, 9, 661071) In the belief that this hope of ours will be realized, we have printed extra copies of this number.
('6', 350, 2, 10, 661171) Copies may be had from the head office or from our Johannesburg office.
('6', 350, 2, 11, 661243) A four penny stamp for each copy may be sent with the order.
('6', 350, 2, 12, 661304) Merely to pass on a copy to a white without any explanation would be like throwing it away.
('6', 350, 2, 13, 661396) It would also be necessary to explain which portion he should read.
('6', 350, 3, 14, 661464) [From Gujarati]
('6', 350, 4, 15, 661480) Indian Opinion, 6 4 1907
('6', 350, 5, 16, 661505) 324. TRANSVAAL MASS MEETING2
('6', 350, 6, 17, 661534) Hundreds of Transvaal Indians met in Johannesburg on the 29th and passed a number of resolutions.
('6', 350, 6, 18, 661632) The function went off smoothly without any untoward incident, for which the British Indian Association deserves to be congratulated.
('6', 350, 6, 19, 661765) The situation at present is not such that, once the meetings are over, we can lapse into inactivity.
('6', 350, 6, 20, 661866) It is the duty of every Indian to put up sustained resistance.
('6', 350, 6, 21, 661929) We should bear in mind that the question does not concern the Transvaal alone.
('6', 350, 6, 22, 662008) Let us think about what we should do if the Bill were passed.
('6', 350, 6, 23, 662070) No one should presume that, because this mass meeting did not pass a resolution about going to gaol, the idea has been abandoned.
('6', 350, 6, 24, 662200) We have no other remedy left except going to gaol and, if the Indian community adheres to this resolve, it may bring in benefits all round.

('6', 351, 10, 23, 663963) A huge meeting of Indians was held at the Gaiety Theatre in Johannesburg on March 29 to protest against the Asiatic Act and pass the necessary resolutions.

('6', 352, 1, 10, 665460) A translation of Mr. Abdul Gani’s speech is given below:
('6', 352, 2, 11, 665517) WELCOME
('6', 352, 3, 12, 665525) It has fallen to me once again to welcome the Indians from Johannesburg and the delegates who have come to participate in the deliberations over important questions concerning our community.
('6', 352, 3, 13, 665716) The act which was rejected by Lord Elgin has been passed again by the new parliament.
('6', 352, 3, 14, 665802) Fortunately we were not under any illusion when we welcomed our Delegates on their return from England with the victory they had won.
('6', 352, 3, 15, 665936) We knew then that our work had just begun.
('6', 352, 3, 16, 665979) However, none of us had any suspicion at the time that the same law would be re enacted within 24 hours and that normal parliamentary procedure would be suspended for the purpose.
('6', 352, 3, 17, 666159) 1 Suspension of parliamentary procedure is nothing surprising; but it is done only in a great emergency.
('6', 352, 4, 18, 666264) 1 Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 30 3 1907.
('6', 353, 0, 1, 666305) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 353, 1, 2, 666347) HOW BILL CAME TO BE PASSED
('6', 353, 2, 3, 666374) If a state of real emergency had arisen and the country had to be saved, we could understand the rushing of a law through parliament; but on this occasion it was merely a fight between the lion and the goat.
('6', 353, 3, 4, 666582) WHITE AND BROWN
('6', 353, 4, 5, 666598) While, on the one hand, there are 250,000 whites who enjoy all political rights and the number goes on increasing monthly because they can enter without restriction, there are, on the other hand, 14,000 Indians whose number, it is said, increases by a hundred a month.
('6', 353, 4, 6, 666867) It is in order to protect the all powerful whites that the Act to keep out Indians without a permit has been passed.
('6', 353, 4, 7, 666984) People who do such a thing must be steeped in ill will against us.
('6', 353, 4, 8, 667051) Normally, the Act would have been placed before the public for consideration for three months and the champions of the Act, which is to protect the rights of 250,000 whites, would have had to run the risk only of 300 Indians entering the Transvaal.
('6', 353, 5, 9, 667300) HOW IS NEW LEGISLATURE?
('6', 353, 6, 10, 667324) It is deliberately that I describe our legislators as the custodians of the rights of the whites alone.
('6', 353, 6, 11, 667428) At any rate the members of the Council do nothing else.
('6', 353, 6, 12, 667484) It is said that the Legislative Council has been charged with the task of preventing the enactment of laws against the blacks.In fact, that this was their duty was urged as a reason when it was demanded that the Bill be postponed for the night.
('6', 353, 6, 13, 667729) But I must regretfully say that this was merely a ruse.
('6', 353, 6, 14, 667785) How could the members become familiar in a night with a bill, which was admittedly very important and complicated?
('6', 353, 6, 15, 667900) How could the Council gauge within a night the feelings and opinions of those whose rights it was supposed to protect?
('6', 353, 6, 16, 668019) Could the Council have passed the Bill as carelessly if the members had been elected by us?
('6', 353, 6, 17, 668111) Could it have ignored our humble demand that the Bill be postponed to enable us to place our case before it?
('6', 353, 6, 18, 668220) To prove that I am not making a mistake when I say this, I quote Mr. Curtis who is believed to be the author of this Bill.
('6', 353, 6, 19, 668343) He said, ‘I am glad that this Bill has come up before the Council.

('6', 359, 0, 1, 680464) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 359, 1, 2, 680506) THE PROPOSAL
('6', 359, 2, 3, 680519) This was in fact done during Lord Milner’s time and both he and Captain Fowled were happy with the Indian community.
('6', 359, 2, 4, 680636) This is the proposal that I make: (1) The Governmnt should fix a day for the simultaneous examination of all the permits.
('6', 359, 3, 5, 680758) (2) Either all of them should be stamped with the seal of the Colonial Secretary or, where the existing permits are genuine, they should be replaced by new ones and their form and contents should be decided on in consultation with the Indian community.
('6', 359, 4, 6, 681011) (3) Instead of the two documents, a permit and a registration [certificate] that are taken out at present, only one should be issued to Indians.
('6', 359, 5, 7, 681156) (4) Permits should also be issued to boys and girls who have come of age.
('6', 359, 6, 8, 681230) (5) No Indian should get a trade licence if he does not produce his permit.
('6', 359, 7, 9, 681306) (6) The children of lawful Indian residents should also receive permits.
('6', 359, 8, 10, 681379) (7) Temporary permits should be issued only after a surety approved by the Colonial Secretary is produced.
('6', 359, 9, 11, 681486) These proposals, if accepted, would solve all problems.
('6', 359, 9, 12, 681542) It is undoubtedly true that the observance of some of the provisions will depend on the goodwill of the Indian community; for example, not getting a trade licence without first having a permit.
('6', 359, 9, 13, 681736) But in such matters we ask the Government to trust us.
('6', 359, 9, 14, 681791) Again this [state of affairs] will not last long, for the whole problem will have to be solved quickly.
('6', 359, 9, 15, 681895) Moreover, these problems are not covered by the registration law; other laws will be required to solve them.
('6', 359, 11, 16, 682004) In your name, I appeal to the Government to accept our proposals.
('6', 359, 11, 17, 682070) That will end their conflict with the Imperial Government.
('6', 359, 11, 18, 682129) We do not want to be always complaining to the Imperial Govern ment.

('6', 363, 3, 8, 689554) SECOND RESOLUTION
('6', 363, 4, 9, 689572) This meeting convened under the auspices of the British Indian Association denies the allegation of illegal influx of Indians on a wholesale scale into the Transvaal, and, in order to satisfy the Govern ment and the people, offers to submit to voluntary re registration as was done by the community during Lord Milner’s| time and in the manner indicated in the chairman’s speech thus fulfilling practically all the requirements of the Bill without its offensive character.

('6', 364, 3, 4, 691373) NADIRSHAH CAMA I move this resolution.
('6', 364, 3, 5, 691412) We must understand the nature of this law.

('6', 366, 5, 9, 695369) MEANING OF SECOND RESOLUTION
('6', 366, 6, 10, 695398) Mr. Abdul Rehman had said that many people did not understand the Second Resolution; they felt that there was no difference between it and the Bill itself.
('6', 366, 6, 11, 695554) Replying to this Mr. Gandhi said:
('6', 366, 7, 12, 695588) It is after serious consideration by the leaders, and with their approval, that the Second Resolution is placed before the meeting.
('6', 366, 7, 13, 695720) Nevertheless, I take upon myself all responsibility for it.
('6', 366, 7, 14, 695780) I feel that the success of our Deputation to England was due solely to the fact that we had earlier taken out fresh permits and registers on Lord Milner’s advice.
('6', 366, 7, 15, 695943) If we had obstinately held out at that time, our plight would have become worse.
('6', 366, 7, 16, 696024) Lord Milner has written a letter to The Times in our favour.
('6', 366, 7, 17, 696085) That is, I think, because he understood the facts put before him by the Deputation.
('6', 366, 7, 18, 696169) For our part, just as we demand our rights vigorously and deny accusations against us where they are false, so should we admit our faults when we realize them.
('6', 366, 7, 19, 696329) Illegal entry by Indians is not as extensive as the whites allege.
('6', 366, 7, 20, 696396) We must nevertheless confess that some Indians do enter in this manner.
('6', 366, 7, 21, 696468) The more this happens the more severe will be the restrictions on us.
('6', 366, 7, 22, 696538) The Government argue that they cannot exercise an effective check [on illicit immigration] with the existing permits.
('6', 366, 7, 23, 696656) According to them, the thumb impressions on some are not clear, and a person sometimes sells his permit at one place and his register at another.
('6', 366, 7, 24, 696802) This is true to some extent; as a community, however, we do not accept this charge.
('6', 366, 7, 25, 696886) But the Government do not believe us.
('6', 366, 7, 26, 696924) It would only be right for us therefore to try to inspire confidence in them.
('6', 366, 7, 27, 697002) There would therefore be nothing wrong if we agreed to take out permits in the form acceptable to us, without the compulsion of law.
('6', 366, 7, 28, 697135) We therefore place the proposal before the Government that they give up the idea of
('6', 367, 0, 1, 697219) 368 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 367, 1, 2, 697261) passing the Act and we voluntarily take out fresh permits.
('6', 367, 1, 3, 697320) If it is accepted, it will do us credit; the Government will have faith in us; we may even be consulted in future when new legislation is contemplated, and above all the new Bill may be abandoned.
('6', 367, 1, 4, 697517) Anything voluntarily accepted by us cannot be regarded as humiliation.
('6', 367, 1, 5, 697588) Another outcome of our proposal will be that our humility, forbearance and good sense will be appreciated in England.
('6', 367, 1, 6, 697706) To prevent the passage of this Bill, there is, apart of course from gaol going, no better remedy than this.
('6', 367, 1, 7, 697814) Moreover, such [a system of] permits will be based on mutual understanding.
('6', 367, 1, 8, 697890) If therefore at any time we were confronted with any inordinate hardship, we could refuse to act on the understanding.
('6', 367, 1, 9, 698009) If gaol going—which we have been contemplating—comes after this proposal, it will appear more graceful.
('6', 367, 1, 10, 698113) The ultimate remedy is, of course, gaol going.
('6', 367, 1, 11, 698160) The fact that this time we have not passed any resolution about going to gaol does not mean that, if the Bill is passed, we are not to court imprisonment.
('6', 367, 1, 12, 698315) No one should put the idea of going to gaol out of his mind.
('6', 367, 1, 13, 698376) After a vote of thanks to the chair, the meeting dispersed.

('6', 368, 26, 38, 700429) RESOLUTION OF SYMPATHY FOR TRANSVAAL INDIANS A largely attended meeting of the Natal Indian Congress was
('6', 368, 27, 39, 700534) 1 This was forwarded to the Under Secretary of State for the Colonies by L. W. Ritch on April 9. 2 Vide “Chamney’s Report”,13 4 1907.
('6', 369, 0, 1, 700668) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 369, 1, 2, 700710) held on Monday the 8th at about 8.30 p.m.
('6', 369, 1, 3, 700752) under the chairmanship of Mr. Dawad Mahomed.
('6', 369, 1, 4, 700797) Many members were present.
('6', 369, 1, 5, 700824) After the minutes of the last meeting and the accounts, etc., had been passed, a resolu tion, moved by Mr. Motilal Dewan and seconded by Mr. Peeran Mahomed, was passed expressing the sympathy of the Natal Indian Congress for the Transvaal Indians in their campaign against the Asiatic [Registration] Bill and appealing to the Imperial Government to accord adequate protection to the Indian community.
('6', 369, 1, 6, 701225) The Secretaries were asked to cable the resolution to the Imperial Government.
('6', 369, 2, 7, 701304) OMAR HAJI AMOD ZAVERI’S RESIGNATION After this, the resignation of Mr. Omar Haji Amod Zaveri, who intends to go to India, was placed before the Congress for considera tion.
('6', 369, 2, 8, 701477) Mr. Gandhi, who was present at the meeting, said that the Cong ress had no alternative but to accept Mr. Zaveri’s resignation, and added that, though there was no other Indian who could fill the void, the best solution was to appoint Mr. Dada Osman as Joint Secretary.
('6', 369, 2, 9, 701746) Mr. Abdul Kadir was of the opinion that Mr. Zaveri’s resigna tion should be accepted with effect from the date of his departure and that it would be only right to hold another meeting to consider his resignation and the appointment of another Secretary.
('6', 369, 2, 10, 702000) Mr. Peeran Mahomed also supported Mr. Abdul Kadir’s view and the subject of the resignation and appointment [of a successor] was postponed till the next meeting.
('6', 369, 2, 11, 702162) Mr. Lawrence’s letter suggesting the admission of young persons [to membership of the Congress] at reduced rates of subscri ption was then taken up for consideration.
('6', 369, 2, 12, 702329) After some deliberation, a resolution moved by Mr. Gandhi and seconded by Mr. Abdul Kadir was unanimously passed, appointing a committee consisting of Mr. Dawad Mahomed, the two Secretaries, Mr. Peeran Mahomed, Mr. Abdul Kadir, Mr. Abdul Haji Adam, Mr. Ismail Gora Mahomed and Mr. Gandhi to meet Mr. Lawrence and his friends [in this connect ion].
('6', 369, 2, 13, 702677) The committee was asked to suggest the necessary changes in the rules, regulations and the constitution of the Congress.
('6', 369, 2, 14, 702798) The meeting then dispersed.
('6', 369, 2, 15, 702826) After the scheduled meeting was over, Mr. Gandhi made a short speech.
('6', 369, 2, 16, 702896) He pointed out that malaria appeared to have broken out in epidemic form among the Indians on the east coast of Umgeni, 1 and
('6', 369, 3, 17, 703022) 1 Vide “Malaria and Duty of Indians”, 23 3 1907.
('6', 370, 0, 1, 703071) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 371
('6', 370, 1, 2, 703115) it was necessary for the community to help them to the utmost.
('6', 370, 1, 3, 703178) Young men who could spare the time should attend to the poor patients.
('6', 370, 1, 4, 703249) Dr. Nanji had offered all possible help, and if volunteers came forward to tend the sick, much useful work could be done.
('6', 370, 1, 5, 703371) It would redound to the fair name of the community and the volunteers would earn the gratitude of poor patients.
('6', 370, 1, 6, 703484) Even a single individual could do much.
('6', 370, 1, 7, 703524) The main thing to do was to go to the river bank, find the patients, inquire about their condition and report to the Congress Secretaries and to Dr. Nanji.
('6', 370, 1, 8, 703680) Many young men had already come forward to do this work with zeal.

('6', 370, 2, 10, 703789) 330. LETTER TO “THE NATAL ADVERTISER”1
('6', 370, 3, 11, 703828) MARITZBURG, April 9, 1907
('6', 370, 4, 12, 703854) [TO THE EDITOR NATAL ADVERTISER DURBAN]
('6', 370, 6, 13, 703894) You, as well as your contemporary The Natal Mercury, have commented adversely upon Reuter’s telegram regarding the report of the Registrar of Asiatics, published in the Transvaal, on the working of the permit system.
('6', 370, 6, 14, 704111) If the facts as you state were true, every word stated by you would be justified, and in order to deserve the credit for honesty, which you have been good enough to give me, I should undoubtedly have to recall all I have said in public in opposition to the allegations as to illegal Asiatic influx into the Transvaal on a wholesale basis.
('6', 370, 6, 15, 704450) Happily for the cause I have the privilege of serving, it is not necessary for me to withdraw anything I have hitherto said, for the simple reason that Reuter’s agency has been instrument all quite unwittingly—in telegraphing an utter mis statement.
('6', 370, 6, 16, 704700) It will now be difficult to entirely undo the mischief created.
('6', 370, 6, 17, 704764) Reuter’s telegram
('6', 370, 7, 18, 704782) 1 The Editor, The Natal Advertiser, replied as follows: “...As we are not in possession as yet of the report itself, we are unable to decide between Mr. Gandhi’s interpretation of it and Reuter’s...”
('6', 371, 0, 1, 704982) 372 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 371, 1, 2, 705024) stated that out of 12,543 registrations only 4,144 were accepted as valid.
('6', 371, 1, 3, 705099) This is a condensation of a statement in the report which I have before me, and the condensation gives a meaning opposite to the one intended by the writer of the report.
('6', 371, 1, 4, 705270) Allow me to state the position as briefly as I can.
('6', 371, 1, 5, 705322) Registration is not to be mixed up with the taking out of permits.
('6', 371, 1, 6, 705389) In 1903 there were 12,543 Asiatics at least in theTransvaal with lawful authority.
('6', 371, 1, 7, 705472) Lord Milner some time during the year issued instructions to enforce Law 3 of 1885 and to exact £3 from those Asiatics who had not paid the amount to the late Boer Government, and in order to establish a uniform system of registration, he advised the Indian community to take out new certificates, both for those who had taken out £3 certificates before and those who had not.
('6', 371, 2, 8, 705849) This position the Indian community voluntarily accepted in order to please His Lordship.
('6', 371, 2, 9, 705938) What Mr. Chamney says in his report is that out of 12,543 men who presented themselves for registration, 4,144 were able to make good their claim for exemption from payment of £3. How many claimants were rejected is not stated, but the point is perfectly clear that this registration did not affect the validity of the permits already issued.
('6', 371, 2, 10, 706281) As a matter of fact, registration was granted only in favour of those who were in possession of permits.
('6', 371, 2, 11, 706386) The statement wired by Reuter, therefore, means that all but 4,144 had to pay the sum of £3 in order to take out registration certificates, which did not in any way replace the permits already issued, so that your inference that 8,000 have managed to enter the Colony illegally is quite wide of the mark.
('6', 371, 2, 12, 706691) The fact that 144 Asiatics died, and only four of their permits were recovered proves nothing except that the dead men forgot to return their permits in anticipa tion.
('6', 371, 2, 13, 706859) There is no law with reference to the return of these documents, and it should be remembered that the men died not in the Transvaal, but in India.
('6', 371, 2, 14, 707006) The only paragraph, therefore, in the report under discussion, dealing with illegal influx, is that wherein 876 men are alleged to have been found without permits or with stolen permits.
('6', 371, 2, 15, 707193) Assuming the accuracy of the figures given by Mr. Chamney, all that has been proved is that about fifty stragglers per month entered the Transvaal on false permits or without any.
('6', 371, 2, 16, 707373) I will not trespass on your courtesy by entering into further discussion beyond stating, without meaning any disparagement to Mr. Chamney, that he, lacking the judicial spirit, has not been able to distinguish between suspicion and proof, and has made statements which do not bear a judicial scrutiny.
('6', 372, 0, 1, 707675) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 373
('6', 372, 1, 2, 707719) They are no more than assertions unsupported by facts, though, as I have already stated, even the one assertion made in support of an illegal influx is capable of being very much boiled down.
('6', 372, 1, 3, 707911) There is, however, nothing in that report to prove that there has been any encouragement on the part of the Indian community as a whole to an illegal entry nor of illegal influx on a wholesale basis.
('6', 372, 1, 4, 708111) No one has ever denied the existence altogether of illegal entries, but it is the wholesale basis that has been challenged, and Mr. Chamney’s report, even taken as it is, without considering the natural defects I have drawn attention to, furnishes a complete vindication of the British Indian position.
('6', 372, 1, 5, 708414) Incidentally, I might mention that your Johannesburg contemporary, The Rand Daily Mail, who had the opportunity of reading the report itself, has come to the conclusion opposite to yours, and it now asks whether, after all, the new Bill is any cure for the evil of illegal entries so far as they have been proved.
('6', 372, 2, 6, 708728) Yours, etc.
('6', 372, 3, 7, 708740) M. K. GANDHI
('6', 372, 4, 8, 708753) The Natal Advertiser, 11 4 1907
('6', 372, 5, 9, 708785) 331. CHAMNEY’S REPORT
('6', 372, 6, 10, 708807) Our Johannesburg correspondent’s summary of Mr. Chamney’s Report is well worth the reading.
('6', 372, 6, 11, 708899) It bears out three things: Mr. Chamney’s hatred of the Indian community, his lack of a sense of justice and the validity of the facts stated by the Indian community.
('6', 372, 6, 12, 709065) Mr. Chamney’s hatred is in evidence in every line he has written.
('6', 372, 6, 13, 709131) He has made mountains out of molehills, and has at times made unfounded statements.
('6', 372, 6, 14, 709215) He says that many people sell old registers for large sums of money but has not been able to adduce any evidence.
('6', 372, 6, 15, 709329) He has mentioned 876 persons as having entered without permits, but does not indicate how they did it.
('6', 372, 6, 16, 709432) He does not have the rights of a magistrate and cannot therefore say of a particular person that he has entered unlawfully.
('6', 372, 6, 17, 709556) He can only express his suspicion of people having entered without permits.
('6', 372, 6, 18, 709632) However, when he asserts that some persons have come in without permits, it only shows his animus and lack of a sense of justice.
('6', 372, 6, 19, 709762) Again, he says that the many Indians who were sent back from Durban and others who entered surreptitiously and were arrested are not included in the 876
('6', 373, 0, 1, 709915) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 373, 1, 2, 709957) mentioned earlier.
('6', 373, 1, 3, 709976) Not one of these facts has any relevance to establishing the number of people who have entered unlawfully.
('6', 373, 1, 4, 710083) He has brought in these facts only to magnify the issue.
('6', 373, 1, 5, 710140) Despite this exaggerated statement of facts, it is not proved that the Indian community gets many persons to enter without permits or that many persons do in fact enter without them.
('6', 373, 1, 6, 710323) Even if Mr. Chamney’s figure is correct, it will only mean that 50 percent Indians have entered the Transvaal each month; it will be quite improper to term this an invasion.
('6', 373, 1, 7, 710497) Again, Mr. Chamney’s Report bears out the Indian community’s statement that the new Bill is absolutely unnecessary.
('6', 373, 1, 8, 710613) He points out that there is nothing in the existing law to compel a person to give his thumb impression.
('6', 373, 1, 9, 710718) This is not true, for the Indian community has never been unwilling to give thumb impressions.
('6', 373, 1, 10, 710813) Besides, if anyone refuses, he can be charged with staying on [in the Colony] without a permit and brought before a court, where he will have to give his thumb impression.
('6', 373, 1, 11, 710985) The new Bill, then, is superfluous if it is only for taking a thumb impression.
('6', 373, 1, 12, 711065) Now Mr. Chamney also says that the law as it stands is inadequate to prevent children from entering the Colony.
('6', 373, 1, 13, 711177) If that were really so, then [how is it that] we do not find any restrictions in the new Bill on the entry of children accompanying their parents[?] This means that the new law does not provide that remedy and that the new Bill is therefore altogether useless.
('6', 373, 1, 14, 711438) Even The Rand Daily Mail now admits this.
('6', 373, 1, 15, 711480) Taking all this into consideration, we see that Mr. Chamney’s Report cannot at all be taken seriously.

('6', 376, 7, 11, 715893) 338. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('6', 376, 8, 12, 715918) DEPUTATION TO SMUTS I wrote last week that a deputation would wait upon Mr. Smuts and place before him the resolution passed at the mass meeting.
('6', 376, 8, 13, 716064) 5 Mr. Smuts had fixed Thursday the 4th for the interview.
('6', 376, 8, 14, 716122) Under a special arrangement with the General Manager of the Railways, Messrs Abdul Gani, Coovadia, Essop Mian, Haji Ojer Ally, Moonlight and Gandhi travelled from Johannesburg to Pretoria by the 8.35 express train.
('6', 376, 8, 15, 716337) At Pretoria they were joined by Messrs Mahomed Haji Joosab and Gaurishankar Vyas.
('6', 376, 8, 16, 716419) They reached the Colonial Office exactly at 12, where Mr. Chamney was also present.
('6', 376, 8, 17, 716503) Mr. Gandhi narrated all the facts to Mr. Smuts.
('6', 376, 8, 18, 716551) He reminded Mr. Smuts that the Indian community had itself registered several times.
('6', 376, 8, 19, 716636) He said that Mr. Chamney’s Report supported the Indian contention and showed in other ways also that the Indians were trust worthy.
('6', 376, 8, 20, 716768) It was with the help of the Indian community that officials of the Asiatic Office who took bribes had been arrested.
('6', 376, 8, 21, 716885) Taking al] this into consideration, Mr. Gandhi said, the Government should, on this occasion, agree to the proposal of voluntary registration made in the Second Resolution passed by the mass meeting.
('6', 376, 8, 22, 717085) Then Mr. Haji Ojer Ally advanced further arguments to bear out what Mr. Gandhi had said and drew Mr. Smuts’s attention to the loyalty of the Indian community.
('6', 376, 8, 23, 717244) Messrs Abdul Gani and Essop
('6', 376, 9, 24, 717272) 1 Clealy, these figures contain printing errors.
('6', 376, 9, 25, 717321) 2 ibid 3 ibid 4 ibid 5 Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, before 4 4 1907.

('6', 377, 1, 2, 717431) Mian also used other arguments and pointed out the difficulties they had in bringing servants, etc.
('6', 377, 1, 3, 717531) [from India].
('6', 377, 1, 4, 717545) Mr. Smuts listened to this carefully for more than three quarters of an hour.
('6', 377, 1, 5, 717623) At the end he said that he had heard several things for the first time, and these he said he would inquire into and send a written reply 1; but the deputation should not interpret this to mean that the Government would agree to the Second Resolution.

('6', 377, 2, 14, 718714) CHAMNEY’S REPORT2
('6', 377, 3, 15, 718732) Mr. Chamney’s Report for the year 1906 has been published.
('6', 377, 3, 16, 718791) It says that 12,899 permits had been issued to Asiatics till December 31, 1905. The Government’s decision was to issue permits to those Asiatics who had been resident in the Transvaal before the war.
('6', 377, 3, 17, 718991) It was difficult to ascertain who the old residents of the Transvaal were as the registers maintained before 1899 had been lost.
('6', 377, 3, 18, 719120) Moreover, as receipts were issued [without names?] to those who paid the £3 tax, it was impossible to determine who had paid the amount [sic].
('6', 377, 3, 19, 719263) Many persons used to sell these certificates at high prices.
('6', 377, 3, 20, 719324) Of the 12,543 permit holders, 4,144 had earlier paid £3 each.
('6', 377, 3, 21, 719386) On some registers it was found that something had been over written in Hindustani which would suggest that the registers must have originally belonged to other persons.
('6', 377, 3, 22, 719555) In the issue of permits the concurrence of two authorities is at present necessary.
('6', 377, 3, 23, 719639) The first is that of the Coast Agent

('6', 378, 1, 2, 719803) posted at Durban who investigates and the other of the Advisory Boards which have been set up at various places and include Europeans.
('6', 378, 1, 3, 719938) At Johannesburg the investigation is made by the Police Commissioner, and no permit is issued to anyone who fails to produce satisfactory evidence.
('6', 378, 1, 4, 720086) In all, 598 permits were issued from 1905 to December 1906; 3,286 applications for permits were rejected.
('6', 378, 1, 5, 720192) Of these, 1,240 were Indian and 1,238 Chinese.
('6', 378, 1, 6, 720239) In addition to these, there are many Asiatics in the Transvaal who have entered the Colony without a permit or with permits belonging to others.
('6', 378, 1, 7, 720384) All these persons cannot be apprehended as they cannot all be forced to give their thumb impressions.

('6', 379, 1, 2, 721685) COMMENTS BY “THE RAND DAILY MAIL”
('6', 379, 2, 3, 721719) The Rand Daily Mail of Johannesburg has strongly criticized the Report.
('6', 379, 2, 4, 721791) It says that Mr. Chamney has given the reasons for restricting Asiatic immigration; but he has not been able to show that anything more than the existing Act is necessary.
('6', 379, 2, 5, 721963) Mr. Chamney’s Report conclusively shows that the present procedure has failed.
('6', 379, 2, 6, 722042) If that is so, that procedure is not likely to change under the new law.
('6', 379, 2, 7, 722115) There is no reason to believe that any great change will be effected in the matter of taking ten finger prints instead of the thumb impression.
('6', 379, 2, 8, 722259) What is now needed is therefore not a new law but a new procedure.
('6', 379, 2, 9, 722326) If a new procedure is evolved in consultation with the leaders of the Indian community, it will be very convenient and avoid friction— which at present appears probable—with the Imperial Government.
('6', 379, 2, 10, 722525) It would have been better if Mr. Chamney had, instead of merely pointing out the existing defects, shown the way for the future.

('6', 379, 5, 19, 723524) These suggestions have not yet been accepted.

('6', 380, 1, 2, 723845) WARNING ABOUT PERMITS It came to my knowledge from several sources that some persons, especially a white among them, have been selling permits to Indians.
('6', 380, 1, 3, 724000) This is very likely true.
('6', 380, 1, 4, 724026) Heavy sums are being paid for such permits by some Indians.
('6', 380, 1, 5, 724086) I must tell them that such permits are of no use whatever.
('6', 380, 1, 6, 724145) Those buying them would be committing an offence, which would be like paying for bringing trouble upon oneself.
('6', 380, 1, 7, 724257) It should be easy to see that there will be no duplicates of false permits in the Permit Office and that permits of which no duplicates are available in the Permit Office will be considered faked.
('6', 380, 2, 8, 724454) CLARIFICATION OF MARCH 31 NOTICE The Editor has forwarded to me a question raised by a correspondent from Johannesburg.
('6', 380, 2, 9, 724574) The correspondent inquires whether the holder of a register who fails to get a permit before March 31 will be liable only to being served with a notice asking him to quit the Transvaal or if he will also be punished in some other way.
('6', 380, 2, 10, 724809) The answer is that a person charged with staying in the Transvaal without a permit, will only get a notice.

('6', 381, 7, 10, 725894) I am glad that you are better now.
('6', 381, 8, 11, 725929) It is likely that the money from Gaurishankar will be received here.

('6', 383, 3, 22, 730914) Where such a relationship obtains, the family prospers; a people, similarly, thrives on such relationships.
('6', 383, 3, 23, 731022) This is one of the potent causes of the prosperity of the British.
('6', 383, 3, 24, 731089) They do not envy the rise of their kith and kin.

('6', 384, 2, 10, 732221) 343. LADYSMITH APPEALS
('6', 384, 3, 11, 732244) The outcome of the eleven Ladysmith appeals that were preferred to the Supreme Court has confirmed our expectations.Since the licensing court 1 gave judgement without taking any evidence, these cases cannot really be called appeals.
('6', 384, 3, 12, 732477) The Supreme Court has on this ground set aside the judgement of the appellate court and ordered a re hearing of these cases.
('6', 384, 3, 13, 732602) The eleven applicants who have been refused licences can appeal again.
('6', 384, 3, 14, 732673) And if, after taking evidence, the appellate court still refuses obstinately to issue a licence, there is nothing the applicants can do.
('6', 384, 3, 15, 732810) It is a bad thing that in this case the court has not allowed costs to the appellants, as it did in the Somnath Maharaj case.
('6', 384, 3, 16, 732936) If costs had been allowed, the appellate court would have been a little more careful.
('6', 384, 3, 17, 733022) We cannot regard the [result of the] appeals as a complete victory.
('6', 384, 3, 18, 733090) The Licensing Act remains what it has always been.
('6', 384, 3, 19, 733141) But since we did not expect any sensational result, there is no cause for despair.
('6', 384, 3, 20, 733224) The Natal Indian Congress must persevere with the struggle.
('6', 384, 3, 21, 733284) If adequate efforts are made, the licensing act will be repealed.

('6', 385, 5, 14, 734413) COLONIAL SECRETARY’S REPLY
('6', 385, 6, 15, 734440) I have already reported on the deputation.
('6', 385, 6, 16, 734483) 1 The following is the reply 2 received from Mr. Smuts.
('6', 385, 6, 17, 734539) 1. I am obliged to the Indian community for your letter of the 30th and for the representation made to me during the Indian deputation’s interview with me on the Asiatic Registration Act and other subjects.
('6', 385, 6, 18, 734746) Objecting to the new Act the deputation said that it would only serve to harass the Indian community, that it was unneces sary in view of the community’s willingness to take out new registers voluntarily, and that it was humiliating because it made registration compulsory.
('6', 385, 6, 19, 735020) The deputation also pointed out that the [Indian] grievance regarding land rights under Law[3] of 1885was not being redressed, and that the difficulties experienced by those coming to
('6', 385, 7, 20, 735204) 1 Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 20 4 1907. 2 Smuts had promised a written reply to the Indian deputation which met him in connection with the new Transvaal Asiatic Registration Act.

('6', 386, 0, 1, 735423) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 387
('6', 386, 1, 2, 735467) the Colony for a temporary stay should be remedied.
('6', 386, 1, 3, 735519) 2. All this has been carefully considered and I have to point out that Section 17 of the new Act provides for the issue of a temporary permit.
('6', 386, 1, 4, 735662) 3. As for land rights, I regret to say that the Government can grant no more relief than the specific reference in Section 21 to the land belonging to a particular person.
('6', 386, 2, 5, 735834) 4. As for the other grounds on which objections have been raised against the Act, I have to assure you that the Government intends no insult to the Asiatic community.
('6', 386, 2, 6, 736001) At the same time, it cannot be deniedthat the question of marks which will make the identification of Asiatic people possible is full of difficulties.
('6', 386, 2, 7, 736152) The main aim of the new Act is to adopt such means as will make it easy to identify persons of that community with a view to ascertaining who are entitled to reside here.
('6', 386, 2, 8, 736323) The new Act is necessary to achieve this object.
('6', 386, 2, 9, 736372) I regret to have to say that the suggestion made by the deputation about fresh registrationcannot be accepted.
('6', 386, 2, 10, 736483) For doing so a proviso for compul sory registration is necessary.
('6', 386, 2, 11, 736549) Moreover, I cannot see how you could say with certainty that your word would be binding on other Asiatic communities, and particularly on those residing without a permit.
('6', 386, 2, 12, 736720) 5. There is no doubt that many whites hold that a number of Asiatics is infiltrating into this territory without permits.
('6', 386, 2, 13, 736842) And they also find that people have been doing so because there is no adequate law in force to identify the [lawfully resident] Asiatics.
('6', 386, 2, 14, 736980) It is not possible for the Government to ignore this feeling.
('6', 386, 2, 15, 737042) Moreover, the Government has strong evidence of such unlawful infiltration.
('6', 386, 2, 16, 737118) Considering this matter, I am sorry to find that, in your meeting and speeches, people have been advised to disobey the law by not registering themselves.
('6', 386, 2, 17, 737273) In your own interests, I expect you will not advocate a course of action that will make it impossible for us to grant special concessions to your community.
('6', 386, 2, 18, 737430) I sincerely hope therefore that your community, which has always had the privilege of being considered law abiding, will maintain its reputation in the matter and that Indians will co operate with the Government in every way by registering themselves lawfully, gracefully and expeditiously.
('6', 386, 2, 19, 737721) The Act has been framed in the
('6', 386, 3, 20, 737752) 1 The reference is to the specific provision exempting the heirs of Abubaker Amod Zaveri from Law 3 of 1885 and other laws relating to ownership of land by Indians.

('6', 387, 1, 2, 738023) interests of both the Asiatics and the whites.
('6', 387, 1, 3, 738070) If the Act were regarded as not binding, greater pressure would be brought on the Government as well as parliament to take more stringent measures to prevent Asiatics from entering without a permit.
('6', 387, 2, 4, 738269) REFLECTIONS ON REPLY The reply is at once good and bad, timorous and threatening.
('6', 387, 2, 5, 738351) I call it good because it is courteous.
('6', 387, 2, 6, 738391) If the Government wanted to disregard the Indian community altogether, they could have disposed of the matter with a two line reply, without giving reasons.
('6', 387, 2, 7, 738548) The reason why I call it bad is that Mr. Smuts hesitates to accept even our most reasonable demands.
('6', 387, 2, 8, 738649) It is timorous, because of the ideas [of Indians], [their] resolutions and speeches on the subject of gaol going, the Government is afraid that the Indian community may [actually] display such strength, for then the Act may be proved ineffective.
('6', 387, 2, 9, 738896) It is threatening, because the Government, being frightened as we have shown above, hold out the threat that, if we do not accept the law, more stringent measures will follow; they hope that they can avoid a difficult situation if, under the threat of severe consequences, we can be made to give up the idea of going to gaol.
('6', 387, 2, 10, 739222) Now what is to be done?
('6', 387, 2, 11, 739246) The present is a crucial moment.
('6', 387, 2, 12, 739279) If we are imbued with the right spirit and care for our honour, we shall win.
('6', 387, 2, 13, 739357) We should certainly not be cowed down by the Government’s threat, for what greater pain can they inflict on us than the law they have already passed?
('6', 387, 2, 14, 739507) What greater harm can be done to a man than to divest him of his honour?
('6', 387, 2, 15, 739580) On the one hand, we are being persuaded to help in enforcing the law and, on the other, they pass an act which proclaims that, in the whole Indian community, there is not a single person trustworthy enough to be exempted from holding a registration certificate, that is, a “thief pass”.
('6', 387, 2, 16, 739867) We are first made out to be thieves and our help is then sought in enforcing the law!
('6', 387, 2, 17, 739953) Nowhere is it stated [in Mr. Smuts’s reply] that even a single right will be granted to us.
('6', 387, 2, 18, 740045) The land right has been flatly denied.
('6', 387, 2, 19, 740084) Locations still loom before our eyes.
('6', 387, 2, 20, 740122) What further humiliation can be inflicted on those who have been degraded to the lowest depths?
('6', 387, 2, 21, 740218) In the present age and according to European standards, there can be no love without fear.
('6', 387, 2, 22, 740309) We have the example of Mr. Smuts’s own people with whom the British Government argued in a similar fashion.
('6', 387, 2, 23, 740417) They told President Kruger that it would be better to concede certain rights

('6', 388, 1, 5, 740675) He himself remained courageous and inspired bravery in his people, and thus immortalized them and himself.
('6', 388, 1, 6, 740782) As a result, the people have today regained what was once theirs.

('6', 388, 1, 14, 741457) It is politely worded, but upholds our honour.
('6', 388, 1, 15, 741504) A translation of it is given below:
('6', 388, 2, 16, 741540) ASSOCIATION’S REPLY
('6', 388, 3, 17, 741560) I have received your letter of the 8th instant about the suggestion of the Indian community regarding the Asiatic Bill.
('6', 388, 3, 18, 741680) My Association is very grateful to the Government for its deta iled and sympathetic reply.
('6', 388, 3, 19, 741771) However, I approach them with a request to reconsider the matter in the light of the following.
('6', 388, 3, 20, 741867) The objections raised by the Indian community are so impor tant, and the suggestion it has made so just and proper that my Association finds it necessary to persuade the Government to accept it.
('6', 388, 3, 21, 742062) May I take the liberty of reminding you that, under Lord Milner’s advice, the Indian community had agreed to registra tion on the same lines as now proposed, and that the Chinese community had also accepted it?
('6', 388, 3, 22, 742273) My Association would humbly state that there is no need to make a promise, as the proposal is such that it could be immediately implemented.
('6', 388, 3, 23, 742414) Moreover, it can be ascertained, without loss of time, how many Asiatics are agreeable to taking out the new registers in place of their pre sent permits.
('6', 388, 3, 24, 742569) Your Honour’s letter raises the question of permitless persons.
('6', 388, 3, 25, 742633) But that question does not arise from our suggestion or from the new Act.
('6', 388, 3, 26, 742707) For in neither case will such men be able to obtain permits.
('6', 388, 3, 27, 742768) When fresh registration is completed, it will
('6', 389, 0, 1, 742814) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 389, 1, 2, 742856) remain only to detect those without permits, and to serve them with ‘quit’ notices for unlawful residence in the Colony.
('6', 389, 1, 3, 742977) My Association admits that European residents are excited about many Indians entering the Colony without permits and it is for that very reason that my community has made the forego ing suggestion which provides for adequate means of our identi fication.
('6', 389, 1, 4, 743232) And when the existing documents are withdrawn [after the issue of new registers,] there will be no difficulty about identification.
('6', 389, 1, 5, 743364) However, I must say that, whatever the means for establishing identity, those bent on entering surreptitiously will continue todo so anyhow.
('6', 389, 1, 6, 743505) I must also add that not many persons enter in this manner and that Mr. Chamney’s Report is enough proof of it.
('6', 389, 1, 7, 743617) My Association therefore prays that the Government reconsider the matter, and hopes that, after doing so, they will come to entertain a better opinion of the Indian community’s proposal.
('6', 389, 1, 8, 743804) You refer to the Resolutions about defying the law.
('6', 389, 1, 9, 743856) We must point out in reply that there can be no question of defying the law at all.
('6', 389, 1, 10, 743940) However, if, for any reason, Indians’ respect for the law is put to a severe strain and if in that context the community seeks to vindicate its honour and prestige, the only way open to it will be to submit to the ultimate penalty prescribed by law, that is, to go to gaol.
('6', 389, 1, 11, 744214) Such action cannot be construed as a desire on the part of the Indian community to disobey the law.
('6', 389, 1, 12, 744314) However, the community desires humbly to point out that the new law gravely offends against its feelings.
('6', 389, 1, 13, 744420) It implies that the Indian community wishes to defeat the objects of the law.
('6', 389, 1, 14, 744498) On the contrary, through this suggestion, the community [seeks to] fulfil the intention of the law.
('6', 389, 1, 15, 744598) My Association therefore humbly requests that the Indian proposal be given a trial before the law is enforced.
('6', 389, 1, 16, 744709) It makes this suggestion in the conviction that all Asiatic communities will act according to it.
('6', 389, 2, 17, 744807) CONSEQUENCE OF REPLY It cannot be predicted how the Government will react to this reply.
('6', 389, 2, 18, 744896) But it is certain that it will set the Government thinking.
('6', 389, 2, 19, 744956) They have themselves raised the question of gaol going.
('6', 389, 2, 20, 745012) If we retract now,
('6', 390, 0, 1, 745031) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 391
('6', 390, 1, 2, 745075) that will only serve to show up the abjectness of the community.
('6', 390, 1, 3, 745140) The reply has in it neither bitterness nor threat.
('6', 390, 1, 4, 745191) It is polite but firm, and reflects the courageous mood of the community.
('6', 390, 2, 5, 745265) CHINESE MOVE
('6', 390, 3, 6, 745278) The Chinese leaders met last Saturday at Mr. Gandhi’s office and resolved to support the Indian community.
('6', 390, 3, 7, 745385) The Chinese Consul has also given them similar advice.
('6', 390, 3, 8, 745440) It is thus seen that we get support from all quarters.
('6', 390, 4, 9, 745495) ASIATIC EATING HOUSES
('6', 390, 5, 10, 745517) Notwithstanding the Association’s struggle against the regulat ions concerning Asiatic eating houses, they have been passed and already published in the Government Gazette.
('6', 390, 5, 11, 745690) Those who run eating houses therefore must take out licences.
('6', 390, 5, 12, 745752) It should be remembered that, if their kitchens and dining rooms are not found absolutely clean, they will not be issued a licence.
('6', 390, 6, 13, 745884) RUMOUR OF ASSENT TO NEW LAW A rumour was going the rounds here that Lord Elgin had approved the new law.
('6', 390, 6, 14, 745989) On an enquiry by the Association it was learnt that no such thing had happened and that the rumour was unfounded.
('6', 390, 6, 15, 746103) WARNING Great caution is necessary in this matter.
('6', 390, 6, 16, 746154) In spite of the tremendous efforts being made, Lord Elgin may after all append his signature to the law.
('6', 390, 6, 17, 746259) It is desirable therefore that those engaged in trade should take out a shopkeeper’s or hawker’s licence for the whole year.
('6', 390, 6, 18, 746384) If they do that, their trade will not be affected at least this year even if the law should come into force.
('6', 390, 6, 19, 746493) If in the meanwhile gaol going is resorted to, the law cannot but be repealed ultimately.

('6', 391, 4, 8, 747462) OSMAN LATIEF’S LETTER
('6', 391, 5, 9, 747484) Mr. Oman under the pen name of “British Indian”, has written a letter to the local Press, in which he has pointed out that the Indian community has taken out registers several times, that the objection based on competition in trade is untenable, and that justice must be done to the Indian community, keeping in view Queen Victoria’s assurances and those of others and the community’s own readiness to share in the defence of the British Empire.

('6', 393, 0, 1, 750553) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 393, 1, 2, 750595) 347. LETTER TO LAKSHMIDAS GANDHI
('6', 393, 2, 3, 750628) [About April 20, 1907] 1
('6', 393, 3, 4, 750653) RESPECTED SIR,
('6', 393, 4, 5, 750668) I have received your letter.
('6', 393, 4, 6, 750697) I wish to answer it with the utmost calmness and as fully as possible.
('6', 393, 4, 7, 750768) I shall first put my thoughts before you as they come to my mind, and then answer your questions.
('6', 393, 4, 8, 750866) I am afraid our outlooks differ widely and I see no possibility, for the present, of their being reconciled.
('6', 393, 4, 9, 750975) You seek peace and happiness through money.
('6', 393, 4, 10, 751019) I don’t depend on money for my peace; and for the moment at any rate my mind is quite calm and able to stand any amount of suffering.
('6', 393, 4, 11, 751153) Like you, I too believe in the old traditions, but there is a difference in our beliefs.
('6', 393, 4, 12, 751242) For you believe in age old superstitions, while I not only do not but consider it sinful to believe in them.
('6', 393, 4, 13, 751351) You desire to attain moksha 2, so do I. Nevertheless, your notion of that state seems to be widely different from mine.
('6', 393, 4, 14, 751471) Though I have the highest regard for you, untainted by any mean or selfish thought, you harbour hatred for me in your mind.
('6', 393, 4, 15, 751595) The reason for this, as I see it, is that you are overcome by attachment and maintain relationships for selfish ends.
('6', 393, 4, 16, 751713) Though you do this unconsciously, the result is practically the same as I have indicated.
('6', 393, 4, 17, 751803) If you have really got to the stage ofstriving for moksha, you should remain calm and unperturbed and forget all about me, even if I am extremely sinful and may be deceiving you.
('6', 393, 4, 18, 751982) But you are not able to do so because of your excessive attachment.
('6', 393, 4, 19, 752050) This is what I believe; but if I am wrong in holding this belief, I prostrate myself at your feet and beg to be forgiven.
('6', 393, 4, 20, 752172) But whether or not you are overcome by greed and attachment, I am not worried.
('6', 393, 4, 21, 752251) It does not affect my love for you.
('6', 393, 4, 22, 752287) My regard for you does not decrease in the least, and I am ready to render you any service that I can and look upon it as my duty.
('6', 393, 4, 23, 752418) I fail to understand what you mean by the word “family”.
('6', 393, 5, 24, 752475) 1 The original carries no date; however, vide the preceding item where Gandhiji refers to Gokuldas’s betrothal, while in this letter (‘Letter to Lakshmidas Gandhi”, 20 4 1907) he refers to the forthcoming marriage.

('6', 394, 1, 2, 752767) me, the family includes not only the two brothers but the sister as well.
('6', 394, 1, 3, 752841) It also includes our cousins.
('6', 394, 1, 4, 752871) Indeed, if I could say so without arrogance, I would say that my family comprises all living beings: the only difference being that those who are more dependent on me, because of blood relationship or other circumstances, get more help from me.
('6', 394, 1, 5, 753116) Hence it was that I took out an insurance policy in my wife’s favour.
('6', 394, 1, 6, 753186) And this I did because of your bitter letters to me when I was in Bombay and in order to escape your imprecations in case the responsibility for [supporting] my wife and children fell on you, as I was at that time engaged in helping the plague stricken.
('6', 394, 1, 7, 753440) Though I am myself against insurance, I took out an insurance policy for these and other reasons.
('6', 394, 1, 8, 753538) If by any chance you die before me, you may be sure that I shall myself [serve as] an insurance policy for your wife and children.
('6', 394, 1, 9, 753669) I beseech you to feel secure on this account.
('6', 394, 1, 10, 753715) I would cite the case of Raliatbehn in this context.
('6', 394, 1, 11, 753768) If Raliatbehn does not stay with you, I do not consider that to be due to any fault of mine, but hold your nature responsible.
('6', 394, 1, 12, 753895) I would humbly remind you that mother was not happy with you, nor at any time were any of the other relatives.
('6', 394, 1, 13, 754006) If Gokuldas and Harilal have gone astray, I am not responsible.
('6', 394, 1, 14, 754070) Gokuldas left me and was spoiled by the pernicious atmosphere there; the same thing happened with Harilal to some extent.
('6', 394, 1, 15, 754192) Nevertheless, neither of them has become as corrupt as you think.
('6', 394, 1, 16, 754258) They have better character than other boys.
('6', 394, 1, 17, 754302) It is only when I judge them by a standard of my own that I find them lacking.
('6', 394, 1, 18, 754381) Harilal has greatly profited by coming here and, if I mistake not, his character has improved.
('6', 394, 1, 19, 754476) Since Harilal is already betrothed, I have nothing to say against it.
('6', 394, 1, 20, 754546) At the same time I cannot say that I am pleased about it.
('6', 394, 1, 21, 754604) I consider it wrong too that Gokuldas is going to get married.
('6', 394, 1, 22, 754667) That it has become necessary for the two brothers to get married is due to the sensual atmosphere there.
('6', 394, 1, 23, 754772) It is not any dislike for the country but the grief I feel for its present sorry plight that prompts me to say this.
('6', 394, 1, 24, 754889) Fortunately, Manio 1, Ramo 2 and Devo 3 are here, and are growing up in a healthy atmosphere.
('6', 394, 1, 25, 754983) I do not therefore worry about their betrothal.

('6', 395, 1, 2, 755193) observe brahmacharya, even if they get married.
('6', 395, 1, 3, 755241) If, therefore, all the three boys were to die unmarried, I shouldn’t be sorry but should rejoice instead.
('6', 395, 1, 4, 755347) However, if when they come of age they wish to marry, I am sure that they will find suitable brides.
('6', 395, 1, 5, 755448) It would cause you great sorrow if I were to give my answer to the question, “What is to be done if no girl is to be had from our caste?”; so I would, with your permission, rather not answer this question.
('6', 395, 1, 6, 755654) I repeat that it is the divine law that one gets fruits according to one’s faith and therefore this problem does not arise in my mind at all.
('6', 395, 2, 7, 755796) Chhaganlal, Maganlal and Anandlal are members of our family, hence service done to them is service done to the family.
('6', 395, 2, 8, 755915) They have become better men after coming to Phoenix and I see their moral sense developed.
('6', 395, 3, 9, 756006) As to your demand for a hundred rupees a month, I must say that I see neither the means at present nor the need of meeting it.
('6', 395, 3, 10, 756133) I run the Phoenix Press with borrowed money.
('6', 395, 3, 11, 756178) Moreover, I may have to go to gaol in the course of the struggle here against the new Ordinance.
('6', 395, 3, 12, 756275) In that case I may become poorer still.
('6', 395, 3, 13, 756315) This will come about in a month or two.
('6', 395, 3, 14, 756355) I am therefore unable at present to do anything to satisfy you.
('6', 395, 3, 15, 756419) If, however, the condition here improves during the next few months and I am free from trouble, I shall try to send you the money you have asked for by money order with the sole intention of pleasing you.
('6', 395, 3, 16, 756624) I do agree that you and Karsandas have [the right to] a share in my earnings.
('6', 395, 3, 17, 756702) But I spend much less on my personal enjoyment than you do [on yours].
('6', 395, 3, 18, 756773) My earnings are what remains after meeting all the charges here.
('6', 395, 3, 19, 756838) My object in staying here was not to make money but to serve the people; hence I deem it my duty to use for the benefit of the people whatever is left over after meeting the expen diture on the family here.
('6', 395, 3, 20, 757045) So please don’t think that I am making money here.
('6', 395, 3, 21, 757096) At this point I would remind you that between you two brothers I have already paid nearly Rs. 60,000. I cleared all the debts while I was there; and you told me that no more money was wanted.
('6', 395, 3, 22, 757288) It was only after this that I began spending money here.
('6', 395, 3, 23, 757345) I handed over all my savings in Natal to you; and I have not kept a penny for myself either from that amount or from my subsequent earnings.
('6', 395, 3, 24, 757486) From this you will see that I have paid back much more than the Rs. 13,000 spent on me during my stay in England.
('6', 395, 3, 25, 757600) In saying this I do not mean to suggest

('6', 396, 1, 2, 757684) that I have done you a favour.
('6', 396, 1, 3, 757715) I only state the bare facts to pacify your anger.
('6', 396, 1, 4, 757765) What Mr. Fitzgerald told you about me only shows that he does not know the facts.
('6', 396, 1, 5, 757847) I shall now answer your questions 1. These I return herewith.
('6', 396, 1, 6, 757909) 1. The object of sending me to England was that we, all the three of us, might thereby maintain the status of our father more or less, be well off and enjoy the good things of life.
('6', 396, 1, 7, 758091) 2. The risk was indeed great as we had decided to stake whatever we had on my education.
('6', 396, 1, 8, 758180) 3. As those who had promised to help us did not keep their word, you worked hard, and even at the cost of your health, ungrudgi ngly gave me as much money as I asked for.
('6', 396, 1, 9, 758351) This shows your magn animity and your affection for a younger brother.
('6', 396, 1, 10, 758422) 4. When we were reduced to the condition described in this question, I did feel—I vaguely recollect—that I would earn enough to satisfy you.
('6', 396, 1, 11, 758563) and make you forget the hardships you underwent for my sake.
('6', 396, 1, 12, 758624) 5. This I do not recollect, as father himself had started selling the property and we did the same after him.
('6', 396, 1, 13, 758734) 6. This is but natural.
('6', 396, 1, 14, 758758) 7. I must say with deep sorrow that, on account of your extravagant and thoughtless way of life, you have squandered a lot of money on pleasures and on pomp and show.
('6', 396, 1, 15, 758925) You kept a horse and carriage, gave parties, and spent money on selfish friends; and some money was spent in what I consider immoral ways.
('6', 396, 1, 16, 759064) 8. I remember to have sold them.
('6', 396, 1, 17, 759097) I am not at all ashamed of it, neither do I regret it.
('6', 396, 1, 18, 759152) 9. I do not remember to have sold them secretly without your knowledge; even if I had done so, I do not mind it.
('6', 396, 1, 19, 759265) 10. Though I did not replace that jewellery, I have already paid its value in cash and much more besides.
('6', 396, 1, 20, 759371) However, if I am required to do so [again], I shall certainly deposit the money in their names, that is, if I am able to save any.
('6', 396, 1, 21, 759502) As for getting the jewellery made afresh, I will not do so, as I consider it a sin.
('6', 396, 1, 22, 759586) When I refuse to get the jewellery

('6', 397, 1, 3, 759803) 11. I do not consider that I have obliged you by doing this.
('6', 397, 1, 4, 759864) Even if nothing was done for me, whatever I have to do for my blood brother I would do as a matter of duty.
('6', 397, 1, 5, 759972) If then I do anything for one who spent a great deal on my account, it would be doubly my duty to do so.
('6', 397, 1, 6, 760077) 12. I am not the master of my earnings, since I have dedicated my all to the people.
('6', 397, 1, 7, 760162) I do not suffer from the illusion that it is I who earn; I simply believe that God gives me the money for making good use of it.
('6', 397, 1, 8, 760291) 13. I do recognize your [right to a] share in all my earnings; but since there is no such thing as an income for me now, what can I send you?
('6', 397, 1, 9, 760433) 14. I am not spending your share [on myself]; but I use all the money that God gives me for the public good.
('6', 397, 1, 10, 760542) If anything is left over after what has been used for this purpose, I would like to send you all of it, not just your share of it.
('6', 397, 1, 11, 760673) 15. I don’t have the faintest recollection of having robbed you or anyone else.
('6', 397, 1, 12, 760753) If I regard all living beings as equal both from the practical and the moral points of view, it is in the fitness of things that those who are more dependent on me have a greater claim on me.
('6', 397, 1, 13, 760945) That is to say, I should help my wife and sons first and then those who are helpless and have therefore a claim on me.
('6', 397, 1, 14, 761064) If, on the other hand, my wife and sons find their means of living independently of me, they may be left alone and others who are helpless anddepend on me will have precedence.
('6', 397, 1, 15, 761241) This means that Goko 1, if he were not earning, would have a prior claim to Hariyo’s 2 if the latter were earning.
('6', 397, 1, 16, 761356) If all of them are earning and you are not, yours will be the first claim.
('6', 397, 1, 17, 761431) Moreover, if all of you were working, but Purshottam was not and he were still with us, his would be the first claim.
('6', 397, 1, 18, 761549) This claim pertains only to maintenance and not to the illusory worldly pleasures.
('6', 397, 1, 19, 761632) Whatever other questions of a subsidiary nature arise out of the above, you will be able to answer for yourself.
('6', 397, 1, 20, 761745) All this is written without any bad motive whatever.

('6', 401, 5, 18, 769423) 351. COLONIAL CONFERENCE AND INDIANS
('6', 401, 6, 19, 769460) Lord Milner has written an article about the Colonial Confer ence from which we publish elsewhere an extract relating to Indians.
('6', 401, 6, 20, 769590) It is clear from this that there is commotion everywhere over the hardships of Indians in South Africa.
('6', 401, 6, 21, 769694) To Lord Milner’s way of thinking, India is more valuable than the Colonies, and if ever a
('6', 401, 7, 22, 769784) 1 Sons of Anandlal Gandhi and Chhaganlal Gandhi 2 The following paragraph is translated from Gujarati.
('6', 401, 7, 23, 769887) 3 For an account of the farewell to Omar Haji Amod Zhaveri, vide 11 5 1907.
('6', 402, 0, 1, 769963) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 403
('6', 402, 1, 2, 770007) question arose as to whether the British should lose the Colonies or India, they would decide to give up the Colonies rather than India.
('6', 402, 1, 3, 770144) But it is in our hands to decide when such an eventuality should arise.
('6', 402, 1, 4, 770216) If we could rid ourselves of all our shortcomings, then such a situation can be said already to exist.
('6', 402, 1, 5, 770319) So long as the officials can persuade [the British people] that we shall put up with any amount of suffering, they will believe in the Colonies and the burden on the Indian people will increase.
('6', 402, 1, 6, 770514) This is the way of the world.
('6', 402, 1, 7, 770544) The rich grow richer, the poor poorer.
('6', 402, 1, 8, 770583) The burden on those who carry it increases and those who do not carry any go unscathed.
('6', 402, 1, 9, 770671) The moral is that we have to let the Government know that we in the Colony will not stand any more burden.
('6', 402, 1, 10, 770778) Lord Milner also adds that India is vital to the entire English nation as well as the Colonies.
('6', 402, 1, 11, 770874) Its value is immeasurable.
('6', 402, 1, 12, 770901) Why should it not be so?
('6', 402, 1, 13, 770926) Her revenues total £44 million (a million = 10 lakhs).
('6', 402, 1, 14, 770981) Out of this £22 million are spent on the military depart ment, that is, a major portion of this amount is spent in paying the salaries of the British soldiers and buying British goods.
('6', 402, 1, 15, 771166) A third part of the £44 million, that is, about£15 million goes straight to England.
('6', 402, 1, 16, 771251) Only the balance remains in India.
('6', 402, 1, 17, 771286) This means that in the partnership between the British and the Indians 83 per cent.
('6', 402, 1, 18, 771370) of the profit goes to the British and 17 per cent.
('6', 402, 1, 19, 771421) to the Indians, but the entire capital comes from the Indians.
('6', 402, 1, 20, 771484) Such a partnership is evidently advantageous to the British.
('6', 402, 1, 21, 771545) Let us now turn to the Colonies.
('6', 402, 1, 22, 771578) Here, all the capital is provided by the British but the profit is consumed by the Colonies.
('6', 402, 1, 23, 771671) If anyone asks the reason of this one sided justice, the only reply is that the Colonies being strong have the lion’s share.
('6', 402, 1, 24, 771796) They can stand up to England.
('6', 402, 1, 25, 771826) If we become as strong as they, we too shall get justice.
('6', 402, 1, 26, 771884) A closed mouth catches no flies; that is the policy of the British.
('6', 402, 1, 27, 771952) But speaking does not mean mere shouting.
('6', 402, 1, 28, 771994) It must be accompanied by kicking.
('6', 402, 1, 29, 772029) The way we can kick in South Africa or in India is to go to gaol.
('6', 402, 1, 30, 772095) If we do not help in the oppression that is being perpetrated on us, we shall be free.
('6', 402, 1, 31, 772182) It is only when the axe is fitted with a wooden handle that it can cut wood.

('6', 403, 2, 3, 772371) Malaria is still raging among Indians.
('6', 403, 2, 4, 772410) To deal with this, a committee has been formed with Dr. Nanji as Chairman and is being assisted by Indians.
('6', 403, 2, 5, 772518) The daily average of patients is expected to be a hundred, and the daily expenditure £4, that is, less than a shilling per head.
('6', 403, 2, 6, 772647) In view of the fact that, in addition to medicine, soup and other articles will have to be supplied to some of the patients, the expen diture of £4 a day cannot be considered excessive.
('6', 403, 2, 7, 772833) It is necessary that the leaders help in this work sincerely.
('6', 403, 2, 8, 772895) If requisite efforts are made, we are sure the disease can be wiped out in a short time.

('6', 403, 5, 11, 773026) 353. PURITY OF THOUGHT
('6', 403, 6, 12, 773049) WHAT TRUE PATRIOTISM IS
('6', 403, 7, 13, 773073) There is far too much of self centredness or selfishness in India today.
('6', 403, 7, 14, 773146) Instead we should have concern for the nation, that is to say, be patriotic.
('6', 403, 7, 15, 773223) But since we are out to improve existing conditions, we should bear in mind that concern for national interest does not imply hatred of others.
('6', 403, 7, 16, 773367) Before we can hate others, we should get tothe stage of being able to safeguard our national interest.
('6', 403, 7, 17, 773470) There is hardly any immediate fear therefore of our hating foreign countries.
('6', 403, 7, 18, 773548) However, what Sir William Wedderburn has written on the subject is worth reading and reflecting on.
('6', 403, 7, 19, 773648) We give below a summary of his article in The Indian Review.
('6', 403, 8, 20, 773709) There are some people in India today who believe that they should not approach the British Government for the redress of their grievances, for they fear that, if by any chance the British do redress their grievances, it will tighten their hold over the country, which will endanger our patriotism.
('6', 403, 8, 21, 774007) This is a mistaken idea.
('6', 403, 8, 22, 774032) Those who offer such advice seek to take upon their heads the sins of the Englishmen, who, priding themselves upon the colour of their skin, oppress Indians.
('6', 403, 8, 23, 774190) This [idea] is moreover
('6', 403, 9, 24, 774214) 1 Vide “Malaria and Duty of Indians”, 23 3 1907 and “Meeting of Natal Indian Congress”, 8 4 1907.

('6', 404, 1, 2, 774356) opposed to the movement afoot all over the world for peace and amity among mankind.
('6', 404, 1, 3, 774440) Even if one replaced self interest by the national interest, one would violate the highest morality.
('6', 404, 1, 4, 774541) If a man wants to become virtuous and remain so, he will keep the highest morality in mind.
('6', 404, 1, 5, 774633) And though he may not be able to act up to it, he must always aim high.
('6', 404, 1, 6, 774705) He whose aim is not true will never hit his target.
('6', 404, 1, 7, 774757) We should always try to climb higher in spite of our shortcomings.
('6', 404, 1, 8, 774824) And this applies as much to a group or a community as to an individual Again, it applies with added force to India for, at present, she is considering what policy, what standard of conduct, she should adopt.
('6', 404, 1, 9, 775032) To serve one’s own interest is low indeed; to serve the interest of the nation is to rise a step higher.
('6', 404, 1, 10, 775137) He who gives up his life for his nation is considered a great man; but when the interest of the world at large is made to suffer in the nation’s interest, then [serving] the latter must be considered mean and degrading.
('6', 404, 1, 11, 775357) If we wish to see peace and goodwill established throughout the world, we should remember that our personal and national interests are served by the well being of the whole world.
('6', 404, 1, 12, 775537) The Indian people have suffered a lot during the last few years because Englishmen who pride themselves on their patriotism pursued only their self interest.

('6', 404, 1, 15, 775802) They should not become the dupes of this temptation.
('6', 404, 1, 16, 775855) The real enemies of freedom and prosperity are the autocratic and tyrannical powers; not the differences of race or colour.
('6', 404, 1, 17, 775979) Though the Russians have their own government, it is oppressive and is as bad as that of India.
('6', 404, 1, 18, 776075) The remedy for such a situation is the getting together of good and altruistic people, wherever they be in the world.
('6', 404, 1, 19, 776193) It is therefore necessary to bring together the English reformers who are strong and Indian reformers who are weak.
('6', 404, 1, 20, 776309) With the relations that prevail at present between England and India, such a meeting can easily be brought about.

('6', 404, 1, 23, 776593) If this happens, England and India can stay together, befriend the world and work for the good of mankind.

('6', 405, 1, 2, 776784) 354. FRENCH INDIA Our readers may be aware that at one time the French also tried to establish their rule in India.
('6', 405, 1, 3, 776900) They have held three bases in India since then, [together] known as French India.
('6', 405, 1, 4, 776982) They are Chandrana gore, Pondicherry and Calicut 1. It is often said that the French have a very sympathetic attitude towards Indians.
('6', 405, 1, 5, 777117) An example of this was seen recently when the Governor of Pondicherry addressed the following letter to the Indians there: Citizens, I shall soon be there to see you and your country.
('6', 405, 1, 6, 777301) I shall inspect your farms and bunds and hear your petitions.
('6', 405, 1, 7, 777363) You may come to me with full confidence.
('6', 405, 1, 8, 777404) A repres entative of the Republic is bound to regard all [citizens] as equals and there is only one thing between us, viz., the laws.
('6', 405, 1, 9, 777538) I will give you whatever [relief] I can under those laws; and Ishall explain their limitations to you quite clearly.
('6', 405, 1, 10, 777655) Please do not ask me unnecessary or frivolous questions, for the time lost in answering them can be better used to solve more important problems.
('6', 405, 1, 11, 777801) You are engaged in your agricultural work.
('6', 405, 1, 12, 777844) I have also many jobs to attend to.
('6', 405, 1, 13, 777880) So we have no time to meet in a grand hall and receive garlands of roses and jasmines.
('6', 405, 1, 14, 777967) Believe me when I say that I shall come to see you without pomp or show.
('6', 405, 1, 15, 778040) And I shall be glad if I meet you in simplicity.
('6', 405, 1, 16, 778089) If I meet you while you are at work, I shall get to know you the better and be able to see for myself and redress your grievances.

('6', 406, 3, 6, 778906) To the last cable sent by the Association to the British Committee, a reply has been received It says that efforts are being made to see General Botha; a strong communication has been addressed to Lord Elgin; and a meeting of the Members of the House of Commons will take Place on Wednesday.
('6', 406, 3, 7, 779198) This reply was received on Thursday the 18th.
