('6', 406, 4, 10, 779389) WHAT WILL BE OUTCOME?
('6', 406, 5, 11, 779411) Because of the foregoing and the Committee’s letter, there is reason to believe that the Bill will receive assent.
('6', 406, 5, 12, 779526) If this happens, it is clear that gaol going will be the only remedy left.
('6', 406, 5, 13, 779601) I hear, the gaol going resolution was once being discussed in the presence of a white official, and he laughed and said, “I don’t at all believe, the Indian community will act up to such resolutions.” This rem ark should be taken very seriously.
('6', 406, 5, 14, 779847) There is no doubt at all that the Indian community has no reputation for bravery and that is why the whites dare to pass any laws they like with impunity.
('6', 406, 5, 15, 780002) If the Bill becomes law and we give up the idea of gaol going, the Indian comm unity, we may take it, is doomed for ever.
('6', 406, 5, 16, 780124) The white official’s derisive laugh shows that, if the whites had taken our gaol going resolution seriously, they would never have introduced the Bill again.
('6', 406, 5, 17, 780282) Now is the time to prove that we mean what we say.
('6', 406, 5, 18, 780333) We have read about the boy who used to cry “wolf”.
('6', 406, 5, 19, 780384) People would rush to his help and, finding no wolf, go back irritated.
('6', 406, 5, 20, 780455) When a wolf did appear, however much the boy shouted, his neighbours took it for a joke, refused to go to his help, and the boy was killed.
('6', 406, 5, 21, 780595) It is now absolutely necessary to show that our cries are genuine.
('6', 406, 6, 22, 780662) SOME DOUBTS CLARIFIED
('6', 406, 7, 23, 780684) Though great efforts are being made to prevent the Bill becoming law, we have to be prepared on the assumption that it will
('6', 407, 0, 1, 780808) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 407, 1, 2, 780850) be passed.
('6', 407, 1, 3, 780861) Questions have been asked from many quarters.
('6', 407, 1, 4, 780907) I give below a clarification of the important questions raised.
('6', 407, 1, 5, 780971) It has to be borne in mind that the whole struggle is on behalf of those who hold genuine permits, and those who are not thus equipped should therefore certainly leave the Transvaal.
('6', 407, 1, 6, 781154) The pre war residents and others, who have come after the war but hold genuine permits, have to put up a fight.
('6', 407, 1, 7, 781266) Nobody can do the boys any harm.
('6', 407, 1, 8, 781299) This point clarified, the important thing to understand is how the struggle is to be waged.
('6', 407, 1, 9, 781391) In this regard we would say [the following]: 1. It is improbable that all the persons [who do not take out permits] will be sent to gaol or that they will all be taken to gaol at once.
('6', 407, 1, 10, 781576) 2. After the law is passed, an order will be published requiring permits to be renewed within a specified period.
('6', 407, 1, 11, 781690) 3. No Indian should get his permit renewed within that period.
('6', 407, 1, 12, 781753) 4. At the expiry of the period, the Government can arrest any person, if they choose, for residing in the Transvaal without a permit.
('6', 407, 1, 13, 781887) 5. It cannot be said for certain who will be arrested and where.
('6', 407, 1, 14, 781952) 6. Suppose, a poor Indian is arrested.
('6', 407, 1, 15, 781991) If he holds a lawful permit, Mr. Gandhi, as he declared last September, will defend him in the court free of charge.
('6', 407, 1, 16, 782108) 7. At the time Mr. Gandhi himself will say that he had advised the entire community not to take out permits as required by the new law but instead to go to gaol in all humility, and that was why his client had not taken out a fresh permit.
('6', 407, 1, 17, 782348) 8. When the counsel himself says this, it is possible that the defaulter may be set free and the counsel arrested.
('6', 407, 1, 18, 782463) That is, Mr. Gandhi will be arrested and his client let off.
('6', 407, 1, 19, 782524) At that time, a similar deposition will!
('6', 407, 1, 20, 782565) if possible, be made on behalf of the Association also.
('6', 407, 1, 21, 782621) 9. However, it is possible that the arrested person may himself be sentenced.

('6', 407, 1, 23, 782808) 10. At the expiry of the time limit, the person will be re arrested and sentenced to fine or imprisonment for disobeying the court’s order.
('6', 407, 1, 24, 782948) 11. As the person concerned will refuse to pay the fine, he will have to go to gaol.
('6', 407, 1, 25, 783033) 12. If many persons are thus prosecuted and all of them go to gaol, the chances are that they will be soon released and the law amended

('6', 408, 1, 4, 783353) 14. The wife and children of a person so going to gaol will, if necessary, be maintained on subscriptions from the public.
('6', 408, 1, 5, 783476) This, in brief, is likely to be the position.

('6', 408, 2, 17, 784566) ‘‘HOW BAD THESE INDIANS ARE !’’
('6', 408, 3, 18, 784598) With reference to the strong criticism of Mr. Chamney’s Report made by the editor of this paper in The Rand Daily Mail a white from Leydenburg, under the pen name “Just”, has written an unjust letter, in which he says: All the seven days in the week are working days for the Indians and they work from sunrise to sunset.
('6', 408, 3, 19, 784919) On Sundays they write up their account books and hawkers settle their accounts.

('6', 408, 3, 21, 785104) Moreover, Indian merchants in rural areas examine samples brought by agents on Sundays so that the latter too can work all the days in the week.
('6', 408, 3, 22, 785249) The Indians know nothing about making payments on time.
('6', 408, 3, 23, 785305) It is the usual practice with them to turn a 90 day credit into one for 150 days.
('6', 408, 3, 24, 785387) It is not unusual for them to settle a creditor’s account by paying him only a part of his dues.

('6', 409, 1, 7, 786099) Only if, follo wing the example of the Orange River Colony, the Transvaal too closes down Indian shops with or without compensation, will clean trade be possible for European traders in towns such as Standerton, Heidelberg, Ermilom and Klerksdorp.
('6', 409, 1, 8, 786347) Referring to this letter, the editor of The [Rand Daily] Mail says that, if what “Just” says is all true, one fails to see how so many Europeans trade with Indians.
('6', 409, 1, 9, 786512) Thus the letter by “Just” has already been answered.
('6', 409, 1, 10, 786565) But while some of his criticism is unduly exaggerated, it will only be fitting that we admit the force of much of it.
('6', 409, 1, 11, 786683) We work day and night, do not rest even on Sundays, fail to keep promises and settle accounts by making only part payments to creditors.
('6', 409, 1, 12, 786820) There is no doubt we should effect improvements in these four matters.
('6', 409, 1, 13, 786891) We need an innate sense of honour, and, as His Majesty the Amir advised, it is essential for us to have western education.
('6', 409, 1, 14, 787014) 1 There are nowadays any number of associat ions.
('6', 409, 1, 15, 787064) If a well known merchant founds an “Association for the Reform of the Trading Class” and brings about the much needed reforms, many of our disabilities will disappear and the stringent licence regulations will also go.
('6', 409, 2, 16, 787283) DIVINE WRATH
('6', 409, 3, 17, 787296) These days the tram service in Johannesburg often becomes dislocated.
('6', 409, 3, 18, 787366) Hardly a day passes without a break down.
('6', 409, 3, 19, 787408) There can be two reasons for this.
('6', 409, 3, 20, 787443) The Indian community may persuade itself that it results from God’s wrath on the municipality which prohibits Coloured persons from travelling by these trams.

('6', 410, 11, 17, 788642) REGISTRATION LAW
('6', 410, 12, 18, 788659) The Rand Daily Mail has—for the present at any rate—come to the rescue of Indians.
('6', 410, 12, 19, 788742) Two leading articles appeared during the last week.
('6', 410, 12, 20, 788794) Commenting upon Lord Milner’s article in the National Review, The Rand Daily Mail pointed out that the Colonies could not carry on without the other parts of the British Empire.
('6', 410, 12, 21, 788972) For example, the trade of New South Wales in Australia with India is valued at £1 million a year.
('6', 410, 12, 22, 789070) Its trade with Ceylon is even larger.
('6', 410, 12, 23, 789108) Its exports to India exceed her exports to New Zealand and her exports to Ceylon are larger than those to South Africa.
('6', 410, 12, 24, 789228) The article shows that the Colonies cannot do without India.
('6', 410, 12, 25, 789289) The liberation of India will come about as soon as Indians wake up and become conscious of their rights.
('6', 410, 12, 26, 789394) As far as the Transvaal is concerned, the remedy lies in our own hands: it is to go to gaol if the registration law is passed.
('6', 410, 12, 27, 789521) The second article in The Rand Daily Mail has greater relevance to the registration law than the first one.
('6', 410, 12, 28, 789629) The writer says that the
('6', 411, 0, 1, 789654) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 411, 1, 2, 789696) present Asiatic Office seems to serve no purpose.
('6', 411, 1, 3, 789746) Its report shows that the Office has proved a failure.
('6', 411, 1, 4, 789801) Though it has several clerks, inspec tors and liveried peons, Indians can enter without permits.
('6', 411, 1, 5, 789898) Though over £4,000 are paid by it every year on account of salaries, it is said that all the power is concentrated in the hands of a single Eurasian clerk.
('6', 411, 1, 6, 790054) If this is so, one cannot see the point of spending £4,000 on the Asiatic Office; it would be better to entrust everything to that clerk.
('6', 411, 1, 7, 790192) In fact, the permit problem is one of adequate police vigilance, not of enacting a new law.
('6', 411, 1, 8, 790284) The Rand Daily Mail has thus strongly criticised and roundly condemned the Asiatic Office.
('6', 411, 1, 9, 790375) It would appear then that the Office is viewed’ with disfavour by others as well.

('6', 411, 4, 17, 790796) ASIATIC BAZAAR
('6', 411, 5, 18, 790811) The authority to control Asiatic Bazaars or Locations has been vested in the respective municipalities.
('6', 411, 5, 19, 790915) For the present this has little significance, as there exists no law compelling Indians to go to Locations.
('6', 411, 5, 20, 791023) But it should be remembered that, if the Indian community submits to the new law, another law will be passed immediately forcing Indians to Locations, and then the municipal authority will prove very troublesome.
('6', 411, 6, 21, 791236) MEETING OF SOUTH AFRICAN CHAMBERS OF COMMERCE
('6', 411, 7, 22, 791282) The twelfth annual meeting of the Chambers of Commerce of South Africa took place on the 24th at Pretoria, when Mr. Mackintosh of Port Elizabeth presided.
('6', 411, 7, 23, 791437) Mr. Prady of Germiston moved a resolution to the effect that Asiatics should be prevented from coming [into the Colony] and their trade stopped.
('6', 411, 7, 24, 791582) He said in his speech that great harm was done by Indian trade as the whites could not compete with Indian traders.
('6', 411, 7, 25, 791698) The whites had struggled hard in South Africa for a hundred years.
('6', 411, 7, 26, 791765) How could Indians be allowed to oust them?
('6', 411, 8, 27, 791808) 1 Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 27 4 1907.
('6', 412, 0, 1, 791849) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 413
('6', 412, 1, 2, 791893) Conditions in Standerton, Heidelberg, Potchefstroom and other places had deteriorated very much.
('6', 412, 1, 3, 791990) If the influx of Indians could not be stopped forthwith, he said, they should be so heavily taxed that they could not afford to stay on.
('6', 412, 1, 4, 792127) According to him, it would be better to drive out the existing traders, even after paying them compensation, if necessary.
('6', 412, 1, 5, 792250) Mr. Hobson of Maseru, who supported him, said that Indian traders had penetrated far into Basutoland and had captured most of the trade.
('6', 412, 1, 6, 792387) However, according to him, Mr. Prady’s resolution for winding up Indian business immediately was too drastic.
('6', 412, 1, 7, 792497) Sir William Van Hulsteyn said that all South Africa was opposed to Indians.
('6', 412, 1, 8, 792573) But it was not proper to drive them out all at once or to discontinue their trade; it would be better to insist on their carrying on business in Bazaars only.
('6', 412, 1, 9, 792732) The question of immigration did not concern the Chambers of Commerce, and hence they could not interfere in the matter.
('6', 412, 1, 10, 792852) He moved an amendment to the effect that it was necessary immediately to frame laws on Asiatic trade for the whole of South Africa.
('6', 412, 2, 11, 792984) Mr. Quinn supported the amendment.

('6', 412, 2, 14, 793177) Like locusts they devoured Natal.
('6', 412, 2, 15, 793211) They caused harm to the Kaffirs also for the latter were powerless against them.
('6', 412, 3, 16, 793292) Mr. Jagger of Cape Town said that he too was opposed to Indians, but that sudden and complete prohibition was a difficult task.
('6', 412, 3, 17, 793420) The Imperial Government would never assent to such laws.
('6', 412, 3, 18, 793477) He therefore moved that, since the presence of the Indian community was detrimental to [the interests of] South Africa, immediate legisla tion was necessary to restrict their immigration and trade.
('6', 412, 4, 19, 793675) Mr. Ireland of Zoutpansburg said that Mr. Prady’s resolution went too far.
('6', 412, 4, 20, 793750) It was certainly necessary to adopt quick measures in the matter.
('6', 412, 4, 21, 793816) The Asiatics were like the plague.
('6', 412, 4, 22, 793851) Mr. Forest said that he shuddered to think of the number of Indians in Natal.

('6', 413, 2, 4, 794452) “AKIKO” OF HASANMIAN’S SON
('6', 413, 3, 5, 794479) A son has been born to Sheth Hasanmian, a partner of the firm of Sheth Mahomed Cassim Camroodeen.
('6', 413, 3, 6, 794577) The akiko ceremony took place on Sunday, when a grand feast was given.
('6', 413, 3, 7, 794648) Guests came from far and near and a lavish dinner was cooked for nearly 500 persons.
('6', 413, 3, 8, 794733) Mr. Abdul Kadir had specially come from Durban for the occasion; so had Mr. Haji Habib from Pretoria.
('6', 413, 3, 9, 794835) The occasion was celebrated with great eclat.
('6', 413, 3, 10, 794881) Some [of our readers] may not know what akiko is.
('6', 413, 3, 11, 794931) It is the ceremonial shaving of the head of the new born child on the seventh day.
('6', 413, 3, 12, 795014) According to their wealth and position, parents set aside gold, silver or copper equal in weight to the hair, and the value of the metal is spent on the feast.
('6', 413, 4, 13, 795174) ATTACK ON NEW CLARE WASHERMEN

('6', 413, 5, 16, 795374) Indian washermen, according to him, have defiled the washing places; the water is dirty and stinks, so that clothes washed in it are as good as not washed at all.
('6', 413, 5, 17, 795537) The writer is afraid that some day an epidemic is bound to break out because of clothes washed in that water.
('6', 413, 5, 18, 795647) The Indian washermen have to be careful about this.

('6', 413, 5, 20, 795780) If this is not done, there is every fear of the washermen losing their livelihood, as the writer has suggested that the municipality should take effective measures.
('6', 413, 6, 21, 795945) “COOLIE MERCHANTS” Under the above heading, a contributor has written bitterly for the Sunday Times.

('6', 413, 6, 23, 796143) It is only thus that they get rich.
('6', 413, 6, 24, 796179) They melt the gold so stolen, make bracelets or armlets out of them and wear them on their persons.
('6', 413, 6, 25, 796279) The detectives know this, but they do not, and sometimes cannot, arrest the offenders.
('6', 413, 6, 26, 796366) The writer is certain of this, but good Indians and their English friends are not aware of this.

('6', 414, 1, 2, 796589) No one knows how much of this is true.

('6', 415, 6, 9, 799190) 358. MR. GANDHI’S PLEDGE
('6', 415, 7, 10, 799215) JOHANNESBURG, April 30, 1907
('6', 415, 8, 11, 799244) TO THE EDITOR INDIAN OPINION
('6', 415, 9, 12, 799273) SIR, Many of our brethren have written to me to say that they will go to gaol in pursuance of the September Resolution, if the Registration Act of the Transvaal is passed.
('6', 415, 9, 13, 799445) Every one of them deserves to be congratulated.
('6', 415, 9, 14, 799493) From some of the letters, I find that a few are annoyed at the absence of such letters from leaders.
('6', 415, 9, 15, 799594) Their not having written is, I am sure, no reason for doubting them.
('6', 415, 9, 16, 799663) I do not think that they will come forward to take out the compulsory registers.
('6', 415, 9, 17, 799744) However, lest I should be guilty of this sin of omission, I hereby declare my Pledge that, should the new law come into force, I will never take out a permit or register under the law but will go to goal; and even if I am the only one left who has not taken a permit, my pledge shall stand for the following reasons: 1. I consider it a humiliation to submit to this law, and I prefer to go to gaol rather than submit to such humiliation; 2. I believe that my country is dearer to me than my person; 3. if, after having announced the September Resolution to the world, the Indian community submits to the law, it will lose everything; 4. I believe that prominent men who have been helping our cause in England rely upon the Fourth Resolution; if we shrink back, we shall
('6', 415, 10, 18, 800514) 1 Vide “Indians Going to Lobito Bay”, 30 3 1907.
('6', 416, 0, 1, 800563) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 417
('6', 416, 1, 2, 800607) not only bring dishonour on them but forfeit their help for ever; 5. the remedy of gaol going cannot be applied against other laws, but for this Act, it is an infallible remedy and it can be adopted by everyone, whether small or great; 6. if I now retract, I shall be deemed unfit to serve the Indian community; 7. I believe that Indians will rise in public esteem if all of them remain staunch in not submitting to the law, and that, moreover, it will evoke sympathy in India also for the cause of the Transvaal Indians.
('6', 416, 2, 3, 801129) Many other reasons can be adduced.
('6', 416, 2, 4, 801164) In the end I appeal to every Transvaal Indian not to miss this occasion and not to turn back.
('6', 416, 2, 5, 801258) I beg the Indians of Natal, the Cape and Delagoa Bay to encourage us, the Transvaal people, and render help when the need arises.
('6', 416, 3, 6, 801388) MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI
('6', 416, 4, 7, 801415) [From Gujarati]
('6', 416, 5, 8, 801431) Indian Opinion, 4 5 1907
('6', 416, 6, 9, 801456) 359. LETTER TO “THE STAR”1
('6', 416, 7, 10, 801483) BOX 6522, JOHANNESBURG April 30, 1907
('6', 416, 8, 11, 801521) TO THE EDITOR THE STAR [JOHANNESBURG]
('6', 416, 10, 12, 801559) You have raised the bogey of the “Indian Peril” and based it on Mr. Ritch’s able letter to The Morning Post.
('6', 416, 10, 13, 801668) Fortunately for the country, you have evidently mis read Mr. Ritch’s letter and ascribed to him a demand not made by him for political rights on behalf of British Indians.
('6', 416, 10, 14, 801840) If you will be good enough to re read the letter, you will find that instead of claiming any such rights, Mr. Ritch has
('6', 416, 11, 15, 801960) 1 This was in reply to an article in The Star, 29 4 1907.
('6', 417, 0, 1, 802018) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 417, 1, 2, 802060) repudiated the claim more than once.
('6', 417, 1, 3, 802097) He says:
('6', 417, 2, 4, 802106) In deference to the demand of the white colonist for protection against an unrestricted influx of Asiatics, the qualifications imposed by an Immigra tion Restriction Law, upon an educational basis, are assented to.
('6', 417, 2, 5, 802321) He (the Indian) seeks no political power, and admits the right of municipalities to control the issuing of trading licences, with power of appeal to the judicial tribunals of the Colony against inequitable administration.
('6', 417, 2, 6, 802543) If words have any meaning, you have, in the above sentences in the letter you have printed, a complete denial of the charge made against the community.
('6', 417, 2, 7, 802695) The ground, therefore, being cleared as to the allegation of the British Indian wanting to have political power in South Africa, with your permission, I would venture to, draw your attention to the fact that you are creating animosity between two communities living under the same flag without the slightest occasion, and, in support of my statement, I ask you to read the compromise offered by the British Indian Association, whereby everything that will be done by the Registration Act can be done immediately and without Imperial sanction being necessary.
('6', 417, 2, 8, 803254) Greater identification is the cry raised.
('6', 417, 2, 9, 803296) British Indians have themselves offered to exchange their lawful documents for those bearing sufficient identification particulars as may be mutually agreed upon.
('6', 417, 2, 10, 803459) Not that the present documents do not contain enough details to identify the holders.
('6', 417, 2, 11, 803545) The compromise has been offered to soothe the agitated mind of the colonist.
('6', 417, 2, 12, 803622) Moreover, the compromise, strange as it may appear, goes further than the Asiatic Act itself, in that the former includes the taking out of permits by minors who have reached the age of discretion, the same to be decided by the Colonial Secretary.
('6', 417, 2, 13, 803870) You may ask why, if the offer is sincere, should there be any fuss about the Act.
('6', 417, 2, 14, 803952) The answer is obvious.
('6', 417, 2, 15, 803975) British Indians do not wish to be classed as criminals, as they undoubtedly are by the Act.
('6', 417, 2, 16, 804067) They repudiate totally the suggestion that there is any illegal influx on a wholesale scale, or that there is any countenance of such influx on the part of the leaders of the community.
('6', 417, 2, 17, 804253) Repressive legislation is requ ired when those to whom it applies are not compliant and do not do voluntarily what is asked of them.
('6', 417, 2, 18, 804386) British Indians have always claimed to be law abiding, and,therefore, object to the class legislation which is a denial of the claim.
('6', 417, 2, 19, 804520) You may call this sentiment, if you will.
('6', 417, 2, 20, 804562) Still, it is one which is very real for the community I have the honour to represent, and it is hardly necessary for me to give you illustrations of sentiment having ruled men’s actions from the time of Adam.
('6', 418, 0, 1, 804771) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 419
('6', 418, 1, 2, 804814) The suggested compromise can cost little.
('6', 418, 1, 3, 804856) If there is any doubt as to its effectiveness, why not give it a trial while the Act isconsidered?
('6', 418, 1, 4, 804955) Will it not be better and more Imperialistic for you to advocate the adoption of the compromise than unnecessarily to inflame the populace against harmless subjects of the Crown?
('6', 418, 2, 5, 805134) I am, etc.,
('6', 418, 3, 6, 805146) M. K. GANDHI
('6', 418, 4, 7, 805159) The Star, 30 4 1907
('6', 418, 5, 8, 805179) 360. LETTER TO RAND PIONEERS1
('6', 418, 6, 9, 805209) [JOHANNESBURG, Before May 2, 1907] 2
('6', 418, 8, 10, 805246) In connection with the action proposed to be taken by the Rand Pioneers and the Transvaal Municipal Association regarding the Asiatic Registration Act, I venture, on behalf of my Association, to draw your Committee’s attention to the compromise offered by the British Indians, and to the fact that it completely meets every requirement of the Registration Act and hastens the fulfilment of the object your Committee has in view.
('6', 418, 8, 11, 805675) My Association has always held the opinion that, as a matter of fact, there is very little difference between what is required by the white colonists and what has been accepted by British Indians.
('6', 418, 8, 12, 805872) The latter ask for no political rights and, as against the repeal of Law 3 of 1885, they consent to municipal control, subject to review by the Supreme Court, over trading licences, and to restriction on immig ration along the Natal or the Cape basis.
('6', 418, 8, 13, 806124) My Association is firmly of opinion that much of the agita tion is due entirely to a misunderstanding of the mutual position.
('6', 418, 9, 14, 806250) 1 This letter, presumably drafted by Gandhiji, was addressed to the Rand Pioneers and the Transvaal Municipal Association, who had announced their intention of agitating in order to bring about the early enforcement of the Asiatic Registration Act.

('6', 419, 1, 2, 806625) My Association, therefore, ventures to suggest that, if your Commi ttee will be prepared to meet a deputation of my Association, a great deal of friction can be removed and a solution of the que stion can be locally arrived at without the weaker party having to seek Imperial protection.
('6', 419, 1, 3, 806913) My Association has no doubt that your Committee is not actuated by any vindictive motives in its agitation my Association for consultation will be accepted in the spirit in against Coloured people.
('6', 419, 1, 4, 807111) It is, therefore, hoped that the suggestion made by which it is offered.

('6', 421, 2, 3, 810683) The Immigration Act of the Cape is so complicated that its implications cannot be realized just yet, but by and by the adverse effects will follow.
('6', 421, 2, 4, 810831) One clause is especially mischievous: if any Indian leaves the Cape without a permit, his right to return will lapse.
('6', 421, 2, 5, 810949) This means that, if 3 leading Indian businessman of the Cape leaves without the annual permit, he will not be able to return.
('6', 421, 2, 6, 811075) Even if his business in the Cape continues and his family stays on there, that will not help him.
('6', 421, 2, 7, 811173) We do not mean to suggest that the law will in fact hit the businessman so hard, but such are the implications of the Act.
('6', 421, 2, 8, 811296) The result will be that all poor Indians will have to leave the Cape.
('6', 421, 2, 9, 811366) And if a few Indians stay behind, what influence can they have?

('6', 422, 3, 9, 813020) Indian Opinion, 4 5 1907
('6', 422, 4, 10, 813045) 365. INTERVIEW TO “THE NATAL MERCURY”
('6', 422, 5, 11, 813083) [May 7, 1907]
('6', 422, 6, 12, 813097) Mr. M. K. Gandhi was yesterday interviewed by a Mercury representative concerning the suggestion put forward by Mr. Lionel Curtis in The Times—a reference to which was contained in our telegraphic news columns on Monday—that the tropical possessions of Great Britain should be reserved for Indian colonization.
('6', 422, 6, 13, 813408) Mr. Gandhi rejects the proposal.
('6', 422, 6, 14, 813441) As long as Indians have domicile rights in the Colonies, whether in South Africa or elsewhere, Mr. Gandhi objects, such a suggestion is not practicable, and would certainly not be acceptable to the British Indians.
('6', 422, 6, 15, 813656) As he has so often asserted, the entire motive which is animating the cause he has taken up on behalf of the South African Asiatic is to protect what he designates the Indians’ “vested rights” in this country; and to deprive them of the title of domicile, which many of them now possess, would, of course, in his view, be to subvert those vested rights.
('6', 422, 6, 16, 814010) Mr. Gandhi said that the rights of domicile were the main strength of the Indians’ position, and he assented to the suggestion that they intended to make the most of it.
('6', 422, 6, 17, 814180) It was pointed out to Mr. Gandhi that the proposal seemed to be that the tropical Colonies should be reserved for immigration of the future, not necessarily contemplating the removal of Indians already possessing domicile rights, and he was asked what his view of that idea would be.
('6', 422, 7, 18, 814464) Mr, Gandhi denied that there was any pressure of population in India leading to the necessity of emigration, and pointed to the fact that the Indians who were brought over as indentured labourers did not offer themselves, but had to be persuaded to come —that, moreover, recruiting was becoming increasingly difficult.
('6', 422, 7, 19, 814783) The same applied to the recruiting for other places in which Indian labour was wanted, and he advanced this to show that India had no real surplus population, and needed no outlet.
('6', 422, 7, 20, 814964) The idea of reserving any territory outside India at all for exclusive colonization by Indians
('6', 423, 0, 1, 815059) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 423, 1, 2, 815101) was therefore a gratuitous and unnecessary one.
('6', 423, 1, 3, 815149) He did not believe that the resources of India had become too exhausted to support its people or the natural increase of its population.
('6', 423, 1, 4, 815286) There was room for what he called “internal” emigration within India itself, but no need of any territorial provision outside.
('6', 423, 2, 5, 815413) He had often been asked, Mr. Gandhi proceeded, why, if this were so, Indians were found emigrating in such numbers to South Africa.
('6', 423, 2, 6, 815545) The explanation was that South Africa had itself made the mischief by adopting the practice of indentured immigration—a system which, Mr. Gandhi said, nearly every Indian in South Africa would sign a petition against, and ask that it should cease.
('6', 423, 3, 7, 815793) [REPORTER:] But the trouble arises, Mr. Gandhi, not so much from the indentured Indian as from the free merchant class, and from whom the demand for equal trading rights mostly comes.
('6', 423, 3, 8, 815977) [GANDHIJI:] The Indian merchant follows the other Indians, to whom he looks for his business.
('6', 423, 3, 9, 816071) If the indentured man was not here, the merchant would not be here.
('6', 423, 3, 10, 816139) As it is, many of the better class Indian merchants, who have large interests, remain in their own country, where they have scope for their business, and where every Indian tradesman would have scope if he preferred to stay instead of coming to the Colonies.
('6', 423, 3, 11, 816398) As long as there remain opportunities for business among his own countrymen, there the Indian merchant will be found.
('6', 423, 4, 12, 816516) .Mr. Gandhi instanced the case of Zanzibar.
('6', 423, 4, 13, 816560) There was, in fact, no need to reserve tropical Colonies for Indian occupation, for East Africa was already open.
('6', 423, 5, 14, 816674) Mr. Gandhi went on to refer to the Registration Ordinance in the Transvaal, and referred in disappointed terms to the decision of the Imperial Government to allow its sanction to the measure.
('6', 423, 5, 15, 816866) Its effect was, he said, to place the Transvaal Indian in the position of a ticket of leave man.
('6', 423, 5, 16, 816963) If they were to be dealt with along these lines it was better that the Indians should be undeceived at once.
('6', 423, 5, 17, 817072) Mr. Gandhi said he foresaw the possibility of a position in which Great Britain would have to decide between losing the Colonies or leasing India, for the people’s self respect was involved, and their existence under such conditions as in the Transvaal would become intolerable.
('6', 423, 5, 18, 817351) The Indian was perfectly capable of realizing both sides of the question.
('6', 423, 5, 19, 817425) and, he thought, did so, but the Asiatic problem was not to be solved by measures such as the Transvaal Ordinance.
('6', 423, 5, 20, 817540) Asked whether he regarded the passing of the Ordinance as a weakening of the Indians’ position in South Africa, Mr. Gandhi asserted that it undoubtedly was so, but he believed that the disappointment of their hopes would in the end result advantageously, if the Indians would abide by their resolve to resist.
('6', 423, 5, 21, 817850) There would be said Mr. Gandhi, no resistance by force, but passive
('6', 424, 0, 1, 817918) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 425
('6', 424, 1, 2, 817961) resistance; and if the Indian people carried out their determination to undergo imprisonment rather than conform to the Ordinance, he thought well enough of the Colonial white to believe that such a demonstration of courage for the sake of a principle would be met with administration and, in the end, sympathy.
('6', 424, 1, 3, 818273) The Natal Mercury, 8 5 1907

('6', 425, 5, 22, 821065) 368. WILL INDIANS BE SLAVES?
('6', 425, 6, 23, 821094) The Transvaal Act has received [Royal] assent earlier than we expected.
('6', 425, 6, 24, 821166) The Imperial Government has chosen to take the first step of binding the Indian community with chains.
('6', 425, 6, 25, 821269) It now remains to be seen whether the community will carry this yoke.
('6', 425, 6, 26, 821339) We know of a young student from Japan who once went to a lawyer in Johannesburg for some personal work.
('6', 425, 6, 27, 821443) As the lawyer could not see him immediately, the student waited outside.
('6', 425, 6, 28, 821516) Meanwhile, an English official came to meet the lawyer.
('6', 425, 6, 29, 821572) As he was about to enter the lawyer’s office after knocking, the young Japanese held him by the sleeve and said to him spiritedly: “You cannot go in just yet.
('6', 425, 6, 30, 821731) I have a prior right.” Being a gentleman, the officer at once saw the point, and requested the young man’s permission to go in first, as he had urgent work.
('6', 425, 6, 31, 821888) The student was as polite as he had been bold.
('6', 425, 6, 32, 821935) For, when the official asked his leave, he readily allowed him to go in.
('6', 425, 6, 33, 822008) This anecdote
('6', 426, 0, 1, 822022) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 427
('6', 426, 1, 2, 822065) should be engraved on the mind of every Indian, for it gives an exact idea of our bond of slavery.
('6', 426, 1, 3, 822164) The young Japanese did not allow his self respect to be flouted.
('6', 426, 1, 4, 822229) When every one in Japan, the rich as well as the poor, came to believe in self respect, the country became free.
('6', 426, 1, 5, 822342) She could give Russia a slap in the face, and today Japan’s flag flies very high in the world.
('6', 426, 1, 6, 822437) Though her people wear a yellow skin, Japan enjoys friendship with white England as between equals.
('6', 426, 1, 7, 822537) In the same way we too need to feel the spirit of self respect.
('6', 426, 1, 8, 822601) Having remained in bondage for a long time like a caged parrot, we cannot realize what honour and freedom are Furthermore, like the parrot which is pleased when bound with a golden string and made to perform, we too are elated and blush pink at the thought of our imagined happiness, when our masters, whether white or Coloured, feign affection for us only in order to bind us with the golden thread and make us forget our real condition.
('6', 426, 1, 9, 823040) To remind us of that condition, this irksome law has been sanctioned.
('6', 426, 1, 10, 823110) Shall we now obey it and become slaves?
('6', 426, 1, 11, 823150) Our Johannes burg correspondent says that the regulations under the new law will be lenient and considerate.
('6', 426, 1, 12, 823259) That is to say, Lord Elgin may bind us with a golden thread.
('6', 426, 1, 13, 823320) Shall we allow ourselves to be deluded thus?
('6', 426, 1, 14, 823365) We, for our part, can only reply in the negative to both these questions.
('6', 426, 1, 15, 823439) A great deal of effort is required to get this law repealed, and in no case must we turn back.
('6', 426, 1, 16, 823534) Let us give this matter a little thought.
('6', 426, 1, 17, 823576) A huge meeting was held in September, and we proclaimed that the Indian community would go to gaol rather than submit to the proposed Act.
('6', 426, 1, 18, 823715) 1 While doing so, every Indian took an oath in the name of Ishwar or Khuda.
('6', 426, 1, 19, 823791) Though that law was disallowed, the one now passed is exactly of the same nature.
('6', 426, 1, 20, 823873) All the arguments that could be advanced against such an act then can be put forward now, and in fact many more.
('6', 426, 1, 21, 823986) For we have worked hard against it and shouted our protests from house tops.
('6', 426, 1, 22, 824063) Moreover, we thought the Bill so objectionable that we raised big subscriptions with which to send the Deputation to England; it cost us £700. In the presence of high officials, the Deputation told Lord Elgin:
('6', 426, 2, 23, 824273) We should also place before Your Lordship one more fact and that is the Fourth Resolution passed by the mass meeting.
('6', 426, 2, 24, 824391) That Resolution, which was unanimously approved by the
('6', 426, 3, 25, 824446) 1 Fourth Resolution; vide “The Mass Meeting”, 11 9 1906.
('6', 427, 0, 1, 824503) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 427, 1, 2, 824545) meeting in all humility and firmness and affirmed with an oath, said that, if ever the Imperial Government should approve the Act, the Indian community would go to gaol rather than suffer the great indignity inflicted on it by the Act.
('6', 427, 1, 3, 824781) So deep was the feeling of the community.
('6', 427, 1, 4, 824823) We have submitted to much suffering till now.
('6', 427, 1, 5, 824869) But the disgrace of this act is unbearable, and that is why we have travelled six thousand miles to make an appeal to you.
('6', 427, 1, 6, 824992) With this Act we have reached the utmost limit.
('6', 427, 2, 7, 825040) As though this were not enough, and as if there was the slightest doubt in anyone’s mind about the gaol going resolution, the South Africa British Indian Committee was formed, and many prominent men joined it.
('6', 427, 2, 8, 825250) Now if, under any pretext, the Indian community should cancel the gaol going resolution, what would be the result?
('6', 427, 2, 9, 825365) Only that the South Africa British Indian Committee would have become futile.
('6', 427, 2, 10, 825443) The Deputation’s labours would have been in vain.
('6', 427, 2, 11, 825493) .All the fame that the Indian community has now gained would turn into disgrace.
('6', 427, 2, 12, 825574) The Government would henceforth put no trust in the Indian community’s word.
('6', 427, 2, 13, 825651) We would be classed with the lowest and meanest.
('6', 427, 2, 14, 825700) If this should happen, the Imperial Government would give ready assent to all the laws directed against the Indians in South Africa.
('6', 427, 2, 15, 825833) And in the end those who are not content to live a dog’s life or that of a crow will have to leave South Africa.
('6', 427, 2, 16, 825946) Moreover, if things should come to such a pass, there would be repercussions in India too, and the whole country might look down upon us with well deserved contempt.
('6', 427, 2, 17, 826112) Such are the force and the usefulness of the Fourth Resolution, and so serious its implications.
('6', 427, 2, 18, 826209) It is therefore our earnest hope that the Indian community will not swerve from it.
('6', 427, 2, 19, 826293) Whether or not all of us are agreed, those who realize how things stand must not fail in their duty.

('6', 428, 4, 8, 827049) 370. INDENTURED INDIANS
('6', 428, 5, 9, 827073) As a result of the Durban Corporation’s decision to reduce the rice ration, the indentured Indians employed by them have struck work, and have got ready to go to gaol.
('6', 428, 5, 10, 827241) They did this earlier also.
('6', 428, 5, 11, 827269) On that occasion, the Magistrate was kind.
('6', 428, 5, 12, 827312) He observed that, even though it was legal to give them maize instead of rice, it would be cruel to insist on the [letter of the] law.
('6', 428, 5, 13, 827447) He therefore let the men off and advised the Corporation to give them rice as usual, even if it was dearer.
('6', 428, 5, 14, 827555) The same situation has arisen today, but the Magistrate is Mr. Beans.
('6', 428, 5, 15, 827625) He has given judgement strictly according to the law and sentenced many workers to a fine of £1 each.
('6', 428, 5, 16, 827727) We hope Indian lawyers will look into the matter and do something about it.
('6', 428, 5, 17, 827803) If we think of the Transvaal Ordinance in this context, we can see that, when laws are found to be harsher, even poor indentured workers can muster enough courage to rise against them and get ready to go to gaol.
('6', 428, 5, 18, 828016) We have seen from the case of the indentured men that such remedies often secure justice.
('6', 428, 5, 19, 828106) If indentured labourers can do so much in self interest, who will deny that the Indian community in the Transvaal ought to do no less?
('6', 428, 5, 20, 828241) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 11 5 1907
('6', 428, 6, 21, 828283) 371. OMAR HABI AMOD ZAVERI
('6', 428, 7, 22, 828310) BIOGRAPHICAL SKETCH Elsewhere in this number we publish an account of a meeting 2
('6', 428, 8, 23, 828392) held in honour of Mr. Omar Zaveri.
('6', 428, 8, 24, 828427) Since our readers must be eager to learn about his career, here is a biographical sketch Mr. Omar
('6', 428, 9, 25, 828525) 1 Vide “Ladysmith Struggle”, p.
('6', 428, 10, 26, 828557) 2 Vide “Farewell to Omar Haji Amod Zaveri”, 11 5 1907.
('6', 429, 0, 1, 828612) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 429, 1, 2, 828654) Zaveri was born at Porbunder in 1872. He set out for Africa at the early age of twelve with his brother, the late renowned Mr. Aboobaker Zaveri 1. While on the ship he began his education, and learnt Gujarati.
('6', 429, 1, 3, 828864) For four years he studied privately and at the Government School in Durban.
('6', 429, 1, 4, 828940) His studies were cut short by the death of Aboobaker in 1887. In 1890 he joined the firm of his guardian, Mr. Abdulla Haji Adam, as an apprentice.
('6', 429, 1, 5, 829087) Then he satisfied, to some extent, his keen desire to learn Arabic and Persian.
('6', 429, 1, 6, 829167) In 1897 he took part in public activities for the first time and was made Joint Honorary Secretary of the Durban Anjuman [ e ] Islam.
('6', 429, 1, 7, 829301) Omar was interested in horticulture, and as fruit was scarce in Porbunder, he experimented with fruit growing as a result of which some fruits are now to be had there in plenty.
('6', 429, 1, 8, 829479) For six months during 1904, he toured Egypt, Italy, Switzerland, France, England and America and obtained valuable experience.
('6', 429, 1, 9, 829606) 2 At this time, he had with him a barrister as a tutor companion.
('6', 429, 1, 10, 829672) It was meant to be an educational tour.
('6', 429, 2, 11, 829712) While in London, he met Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji, Sir Muncherji Bhownaggree and others, and returned to Durban the same year.
('6', 429, 2, 12, 829834) He was then made Joint Honorary Secretary of the Natal Indian Congress, along with Mr. Adamji Miankhan.
('6', 429, 2, 13, 829938) The work he has done since then is well known to the Indian community.
('6', 429, 2, 14, 830009) His wealth, his servants, his house, his time and his education—all these have been entirely at the disposal of the community.
('6', 429, 2, 15, 830136) During the Transvaal Deputation’s visit to England and again during the agitation against the Dealers’ Licenses Act, Mr. Omar Zaveri worked very hard along with Mr. Anglia.
('6', 429, 2, 16, 830309) Mr. Zaveri also took a leading part in founding the Memon Committee.
('6', 429, 2, 17, 830378) The Durban Library has received many gifts of books from him and he himself visited it almost daily.
('6', 429, 2, 18, 830479) Impelled by a kind nature, he has always attempted to bring about private settle ment of disputes among members of the Indian community.
('6', 429, 2, 19, 830616) People hold such a high opinion of his integrity that he has had with him a general power of attorney from a number of people.
('6', 429, 2, 20, 830743) In the course of all this work, Mr. Omar realized the need for further education and intends to become a barrister after passing the Matriculation examina tion.
('6', 429, 2, 21, 830904) As an instance of his humility and simplicity, it may be mentioned that he himself teaches his servants and children at home whenever he has the leisure.
('6', 429, 3, 22, 831058) 1 Aboobaker Amod Zaveri 2 Vide “A Good Example”, 1 10 1904.
('6', 430, 0, 1, 831118) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 431
('6', 430, 1, 2, 831161) Mr. Omar Haji Amod Zaveri possesses all the qualities denoted by his name 1. He is still young in years.
('6', 430, 1, 3, 831266) If hispresent ideas keep growing, he is sure to prove himself invaluable in India also.
('6', 430, 2, 4, 831354) [From Gujarati]
('6', 430, 3, 5, 831370) Indian Opinion, 11 5 1907
('6', 430, 4, 6, 831396) 372. KALYANDAS JAGMOHANDAS [MEHTA]
('6', 430, 5, 7, 831431) Another gentleman who, by virtue of his qualities is a zaveri— although his name is Kalyandas—has sailed home by the same boat as Mr. Omar Haji Amod Zaveri.
('6', 430, 5, 8, 831588) Mr. Zaveri’s function was to lead, that of Mr. Kalyandas to work silently for a good cause remaining in the background.
('6', 430, 5, 9, 831708) In years he is still a child, but in our experience we have seldom come across a youth so tender of heart, so scornful of money, so regardless of his own body but at the same time so solicitous of the welfare of others.
('6', 430, 5, 10, 831928) Johannesburg Indians are aware of the work done by Kalyandas during the terrible outbreak of plague in that city.
('6', 430, 5, 11, 832042) We do not know of anyone having had occasion to be displeased with him at any time.
('6', 430, 5, 12, 832126) India’s chains would snap this day, if in that country captains like Mr. Omar Haji Amod Zaveri and soldiers like Kalyandas came forward in large numbers.
('6', 430, 5, 13, 832280) Rarely does one come across heroes who would ceaselessly, and always with a cheerful smile, quietly give themselves over to public service in pursuance of duty, that is, in the name of Khuda, seeking neither money nor honours, and never even creaming of leadership.
('6', 430, 5, 14, 832546) Kalyandases are rare indeed.

('6', 437, 6, 23, 847676) 374. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('6', 437, 7, 24, 847701) ‘‘THE PLAGUE’’
('6', 437, 8, 25, 847716) A calamity as great as plague has now befallen the Indian community.
('6', 437, 8, 26, 847785) On Friday—after my last letter was sent—a cable was received saying that the Imperial Government had assented to the act, which will mean slavery for Indians.
('6', 437, 8, 27, 847944) Every one is asking: what can
('6', 438, 0, 1, 847974) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 439
('6', 438, 1, 2, 848017) avail us now?

('6', 439, 1, 3, 850574) The story of the wolf and the lamb fits this Act.
('6', 439, 1, 4, 850624) When the strong wolf resolved to eat up the poor lamb, he began looking for a pretext for doing so.
('6', 439, 1, 5, 850724) He blamed the lamb for muddying the water which he, the wolf, was to drink.
('6', 439, 1, 6, 850800) When the lamb pointed out that he had really been drinking the water down stream, the wolf replied, “If it is not you, then it must have been your father who did that.” So saying, he ate up the lamb.
('6', 439, 1, 7, 851000) There is not the slightest difference between our plight and that of the lamb in the fable.
('6', 439, 1, 8, 851092) They wish somehow to show that, even outside the field of politics, we are not their equals.
('6', 439, 1, 9, 851185) That is why they have got this law passed.
('6', 439, 1, 10, 851228) Lord Elgin’s fear has proved a stronger motive than his inclination to do justice.

('6', 439, 1, 15, 851635) On all sides people appear filled with enthusiasm at the thought of going to gaol and making themselves happy there as in a palace.
('6', 439, 3, 16, 851767) Something else has transpired which lends much support to these views.

('6', 439, 3, 18, 851945) He has written to The Times to say that the law should be regarded as having been passed to establish the doctrine that there can be no equality between the whites and the Indians.
('6', 439, 3, 19, 852126) All British subjects should not be regarded as equal.

('6', 439, 3, 21, 852255) They want to prove by it that they have the authority and the right to deal with us in any way they choose, without caring to think whether we like it or not.
('6', 439, 3, 22, 852414) In the measure in which they have obtained self government and become free, they want to make slaves of us.
('6', 439, 3, 23, 852522) The difference between slavery and freedom consists in the manner in which others deal with us.
('6', 439, 3, 24, 852618) If, for the sake of a friend, master or father, I willingly perform the meanest job, I shall win greater respect, my master will think of me as a very loyal servant, and my father will regard me with affection.
('6', 439, 3, 25, 852829) But if I do the same thing under compulsion, men will spit at me, think me a coward and ask why I did not kill myself instead of submitting to such slavery.

('6', 440, 1, 2, 853103) would be under the law is of comparable magnitude.
('6', 440, 1, 3, 853154) We may put up with being unable to enjoy any rights in regard to land, with having our trade restricted, and with the denial of certain other rights, for there is no use of actual force against us in these matters.
('6', 440, 1, 4, 853369) But the law in question seeks physically to bring compulsion to bear on our persons.
('6', 440, 1, 5, 853454) Just as in India some of us oppress the bhangis and force them to dress in some particular fashion and use obsequious language lest we be polluted by their proximity [sic], it has fallen to our lot to be treated like bhangis here in the Transvaal.
('6', 440, 1, 6, 853702) To remind us perpetually of this status, we are to be obliged to carry permits on our persons.

('6', 440, 1, 8, 854002) Tell him of the fate of his bull.” Since that day Luther has remained immortal.
('6', 440, 1, 9, 854082) Millions may want to do what Luther did, but not every one can succeed.
('6', 440, 3, 10, 854154) After reading this news letter, many readers will want to know what we are to do now.

('6', 440, 3, 14, 854465) Anyone asking for a permit can do so only under the new law.

('6', 440, 3, 22, 855070) For the present, therefore, we should stay away from the Permit Office to show that we are firm and fearless and determined to implement our Resolution.

('6', 441, 2, 3, 855709) LORD ELGINS OINTMENT
('6', 441, 3, 4, 855730) After having inflicted a cruel wound on us, Lord Elgin now seeks to heal it with an ointment of his own make.
('6', 441, 3, 5, 855840) Reuter has cabled that, while replying to a question concerning the Act, it was stated by Mr. Churchill that, during his discussions with General Botha, the latter had mentioned that the regulations under the new Act would be very liberal and would not hurt anyone’s feelings.
('6', 441, 3, 6, 856117) Reuter also adds that the Members of the House of Commons received the information with applause.
('6', 441, 3, 7, 856215) Only a woman in labour knows the pangs of childbirth.
('6', 441, 3, 8, 856269) The Members of the House of Commons doubtless play the midwife to us.
('6', 441, 3, 9, 856339) Their applause shows that they were touched because our feelings had earlier been hurt.
('6', 441, 3, 10, 856427) But they applauded without realizing the significance of Mr. Churchill’s reply.
('6', 441, 3, 11, 856507) Lord Elgin seems to be trying to win over children by humouring them.
('6', 441, 3, 12, 856577) After the Act is passed, however liberal the regulations, our condition of slavery will remain unchanged.
('6', 441, 3, 13, 856683) If we are yoked to a cart and the driver holds the reins loose, we do not for that reason cease to be cattle.
('6', 441, 3, 14, 856793) What does it matter if, instead of impressions of all the ten fingers, only one finger print were required, or even if only a signature were required instead of a fingerprint?
('6', 441, 3, 15, 856969) Even so, for reasons which I have explained, we cannot submit to the Act.
('6', 441, 3, 16, 857043) Though we may be given good food and comfort as slaves, these things ought not to turn our heads and make us forget our true state of slavery.
('6', 441, 3, 17, 857186) We have in all humility to inform His Lordship that, as long as compulsory registration is to remain in force, we will not submit to the act, no matter what relief is granted.

('6', 442, 1, 2, 857802) 375. HEJAZ RAILWAY: SOME INTERESTING INFORMATION
('6', 442, 2, 3, 857851) The special correspondent of The Times of India at Istanbul has reported some interesting facts about the Hejaz Railway.
('6', 442, 2, 4, 857972) Here is a summary of his report.
('6', 442, 2, 5, 858005) The correspondent has passed severe strictures on the railway officials, and he advises all those who wish to give money not to pay so long as the extreme corruption in the railway is not ended.
('6', 442, 2, 6, 858200) He has also sent the photographs of Mr. Kidwai and Mr. Abdul Kadir, the students who had gone to Istanbul with money.
('6', 442, 2, 7, 858318) We have written to the two gentlemen in order to ascertain their views and shall publish their replies when received.
('6', 442, 2, 8, 858436) We cannot say how much truth there is in this report, but The Times of India has given it wide publicity—which would suggest that there is an element of truth in it.
('6', 442, 3, 9, 858602) ORIGIN OF RAILWAY The man who first mooted the idea of the Hejaz Railway was the notorious Izzet Pasha, who was responsible for the slaughter of Armenians.
('6', 442, 3, 10, 858758) He is one of the self seekers who surround His Majesty the Sultan.
('6', 442, 3, 11, 858825) He hails from Damascus.
('6', 442, 3, 12, 858849) Few people outside Istanbul know that the Sultan lives as a prisoner of the Syrian Pashas at Yildiz Kiosk 1. Being a true Muslim, the Sultan readily approved the Hejaz Railway proposal when it was put before him.
('6', 442, 3, 13, 859062) With a view to suiting everyone’s convenience, he suggested that the proposed line should connect the harbours at Jidda and Yenbo with Medina and Mecca.
('6', 442, 3, 14, 859215) But his suggestion was not accepted.
('6', 442, 3, 15, 859252) Izzet Pasha persuaded the Sultan to believe that, if the line were started from Jidda, the British were sure to take advantage of it.
('6', 442, 3, 16, 859386) They would set up their own man as Caliph.
('6', 442, 3, 17, 859429) Izzet Pasha had made his own arrangements.
('6', 442, 3, 18, 859472) He had even bought some land.
('6', 442, 3, 19, 859502) He was being helped by Shaikh Abu Handa.
('6', 442, 3, 20, 859543) It was accordingly decided to lay the track between Damascus and Medina.
('6', 442, 4, 21, 859616) FROM DAMASCUS TO MEDINA
('6', 442, 5, 22, 859640) The proposed track is to extend over about 1600 miles, of which 450 miles have been covered by now.
('6', 442, 5, 23, 859740) Last year the profits from this venture amounted to only £61,900. Strenuous efforts are being made to raise subscriptions, but the people of Istanbul do not trust Izzet Pasha.
('6', 442, 5, 24, 859916) No one therefore contributes any money.
('6', 442, 5, 25, 859956) And though all the

('6', 445, 1, 2, 864257) 376. LETTER TO “THE STAR”1
('6', 445, 2, 3, 864284) JOHANNESBURG, May 11, 1907
('6', 445, 3, 4, 864311) TO THE EDITOR THE STAR [JOHANNESBURG]
('6', 445, 4, 5, 864349) SIR, In your letterhead on Mr. Polak’s letter regarding the Asiatic Registration Act, you state that “the most bitter opponents of the Asiatic trader would, probably, not be sorry if the proposed passive resistance movement resulted in the deportation of the most aggressive agitators”.
('6', 445, 4, 6, 864636) Unfortunately for the “bitter opponents”, so far I have been able to see, there exists no such provision for compulsory deportation, as you seem to think there is.
('6', 445, 4, 7, 864800) If, therefore, their wish is to be satisfied, a new Act will be necessary to drive out of the Colony by physical compulsion those Indians who, in their own opinion, are doing a service to their country and the Empire in their struggle to retain for their countrymen some degree of self respect and manliness.
('6', 445, 4, 8, 865109) You proceed to add:
('6', 445, 5, 9, 865129) Freed from the domination of the latter, we believe the great bulk of British Indians lawfully domiciled in the Transvaal would soon learn to appreciate the greater security which the act confers upon them, and to recognize how much they have been misled as to the real effect of the new legislation.
('6', 445, 5, 10, 865430) One can quite understand your inability to enter into the feelings of British Indians.
('6', 445, 5, 11, 865517) You have misread them entirely if you think that there is a single Indian who is likely, after the withdrawal of the domination (which does not exist), to appreciate the “greater security” conferred by the Act.
('6', 445, 5, 12, 865728) In spite of my efforts to detect it, I have failed to trace any greater security.
('6', 445, 5, 13, 865810) There can be no question of misleading the mass of the Indians as to the real effect of the new legislation.
('6', 445, 5, 14, 865919) The issue is simple.
('6', 445, 5, 15, 865940) Compulsory registration involves a special restriction on the personal liberty of the subject because of the colour of his skin.
('6', 445, 5, 16, 866069) It has been put before the Indians in the Transvaal that such legislation amounts to a deep humiliation and a kind of
('6', 445, 6, 17, 866187) 1 This was reproduced in Indian Opinion, 18 5 1907.
('6', 446, 0, 1, 866239) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 447
('6', 446, 1, 2, 866282) slavery.
('6', 446, 1, 3, 866291) They have, therefore, been advised that they ought not to barter away their present comparative state of freedom for the state prescribed for them by the new legislation, no matter how tempting it may otherwise appear to be.
('6', 446, 1, 4, 866516) The above is the position they will be reduced to, according to my view, under the new legislation.
('6', 446, 1, 5, 866616) In order to avert the degrading blow, I have ventured, also, to tell them, first, that it is their duty firmly and respectfully to decline to submit themselves to re registration under the Act; secondly, that, seeing that the Transvaal is their adopted home and that they are without any voice in the choice of their legislators, the only effective way in which they can make themselves heard is to submit to the ultimate result of a breach of the conditions of the law, namely, to prefer gaol to either re registration or leaving the country or paying the fine; and, thirdly, that, consistently with the above attitude, they should cease to have any communication with the Permit Department, and should ask their friends and other Indians who may wish to re enter the Transvaal not to apply for permits, either temporary or permanent, under the new law.
('6', 446, 1, 6, 867471) If it be said that both the last mentioned points distinctly advance the anti Asiatic purpose, so be it.
('6', 446, 1, 7, 867576) It merely proves what I have often said —that the struggle, on the Indian side, is not to grasp as much of the Transvaal trade as possible, but to remain in the country with dignity and self respect, and not to sell their birthright for a mess of pottage.
('6', 446, 1, 8, 867832) I admit, and many English friends have told me, that my advice may not be widely followed.
('6', 446, 1, 9, 867923) I shall still be content if the misgivings of such friends prove to be well founded.
('6', 446, 1, 10, 868008) And, if British Indians choose to submit to the serfdom which the legislation seeks to impose on them, I can only say that we shall have deserved the Registration Act.
('6', 446, 1, 11, 868176) We are undoubtedly put upon our mettle, and it remains to be seen whether, as a body, we shall rise to the occasion.
('6', 446, 1, 12, 868293) I consider that the attitude above sketched is unexceptionable, and I claim for it from the brave colonists not derision but praise.
('6', 446, 1, 13, 868426) But derision or praise, it will be churlish and sinful for myself and my fellow workers to turn aside from a course which has been dictated by a conscientious purpose.
('6', 446, 2, 14, 868594) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI The Star, 14 5 1907
('6', 447, 0, 1, 868639) 448 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 447, 1, 2, 868681) 377. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('6', 447, 2, 3, 868714) [JOHANNESBURG,] Sunday, May 12, 1907
('6', 447, 3, 4, 868751) CHHAGANLAL,
('6', 447, 4, 5, 868763) I had intended to write to you a very long letter, but was unable to do so owing to a very severe headache during the train journey.
('6', 447, 4, 6, 868896) The condition continued yesterday, and today it is no better.
('6', 447, 4, 7, 868958) My health seems to have been seriously affected by my exertions in Durban this time.
('6', 447, 4, 8, 869043) However, I feel confident of regaining my health through sufficient rest, earth treatment, etc.
('6', 447, 4, 9, 869139) I have sent some matter today.
('6', 447, 4, 10, 869170) I expect to write or dictate more tonight.
('6', 447, 4, 11, 869213) When I heard about the balance sheet, it immediately occurred to me that it was desirable—indeed it was our duty—to give Thakkar an increment without his asking for it.
('6', 447, 4, 12, 869382) I believe he is very useful to us.
('6', 447, 4, 13, 869417) Despite some of his bad habits, he is strong on two points: his determined patriotism and his celibacy.
('6', 447, 4, 14, 869521) His work is on the whole satisfactory.
('6', 447, 4, 15, 869560) I would therefore specially advise you to give him an increment immediately.

('6', 451, 8, 20, 876653) In our opinion, the usefulness of the liberal education received by them can be measured only in so far as they use it for the advancement of their countrymen.
('6', 451, 8, 21, 876813) Of all the countries in the world, perhaps India today, whether within her own borders or outside, has the greatest need of the talents possessed by her sons, and we hold that, before Indians who have received a liberal education’s can make such public use thereof, they will have to adopt voluntary poverty.
('6', 451, 8, 22, 877122) Indeed, we are not sure that it is not the duty of every man to limit his personal pecuniary ambition.
('6', 451, 8, 23, 877225) Whether, however, the larger proposition can be sufficiently proved or not, the smaller one we have already laid down is indisputable.
('6', 451, 8, 24, 877360) Apart from the work of securing ordinary civil rights for their countrymen in South Africa, Indians like Mr. Royeppen can do a vast amount of useful and quiet work in the way of internal and social reform.

('6', 454, 4, 7, 881961) 384. LADYSMITH STRUGGLE
('6', 454, 5, 8, 881985) There has been a fresh defeat for Indians in the matter of licences, and this calls for second thoughts.
('6', 454, 5, 9, 882090) The Ladysmith struggle is to be treated as part of the struggle all over the Transvaal.
('6', 454, 5, 10, 882178) We hope that no Indian will wind up his business.
('6', 454, 5, 11, 882228) In the Transvaal an Indian not taking out a permit will go to gaol; but it is not so in Natal.
('6', 454, 5, 12, 882323) For, according to the [Dealers’] Licenses Act, one can only be fined for carrying on business without a licence.
('6', 454, 5, 13, 882436) There is no provision for imprisonment in default of fine.
('6', 454, 5, 14, 882495) This appears confusing at first sight, in fact there is no confusion here.
('6', 454, 5, 15, 882570) If the fine imposed under the Act for trading without a licence is not paid, the Government will have the right to recover it by attaching and selling the shopkeeper’s stocks.
('6', 454, 5, 16, 882746) This is not the time for people to be afraid of such things.
('6', 454, 5, 17, 882807) Only when we allow our goods to be sold in this manner will the eyes of the Government be opened to the magnitude of the oppression inflicted on us.
('6', 454, 5, 18, 882956) As for the situation in Ladysmith, we know that the Govern ment itself is displeased with the Ladysmith regulation.
('6', 454, 5, 19, 883072) Very likely no one will be prosecuted.
('6', 454, 5, 20, 883111) But things will become difficult if what happened at Ladysmith today happens elsewhere.
('6', 454, 5, 21, 883199) Just as we must show courage [at the prospect] of going to gaol, so must we show courage and face [a possible] confiscation of our goods.
('6', 454, 5, 22, 883337) Here too we can point to the example of Englishmen themselves.
('6', 454, 5, 23, 883400) When two years ago the Education Act was enforced in England, many people were reluctant to pay the Education Cess.
('6', 454, 5, 24, 883516) There was only one way of collesting the tax from those who refused to pay it: that was to attach and sell their goods.
('6', 454, 5, 25, 883636) Those who were displeased by the tax refused to pay it and allowed their goods to be sold, with the result that the Act is about to be repealed.
('6', 454, 5, 26, 883781) In our opinion, the same course has to be taken if the licence menace becomes serious and no redress can be had by
('6', 455, 0, 1, 883896) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 455, 1, 2, 883938) other means.
('6', 455, 1, 3, 883951) While adopting this course, we should ensure that the shops and houses of Indian traders and their account books are all kept in order.
('6', 455, 1, 4, 884087) We also hold that, if the Indian community in the Transvaal makes good its pledge, it will have good results in Natal too.

('6', 455, 4, 7, 884252) 385. GAME OF CHESS
('6', 455, 5, 8, 884271) When the news of the passing of the new Act was received, The Star published a forceful cartoon.
('6', 455, 5, 9, 884368) It shows the whites and the Indians playing a game of chess.
('6', 455, 5, 10, 884429) With the permission of The Star, we reproduce the cartoon elsewhere with our own cartoon in reply.
('6', 455, 5, 11, 884528) According to The Star, the black king has mounted an attack on the Transvaal rook.
('6', 455, 5, 12, 884611) The white knight; if it can enter the Ordinance square, will be in a position to check the black king.
('6', 455, 5, 13, 884714) Now that the Bill has become law, the white knight can move into the Ordinance square and force the black king into the Indian square.
('6', 455, 5, 14, 884849) The white knight is pleased.
('6', 455, 5, 15, 884878) In the cartoon which we publish in reply, it is shown that the square of the gaol going resolution is occupied by a black pawn.
('6', 455, 5, 16, 885006) The white knight in its hurry has overlooked the black pawn which guards the Ordinance square and the fact that it cannot move into the Ordinance square as long as the black pawn is on the gaol square.
('6', 455, 5, 17, 885208) It is further suggested that what in its blind hurry the white knight takes to be the black king is really not a king; it can only be a poor pawn.
('6', 455, 5, 18, 885355) The Star has attached so much importance to the Ordinance.
('6', 455, 5, 19, 885414) It has charged the Indians with overrunning the Transvaal.
('6', 455, 5, 20, 885473) All this shows that the new Act is not a trivial matter.
('6', 455, 5, 21, 885530) We commend this drawing to every Indian for careful study.

('6', 455, 9, 25, 885661) The boycott was first started by the Chinese last year.
('6', 455, 9, 26, 885717) We have seen the effects it has had.
('6', 455, 9, 27, 885754) The Transvaal Indians, and other Indians
('6', 456, 0, 1, 885795) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 457
('6', 456, 1, 2, 885838) wishing to enter the Transvaal, need not go to such lengths as the Chinese, but they should support the resolution on gaol going, for implementing which it is necessary to suspend all business with the Permit Office.
('6', 456, 1, 3, 886055) In Durban, no Indian should go to Mr. Burgess’s office.
('6', 456, 1, 4, 886111) In Pretoria likewise, no Indian should go to the Permit Office, or enter into any correspondence with it.
('6', 456, 1, 5, 886217) It can be readily seen that, if we do not accept the new Ordinance, we cannot now go anywhere near the Permit Office, since all applications to the Permit Office made now will be treated as having been made under the new Act.

('6', 456, 1, 7, 886539) We were glad to learn that Mr. Mahomed Cassim Anglia, who had applied for a permit, intends to withdraw his application.
('6', 456, 1, 8, 886660) Mr. Osman Ahmed intends to do the same.

('6', 456, 1, 10, 886742) Every Indian should do the same.
('6', 456, 1, 11, 886775) Now, considering the matter carefully, what can we gain by having anything to do with the Permit Office?
('6', 456, 1, 12, 886880) What difference will it make [to our situation] if three or four Indians are able to enter the Transvaal [as a result of our dealings with the Permit Office]?
('6', 456, 1, 13, 887039) And what harm will be done if they cannot?
('6', 456, 1, 14, 887082) We hope that in view of the damage that is likely to be done to [the interests of the] entire Indian community if any business is done with that Office, every Indian will boycott it, as suggested by the British Indian Association.
('6', 456, 1, 15, 887313) On reflection, we think that young Indians, and others who have anything to do with the Permit Office, should break off all relations with it, and persuade others to do likewise.
('6', 456, 1, 16, 887492) A couple of men can stand near the Office entrance by turns and if anyone wishes to go in, dissuade him from doing so.

('6', 456, 5, 20, 887677) In Western countries education is so highly valued that senior teachers are treated with much respect.
