('6', 457, 1, 3, 888121) Writing about the occasion, The Pall Mall Gazette, a well known journal in England, has explained the nature of real education.
('6', 457, 1, 4, 888249) Its comments deserve the attention of us all The writer in The Pall Mall Gazette says: We hold that real education does not consist merely in acquainting oneself with ancient or modern books.
('6', 457, 1, 5, 888441) It consists in the habits which one knowingly or unknowingly imbibes from the atmosphere, one’s surroundings and the company one keeps and above all in work.
('6', 457, 1, 6, 888599) It is all very well to acquire a stock of knowledge from good books or from other sources.
('6', 457, 1, 7, 888690) But the more important thing is to learn humanity.
('6', 457, 1, 8, 888741) The primary function of teachers is, therefore, not to teach the alphabet, but to inculcate humanity.
('6', 457, 1, 9, 888843) Aristotle said that virtue is not learnt by reading big volumes.
('6', 457, 1, 10, 888908) It is by doing good deeds that we learn virtue.
('6', 457, 1, 11, 888956) Another great writer also says that it is well for one to know what isgood, but one will be considered a happy person only if one Acts upon that knowledge.
('6', 457, 2, 12, 889112) Judged by these standards, English schools will not be found wanting.
('6', 457, 2, 13, 889182) If we think of English schools as places for turning out human beings, we shall see that they give us statesmen and administrators.
('6', 457, 2, 14, 889314) Those educated in German schools may have greater knowledge, but if they become also men of action like the pupils of Eton, it is not by virtue of their training in the schools.
('6', 457, 2, 15, 889492) Despite the defects that may exist in English schools, it is these that produce true men.
('6', 457, 2, 16, 889582) They are men who are ever ready to meet an enemy threatening at the gates of England.
('6', 457, 2, 17, 889668) We can readily realize how a country that invests education with such a noble purpose becomes prosperous.
('6', 457, 2, 18, 889774) India’s star will shine bright when Indian children receive such education.
('6', 457, 2, 19, 889850) Parents, teachers and pupils ought to ponder over the passage quoted above.
('6', 457, 2, 20, 889926) It would not do merely to know it, it is necessary to Act upon it.
('6', 457, 2, 21, 889993) That is to say, parents should provide for excellent education, teachers should discharge their responsibility and pupils should recognize that mere literacy is not education.
('6', 457, 3, 22, 890169) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 18 5 1907
('6', 458, 0, 1, 890211) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 459
('6', 458, 1, 2, 890254) 388. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('6', 458, 2, 3, 890279) MIRACLE OF GAOL GOING
('6', 458, 3, 4, 890301) In the Transvaal and, if I am not mistaken, all over South Africa, Indians are discussing the gaol going resolution.
('6', 458, 3, 5, 890418) They feel certain that the Transvaal Indians will court imprisonment.
('6', 458, 3, 6, 890488) Some say that gaol is a palace; others look upon it as a beautiful garden.
('6', 458, 3, 7, 890563) Yet others consider it paradise.
('6', 458, 3, 8, 890596) Again there are some who think that gaol will prove to be a key which will unshackle the Indians.
('6', 458, 3, 9, 890694) Some others hold that, through the gaol gates, we shall pass from our present bondage to freedom.
('6', 458, 3, 10, 890792) Thus in their several ways, people have shown enthusiasm about going to gaol.
('6', 458, 3, 11, 890870) There are also some who, when the enthusiasm wanes, start worrying about what will happen to this person or that, and get into a panic.
('6', 458, 3, 12, 891006) I have received a few letters of this kind and the questions they raise do deserve not to be rejected out of hand.
('6', 458, 3, 13, 891121) For if we are to achieve success in the end, we should provide for the difficulties that are being felt.
('6', 458, 3, 14, 891226) Indian Opinion as well as the Association has received some letters to this effect.
('6', 458, 3, 15, 891310) I reply to them all in this letter and, on behalf of the Association, I apologize to the writers for its inability to answer them individually.
('6', 458, 3, 16, 891454) I do not refer to the writers by name as this is unnecessary.
('6', 458, 4, 17, 891516) WHAT SHOULD TRADERS DO?
('6', 458, 5, 18, 891540) An Indian writes that his shop is run by him and his son, and that he has debts to pay.
('6', 458, 5, 19, 891628) What should they do if they are both arrested?
('6', 458, 5, 20, 891675) To this question there can be many answers.
('6', 458, 5, 21, 891719) First, let me give the one that comes readily to mind.
('6', 458, 5, 22, 891774) Reply 1. Going to gaol is a great adventure, which will benefit not only the person concerned; but all the Transvaal Indians and, in fact, the Indian community as a whole.
('6', 458, 5, 23, 891946) To win such great benefits, one must put up with whatever loss may occur.
('6', 458, 5, 24, 892020) I believe that going to gaol will please Khuda or Ishwar.
('6', 458, 5, 25, 892078) The Creator always helps us in anything we do in fear of Him.
('6', 458, 5, 26, 892140) We reap the fruit of our labour in proportion to our faith in Him.
('6', 458, 5, 27, 892207) The Prophet Mahomed and his disciples were once in a cave.
('6', 458, 5, 28, 892266) A whole army was marching towards them.
('6', 458, 5, 29, 892306) The disciples cried out in fear: “O Prophet!
('6', 458, 5, 30, 892351) We are only three, and the army consists of hundreds of men.
('6', 458, 5, 31, 892412) How shall we save ourselves?” The Prophet replied, “We are not just three.
('6', 458, 5, 32, 892487) God, Who is a match for all, is
('6', 459, 0, 1, 892519) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 459, 1, 2, 892561) also with us.” It was owing to such superhuman faith that the Prophet succeeded in all that he attempted.
('6', 459, 1, 3, 892667) The enemy could not do him the least harm.
('6', 459, 1, 4, 892710) They passed the cave by; it did not occur to them even to look in.
('6', 459, 1, 5, 892777) Likewise, if we turn to the Hindu scriptures, we find Prahlad, a steadfast devotee of God, who remained unharmed even when made to embrace a red hot pillar, because he too had unshakable faith in God’s help.
('6', 459, 1, 6, 892985) In the same way, for an Indian who undertakes this adventure with Khuda as witness, there is nothing more to think about.
('6', 459, 1, 7, 893107) The great God, the protector of the faithful and the preserver of their honour, is present everywhere and at all times.
('6', 459, 1, 8, 893227) This reply implies reliance on fate.
('6', 459, 1, 9, 893264) But, as we know, fate without human effort is of no avail.
('6', 459, 1, 10, 893323) Hence, we need to think of other things too.
('6', 459, 1, 11, 893368) Reply 2. While thinking of human effort, we have always to bear the first reply in mind.
('6', 459, 1, 12, 893457) For those who cannot fully and sincerely trust in God, there is a remedy indicated by Mr. Coovadia: that is, even if all the men working in a shop are arrested simultaneously, they should go to gaol.
('6', 459, 1, 13, 893657) After returning from gaol, someone —not the proprietor of the shop—might take out a permit (not with the intention of obeying the law, but with that of getting it repealed) and run the shop.
('6', 459, 1, 14, 893848) Every person will thus come out of gaol well trained.
('6', 459, 1, 15, 893902) Reply 3. If anyone finds it difficult to Act up to Reply 2, permits for all persons other than the proprietor of the shop may be taken out on the last day fixed in the Gazette for the purpose.
('6', 459, 1, 16, 894095) Reply 4. The reader will remember what I said earlier: before it becomes necessary for an Indian to go to gaol, he will receive a notice to quit the Transvaal.
('6', 459, 1, 17, 894255) 1 He will be arrested after the expiry of the notice period, then sentenced to pay a fine and to imprisonment in case of default.
('6', 459, 1, 18, 894385) One must then go to gaol instead of paying the fine.
('6', 459, 1, 19, 894438) It will thus be possible for the trader, during the notice period, to make over his goods to his creditors.
('6', 459, 1, 20, 894546) For the small trader this will be the best remedy.
('6', 459, 1, 21, 894597) He is unlikely to find any difficulty in earning his daily bread after release from gaol.
('6', 459, 2, 22, 894687) WHAT OF WOMEN AND CHILDREN?
('6', 459, 3, 23, 894715) The Act gives [the Government] no power to arrest women, and children under sixteen.
('6', 459, 3, 24, 894800) They will thus have to suffer nothing more
('6', 459, 4, 25, 894843) 1 Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 13 4 1907 and 27 4 1907.
('6', 460, 0, 1, 894898) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 461
('6', 460, 1, 2, 894941) than separation from husband or father.
('6', 460, 1, 3, 894981) As for their maintenance, the answer has already been given that the Indian community will look after them.
('6', 460, 1, 4, 895089) It is to be remembered that all the thirteen thousand Indians will not have to go to gaol at the same time.
('6', 460, 1, 5, 895197) If, however, this should happen, our deliverance would be immediate.
('6', 460, 1, 6, 895266) Since all the Indians will not be going to gaol at the same time, there will always be a few people outside to look after one another.
('6', 460, 2, 7, 895401) WHAT IS A VALID PERMIT?
('6', 460, 3, 8, 895425) A correspondent has raised a further query.
('6', 460, 3, 9, 895469) Anyone who has obtained a permit after making a true affidavit and whose permit bears his signature or thumb impression is the holder of a valid permit, irrespective of whether or not he is a refugee.
('6', 460, 3, 10, 895670) Only these [that is, holders of valid permits] are to live on in the Transvaal and court imprisonment.
('6', 460, 4, 11, 895773) WHAT WILL HAPPEN TO MEN IN SMALL VILLAGES?
('6', 460, 4, 12, 895816) This question has been asked by a correspondent from Belfast.
('6', 460, 4, 13, 895878) The answer to this is contained for the most part in the foregoing replies.
('6', 460, 4, 14, 895954) If, however, the villages come in for attack first, Mr. Gandhi will very probably rush there.
('6', 460, 4, 15, 896048) Even if he happens to be busy in another part of the Transvaal, the people need not at all be afraid.
('6', 460, 4, 16, 896150) When an officer comes to investigate, whatever permit one holds should be shown to him.
('6', 460, 4, 17, 896238) He should be told that taking out a new permit is humiliating to us and that it would never happen.
('6', 460, 4, 18, 896338) If he asks for any finger prints other than the thumb impression, these should be flatly refused.
('6', 460, 4, 19, 896436) If a notice is served on anyone, information should be immediately sent to the Association with particulars, such as name, address, etc.
('6', 460, 4, 20, 896573) On the expiry of the notice period, he should appear before the court and accept whatever gaol sentence is awarded.
('6', 460, 4, 21, 896689) If a fine is imposed, it should not be paid.
('6', 460, 4, 22, 896734) It is necessary that every Indian everywhere should communicate these instructions to those who may not know about them.
('6', 460, 4, 23, 896855) BOYS OVER SIXTEEN Questions on this subject have been asked from Petersburg.
('6', 460, 4, 24, 896932) No boy, as long as he is under sixteen, will be arrested.
('6', 460, 4, 25, 896990) Boys who are over sixteen, whether or not they hold permits or other documents, are in the same situation as the holders of valid permits.
('6', 460, 5, 26, 897129) WHAT WILL HAPPEN TO EXISTING PERMITS?
('6', 460, 5, 27, 897167) A correspondent from Lindleyspoort seeks to know what will happen to those who hold permits now, but go to India on business
('6', 461, 0, 1, 897292) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 461, 1, 2, 897334) while the struggle is on, and then wish to return.
('6', 461, 1, 3, 897385) He asks whether their permits will hold good then.
('6', 461, 1, 4, 897436) For those who are preparing to go to gaol, this question will not arise.
('6', 461, 1, 5, 897509) For no one can tell what the end of the struggle will be.
('6', 461, 1, 6, 897567) However, generally speaking, the reply to this question is that such a permit holder will probably find no difficulty in returning.
('6', 461, 2, 7, 897699) HOW TO ACT DURING POLICE INVESTIGATION
('6', 461, 3, 8, 897738) A correspondent from Volkstroom asks: what are the police to be told when they come to investigate?
('6', 461, 3, 9, 897838) What is to be done if the police forcibly take away the permits?
('6', 461, 3, 10, 897903) The answer to these questions is only this: produce the permit when they come.
('6', 461, 3, 11, 897982) If required, give one thumb impression only.
('6', 461, 3, 12, 898027) If asked to take out new permits, refuse to do so, and say that you have no intention at all of taking out one, and that, if, for not doing so, the Government sends you to gaol, you will be ready for it.
('6', 461, 3, 13, 898231) The police do not have the authority to take away permits by force.
('6', 461, 3, 14, 898299) Therefore, if they threaten you in any way, reply boldly that you will not give up the permit.
('6', 461, 3, 15, 898394) If any such thing happens, report it to the Association.
('6', 461, 3, 16, 898451) The same person also inquires what arrangements will be made for the dependants of those who go to gaol according to the Fourth Resolution, and whether the Association will pay the counsel’s fees, etc.
('6', 461, 3, 17, 898653) Answers to these questions have already been given above.
('6', 461, 4, 18, 898711) CURTIS’S LETTER Mr. Curtis has addressed a letter to The Times of London.
('6', 461, 4, 19, 898785) A comment on it has already appeared in this journal.
('6', 461, 4, 20, 898839) 1 The whole letter is reproduced in The Star.
('6', 461, 4, 21, 898885) It is not necessary to offer a translation of it, as most of the facts in it are a matter of history.
('6', 461, 4, 22, 898987) There are, however, some points in the letter that deserve to be noted.
('6', 461, 4, 23, 899059) For Mr. Curtis is a member of the Council, and importance will always be attached to his statements.
('6', 461, 4, 24, 899160) Every Indian will therefore have to think about the matter.
('6', 461, 4, 25, 899220) Mr. Curtis says: (I) that Englishmen and Indians ought never to have equal rights; (2) that the law which has been enacted lays down quite properly that their rights are not equal (3) that this law is onlt the beginning of a series of many similar laws to come; and
('6', 461, 5, 26, 899486) 1 Vide “Interview to The Natal Mercury”, 7 5 1907 and “Johannesburg Letter”, 11 5 1907.
('6', 462, 0, 1, 899574) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 463
('6', 462, 1, 2, 899617) (4) that Lord Selborne’s promise that no new Indian would be allowed into the Transvaal should be honoured.
('6', 462, 2, 3, 899725) Mr. Curtis goes on to make other points, but those mentioned above are sufficient to put the Indian community on its guard.
('6', 462, 2, 4, 899849) The letter shows that the Transvaal Act is intended not merely to provide for registration, but to humiliate us also, to show that we are not their [the whites’] equals in any way, and to brand us as slaves.
('6', 462, 2, 5, 900057) From the letter one thing at least becomes certain: if the Act comes into force, and if we submit to it, instead of fresh rights being granted to us, we shall be deprived of what little remains to us, not merely in the Transvaal, but all over South Africa.
('6', 462, 2, 6, 900314) We shall, therefore, do well to remember what kind of law this is.
('6', 462, 2, 7, 900381) It will be better for every worthy son of India to leave the Colony or commit suicide than to submit to a law with such dire consequences.
('6', 462, 2, 8, 900520) Mr. Polak, the editor of this journal, has given Mr. Curtis a biting and powerful reply.
('6', 462, 2, 9, 900609) There is no time for translating it here.
('6', 462, 2, 10, 900651) But it may be read in the English section.
('6', 462, 3, 11, 900694) WELL DONE, STANDERTON!
('6', 462, 4, 12, 900717) The Indian community in Standerton has been carrying on a vigorous campaign against the new Act.
('6', 462, 4, 13, 900814) A correspondent of The Star went there to interview the local leaders.
('6', 462, 4, 14, 900885) They told him plainly that Indians thought nothing of the hardships of imprisonment as compared to those that would result from submission to the new Act.
('6', 462, 4, 15, 901040) They were well prepared to resist it, and had even raised funds for the purpose; but they would never submit to it.
('6', 462, 4, 16, 901156) I hope that, following the example of Standerton, every Indian everywhere will boldly give the same reply.
('6', 462, 4, 17, 901263) Now that we are on the battle field, we have nothing to fear and nothing to hide.
('6', 462, 5, 18, 901345) THREAT BY “THE STAR” The editor of The Star was somewhat piqued that the Klerksdorp Indians should have held a meeting about gaol going.
('6', 462, 5, 19, 901482) Mr. Polak therefore replied to him that not only in Klerksdorp but in Germiston and other places also such meetings had been held and that news was coming in from all over concerning the gaol going resolution.
('6', 462, 5, 20, 901692) This has enraged the editor all the more.
('6', 462, 5, 21, 901734) He has said in his comment that there were only a few leaders who were inciting the Indiancommunity, and that, if they were deported, the other Indians would not utter a word but would cheerfully accept the new Act.
('6', 462, 5, 22, 901950) Mr. Gandhi has replied to him as follows:
('6', 463, 0, 1, 901992) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 463, 1, 2, 902034) GANDHI’S REPLY1
('6', 463, 2, 3, 902050) You say in your leaderette that those who oppose the Indians would not be sorry if their leaders were deported.
('6', 463, 2, 4, 902162) But I ought to point out to such opponents that there is no law authorizing the Government forcibly to deport anyone.
('6', 463, 2, 5, 902280) If that is to be done, another law will have to be passed.
('6', 463, 2, 6, 902339) Then the Transvaal Government will be able to deport those Indians who are ready to serve their country and even the government.
('6', 463, 2, 7, 902468) You say that, if the leaders are deported, the remaining Indians will obey the Act.
('6', 463, 2, 8, 902552) They will then realize how the Act protects them and how they had been misled about it.
('6', 463, 2, 9, 902640) It is readily seen that, in saying this, you cannot appreciate the feelings of Indians.
('6', 463, 2, 10, 902728) You are mistaken if you think that there is a single Indian who takes the Act as being meant for his protection.
('6', 463, 2, 11, 902841) I have repeatedly gone through the Act without coming across any section which might protect Indians.
('6', 463, 2, 12, 902943) Moreover, there can be no question of misleading any Indians in this regard for what has been placed before them is a very simple matter: the new Act only insults Indians by branding them as slaves.
('6', 463, 2, 13, 903142) In several ways the Act reduces Indians to the position of slaves since it is an attack on them as a community.
('6', 463, 3, 14, 903254) They have therefore been advised not to forego in any circumstances the existing rights by submitting to the new Act.
('6', 463, 3, 15, 903372) If the new Act comes into force, I believe that the Indian community will be reduced to that position.
('6', 463, 4, 16, 903475) To ward off this deadly blow, I have advised people to do three things as under:
('6', 463, 5, 17, 903556) (1) They should not take out new registers.
('6', 463, 6, 18, 903600) (2) As the Indians residing in the Transvaal have no right to vote, the resolution about going to gaol is the only means they have to oppose any particular law.
('6', 463, 6, 19, 903761) They should not take out a permit, nor leave the country, nor pay a fine; the only straightforward and effective course for them is to go to gaol.
('6', 463, 7, 20, 903908) (3) If they do this, they should have nothing to do with the Permit Office, and should also write to their friends to persuade them not to ask for new permits, whether temporary or permanent.
('6', 463, 8, 21, 904100) 1 Vide “Letter to The Star”, 11 5 1907.
('6', 464, 0, 1, 904140) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 465
('6', 464, 1, 2, 904183) If anyone should say that, by doing so, they would be doing just what the whites wanted, let the whites think so.
('6', 464, 1, 3, 904297) This will prove what I have always said, viz., that the Indian community is not out to save its trade in the Transvaal, but to stay here with honour.
('6', 464, 1, 4, 904447) The Indian community will not sacrifice its good name just for the sake of a living.
('6', 464, 1, 5, 904532) Many English friends have told me—and I myself believe that —that not all Indians will perhaps accept this advice.
('6', 464, 1, 6, 904647) Even so, I have no fear.
('6', 464, 1, 7, 904672) I can only say that in that case we deserve the Act.
('6', 464, 1, 8, 904725) It is certain that we are now being put to the test.
('6', 464, 1, 9, 904778) It remains to be seen whether we stand it well or not.
('6', 464, 1, 10, 904833) I assert that no one can have anything to say against the position as set out above.
('6', 464, 1, 11, 904918) Instead of looking down upon it, the brave colonists should admire our stand.
('6', 464, 1, 12, 904996) But I think it to be a degrading and sinful thing to turn away from the path that we have chosen with true sincerity without caring whether others admire or condemn.

('6', 464, 8, 21, 905735) 390. MEETING OF BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('6', 464, 9, 22, 905778) A meeting of the [executive Committee of the] British Indian Association was held on Saturday the 11th.
('6', 464, 9, 23, 905882) It was presided over by Mr. Essop Mian, and was attended by Mr. Coovadia, Mr. Kazi of Krugersdorp, Mr. Nagadi of Warmbaths, Mr. Suleman Ahmed, Imam
('6', 465, 0, 1, 906030) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 465, 1, 2, 906072) Abdul Kadir, Mr. A. A. Pillay, Mr. Bhikha Ratanji, Mr. A. M. Bhayat, Mr. A. M. Aswat, Mr. Ameeruddin, Mr. Suleman Ibrahim Bhayat of Rustenburg, Mr. Naidu, Mr. Cachalia of Pretoria, Mr. A. M. Gatu, Mr. Alibhai Akuji, Mr. Omarji Saleji, Mr. Thomas, Mr. Bomanshah and others.
('6', 465, 1, 3, 906345) Mr. Gandhi told the meeting of the help received from Durban and answered many questions.
('6', 465, 1, 4, 906435) He then added: “The present time is so critical that every Indian, without depending on what others do and irrespective of it, must Act upon the resolution on gaol going for the sake of his honour and for the sake of his country.
('6', 465, 1, 5, 906665) In both Durban and Pretoria, no one should have anything to do with the Permit Office.
('6', 465, 1, 6, 906752) No one should enter [the Colony] with a new permit.
('6', 465, 1, 7, 906804) Mr. Coovadia made a powerful speech and moved the following resolution: The Honorary Secretary should write to people everywhere, asking them to stop having any dealings with the Permit Office Telegrams should be sent to Bombay and other places to say that those intending to go to the Transvaal should give up their plans for the time being.
('6', 465, 1, 8, 907147) No one should give all the ten finger impressions.
('6', 465, 1, 9, 907198) Meetings should be held at all the places and people should be asked to refuse to submit to the new Ordinance.
('6', 465, 1, 10, 907309) The resolution was supported by Mr. Aswat and passed unanimously.
('6', 465, 1, 11, 907375) Concluding the deliberations, Mr. Essop Mian said: No one should be afraid of acting upon the resolution on gaolgoing.
('6', 465, 1, 12, 907494) Going to gaol is for us like receiving an honour.
('6', 465, 1, 13, 907544) We should not become dupes of our temptation that, if we submit to the new Ordinance, we shall get a few rights in return.
('6', 465, 1, 14, 907667) Lord Milner and other officials made many promises, none of which was kept.
('6', 465, 1, 15, 907743) That shows that we can win nothing unless we exert ourselves and give proof of our courage.

('6', 465, 3, 17, 907851) Indian Opinion, 18 5 1907
('6', 465, 4, 18, 907877) 391. THE TRANSVAAL STRUGGLE
('6', 465, 5, 19, 907905) Why should you suffer taunts, my brother?
('6', 465, 5, 20, 907947) To be cowardly is a disgrace.
('6', 465, 5, 21, 907977) Suffer not insult; death is far better.
('6', 466, 0, 1, 908017) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 467
('6', 466, 1, 2, 908060) The pain of death comes only once; Disgrace brings unending pain, And every finger will point at you.
('6', 466, 1, 3, 908162) Early death with fame is gain, And this the noble soul doth love.
('6', 466, 1, 4, 908228) A base thing it is to live for long A lingering life of pain and shame.
('6', 466, 1, 5, 908300) Wealth may return that once has gone; Forever gone are honour and name.
('6', 466, 1, 6, 908372) The loss of honour brings in its train Miseries untold and threefold pain.
('6', 466, 2, 7, 908447) Letters received by us prove that today the Indian community in the Transvaal can think of nothing to talk about but the new Act.
('6', 466, 2, 8, 908577) This is a matter for rejoicing.
('6', 466, 2, 9, 908609) True to this spirit, we too will continue our discussion of the subject.
('6', 466, 2, 10, 908682) Last week we quoted a poem by the great heroic poet 1 of Gujarat.
('6', 466, 2, 11, 908748) Another poem by him charged with the heroic spirit is printed above.
('6', 466, 2, 12, 908817) The poet has shown vividly how it is a disgraceful thing to suffer taunts.
('6', 466, 2, 13, 908892) Honour once lost cannot be recovered, as wealth or other things, if lost, can be.
('6', 466, 2, 14, 908974) Moreover, the poet asserts that the loss of honour results in threefold suffering—of mind, of body, and poverty.

('6', 466, 2, 19, 909463) The poor lady wondered what it could be.
('6', 466, 2, 20, 909504) She checked up the total and politely said that there was no mistake.
('6', 466, 2, 21, 909574) The Amir shook his head and handed back the bill.
('6', 466, 2, 22, 909624) Nervously, she went over the bill again and, finding nothing wrong, requested him to point out the mistake.

('6', 467, 5, 24, 911947) Indians in Estcourt had claimed the right to vote at municipal elections, and the claim has been rejected by the Magistrate on the ground that, under the new [Natal] Municipal ACT, an Indian who does not enjoy the right to vote at political elections cannot have the municipal franchise either, that is, the rights of citizenship.
('6', 468, 0, 1, 912278) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 469

('6', 468, 1, 3, 912352) The Municipal Act has not yet been passed, and our fight against it is still going on.
('6', 468, 1, 4, 912439) It is obvious that the Magistrate at Estcourt does not read this journal, although he gets it free.
('6', 468, 1, 5, 912539) Otherwise he would not have given such a wrong judgement under an act which has not yet received the approval of the Imperial Government.
('6', 468, 1, 6, 912677) It is now essential that Estcourt Indians make an appeal.
('6', 468, 1, 7, 912735) Having considered the matter carefully, we want to say that Estcourt Indians ought not to have taken this step without the approval of the Natal Indian Congress.
('6', 468, 1, 8, 912897) This is not the time when any one section of the Indian community can act independently of the others.
('6', 468, 1, 9, 913000) There are many grievances [Indians have] in Natal.
('6', 468, 1, 10, 913051) It is imperative to put up a fight.
('6', 468, 1, 11, 913087) If in the course of this struggle, a mistake is made even in one town, it may prove detrimental to the interests of the whole community.
('6', 468, 1, 12, 913224) We believe that there was no need of such precipitate action in the matter of the municipal franchise.
('6', 468, 1, 13, 913327) Efforts are being made to have the Bill—now being discussed in Britain—disallowed.

('6', 468, 1, 19, 913840) On the other hand, there is no indignity in desisting from the exercise of a right which we have.

('6', 469, 6, 18, 915952) WHAT DOES FREE DEFENCE BY GANDHI MEAN?
('6', 469, 7, 19, 915991) There have been many inquiries in this regard.
('6', 469, 7, 20, 916038) Let me clarify the matter further.
('6', 469, 7, 21, 916073) If anyone is prosecuted under the new Act, and if t he person concerned holds a valid permit or is otherwise entitled to reside in the Transvaal, Mr. Gandhi will defend him in the court free of charge.
('6', 469, 7, 22, 916275) If the case is to be heard outside Johannesburg, the Association will pay Mr. Gandhi’s railway fare; but if the place he is required to visit has made no contribution to the British Indian Association [funds] already, the Association will collect the dues.

('6', 470, 1, 2, 916617) defence will be in respect of the permit and the Government’s refusal to issue a licence 1 when a new permit has not been taken out.

('6', 470, 1, 4, 916862) But a person who has been refused a licence for having failed to take out a new permit will be defended free of charge.
('6', 470, 1, 5, 916982) The result of it will be that the person will ultimately have to go to gaol.

('6', 471, 5, 22, 920067) This question and a few others arising from it have been raised by a correspondent.
('6', 471, 5, 23, 920151) I know that some temporary permits expire at the end of June.
('6', 471, 5, 24, 920213) My advice is that the holders of temporary permits should leave the Transvaal before the expiry of the permit period.
('6', 471, 5, 25, 920331) To the very end, it is essential to show that our struggle rests on truth alone.
('6', 471, 5, 26, 920412) Those who are in the Transvaal by right ought to defend their honour stubbornly.
('6', 471, 5, 27, 920493) I can think only of two exceptions in relation to this reply—the Imam of a mosque and the Hindu Shastri.
('6', 471, 5, 28, 920598) These two have come in for imparting religious instruction.

('6', 472, 1, 4, 921420) Holders of temporary permits do not have the rights of refugees.
('6', 472, 1, 5, 921485) They had come here for a temporary period and, at the end of it, are bound honestly to leave.

('6', 472, 1, 7, 921808) They can thus render much service to the community as and when the occasion arises.
('6', 472, 1, 8, 921892) He who wants to be of use will always have the opportunity, wherever he may be at the moment and in whatever condition.
('6', 472, 2, 9, 922012) AND OF OTHERS WHO ENTERED WITHOUT PERMITS AND OBTAINED THEM LATER Some Indians entered without permits when in the beginning they were free to do so.

('6', 472, 3, 16, 922633) “GO TO GAOL” I have received some letters containing exhortations to Indians to go to gaol.

('6', 472, 3, 18, 922765) Today we need men who are themselves prepared to go to gaol.

('6', 472, 3, 20, 922987) To those who have made this appeal my plea is that they should write and tell us what they propose to do themselves, so that their names can be published in the English and Gujarati sections of this journal.
('6', 472, 4, 21, 923195) WARNING TO HAWKERS Regulations have been framed for hawkers all over the Transvaal, of which the following is a summary: A person carrying his goods in a wagon will be treated as a hawker, one who goes about on foot will be regarded as a

('6', 473, 3, 17, 925480) TRAMWAY REGULATIONS

('6', 474, 1, 4, 926019) The Council has the authority to grant special permission to any person to travel by any tram car.
('6', 474, 1, 5, 926118) The servants accompanying white children can travel by all tram cars.
('6', 474, 1, 6, 926188) A servant is allowed to travel with his master by any tram car that the master is authorized to use.

('6', 474, 1, 9, 926427) One is that the servants of whites, however dark, can travel by the same car as their masters.

('6', 474, 1, 11, 926658) In other words, unlike dogs and black servants, a free Indian will not be free to travel by a tram car of his choice unless a special permit has been obtained by him for that purpose.

('6', 474, 1, 15, 927205) It all depends on us whether or not we continue to be treated as the youngest housewife in the village.

('6', 476, 1, 2, 929773) 395. SPEECH AT MEETING OF CHINESE1
('6', 476, 2, 3, 929808) [JOHANNESBURG May 26, 1907] THE CHINESE AS PASSIVE RESISTERS
('6', 476, 3, 4, 929869) ...On Sunday last, at the hall of the Transvaal Chinese Association, a large and representative meeting was held to consider the next step to be taken with regard to the new anti Asiatic law.
('6', 476, 3, 5, 930061) Mr. Quinn, Chairman of the Cantonese Club, presided, and the meeting was addressed by Mr. M. K. Gandhi, who had been specially invited to set forth the position.
('6', 476, 3, 6, 930223) This he did, briefly and succinctly, pointing out that...the new law did not add to the security of those Asiatics [who were] rightly in the Transvaal, as had been so often alleged by the anti Asiatic party and echoed by the uninformed general public, but really took away all their existing personal liberty, guaranteed under solemn Imperial pledges, substituting a restricted liberty, which no self respecting subject of a civilized country could possibly accept...the only dignified defence of their rights that the Asiatics in the Transvaal could make was to ignore the compulsory clauses entailing re registration, and submit themselves to the extreme penalty of the law, namely, liability to imprisonment; as also to boycott the Permit Office....
('6', 476, 4, 7, 930976) Indian Opinion, 1 6 1907
('6', 476, 5, 8, 931001) 396. LETTER TO “THE STAR”
('6', 476, 6, 9, 931027) JOHANNESBURG, May 30, 1907 [TO THE EDITOR THE STAR JOHANNESBURG]
('6', 476, 7, 10, 931092) SIR, The arrival of General Botha and the fact that the Asiatic Registration Act, though it has received the Royal sanction, is still the subject matter of correspondence between the Imperial Government
('6', 476, 8, 11, 931295) 1 This is extracted from “Johannesburg Jottings”, which H. S. L. Polak, “Our Johannesburg Correspondent”, contributed as a regular feature for Indian Opinion.
('6', 476, 8, 12, 931454) 2 The Chinese had pledged their support to the Fourth Resolution of the Indian mass meeting of September, 1906 and to the Second Resolution of the mass meeting of April, 1907 and also announced their intention of going to gaol if the Transvaal Asiatic Registration Act was enforced.
('6', 476, 8, 13, 931737) Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 27 4 1907.
('6', 477, 0, 1, 931776) 478 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 477, 1, 2, 931818) and the local Government, encourage me to appeal once more to your good sense and, through you, to that of the colonists.
('6', 477, 1, 3, 931940) Now that the anti Asiatic party has obtained what it wanted, is it impossible to arrive at a reasonable compromise and to save British Indians from being considered untrustworthy and feloniously inclined?
('6', 477, 1, 4, 932145) the Act is not yet gazetted, and it need not be until the Government wishes to do so.
('6', 477, 1, 5, 932231) I, therefore, suggest that, before it is gazetted, a form for new permits may be mutually agreed upon, and, in accordance with it, Indians and other Asiatics may be registered afresh in exchange for proper documents they may possess.
('6', 477, 1, 6, 932465) If, then, all Asiatics thus voluntarily surrender their documents, there can be no occasion for submitting them to the degradation contemplated by the Act.
('6', 477, 1, 7, 932621) If, however, there are Asiatics in the Colony who do not surrender their documents, the Act can be immediately gazetted, and be made applicable, by a short Bill, to them.
('6', 477, 1, 8, 932792) Thus, those who are bona fide holders of permits and are honest will be automatically separated from those who are guilty.
('6', 477, 1, 9, 932915) I do not know whether you can see any flaw in this proposal, unless you think that the object of the legislation is not that illicit traffic in permits may be stopped, but that it is to, openly and boldly, put an unwarranted affront upon British Indians and other Asiatics.
('6', 477, 1, 10, 933189) Let me remind you, before any such declaration is made, of Lord Ampthill's remarks:
('6', 477, 2, 11, 933273) This is not a matter which only touches our honour.
('6', 477, 2, 12, 933325) We are pledged to our fellow citizens in India—pledged by the solemn declaration of the Sovereign, by the pronouncements of our statesmen, and by all that is implied in the whole method of our administration of that great dominion—to treat the people of India as fellow citizens in every sense of the word.
('6', 477, 2, 13, 933632) We invite them to be proud of their citizenship of the Empire.
('6', 477, 2, 14, 933695) We tell them, again and again, that there is nothing to prevent their rising to the same positions as are held by Englishmen in India, and we imply, in all that we do for them and say to them, that, whenever they are under the British flag in any part of the world, they will be treated as British citizens.
('6', 477, 2, 15, 934003) Lord Lansdowne feels so keenly the humiliation in which British statesmen are placed by this Act that he questions whether to wound the susceptibilities of the whole Indian nation is not more injurious and imprudent than to allow the surreptitious entry of a few Indians into the country.
('6', 477, 2, 16, 934292) But the proposal I have ventured to sketch above is just as effective against surreptitious: entry as may be by [sic] the Asiatic Act.
('6', 477, 2, 17, 934427) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI Indian Opinion, 8 6 1907
('6', 478, 0, 1, 934477) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 479
('6', 478, 1, 2, 934520) 397. JURIES ON TRIAL
('6', 478, 2, 3, 934541) Ever since the birth of this journal, it has studiously restricted itself to questions affecting Indians in South Africa.
('6', 478, 2, 4, 934663) We consider that, however desirable other questions may be from a journalistic stand point, we must recognize our own limitations and not enter into questions of high policy, or questions that do not directly affect Indians in this country.
('6', 478, 2, 5, 934904) But there are exceptions to every rule.
('6', 478, 2, 6, 934944) We feel we should be false to our profession, if we did not deal with the now celebrated Mtonga case 1, which has attracted so much attention.
('6', 478, 2, 7, 935087) It rises from the platform of Native policy to that of humanity and, to a certain extent, the principle underlying it is applicable to Indians also.
('6', 478, 2, 8, 935236) We, therefore, gladly make room for an extract from the extremely well reasoned and humane leading article from the columns of The Natal Mercury.
('6', 478, 2, 9, 935382) It constitutes an indictment of the jury system in particular when applicable to trials between whites and blacks.
('6', 478, 2, 10, 935497) We join with our contemporary in its repudiation of the charge of the special ill treatment of Natives levelled against Natal in some quarters and based on the abortion of justice in the Mtonga case.
('6', 478, 2, 11, 935697) We believe that what happened in Natal is likely to happen, under similar circumsta nces, in any part of South Africa, or in any country conditioned as South Africa is.
('6', 478, 2, 12, 935866) Natal, no more than any other country, can claim a monopoly of jurymen fired with passion and prejudice, but the fact that instances like the Mtonga case happen in South Africa must waken the public conscience, and make those who are jealous of the reputation of South Africa seriously consider whether the time has not arrived to revise our ideas about the jury system.
('6', 478, 2, 13, 936237) In a place like South Africa, where there is no leisured class and where people of all nationalities congregate, the jury system is about the worst that could be devised in connection with the administration of justice.
('6', 478, 2, 14, 936457) The inherent condition of success of trial by jury is that the accused is tried by his equals.
('6', 478, 2, 15, 936552) It is an insult to man’s intelligence to contend that
('6', 478, 3, 16, 936606) 1 Mtonga, an African, was assaulted by certain persons on suspicion of having committed an offence.
('6', 478, 3, 17, 936706) Tried later, he was fount guilty by the jury; but the Governor, convinced of his innocence, reprieved him.
('6', 479, 0, 1, 936813) 480 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 479, 1, 2, 936855) there is any such trial in South Africa, when the question is as between whites and blacks.
('6', 479, 1, 3, 936947) When passions are roused, men who are not trained to examine facts and apply a well balanced mind to the matters before them cannot possibly arrive at a just conclusion.
('6', 479, 1, 4, 937117) Even in a well settled and old place like Liverpool, possessing a homogeneous population with traditions to go by, it required a judge of the calibre of the late Justice Stephen to secure a verdict at the trial of Mrs. Haybrick.
('6', 479, 1, 5, 937346) How is it possible, then, to get any satisfaction out of jurymen in a place like South Africa, where different nationalities are still in the melting pot, and a South African nation has yet to rise in the dim and distant future?
('6', 479, 1, 6, 937575) We are no worshippers of the idol of equality, when there is no foundation for it.
('6', 479, 1, 7, 937658) It is possible that any attempt to abolish the jury system, in cases where there are whites and blacks concerned, will be met by the cry of false equality.
('6', 479, 1, 8, 937814) We hold that any Native or Coloured man who takes up a position of that description does not know real equality.
('6', 479, 1, 9, 937927) All that can reasonably be claimed, today, by or for them is equality in the eye of the law.
('6', 479, 1, 10, 938020) White people from different parts of Europe, who come to South Africa with no notion of Imperialism, cannot be expected either to think of Imperial obligations or other notions of justice and equal rights as between themselves and others whom they hold to be inferior, save from the dictates of whatever humanity there may be in them.
('6', 479, 2, 11, 938355) We hope, therefore, that no Coloured man or Asiatic, because our argument applies equally to Asiatics as to other Coloured people, will think of opposing the movement that the Natal Press has, from purely disinterested and just motives, inaugurated for the abolition of trial by jury in cases where there are European and Coloured people concerned.
('6', 479, 2, 12, 938704) It would, indeed, be the best thing if trial by jury were abolished altogether, but it is such a time honoured superstition that one can hardly expect public opinion to reject it altogether, nor will it be possible to make out a strong case against the institution so far as it may apply to whites only.
('6', 479, 2, 13, 939008) We believe that, if the matter is left where the Press has left it, no result will be achieved.
('6', 479, 2, 14, 939104) The churches in South Africa are rightly supposed to be the custodians of the interests, we will not call them the rights, of the Natives in South Africa, and, though the immediate question has arisen in Natal, we feel that there should be among the
('6', 480, 0, 1, 939354) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 481
('6', 480, 1, 2, 939397) churches a simultaneous movement and a petition to the respective South African Governments for the complete abolition of trial by jury in cases as between white and Coloured men.
('6', 480, 1, 3, 939577) We think, also, that such a movement on the part of the churches should be very widely supported by the Natives and the Coloured communities of South Africa.
('6', 480, 2, 4, 939735) Indian Opinion, 1 6 1907

('6', 483, 3, 20, 946792) Afghanistan has grown strong.
('6', 483, 3, 21, 946822) And now India.

('6', 483, 3, 24, 946989) In the Punjab, a Muslim has started a paper named Hindu Muslim, and he urges the two communities to become united.
('6', 483, 3, 25, 947104) From the other side, agitation is being carried on by papers like Bande Mataram for ending British rule.

('6', 485, 3, 14, 950998) 401. INDIAN PRINCES
('6', 485, 4, 15, 951018) His Majesty the late Amir Abdur Rahman 1 has said:
('6', 485, 5, 16, 951069) During my visit I saw one sorry sight which affected my mind very much.
('6', 485, 5, 17, 951141) The dress of the poor Indian princes resembled that of women.
('6', 485, 5, 18, 951203) They had diamond pins in their hair, pendants in their ears, bands on their wrists, gold chains round their necks, and other ornaments such as women wear.
('6', 485, 5, 19, 951358) Their trouserbelts were studded with jewels and the pendants, hanging from their waistribbons, almost reached their feet.
('6', 485, 5, 20, 951480) Theyallowed in ignorance, indolence and luxury.
('6', 485, 5, 21, 951528) They little knew what was happening in the world or what it contained.
('6', 485, 5, 22, 951599) They passed their time in consuming wine and opium.
('6', 485, 5, 23, 951651) They believed that their status would be lowered if they went on foot.
('6', 485, 6, 24, 951722) This is, for the most part, a true picture.
('6', 485, 6, 25, 951766) It can be said that there
('6', 485, 7, 26, 951792) 1 (1844 1901), King of Afghanistan, 1881 1901.
('6', 486, 0, 1, 951839) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 487
('6', 486, 1, 2, 951882) are Indian princes who do not live in this manner.
('6', 486, 1, 3, 951933) But we are not concerned with them at the moment.
('6', 486, 1, 4, 951983) The fact is that the state of affairs described above is one powerful cause of our miserable plight.
('6', 486, 1, 5, 952084) It is not only the princes that live in such a base manner.
('6', 486, 1, 6, 952144) Among the people also this state of things is seen often enough.
('6', 486, 1, 7, 952209) Our comment mainly refers to the Hindus in India.
('6', 486, 1, 8, 952259) The so called big men and their children are mostly recognized by the marks vividly described by the late Amir.
('6', 486, 1, 9, 952371) Luxuries, ornaments, garments of silk or brocade—these are seen to be quite common with them.
('6', 486, 1, 10, 952465) If the so called modern people do not wear ornaments, etc., they satisfy their desire in other ways.
('6', 486, 1, 11, 952566) It is no use blaming any one section for this.
('6', 486, 1, 12, 952613) Customs coming down from ancient times die hard.
('6', 486, 1, 13, 952662) But we Indians in South Africa have to learn the lesson that all of us, big or small, should free ourselves from these faults.
('6', 486, 1, 14, 952789) The condition of our country and of ourselves is so unsatisfactory that, at present, we are in a state of continuous mourning.
('6', 486, 1, 15, 952916) How can we enjoy comfort or pleasure, when every week thousands of our countrymen die of plague or starvation?
('6', 486, 1, 16, 953027) We are convinced that it is necessary for every Indian to colour his mind with the yellow of a monk’s robe.
('6', 486, 1, 17, 953135) His outfit should display none of the evils of jewellery, silk, gold, etc.
('6', 486, 2, 18, 953210) KING OF ENGLAND
('6', 486, 3, 19, 953226) Our London Letter in this issue lends weighty support to what we have said above.
('6', 486, 3, 20, 953308) King Emperor Edward’s grandson is 13 years old today.
('6', 486, 3, 21, 953362) From now on he is being made to go through a rigorous training.
('6', 486, 3, 22, 953426) The Prince is required to study at school with other boys and he will be served the same simple food that the others get.
('6', 486, 3, 23, 953548) A people ruled over by such a King does what the King does.
('6', 486, 3, 24, 953608) Is it any wonder that such a people are prosperous?
('6', 486, 3, 25, 953660) We are not to envy them, but to become like them.
('6', 486, 3, 26, 953710) Let it not be argued that they, too, have their pleasures and luxuries.
('6', 486, 3, 27, 953782) Such a thought bespeaks indolence.
('6', 486, 3, 28, 953817) They enjoy themselves after their work is done, and their luxuries become them well enough.
('6', 486, 3, 29, 953909) Even so, we are not to imitate their weakness for a life of pleasure and comfort.

('6', 487, 1, 2, 954204) 402. JOHANNESBURG LETTER 1
('6', 487, 2, 3, 954231) NEW LAW: MORE QUESTIONS
('6', 487, 3, 4, 954255) Questions about this law are still coming in.
('6', 487, 3, 5, 954301) I am glad of it, and all questions so received will be dealt with in this journal.
('6', 487, 4, 6, 954384) WHAT SHOULD BE DONE BY THOSE HOLDING DUTCH REGISTERS?
('6', 487, 5, 7, 954438) According to the notice in the Gazette, an Indian has made an application to the Permit Office on the basis of his register 2. In that connection, Mr. Mahomed Daoji Patel from Wakkerstroom makes the following enquiries: (1) Can it be taken as a certainty that the application will be accepted by the Permit Office?
('6', 487, 5, 8, 954753) (2) If it is accepted, should the applicant withdraw it, since it violates the Fourth Resolution?
('6', 487, 5, 9, 954851) (3) In case the application is withdrawn, will the police arrest him?
('6', 487, 5, 10, 954921) (4) If he is arrested and the magistrate orders him to leave the Transvaal, what is he to do?
('6', 487, 5, 11, 955015) (5) If on his acting thus a case is instituted against him, will Mr. Gandhi come here to defend him?
('6', 487, 5, 12, 955116) The answers are: Neither this man nor anyone else in his situation need withdraw the application so long as the new law has not been gazetted.
('6', 487, 5, 13, 955259) And it is also unnecessary now to proceed in the matter of the said application.
('6', 487, 5, 14, 955340) The application will have to be withdrawn as soon as the new law is gazetted.
('6', 487, 5, 15, 955418) If the matter comes up before the magistrate, the said applicant or others in his position who a rightful holders of registers will be defended by Mr. Gandhi.
('6', 487, 5, 16, 955577) As for the nature of the defence, please refer to earlier news letters.
('6', 487, 5, 17, 955649) The boycott of the Permit Office means that henceforth we shall have nothing to do with that Office.
('6', 487, 5, 18, 955750) The cases of the Transvaal residents that may be pending in that Office need not be withdrawn.
('6', 487, 5, 19, 955845) That step is to be taken immediately after the law is gazetted.
('6', 487, 6, 20, 955909) 1 Literally, the tide reads “News Letter”.
('6', 487, 6, 21, 955952) These despatches were published weekly in lndian Opinion as “From Our Johannesburg Representative”.
('6', 487, 6, 22, 956052) The first despatch appeared on March 3, 1906; vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 26 2 1906.
('6', 487, 7, 23, 956137) 2 In Gujarati, registration certificate has been referred to as “register”.
('6', 488, 0, 1, 956213) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 489
('6', 488, 1, 2, 956256) WHAT IF MR. GANDHI IS SENT TO GAOL FIRST?
('6', 488, 2, 3, 956298) A correspondent asks what is to be done for defence if Mr. Gandhi is imprisoned first.
('6', 488, 2, 4, 956385) It is a relevant question.
('6', 488, 2, 5, 956412) But one mustknow what the defence by Mr. Gandhi is going to be.
('6', 488, 2, 6, 956476) The defence will only state that it was upon his advice that people had taken the firm decision to go to gaol, and that he (Mr. Gandhi), therefore, deserved to be sentenced first.
('6', 488, 2, 7, 956656) If such a defence by him is rendered unnecessary and he is straight away taken to gaol first, the defence would have already been made.
('6', 488, 2, 8, 956792) The main aim of Mr. Gandhi’s presence is to keep up the courage of the accused.
('6', 488, 2, 9, 956872) People will have nothing to fear if, fortunately for the community and for Mr. Gandhi, he is sent to gaol first.
('6', 488, 2, 10, 956985) Even while in gaol, Mr. Gandhi can put up a defence, that is, he can pray to God to give courage to all Indians.
('6', 488, 2, 11, 957098) At this stage, I should also add that it is mainly because the new law is humiliating that all Indians accept the gaol resolution.
('6', 488, 2, 12, 957229) Thus, the only conclusion is that every Indian must maintain his self respect.
('6', 488, 3, 13, 957308) WHERE ARE FUNDS TO SUPPORT WOMEN AND CHILDREN?
('6', 488, 4, 14, 957355) The person raising this question asks how maintenance can be provided when the Association’s funds are meagre.
('6', 488, 4, 15, 957466) The law has not yet been gazetted.
('6', 488, 4, 16, 957501) As soon as it is, leaders will visit every place to explain matters to the people and raise contributions.
('6', 488, 4, 17, 957608) Moreover, leaders in Natal and East London have already communicated their willingness to help.
('6', 488, 4, 18, 957704) It has also been arranged that if Mr. Gandhi should be imprisoned, Mr. Polak, the editor of Indian Opinion, will go from place to place collecting funds, encouraging people and explaining the position to them.
('6', 488, 4, 19, 957914) Some whites also have indicated their willingness to help.
('6', 488, 5, 20, 957973) GERMISTON LOCATION

('6', 488, 6, 22, 958085) In this connection, the British Indian Association had addressed a letter to the local Government and to this a reply has been received stating that such passes would not be issued in future.
('6', 488, 6, 23, 958277) Those living in the Locations may, therefore, get their passes framed and keep them as exhibits.
('6', 488, 6, 24, 958374) If they are asked again to take out

('6', 489, 2, 3, 958666) STRIKE OF MINE LABOURERS We have been talking of boycotting the Permit Office and going to gaol.
('6', 489, 2, 4, 958763) The white labourers in the mines have struck work with a view to getting higher wages.
('6', 489, 2, 5, 958850) The result was that in about ten mines work came to a standstill.
('6', 489, 2, 6, 958916) Everyone knows that these miners live from hand to mouth.
('6', 489, 2, 7, 958974) Some of them are married.
('6', 489, 2, 8, 959000) For the sake of their rights, they have walked out of the mines, giving up their present income, without bothering about their families and their means of livelihood.
('6', 489, 2, 9, 959167) There is no question of their self respect having been wounded.
('6', 489, 2, 10, 959231) Yet, for the sake of what they believe to be their right, they have girded up theirloins against the authorities and the fabulously rich mine owners.
('6', 489, 2, 11, 959381) Whether their demands are reasonable or not need not be considered just now.
('6', 489, 2, 12, 959458) On this occasion, it is their spirit and their daring that we are to think of and emulate.
('6', 489, 3, 13, 959549) ENCOURAGEMENT PROM EAST LONDON AND KIMBERLEY’S WRONG VIEW The President of the Association has received a letter of sympathy from the Indians of East London.
('6', 489, 3, 14, 959707) Mr. A. G. Ismail hopes that all Indians will remain firm in disobeying the law and will go to gaol.
('6', 489, 3, 15, 959807) He also says that help will be sent from there.
('6', 489, 3, 16, 959855) On the other hand, there is a telegram from Kimberley expressing sympathy but asking the Indian community to think well before taking the step of going to gaol.
('6', 489, 3, 17, 960016) This is a wrong view.
('6', 489, 3, 18, 960038) The Indian community believes in God, and will not trifle with Him.
('6', 489, 3, 19, 960106) Moreover, it was after mature deliberation that the gaol resolution was passed in September.
('6', 489, 3, 20, 960199) It is the duty of every Indian, therefore, to give us, residents of the Transvaal, full encouragement and to pray to God to sustain our courage at the time of our real test.
('6', 489, 4, 21, 960373) INDIANS IN GERMAN EAST AFRICA
('6', 489, 5, 22, 960403) The Star correspondent in England states in a cable that, at a meeting of the German Colonial Society in Germany, some members said that Indian merchants in German East Africa harmed the interests of small European traders.
('6', 489, 5, 23, 960627) The Indians cheated the Kaffirs.
('6', 489, 5, 24, 960660) It was they who incited the rebellion.
('6', 489, 5, 25, 960699) Therefore, laws like those enacted against them in South Africa should be enacted in German East Africa, too.
('6', 489, 5, 26, 960809) The Society’s committee has reported that, though it was
('6', 490, 0, 1, 960866) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 491
('6', 490, 1, 2, 960909) possible to level some charges against the Indian traders, their presence in the land had on the whole proved to be an advantage.
('6', 490, 1, 3, 961039) It was likely that any attempt to make a law for deporting them would lead to complications with England.
('6', 490, 1, 4, 961145) Some other members who were acquainted with the situation prevailing in the Colony defended the Indian traders.
('6', 490, 2, 5, 961257) PENALTY FOR GIVING FALSE EVIDENCE
('6', 490, 3, 6, 961291) A washerman named Ponnusami was put up before Sir William Smith for giving false evidence.
('6', 490, 3, 7, 961382) Ponnusami had made unfounded allegations against other Indians who, he knew, were innocent.
('6', 490, 3, 8, 961474) The jury found Ponnusami guilty.
('6', 490, 3, 9, 961507) The judge sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for 18 months.
('6', 490, 3, 10, 961571) Those Indians who are not afraid of giving false evidence should take a warning from this case.
('6', 490, 4, 11, 961667) MOVEMENT TO CLOSE SHOPS AT FIXED HOUR
('6', 490, 5, 12, 961705) A proposal for the closing of shops at a fixed hour was discussed in the Johannesburg Town Council on the 22nd [May].
('6', 490, 5, 13, 961823) Owing to the many divergent views expressed at the meeting, the members could not agree on a solution.
('6', 490, 5, 14, 961926) They therefore decided thatthe whole matter should go to the Parliament for decision.
('6', 490, 5, 15, 962012) The Council’s proposal was also forwarded to the Parliament at the same time.
('6', 490, 5, 16, 962090) The proposal provides in effect that ordinarily shops should close at 6 p.m., on Wednesdays at I p.m.
('6', 490, 5, 17, 962192) and on Saturdays at .9 p.m.
('6', 490, 5, 18, 962220) On holidays they should remain closed altogether.
('6', 490, 5, 19, 962270) When shops are closed, the hawkers too should stop going on their rounds.
('6', 490, 5, 20, 962344) The law to this effect has not yet been passed, but one may take it that it is about to be.
('6', 490, 5, 21, 962436) The Indian who concedes the need for early closure of shops and acts accordingly of his own free will, will find himself at an advantage over others.
('6', 490, 6, 22, 962586) LAND TAX IN JOHANNESBURG
('6', 490, 7, 23, 962611) The tax on land is fixed this time at a penny and a quarter per £100. The tax will be calculated for the period from January 1, 1907 to June 30, 1907, and will be due on June 24, 1907. Those who fail to pay it by that date will have to pay interest at the monthly rate of one pound per £100.

('6', 491, 1, 2, 962945) CHINESE MEETING AND GAOL RESOLUTION
('6', 491, 2, 3, 962981) Last Sunday a meeting of the Chinese Association was held in its hall.
('6', 491, 2, 4, 963052) About 300 Chinese, mostly merchants, were present.
('6', 491, 2, 5, 963103) Mr. M. Quinn took the chair.
('6', 491, 2, 6, 963132) Mr. Gandhi also attended by invitation.
('6', 491, 3, 7, 963172) Explaining the position, he said that the Chinese and the Indians had been classed together under the new law.
('6', 491, 3, 8, 963283) The law humiliated the Asiatics and it should not therefore be accepted by the Chinese.
('6', 491, 3, 9, 963371) The various questions that are answered in this letter were all raised and answered at the meeting.
('6', 491, 3, 10, 963471) In the end, it was decided that every Chinese should declare on oath, in accordance with his religion, that in no case would he take out a new permit and that, if necessary, he would be prepared to face imprisonment.
('6', 491, 4, 11, 963688) PERMIT CASE
('6', 491, 5, 12, 963700) A permit case has been going on for some days past against an Indian named Lala.
('6', 491, 5, 13, 963781) It came up for hearing on the 27th before Mr. Wenderburg.
('6', 491, 5, 14, 963839) Superintendent Vernon deposed as follows:
('6', 491, 6, 15, 963881) I have the power to ask for permits from people.
('6', 491, 6, 16, 963930) It is also my duty to investigate the rights of people who want to enter with permits.
('6', 491, 6, 17, 964017) On April 20, I saw Lala near my office, and he said to me, “I wish to work with you.
('6', 491, 6, 18, 964102) Many men desire to take out permits.
('6', 491, 6, 19, 964139) If you supply me information about them, both of us will make much money.
('6', 491, 6, 20, 964213) I shall charge everyone £20 of which I shall give you £8. There are many Indians and Chinese here with false permits.
('6', 491, 6, 21, 964331) If you get their permits set right, I shall pay you £20. Here is a permit; put yourinitials on it and pass it.
('6', 491, 6, 22, 964442) That way you will earn £400 a month, and I £200. Mr. Harris too will get £200. My information is that irregular forms are current in Johannesburg and that many Indians are without permits.” Then I asked him to come again the following day.
('6', 491, 6, 23, 964682) He did come, and after some talk with him, I rang the bell and got him arrested.
('6', 491, 6, 24, 964763) As he was being taken to the Charge Office, Lala said, “Sir, you have missed a golden opportunity of making money.”
('6', 491, 7, 25, 964879) Constable Harris also deposed as above.
('6', 491, 7, 26, 964919) Mr. Chamney 2, giving evidence,.

('6', 492, 4, 23, 966660) 403. SERVANTS OF INDIA
('6', 492, 5, 24, 966683) An Indian savant has written in The Indian Sociologist proposing the establishment of a society of servants of India.
('6', 492, 5, 25, 966801) We give here a summary of what he has said.
('6', 492, 5, 26, 966845) That India should become united and independent is an idea that many Indians now understand and cherish.
('6', 492, 5, 27, 966950) But the moral energy needed to achieve this aim is wanting.
('6', 492, 5, 28, 967010) Those who would serve their country should first realize that one’s life is not to be spent in pampering oneself with easy living, but that it is to be used in doing
('6', 492, 6, 29, 967176) Letter”, 26 6 1907.
('6', 493, 0, 1, 967196) 494 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 493, 1, 2, 967238) one’s duty.
('6', 493, 1, 3, 967250) The population of India comprises one fifth of the world’s population.
('6', 493, 1, 4, 967321) The task of promoting its uplift belongs to “the servants of India”.
('6', 493, 1, 5, 967390) These servants are the trustees of the Indian people.
('6', 493, 1, 6, 967444) They should give up the desire for wealth, status and physical comforts, and dedicate their lives to India.
('6', 493, 1, 7, 967552) Fear of every kind must be overcome.
('6', 493, 1, 8, 967589) Such service should be regarded as part of one’s religion.
('6', 493, 1, 9, 967648) Men of such patriotism will be able to imbue the people with enthusiasm by their actions rather than by their words.
('6', 493, 1, 10, 967765) Besides ardour, knowledge and wisdom will also be required.
('6', 493, 1, 11, 967825) Hence “the Servants of India” should know the history of India.
('6', 493, 1, 12, 967889) They should understand what India needs now.
('6', 493, 1, 13, 967934) They should also study the history of other countries.
('6', 493, 1, 14, 967989) This enthusiasm and knowledge cannot remain fresh for long in a man burdened with the responsibilities of a family.
('6', 493, 1, 15, 968105) A true servant will need to observe total celibacy.
('6', 493, 1, 16, 968157) Those who are married but wish to render service to the country can train the members of their families to take up the same kind of work.
('6', 493, 1, 17, 968295) Indian women are ignorant.
('6', 493, 1, 18, 968322) It is very necessary to awaken patriotism in them.
('6', 493, 1, 19, 968373) But those, who are not married and wish to render service as explained above will find it best not to marry.
('6', 493, 1, 20, 968482) The great patriot Mazzini 1 used to say that it was to his country that he was married.
('6', 493, 1, 21, 968570) In conclusion, he who wants to be a servant of the people needs faith.
('6', 493, 1, 22, 968641) He should not worry as to where he would get his next meal from.
('6', 493, 1, 23, 968706) God will provide for all His creatures.

('6', 495, 1, 2, 970565) the practice of the Licensing Officers in discriminating between Indian applicants and others to the disadvantage of the former is reprehensible and unjust, especially when it is a matter of existing trade rights.
('6', 495, 1, 3, 970779) Mr. Robinson also thinks that, if the Colony wishes to deal with the Indian question, it should do so in a straightforward, bold and honest manner.
('6', 495, 1, 4, 970927) We congratulate him on having ranged himself so honourably on the side of justice and equity.
('6', 495, 1, 5, 971021) If all our legislators would adopt the same bold attitude, the Colony would soon rid itself of a great deal of cant and hypocrisy.
('6', 495, 2, 6, 971152) Indian Opinion, 8 6 1907
('6', 495, 3, 7, 971177) 407. THE CAPE IMMIGRATION ACT
('6', 495, 4, 8, 971207) We draw attention to the gruesome story a correspondent from Mafeking tells about the working of the Cape Immigration Restriction Act.
('6', 495, 4, 9, 971342) According to our correspondent, Indians who have returned to India, leaving their businesses ten years old and having landed property at the Cape, find it difficult to return if they are not in possession of certificates of domicile taken out by them prior to their departure, and that, similarly, Indians having been resident for a number of years find it difficult to obtain such certificates, on leaving.
('6', 495, 4, 10, 971750) He adds that when they are issued, they are tenable only for one year, so that if an Indian returns to his adopted home in the Colony of the Cape of Good Hope a day later than the period given in thecertificate, he would be a prohibited immigrant.
('6', 495, 4, 11, 971998) A system such as this can only be described as a deliberate and cruel attempt to drive Indians out of the Cape without having to pay them any compensation whatsoever.
('6', 495, 4, 12, 972165) The remedy is largely in the hands of the Cape Indians, and we warn the various associations there that they will be responsible to the community should the threatened disaster befall British Indians, and should they, five years hence, find that there are very few Indians to be found at the Cape.
('6', 495, 4, 13, 972463) We would advise our correspondent to contin ually address the Indian associations at Cape Town until they are roused to action from their apparent lethargy.
('6', 495, 5, 14, 972620) Indian Opinion, 8 6 1907
('6', 496, 0, 1, 972645) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 497
('6', 496, 1, 2, 972688) 408. THE ASIATIC REGISTRATION ACT 1
('6', 496, 2, 3, 972724) A TERRIBLE CONTRAST
('6', 496, 3, 4, 972744) Whilst Indians are showing their firm determination not to submit to the Asiatic Registration Act, it is as well to understand their objection to it.
('6', 496, 3, 5, 972894) I, therefore, propose to show in parallel columns the state that they are in now and that in which they would be under the new law.
('6', 496, 4, 6, 973026) NOW UNDER THE NEW LAW
('6', 496, 5, 7, 973048) 1. Malays are subject to Law 3 of 1885. 1. They are exempted from the new law.
('6', 496, 5, 8, 973127) Many Indians have Malay wives and relatives.
('6', 496, 5, 9, 973172) The position of such Indians when they meet their Malay relatives can be better imagined than described.
('6', 496, 5, 10, 973277) 2. Every Asiatic in posse ssion of a permit bona fide obtained is a full fledged and lawful resident of the Transvaal.
('6', 496, 6, 11, 973396) 2. He becomes dispossessed of this title and the burden of showing that the permit lawfully held by him was not fraudulently obtained is thrown on him to entitle him to receive the new registration certificate.
('6', 496, 6, 12, 973607) 3. An Asiatic child born since the 31st day of May, 1902 in the Orange River Colony, is entitled to enter and remain in the Transvaal.
('6', 496, 7, 13, 973742) 3. Such child is debarred.
('6', 496, 8, 14, 973769) 4. Present permits held by Asiatics entitle them to enter and reside in the Transvaal and Orange River Colony.
('6', 496, 8, 15, 973880) Whether these are of any use for going into the Orange River Colony is not the question.
('6', 496, 9, 16, 973969) 4. This right, so far as the permit can give it, is taken away.
('6', 496, 10, 17, 974033) 5. Asiatics holding permits 5. These are not allowed.
('6', 496, 11, 18, 974087) 1 This appeared as “Specially Contributed”.
('6', 496, 11, 19, 974131) For the text of the Act as it was finally passed, vide Appendix V.
('6', 497, 0, 1, 974198) 498 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 497, 1, 2, 974240) to reside in the Orange River Colony are in a position to enter the Transvaal on the strength thereof.
('6', 497, 1, 3, 974343) 6. Present permits cannot be changed without the consent of the holders.
('6', 497, 2, 4, 974416) 6. They are subject to altera tion at the will of the Government.
('6', 497, 3, 5, 974482) 7. Asiatic children are not required to take out permits.
('6', 497, 3, 6, 974540) 7. The guardian of such child is bound, under heavy penalty, to have particulars of identification of: such child, no matter how young, endorsed on his registration.
('6', 497, 3, 7, 974706) When the child reaches the age of 8 years, the guardian is bound to again app roach the Registrar and take out registration for such child, furnishing further particulars as to identification, etc.
('6', 497, 4, 8, 974904) 8. Minors who are at present in the Transvaal are entitled to remain without a permit, and are not liable to leave the country on attaining majority.
('6', 497, 5, 9, 975054) 8. All such boys on reaching the age of 16 are liable to be deported unless they obtain from the Registrar registration certificates, the granting of which is at his discretion.
('6', 497, 5, 10, 975232) 9. No Asiatic is bound to furnish particulars of identification
('6', 497, 6, 11, 975296) 9. Even a Kafir policeman may demand production of certificate and particulars of identi fication, which may be fixed by regulation from time to tirne.
('6', 497, 6, 12, 975448) Such policeman may, notwithstanding, take the Asiatic to the nearest police station, where the same inquiry may be repeated, and, if the Officer at the station is not satisfied, he may detain the Asiatic in the cell overnight.
('6', 497, 6, 13, 975675) 10. An Asiatic can 10. No Asiatic may receive
('6', 498, 0, 1, 975721) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 499
('6', 498, 1, 2, 975764) demand a trade licence as a right against payment without production of permit.
('6', 498, 2, 3, 975844) such licence unless he produces his registration certificate and furnishes means of identification, as may be prescribed by regulation.
('6', 498, 2, 4, 975980) If, there fore, there are partners in any Asiatic firm, the Licensing Officer may insist upon the presence of all the parties and submit them to a humiliating examination before giving them their licence.
('6', 498, 2, 5, 976185) 11. Any Asiatic is free to employ any other Asiatic.
('6', 498, 2, 6, 976238) 11. Any Asiatic who brings into the Colony an Asiatic under the age of 16 (even his son!) without a permit for him, or who employs such child, is liable to be heavily fined or sent to gaol, and to have his own right to reside in the Transvaal cancelled.
('6', 498, 2, 7, 976492) 12. The Registrar, at pre sent, has fairly strong authority.
('6', 498, 2, 8, 976553) 12. The Registrar practically becomes the master of Asiatics with almost unlimited power over their personal liberty.
('6', 498, 2, 9, 976671) 13. Asiatics who come in possession of certificates belonging to others commit no crime.
('6', 498, 3, 10, 976760) 13. Asiatics having such certificates (evidently a father having his son’s register) are bound to deliver same by post under pain of being fined £50 or, in default, sent to gaol.
('6', 498, 4, 11, 976939) ADDITIONAL POINTS TO BE NOTED
('6', 498, 5, 12, 976969) The new law does not apply to Kaffirs, to Cape Boys, and Christian subjects of the Turkish Empire, whereas it applies to the Mahomedan subjects of that Empire, and it thus insults Indians and their religion in a cold blooded manner.
('6', 498, 5, 13, 977202) It reduces them to a state of serfdom although belonging to civilized countries.
('6', 498, 5, 14, 977283) It reduces them to a position lower than that of the Kaffirs, Cape Boys and Malays.
('6', 498, 5, 15, 977367) 2. It puts a premium on fraud.
('6', 498, 5, 16, 977398) It might have occurred to the framers of the law that there is nothing to prevent an Asiatic
('6', 499, 0, 1, 977491) 500 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 499, 1, 2, 977533) impersonating a Malay or Cape Boy.
('6', 499, 1, 3, 977568) 3. It opens up a fertile field for permit agents to prey upon harmless Asiatics.
('6', 499, 1, 4, 977649) It must be well known to the Permit authorities that Asiatics are not, as a rule, capable of filling in complicated applicationforms, being ignorant of the ways of Government departments and easily terrorized.
('6', 499, 1, 5, 977859) At the very least, therefore, assuming that Indians and Chinese combined would make 12,000 applicants, they would be robbed of £36,000, counting the fee at £3 per head on an average.
('6', 499, 1, 6, 978042) Who, then, can wonder if Asiatics prefer gaol to submission to such an extraordinary law and to such extortion?
('6', 499, 1, 7, 978154) Verily, the whole of the Transvaal would to them become, during their residence therein, a wretched gaol.
('6', 499, 1, 8, 978260) It does, indeed, need the intoxication of power to blind one to the wretched state of misery to which the new law reduces Asiatics.
('6', 499, 1, 9, 978392) Indian Opinion, 8 6 1907
('6', 499, 2, 10, 978417) 409. NEW OBNOXIOUS LAW
('6', 499, 3, 11, 978440) Futile is strength devoid of courage, Doomed is a house divided; Naught is wealth without knowledge, And evil the use of learning by the wicked.
('6', 499, 3, 12, 978585) A summary of this Act was published in our issue of September 1[1906].
('6', 499, 3, 13, 978656) Even so, we give here a more detailed translation, so that people may form a correct judgment on the real nature of the Act.
('6', 499, 3, 14, 978781) Between the summary of the Act published by us in September and the Act that has now been passed, there is some difference that is worth noting.
('6', 499, 3, 15, 978926) The Act as it stands now is even more anti Indian than the original version.
('6', 499, 3, 16, 979003) 1. Law No.
('6', 499, 3, 17, 979014) 3 of 1885 will remain in force with modifications that follow.
('6', 499, 3, 18, 979077) 2. The term “Asiatic” will mean Indians, coolies, and Muslim subjects of Turkey.
('6', 499, 3, 19, 979158) It will not include Malays and the Chinese who had come in as indentured labourers.
('6', 499, 3, 20, 979242) (There are other definitions, of Registrar, etc., which are not given here.) 3. Every Asiatic lawfully residing in the Transvaal must
('6', 500, 0, 1, 979376) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 501
('6', 500, 1, 2, 979419) register himself.
('6', 500, 1, 3, 979437) There will be no fee for such registration.
('6', 500, 2, 4, 979481) Asiatics of the following description will be deemed lawful residents of the Transvaal:
('6', 500, 3, 5, 979569) (a) Any Asiatic who holds a permit under the Permit Act, unless such permit was fraudulently obtained.
('6', 500, 3, 6, 979672) (Temporary permits are not covered by this.) (b) Any Asiatic resident and actually in the Transvaal on the 31st of May, 1902. (c) Any Asiatic born in the Transvaal after the 31st of May, 1902. 4. Every Asiatic resident in the Transvaal at the date of the taking effect of this Act shall apply for registration to such officer, at such place and before such date as may be prescribed by the Colonial Secretary.
('6', 500, 3, 7, 980082) Every Asiatic who enters the Transvaal after the date of the taking effect of this Act, who has not previously been registered thereunder, shall apply for registration within eight days of his entry.
('6', 500, 3, 8, 980282) (a) It is not necessary to make an application under this clause for a child under the age of eight years.
('6', 500, 3, 9, 980389) (b) For the registration of a child above eight years and under sixteen years, the application shall be made by his guardian and, if not so made, shall be made by such child within one month after attaining the age of sixteen years.
('6', 500, 3, 10, 980622) 5. The Registrar shall consider the applications of Asiatics who are lawful residents, ‘and register every such applicant whose application may be approved by him.
('6', 500, 4, 11, 980786) If the Registrar rejects the application of any Asiatic, he will give to the person concerned at least fourteen days’ notice to appear before a magistrate.
('6', 500, 4, 12, 980942) If he fails to appear at the time specified, or having appeared fails to satisfy the magistrate as to his right to remain in the Transvaal, the magistrate shall order such Asiatic to leave the Transvaal if he is above sixteen years of age.
('6', 500, 4, 13, 981182) On the other hand, if the magistrate is satisfied that the Asiatic concerned is lawfully resident in the Transvaal, he shall order the Registrar to issue him the certificate of registration.
('6', 500, 5, 14, 981373) 6. Any Asiatic who is the guardian of a child under eight shall, upon making application for registration on his own
