('6', 501, 1, 2, 981532) behalf, supply to the Registrar such particulars and furnish such means of identification in respect of the child as may be prescribed by regulation.
('6', 501, 1, 3, 981682) If the applicant is himself registered, such particulars shall be noted on the register.
('6', 501, 1, 4, 981771) Within one year of the child attaining the age of eight, the guardian concerned shall make application for registration on behalf of the child at the office of the Resident Magistrate of the district in which he resides.
('6', 501, 1, 5, 981992) An Asiatic who is the guardian of a child born in the Transvaal shall apply for registration on behalf of the child within one year of the child reaching the age of eight.
('6', 501, 1, 6, 982164) (a) If the guardian does not apply as required above, he shall if required by the Registrar or the Resident Magistrate make such application at any later date.
('6', 501, 1, 7, 982324) (b) If the guardian does not apply, or if the application made by the guardian is rejected, the application for registration shall be made by the child within one month after reaching the age of sixteen.
('6', 501, 1, 8, 982528) The Resident Magistrate at whose office such applica tion is made shall cause the application along with the relevant documents to be forwarded to the Registrar who shall, if satis fied that the same is in order, issue a certificate 7. of registration.When the guardian has not, as required above, furnished the particulars of a child under the age of eight years and has not made application for registration on behalf of the child after he had attained the age of eight years, the application shall be made by the child within one month after he attains the age of sixteen, and the Registrar may issue a certificate of registration in his discretion.
('6', 501, 1, 9, 983181) 8. Any person who shall fail to make application for registration as required by this Act shall be liable to a fine not exceeding £100 and, in default of payment, to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a period not exceeding three months.
('6', 501, 1, 10, 983429) Any person who brings into the Transvaal an Asiatic under the age of sixteen years not lawfully resident in the Transvaal, and any person who shall employ such child, shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to the penalties mentioned above and to cancellation of his certificate of registration, in addition to which he will be ordered to leave the Transvaal.

('6', 502, 1, 4, 984244) If an Asiatic who has failed to make application for registration shall satisfy the magistrate that such failure was due to some good and sufficient cause, the magistrate may give him time to make such application.
('6', 502, 1, 5, 984459) If the person fails to obtain registration within the appointed time, he shall again be ordered to leave the Transvaal, and if he fails to do so, shall be liable to the usual penalties.
('6', 502, 2, 6, 984645) 9. ('6', 502, 4, 8, 985165) 10. Any person holding a new certificate of registration issued to him under this Act shall be entitled to enter and to reside in the Transvaal.
('6', 502, 4, 9, 985310) 11. Any person into whose hands shall come any certificate of registration or temporary permit of which he is not the lawful holder shall transmit the document immediately to the Registrar.

Any person who commits any fraudulent act in connection with an application for registration or for the purpose of obtaining a certificate of registration or makes a false statement, or incites or aids any person in such act or statement, or forges any certificate of registration, or uses as his certificate any certificate of registration of which he is not the lawful holder or any forged certificate, or causes such certificate to be used by others, shall be liable to a fine not exceeding £500 or to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a term not exceeding two years.
('6', 503, 1, 6, 987169) 17. The Colonial Secretary may in his absolute discretion issue to any Asiatic a permit for a limited time only.
('6', 503, 1, 7, 987282) The provisions of Section 9 shall apply to such permits, and temporary permits issued before the date of the taking effect of this Act shall also be governed by this Act.
('6', 503, 1, 8, 987453) Any person who holds a temporary permit may be exempted from the restrictions on the use of liquor.
('6', 503, 1, 9, 987553) The Colonial Secretary may also grant such exemption to an Asiatic who is not subject to the provisions of this Act.

('6', 504, 1, 6, 988845) 20. The Labour Importation Ordinance relating to the Chinese shall not apply to Asiatics.

('6', 504, 2, 9, 989232) IMPLICATIONS OF ACT
('6', 504, 3, 10, 989252) Fortunately for Indians, no Indian is found ready to accept this obnoxious law.
('6', 504, 3, 11, 989332) Nevertheless, we show below how the condition to which Indians will now be reduced will be much worse than what they have suffered so far, so that those Indians who are firm may become stronger in their determination, and those who are wavering in their minds may give up their doubts, may of their own accord break away from the clutches of the Act, remain free and thus prove themselves to be brave men.
('6', 504, 4, 12, 989738) 1. The new law does not apply to Malays, but applies to Indians.
('6', 504, 5, 13, 989803) 2. It does not apply to Kaffirs and Cape Boys.
('6', 504, 6, 14, 989850) 3. It does not apply to Turkish Christians, but does to
('6', 505, 0, 1, 989906) 506 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 505, 1, 2, 989948) [Turkish] Muslims.
('6', 505, 2, 3, 989967) 4. At present, every Indian in possession of a permit bearing his thumb impression is a lawful resident.
('6', 505, 2, 4, 990072) Under the new Act, he becomes dispossessed of this title, and, when applying for a new permit, such Indian will have to show how his earlier valid permit was obtained.
('6', 505, 3, 5, 990240) 5. Present permits cannot be changed without the consent of the holders.
('6', 505, 3, 6, 990313) The permits to be issued under the new Act are subject to alteration at the will of the Government.
('6', 505, 4, 7, 990413) 6. The present permits held by Indians entitle them to enter and reside in the Orange River Colony.
('6', 505, 4, 8, 990513) Whether these are of any use or not is not the question.
('6', 505, 4, 9, 990570) Under this newAct, the name of the Orange River Colony is omitted from the permits.
('6', 505, 5, 10, 990654) 7. At present, Indians holding permits to reside in the Orange River Colony are in a position to enter the Transvaal on the strength thereof.
('6', 505, 5, 11, 990796) Under the new Act, they will not be able to do so.
('6', 505, 6, 12, 990847) 8. At present, no Indian is bound to give his thumb impression or his signature to obtain a permit.
('6', 505, 6, 13, 990947) Under the new Act, by making or modifying rules from time to time at its pleasure, the Government can prescribe the giving of signature or thumb impression, or any other thing to be done, as compulsory.
('6', 505, 7, 14, 991150) 9. At present, only the Permit Secretary is authorized to inspect a permit.
('6', 505, 7, 15, 991226) Under the new Act, every Kaffir police constable can do so.
('6', 505, 8, 16, 991286) 10. Under the new Act, a Kaffir police constable can ask [an Asiatic] for particulars of name and identity, and, if not satisfied, can take him to the police station.
('6', 505, 8, 17, 991453) The Station Officer, if not satisfied with the particulars, may detain the Asiatic in a cell and produce him before a magistrate the next day.
('6', 505, 8, 18, 991596) All this cannot be done under the present Act.
('6', 505, 9, 19, 991643) 11. At present, no permit is required for a child one day old, and no one dare ask for particulars of name and identity in respect of such child.
('6', 505, 9, 20, 991789) Under the new Act, the guardian of
('6', 506, 0, 1, 991824) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 507
('6', 506, 1, 2, 991867) such child is bound to have particulars of identification of such child, no matter how young, endorsed on his registr ation.
('6', 506, 2, 3, 991992) 12. At present, an Asiatic child is free after reaching the age of eight.
('6', 506, 2, 4, 992066) Under the new Act, even after having the required particulars endorsed as above, the guardian is bound again to approach the Registrar and take out registration for such child, furnishing further particulars as to identification, etc.
('6', 506, 2, 5, 992301) In case he fails to do so, he will be liable to punishment.
('6', 506, 2, 6, 992361) 13. Asiatic children who are at present in the Transvaal are entitled to remain without a permit, and are not liable to leave the country on attaining majority.
('6', 506, 2, 7, 992522) Under the new Act, all such boys are liable to be deported unless they obtain from the Registrar registration certificates, the granting of which is at his discretion.
('6', 506, 2, 8, 992690) 14. At present, an Asiatic is free to bring with him a child under the age of sixteen without a permit for him.
('6', 506, 2, 9, 992802) Under the new Act, any Asiatic doing so is liable to imprisonment with hard labour, and to have his own registration cancelled.
('6', 506, 2, 10, 992930) 15. At present, any Asiatic can obtain a trading licence without production of a permit.
('6', 506, 2, 11, 993019) Under the new Act, he will have to produce his new register and furnish particulars of name, etc.,and means of identification.
('6', 506, 2, 12, 993146) Which means that if there are partners in an Indian firm, the Licensing Officer may insist upon the presence of all the parties.
('6', 506, 2, 13, 993275) In case they do not remain present, he can refuse to issue the licence.
('6', 506, 2, 14, 993347) 16. At present, the authority of the Registrar is relatively limited.
('6', 506, 2, 15, 993417) Under the new Act, if accepted by Indians, the Registrar will practically become their master.
('6', 506, 2, 16, 993512) 17. Under the new Act, applying for registration is compulsory for every Indian.
('6', 506, 2, 17, 993593) Indians who are in a position to apply for themselves are very rare.
('6', 506, 2, 18, 993662) Permit agents have earned much but if the Indians submit to the new Act, those agents will have a fertile field opened up to them, money flowing into their hands like a swarm of serpents rushing out of a mound.
('6', 506, 2, 19, 993873) At the very least, therefore, assuming that there will be 10,000 Indian applicants, they will be robbed of £ 30,000, counting the fee at £3 per head on an average.
('6', 507, 0, 1, 994037) 508 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 507, 1, 2, 994079) 18. Anyone submitting to such an oppressive law and obtaining registers, or causing others to obtain them, will be shedding the blood of Indians by robbing them as above.
('6', 507, 1, 3, 994250) Is there any Indian who is not roused to fury by such a law?
('6', 507, 1, 4, 994311) We should very much like to know the Indian whose blood does not boil.
('6', 507, 1, 5, 994382) And it is incredible to us that any Indian may want to submit to such legislation.
('6', 507, 1, 6, 994465) This new Act is the extreme limit of slavery.
('6', 507, 1, 7, 994511) And it is our earnest hope that no Indian will accept it, whatever the benefit he may get thereby, but that everyone will resist it at all cost.
('6', 507, 1, 8, 994656) What Mr. Kallenbach 1 writes is quite true: that is, if we submit to such a law, we deserve it 2 Everyone will believe so.
('6', 507, 1, 9, 994779) It is to be borne in mind that this Act not only insults Indians but casts a slur on the religion of both Hindus and Muslims.

('6', 508, 1, 2, 996327) suggestion that the Indian community may, at its option, append photographs in place of finger prints.

('6', 509, 5, 11, 999113) He was born in 1826. He suffered imprisonment five times, between 1847 and 1849, in the cause of freedom and for the rights of others.
('6', 509, 5, 12, 999248) In this way he had to suffer imprisonment for opposing his Government.
('6', 509, 5, 13, 999319) Once he was even sentenced to death for a public cause, but was saved.

('6', 510, 1, 3, 1000477) Many bavas and fakirs maintain themselves by begging, but serve neither themselves nor the country.
('6', 510, 1, 4, 1000577) For going about begging in this manner, they will not be regarded as having attained true renunciation.

('6', 510, 1, 6, 1000778) And to that extent the wealth of India is being wasted.

('6', 510, 1, 12, 1001175) The work of the institution has been expanding.

('6', 510, 1, 17, 1001668) From every point of view, education is the most important thing for us.

('6', 511, 5, 22, 1004340) He quoted Burke, the great English writer, who used to say that thousands of men could not be sent to the gallows, nor could they be kept confined behind prison bars.

('6', 512, 2, 9, 1005423) LETTER TO “THE STAR”
('6', 512, 3, 10, 1005444) As General Botha has returned and the Committee in England is still continuing its struggle against the law, Mr. Gandhi has addressed the following letter to The Star: 1
('6', 512, 4, 11, 1005614) The arrival of General Botha and the fact that the Asiatic Registration Act is still the subject matter of correspondence between the Imperial Government and the local Government, encourage me to appeal once more to your good sense and, through you, to that of the Colonists.
('6', 512, 4, 12, 1005890) Now that the anti Asiatic party has obtained what it wanted, is it impossible to arrive at a reasonable compromise and to do away with a law under which Indians will be treated as criminals?
('6', 512, 4, 13, 1006081) The Act is not yet gazetted, and it need not be.
('6', 512, 4, 14, 1006130) I, therefore, suggest that a form for new permits may be mutually agreed upon, and, in accordance with it, Indians and other Asiatics may be registered afresh in exchange for proper documents they may posses.
('6', 512, 4, 15, 1006339) If, then, all Asiatics thus voluntarily surrender their documents, there can be no occasion for submitting them to any degradation.
('6', 512, 4, 16, 1006471) If, however, there are Asiatics in the Colony who do not surrender their documents, the Act can be immediately gazetted, and be made applicable, by a short Bill, to them.
('6', 512, 4, 17, 1006642) Thus, those who are bona fide holders of permits and are honest will be automatically separated from those who are guilty.
('6', 512, 5, 18, 1006765) I do not know whether you can see any flaw in this proposal, unless you think that the object of the legislation is not that illicit traffic in permits may be stopped, but that it is to, openly and boldly, put an unwarranted affront upon British Indians and other Asiatics.
('6', 512, 5, 19, 1007039) Let me remind you, before any such declaration is made, of Lord Ampthill’s remarks:
('6', 512, 6, 20, 1007123) This is not a matter which only touches our honour.
('6', 512, 6, 21, 1007175) We are pledged to our fellow citizens in India—pledged by the solemn declaration of the Sovereign, by the pronouncements of our statesmen, and by all that is implied in the
('6', 512, 7, 22, 1007348) 1 The text is given here with some alterations needed to bring it into conformity with the Gujarati version; vide “Letter to The Star”, 30 5 1907.
('6', 513, 0, 1, 1007495) 514 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 513, 1, 2, 1007537) whole method of our administration of that great dominion—to treat the people of India as fellow citizens in every sense of the word.
('6', 513, 1, 3, 1007671) We invite them to be proud of their citizenship of the Empire.
('6', 513, 1, 4, 1007734) We tell them, again and again, that there is nothing to prevent their rising to the same positions as are held by Englishmen in India, and we imply, in all that we do for them and say to them, that wherever they are under the British flag in any part of the world, they will be treated as British citizens.
('6', 513, 2, 5, 1008041) Lord Lansdowne feels so keenly humiliated by this Act, that he questions whether to wound the susceptibilities of the whole Indian nation is not a more important matter than the conditions in the Transvaal.
('6', 513, 2, 6, 1008248) But the proposal I have ventured to sketch above is just as effective against surreptitious entry as may be by the Asiatic Act.
('6', 513, 3, 7, 1008376) If the Government does not accept the suggestion made in this letter, it would obviously mean that the new law had no other aim than that of humiliating the Indian community.

('6', 513, 4, 10, 1008649) KALLENBACH’S HELP
('6', 513, 5, 11, 1008667) Mr. Kallenbach is a well known architect of Johannesburg.
('6', 513, 5, 12, 1008725) He has written the following letter to The Star in order to sustain the spirit of the Indian community and encourage it in its gaol going resolve.
('6', 513, 5, 13, 1008872) This letter is also published along with Mr. Gandhi’s: 1
('6', 513, 6, 14, 1008929) Although, for some reasons, I am not taking part in political matters, I have been following with interest the various stages of action among the Transvaal Indians in their struggle to defend their legitimate rights by that ‘gaol resolution’.
('6', 513, 7, 15, 1009172) I have read the various Press comments on the latter question, and also Mr. Gandhi’s letter to The Star, in all of which the gaol resolution was discussed.
('6', 513, 7, 16, 1009328) I for one am of the opinion that the Asiatic Registration Ordinance imposes certain conditions which are degrading to any man of self respect, and if this was not keenly felt by Asiatics, it would be a clear proof that they fully deserve the Registration Act.
('6', 513, 7, 17, 1009588) I think it most unfair to call those men, who are working in order to show to their countrymen the deep humiliation which the new legislation tries to impose upon them, “aggressive agitators”.
('6', 513, 7, 18, 1009781) I believe it to be the duty of those Indians, who are able to grasp the conditions

('6', 514, 1, 2, 1010016) of the new legislation, to impart this knowledge to every one of their countrymen and to do their utmost to so raise and strengthen their self respect that by united action those humiliating conditions are changed.
('6', 514, 1, 3, 1010231) I feel sure that the fear of the Indian storekeepers’ competition has not deadened every “white man’s” sense of justice, and that many of them—and I hope that their number is not small—cannot do otherwise than show their admiration and full sympathy for men who, rather than submit to humiliating legislative conditions, go to gaol, setting aside, in addition to the hardships of prison life which they are prepared to face, monetary losses too.

('6', 515, 2, 6, 1013113) WHAT CAN GOVERNMENT DO BUT IMPRISON US?
('6', 515, 3, 7, 1013153) It has been suggested that the Government may not prosecute any Indian for not taking out the new registers, but quietly wait till the end of the year when Indians will have to close down their businesses, since their trading licences will not be renewed.
('6', 515, 3, 8, 1013409) It is improbable that this will happen.
('6', 515, 3, 9, 1013449) For, in that case, the hundreds of Indians who hold no trading licences will never come within the sweep of the law.
('6', 515, 3, 10, 1013566) The employees of a trader will escape penalty.
('6', 515, 3, 11, 1013613) Adopting that course will render the law as good as non existent.
('6', 515, 3, 12, 1013679) But supposing that the Government’s intention is only to harass merchants, I have already given the reply that once we have discarded the fear of imprisonment, there is nothing for us to be afraid of.
('6', 515, 3, 13, 1013880) The Government itself will stand to lose if it does not grant licences.
('6', 515, 3, 14, 1013952) For, the merchant can carry on his trade without a licence.
('6', 515, 3, 15, 1014012) The risk in doing so will be just the same as the risk in not taking out the new register.
('6', 515, 3, 16, 1014103) If the new registeris not taken out, at the most one has to go to gaol.
('6', 515, 3, 17, 1014175) In the same way, for trading without a licence one may have to go to gaol.
('6', 515, 3, 18, 1014250) The only difference will be that only one man will be punished for trading without a licence, with the result that the shop can remain open and the employees can work in it.
('6', 515, 3, 19, 1014424) On the other hand, for not holding the new register everyone can be arrested.
('6', 515, 4, 20, 1014502) CAN GOODS OF MERCHANT TRADING WITHOUT LICENCE BE AUCTIONED?
('6', 515, 5, 21, 1014562) This question also has been raised.
('6', 515, 5, 22, 1014598) According to the Natal law the goods can be auctioned.
('6', 515, 5, 23, 1014653) But in the Transvaal, in case of non 
('6', 515, 6, 24, 1014691) 1 Vide “Letter to Prime Minister’s Secretary”, 1 6 1907. The deputation, however, did not materialize.
('6', 516, 0, 1, 1014794) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 517
('6', 516, 1, 2, 1014837) payment of fine the defaulter has to go to gaol.
('6', 516, 1, 3, 1014886) Fine is not to be paid by anyone.
('6', 516, 1, 4, 1014920) If therefore the Government should want to exercise pressure on us through the trade licence, all shopkeepers and hawkers will start trading without a licence.
('6', 516, 2, 5, 1015080) CAN SHOPS BE CLOSED DOWN?
('6', 516, 3, 6, 1015106) It has been asked whether the Government can close down the shop of anyone trading without a licence.
('6', 516, 3, 7, 1015208) Nowhere in South Africa is there a law providing for the forcible closure of a shop.
('6', 516, 3, 8, 1015293) There is therefore no such danger.
('6', 516, 4, 9, 1015328) WHAT CHANGES CAN BE MADE THROUGH REGULATIONS?
('6', 516, 5, 10, 1015374) There has been an inquiry as to whether it will be possible for General Botha to give us relief in the regulations, and whether it will still be necessary for us to resist the law if we get all the relief asked for.
('6', 516, 5, 11, 1015590) In the first place, it is.
('6', 516, 5, 12, 1015617) essential to know what can be secured through regulations.
('6', 516, 5, 13, 1015676) These can only determine whether a thumb impression or digit impressions will be required or whether signatures will be enough.
('6', 516, 5, 14, 1015804) But such matters as registration of children,harassment by the police, showing of identification marks to the police, etc., which are the oppressive sections in this Act, cannot be changed by regulations.
('6', 516, 5, 15, 1016009) In brief, the slur that the law casts on us cannot be wiped out by regulations framed under it.
('6', 516, 5, 16, 1016105) Without amending the law therefore General Botha cannot give us the redress we seek.
('6', 516, 5, 17, 1016190) It is absolutely futile to hope that the law will be amended.
('6', 516, 5, 18, 1016252) The utmost that can be done is not to have the law gazetted for the present.
('6', 516, 5, 19, 1016329) By this the prestige of both parties will be maintained.
('6', 516, 5, 20, 1016386) If the law is so amended as to make it acceptable to us, the Government will lose face.
('6', 516, 6, 21, 1016474) FREE INDIANS WORSE THAN DOGS
('6', 516, 7, 22, 1016503) A huge agricultural exhibition is being held here just now.
('6', 516, 7, 23, 1016563) The Exhibition Committee has framed a regulation to the effect that free Asiatics or Natives who are not employees of whites cannot visit the exhibition.
('6', 516, 7, 24, 1016717) However, dogs are free to enter, and, what is more, good pedigree dogs are awarded prizes!
('6', 516, 7, 25, 1016808) In the opinion of this white Committee, a free Indian is worse than these dogs.
('6', 516, 8, 26, 1016888) PERMIT OFFICE
('6', 516, 9, 27, 1016902) A case appears to have just occurred which shows that we did very well in having boycotted the Permit Office.
('6', 516, 9, 28, 1017012) An Indian had
('6', 517, 0, 1, 1017026) 518 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 517, 1, 2, 1017068) received a notice saying that a permit would be issued to him.
('6', 517, 1, 3, 1017131) He had only to go to the Office and receive it He was therefore advised that he might accept the permit if no mention of the new law was made.
('6', 517, 1, 4, 1017274) Accordingly, he went to the Permit Office.
('6', 517, 1, 5, 1017317) However, Mr. Chamney told him that the permit would be issued to him only if he gave an assurance that he would submit to the new law.
('6', 517, 1, 6, 1017452) The brave Indian refused to comply and left the Office without the permit.
('6', 517, 1, 7, 1017527) Every Indian should understand that the Permit Office is a trap for Indians.
('6', 517, 2, 8, 1017604) WHAT INDIAN TRADERS CAN DO
('6', 517, 3, 9, 1017631) Many Indian traders say that the Dutchmen are ready to send a petition to the Government stating that they are not against us.
('6', 517, 3, 10, 1017758) If this is the case, it is necessary for every Indian trader to obtain signatures of Dutchmen on such a petition.
('6', 517, 3, 11, 1017872) It is not necessary to make much fuss in the matter.
('6', 517, 3, 12, 1017925) If the traders wish to take it up, petition forms will be sent to them.
('6', 517, 3, 13, 1017997) Those in a position to obtain signatures should write to the Association.
('6', 517, 4, 14, 1018071) REGULATIONS FOR HAWKERS
('6', 517, 5, 15, 1018095) The Government has returned [to the Town Council] the regula tions for hawkers, saying that the licence fee of £5 may be reduced to £3. The Council Committee has sent a reply stating that the rate of £5 should be retained, as a reduction would result in financial loss.
('6', 517, 6, 16, 1018365) PERMIT CASE
('6', 517, 7, 17, 1018377) Permit cases have been going on for some time.
('6', 517, 7, 18, 1018424) Two washermen were accused of using false permits and of staying without permits.
('6', 517, 7, 19, 1018506) In their defence, they stated that an Indian had taken them to Johannes burg, telling them that the Permit Officer visited the town and issued permit.
('6', 517, 7, 20, 1018657) The said Indian demanded from each of the washermen £30, which they agreed to pay.
('6', 517, 7, 21, 1018740) They went to the place of the Indian where they saw a disguised European.
('6', 517, 7, 22, 1018814) He gave them permits and they each paid £30. They were acquitted of the charge of having used false permits as they were not aware that the permits given by the European were false.
('6', 517, 7, 23, 1018996) But on the charge of having resided without a permit, they have been ordered to leave the Transvaal within seven days.
('6', 517, 7, 24, 1019115) It will be interesting to know who this officer may be, for there are various rumours current in the town.
('6', 517, 7, 25, 1019222) A similar charge was brought against another Indian.
('6', 518, 0, 1, 1019275) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 519
('6', 518, 1, 2, 1019318) based on the affidavit of some Indian.
('6', 518, 1, 3, 1019357) In deposing before the magistrate, the Indian who had made the affidavit turned hostile to theprosecution.
('6', 518, 1, 4, 1019464) Thereupon the magistrate discharged the accused and sentenced the other Indian for giving false evidence.
('6', 518, 1, 5, 1019570) The case of this gentleman appears to prove the truth of the saying, “He who digs a pit will I himself fall into it.”
('6', 518, 2, 6, 1019688) [From Gujarati]
('6', 518, 3, 7, 1019704) Indian Opinion, 8 6 1907
('6', 518, 4, 8, 1019729) 415. CONDITION OF MUSLIMS IN AFGHANISTAN
('6', 518, 5, 9, 1019770) We published some time ago an article by Mr. Saiyed Ali, B.A., on Muslim administration.
('6', 518, 5, 10, 1019859) The second part of that article appeared in the Indian Review of March which we briefly summarize below.
('6', 518, 5, 11, 1019964) We have considered Turkey and Iran.
('6', 518, 5, 12, 1020000) Let us now turn to Afghanistan, which has made big advances recently.
('6', 518, 5, 13, 1020070) It can safely be stated that before Amir Abdur Rahman ascended the throne, there was hardly any administration in Afghanistan, though, even then, there were councils called Ulu and Malik.
('6', 518, 5, 14, 1020258) Residents of the various localities in a village sent representatives to a council known as Khel, and the Ulu was elected from out of them.
('6', 518, 5, 15, 1020398) But in those times, owing to the difficult temper of the people, no one could maintain control over the administration.
('6', 518, 5, 16, 1020518) Then thieves had their arms cut off.
('6', 518, 5, 17, 1020555) If a slave tried to run away, he had his legs chopped off.
('6', 518, 5, 18, 1020614) The different provinces were governed by local chieftains and Sardars.
('6', 518, 5, 19, 1020685) Above the Sardars there were Amirs, but the Sardars showed little respect for their authority.
('6', 518, 5, 20, 1020780) The Pathan is by nature an adventurous individual, and so he was quite at home with such unsettled conditions.
('6', 518, 5, 21, 1020891) In those times, punishments such as those described above were the only effective ones.
('6', 518, 5, 22, 1020979) Once a Pathan told General Elphinstone 1 in reply to a question: “We are content to remain quarrelling; we are not afraid of dangers, and do not grow pale at the sight of blood.
('6', 518, 5, 23, 1021157) Come what may, we will not give up our freedom and submit ourselves to any Emperor.” After coming to the throne, Amir Abdur Rahman introduced important changes.
('6', 518, 5, 24, 1021318) He took the utmost advantage of the fact that his kingdom was a buffer State between Russia and England.
('6', 518, 5, 25, 1021423) Sometimes
('6', 518, 6, 26, 1021433) 1 (1779 1859), statesman and historian, Lieutenant Governor of Bombay, 1819 27.
('6', 519, 0, 1, 1021513) 520 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 519, 1, 2, 1021555) he would lean towards Russia and sometimes towards England.
('6', 519, 1, 3, 1021615) He would not quarrel openly with either, and in the end, would side with England.
('6', 519, 1, 4, 1021697) This shrewdness of his won the admiration of European statesmen.
('6', 519, 1, 5, 1021762) He always had things to his advantage, but yielded nothing to others in return.
('6', 519, 1, 6, 1021842) In the internal affairs of the kingdom, too, he showed the highest ability, and broke the power of the local chieftains.
('6', 519, 1, 7, 1021963) He reformed the civil law.
('6', 519, 1, 8, 1021990) The annual tribute of twelve lakhs of rupees which he used to receive from the Government of India, later raised to eighteen lakhs, was put to wise use.
('6', 519, 1, 9, 1022143) He formed an army, stocke dammunition and expanded trade.
('6', 519, 1, 10, 1022201) Unnecessary faxes were removed, and a mint was established.
('6', 519, 1, 11, 1022261) The present ruler has raised the status of Afghanistan even further.
('6', 519, 1, 12, 1022330) He has established two councils, named Darbar e Shahi and Kwajan Shahi.
('6', 519, 1, 13, 1022402) Under such a political system even the temper of the Pathans has begun to change.
('6', 519, 1, 14, 1022484) If the present trend continues for long, the warlike Pathan will have established a strong kingdom in the East.
('6', 519, 1, 15, 1022596) All the same, it must be admitted that the people of Afghanistan do not interest themselves in political affairs.
('6', 519, 1, 16, 1022710) Amir Habibullah Khan is an Emperor.
('6', 519, 1, 17, 1022746) He is a brave soldier and a pious man.
('6', 519, 1, 18, 1022785) His Majesty never missed his prayers while in India.
('6', 519, 1, 19, 1022838) We cannot say for certain whether or not he will observe the agreement of 1905. The Amir is now accorded the status of an Emperor and receives a salute of thirty one guns.
('6', 519, 1, 20, 1023010) He now enjoys the same power that the Shah of Iran does.

('6', 519, 3, 22, 1023108) 416. LETTER TO “ THE STAR” 1
('6', 519, 4, 23, 1023137) P. O. BOX 3553, [JOHANNESBURG,] June 8, 1907
('6', 519, 5, 24, 1023182) TO THE EDITOR THE STAR [JOHANNESBURG]
('6', 519, 6, 25, 1023220) SIR, I have seen the Gazette notice today intimating that the Asiatic Law Amendment Act has received the Royal sanction, and that it will
('6', 519, 7, 26, 1023358) 1 Presumably, this was drafted by Gandhiji.
('6', 519, 7, 27, 1023402) It was reproduced in India Opinion 15 6 1907.
('6', 520, 0, 1, 1023448) VOL. 6: 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 521
('6', 520, 1, 2, 1023491) come into force on a day to be appointed.
('6', 520, 1, 3, 1023533) I do not know what this means, but it leaves breathing space, and I, therefore, wish to place before the public a mercantile view of the Act.
('6', 520, 1, 4, 1023675) In order to do that, I am obliged to enter into a bit of autobiography.
('6', 520, 1, 5, 1023747) I have been settled in the Transvaal for the last 19 years, and have the honour to represent, as managing partner, the firm of Suliman Ismail Mia and Co.
('6', 520, 1, 6, 1023901) My firm has very large dealings with European wholesale houses, who have need I say, derived very considerable pecuniary profit from their transactions with the firm.
('6', 520, 1, 7, 1024068) It suffered severe reverses during the Jameson Raid 1, and yet its creditors were paid in full.
('6', 520, 1, 8, 1024164) It underwent asimilar ordeal during the Boer War; the creditors were still paid in full.
('6', 520, 1, 9, 1024253) And now, for the third time,complete ruin stares it in the face.
('6', 520, 1, 10, 1024318) In the two previous instances, the cause was beyond human, at any rate my firm’s, control.
('6', 520, 1, 11, 1024409) Today, the cause will be of its own seeking, and why?
('6', 520, 1, 12, 1024463) For the simple reason that the Asiatic Law Amendment ‘Act is considered by every Indian who has understood it as a mark of slavery pure and simple.
('6', 520, 1, 13, 1024611) It makes of the Transvaal a prison house for every Indian, so far as I know my countrymen’s mind.
('6', 520, 1, 14, 1024709) They have, therefore, decided not to submit to such an Act, but to suffer the consequence of such disobedience.
('6', 520, 1, 15, 1024821) It goes against the grain for an Indian to disobey any law, and yet the feeling aroused by this Act is so strong that disobedience is deemed a virtue and obedience a cowardly vice.
('6', 520, 1, 16, 1025002) The position that I, as an Indian merchant, am placed in is the position occupied by many like myself.
('6', 520, 1, 17, 1025105) Do you suppose that all such Indians do not realize the full force and effect of what they stand to lose from a worldly standpoint by disobeying the law?
('6', 520, 1, 18, 1025259) But we have learned at the feet of your countrymen that it is better to suffer such loss than to surrender personal freedom and accept humiliation.
('6', 520, 1, 19, 1025407) Why should I accept cancellation of my title deeds, and have to go to the Permit Office, hat in hand, and beg for a new title deed with many restrictions?
('6', 520, 1, 20, 1025562) Moreover, as a Mahomedan, I resent most bitterly that, whereas non Mahomedan subjects of the Turkish Empire are free from the galling yoke of the Act, Mahomedan subjects of that Empire are not.
('6', 520, 1, 21, 1025756) These are facts which I venture to ask you and the public to weigh well.
('6', 520, 2, 22, 1025829) I should not have troubled you were it not for the fact that the Government have reserved to themselves yet the right to retire from what is, from the Indian standpoint, a false position.
('6', 520, 2, 23, 1026017) Let the offer of
('6', 520, 3, 24, 1026034) 1 In 1895.
('6', 521, 0, 1, 1026045) 522 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 521, 1, 2, 1026087) voluntary re registration be accepted and, if it fails, a ‘day may be fixed for the compulsory registration of those who have not abided by the voluntary offer.
('6', 521, 1, 3, 1026248) It is true that, under the voluntary offer, there will be no ear marking of Indian babes, but I must frankly confess that no loss of the good things of this world will deter me from disobeying an Act which means that I shall have to supply identification particulars of a day old son of mine, and be subject to the tacit assumption that the infant is a future criminal of the direst type.
('6', 521, 1, 4, 1026637) I have spoken to many European friends of mine.
('6', 521, 1, 5, 1026685) They all consider that our offer is very reasonable.
('6', 521, 1, 6, 1026738) I ask you, and them, to support us in our struggle for a respectable existence in the Transvaal.
('6', 521, 1, 7, 1026835) Jesus is as much a prophet of the Mahomedans as he is of the Christians.
('6', 521, 1, 8, 1026908) He has somewhere said: “Do unto others as you would that they should do unto you.” May I ask the Christian Government to follow this wise saying?

('6', 525, 20, 20, 1033272) The following is the full official text published by the Transvaal Government:
('6', 525, 21, 21, 1033351) 1 These affidavits, duly executed before a Justice of the Peace and corroborating each other, were signed by Candasamy Pillay, Samuel Vincent Thomas, Siva Lingham and Vadival Naidoo who all testified that Dr. William Godfrey had collected signatures on blank paper by the false use of the authority of the British Indian Association.
('6', 525, 21, 22, 1033685) The petition itself, which is summarized by Gandhiji in a statement on the subject addressed to Lord Elgin (pp.
('6', 525, 21, 23, 1033797) 196 202) and the real purpose of which Dr. Godfrey misrepresented to the signatories, was drafted later.
('6', 525, 21, 24, 1033902) When these facts became known, many of the signatures to Godfrey's petition were withdrawn.
('6', 526, 0, 1, 1033994) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 527
('6', 526, 1, 2, 1034038) Be it enacted by the King’s Most Excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the Legislative Council and Legislative Assembly of the Transvaal as follows:
('6', 526, 3, 3, 1034205) 1. Sub section (c) of Article two of Law No.
('6', 526, 3, 4, 1034250) 3 of 1885 as amended by Volksraad Resolutions, Article 1419 of the twelfth day of August 1886 and Article 128 of the sixteenth day of May 1890 shall be and is hereby repealed.
('6', 526, 4, 5, 1034426) DEFINITIONS
('6', 526, 5, 6, 1034438) 2. In this Act unless inconsistent with the context:
('6', 526, 6, 7, 1034491) “Asiatic” shall mean any such male person as is described in Article one of Law No.
('6', 526, 6, 8, 1034575) 3 of 1885 not being a Malay born and resident in any British Colony or possession in South Africa nor a person introduced into the Colony under the Labour Importation Ordinance 1904 and not being an officer in the Chinese Consular Service;
('6', 526, 7, 9, 1034815) “register of Asiatics” shall mean the register to be kept under this Act as prescribed by Regulation;
('6', 526, 8, 10, 1034917) “Registrar” shall mean the officer appointed by the Governor to keep the register of Asiatics and any person lawfully acting in such capacity;
('6', 526, 9, 11, 1035060) “Resident Magistrate” shall include an Assistant Resident Magistrate;
('6', 526, 10, 12, 1035130) “Regulation” shall mean any Regulation made under section eighteen of this Act;
('6', 526, 11, 13, 1035210) “Guardian” shall mean the parent of an Asiatic under the age of sixteen or any other person under whose care or control such Asiatic is living for the time being or, failing any such person, the employer of such Asiatic;
('6', 526, 12, 14, 1035431) “application for registration” shall mean an application to be placed on the register of Asiatics made in such manner and form as may be prescribed by Regulation and accompanied by the supplying of such particulars and the furnishing of such means of identification as may be required by this Act or by Regulation;
('6', 526, 13, 15, 1035746) “applicant” shall mean any person who makes application for registration on his own behalf or any person on whose behalf application for registration is made by his guardian; “certificate of registration” shall mean a certificate of registration under this Act in the form prescribed by Regulation;
('6', 526, 14, 16, 1036045) “lawful holder” as used in relation to any certificate of registration shall mean the person whose registration is thereby certified.
('6', 526, 15, 17, 1036179) ALL ASIATICS LAWFULLY RESIDENT IN COLONY TO BE REGISTERED
('6', 526, 16, 18, 1036237) 3. (1) Every Asiatic lawfully resident in this Colony shall subject to the
('6', 527, 0, 1, 1036312) 528 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 527, 1, 2, 1036354) exceptions hereinafter mentioned be registered in the register of Asiatics and shall there upon be entitled to receive a certificate of registration and no charge shall be made for such registration or certificate save as in section twelve of this Act provided.
('6', 527, 2, 3, 1036616) (2) The following shall be deemed for the purposes of this Act to be Asiatics lawfully resident in this Colony:
('6', 527, 3, 4, 1036728) (i) Any Asiatic duly authorized to enter and reside in this Colony by a permit issued under the Indemnity and Peace Preservation Ordinance 1902 or any amendment thereof or issued between the first day of September 1900 and the date of the passing of the said Ordinance, unless such permit shall have been fraudulently obtained; provided that any permit expressed to authorize any Asiatic to remain in this Colony for a limited time only shall not be deemed to be a permit within the meaning of this sub section.
('6', 527, 4, 5, 1037240) (ii) Any Asiatic resident and actually in this Colony on the thirty first day of May 1902.
('6', 527, 5, 6, 1037331) (iii) Any Asiatic born in this Colony since the thirty first day of May 1902 not being the child of any labourer introduced into this Colony under the Labour Importation Ordinance 1904.
('6', 527, 6, 7, 1037517) ASIATICS TO APPLY FOR REGISTRATION WITHIN FIXED TIME
('6', 527, 7, 8, 1037570) 4. (1) Every Asiatic resident in this Colony at the date of the taking effect of this Act shall before such date or dates and at such place or places and to such person or persons as the Colonial Secretary may prescribe by notice in the Gazette make application for registration.
('6', 527, 8, 9, 1037850) (2) Every Asiatic who enters this Colony after the date of the taking effect of this Act and who has not previously been registered thereunder shall within eight days after entering the Colony, unless he shall have entered under a permit granted under section seventeen, make application for registration to such person and at such place as may be so prescribed; provided that
('6', 527, 9, 10, 1038227) (a) no application shall be required to be made under this section on behalf of any Asiatic child who at the expiration of the time within which such application is required to be made is under the age of eight years;
('6', 527, 10, 11, 1038445) (b) in the case of any Asiatic child who at the expiration of such time is eight years of age but under sixteen years of age, such application shall be made on such child’s behalf by his guardian and if not so shallbe made by such child within one month after attaining the age of sixteen years.
('6', 528, 0, 1, 1038741) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 529
('6', 528, 1, 2, 1038785) REGISTRAR TO REGISTER APPLICANTS IF APPROVED AND
('6', 528, 2, 3, 1038834) IN CASE OF REFUSAL TO GIVE NOTICE
('6', 528, 3, 4, 1038868) 5. (1) The Registrar shall consider every application for registration made under the last preceding section and register every applicant who is lawfully resident in this Colony or whose application is approved by him and shall cause to be issued to such applicant or the guardian who made the application on his behalf a certificate of registration
('6', 528, 4, 5, 1039218) (2) If it shall appear to the Registrar that any applicant is not lawfully resident in this Colony, he may refuse to register such applicant and in case of refusal where the applicant is of the age of sixteen years or over shall cause a notice of refusal to be sent by post to the applicant at the address given by him on the application and a copy of such notice shall be affixed to the principal door of the Magistrate’s office of the District where such application was made and the Registrar shall by such notice direct such applicant to appear before the Resident Magistrate of the District at a time therein specified being not less than fourteen days from the date of such notice and shew cause why he should not be ordered to leave this Colony and if such applicant shall fail to appear at the time specified in such notice or having appeared shall fail to satisfy the Resident Magistrate that he is lawfully resident in the Colony, the Resident Magistrate if the applicant is of the age of sixteen years or over shall make an order in writing directing him to leave this Colony within a time to be specified in such order; provided always that if such order made in the absence of the applicant, such time shall run from the date of the service of the order upon him and such order shall be deemed to be an order made under section six of the Peace Preservation Ordinance 1903 and sections seven and eight of the said Ordinance shall apply accordingly; provided further that if the Resident Magistrate shall be satisfied that the applicant is lawfully resident within this Colony, such Magistrate shall make an order upon the Registrar requiring him to register such applicant and to issue to him a certificate of registration.
('6', 528, 5, 6, 1040955) PROVISIONS AS TO PARTICULARS TO BE SUPPLIED AND APPLICATIONS TO BE MADE BY GUARDIANS
('6', 528, 6, 7, 1041040) 6. (1) Any Asiatic who is the guardian of an Asiatic child under the age of eight years shall upon making application for registration on his own behalf supply such particulars and furnish such means of identification in respect of such child as may be prescribed by Regulation and if such guardian is
('6', 529, 0, 1, 1041342) 530 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 529, 1, 2, 1041384) himself registered, the particulars aforesaid which he has supplied shall be provisionally noted on the register and such guardian shall within one year after the child aforesaid attains the age of eight years make application for registration on such child’s behalf at the office of the Resident Magistrate of the District in which he himself resides;
('6', 529, 2, 3, 1041737) (2) The guardian of every Asiatic child born i1n this Colony after the date of the taking effect of this Act shall within one year after such child attains the age of eight years make application for registration on such child’s behalf at the office of the Resident Magistrate of the District in which he himself resides; provided that
('6', 529, 3, 4, 1042073) (a) where any guardian fails to make application for registration on behalf of any Asiatic child whose guardian he is within the time hereby prescribed for making the same, such guardian shall on being thereto required by the Registrar or any Resident Magistrate make such application at any later date;
('6', 529, 4, 5, 1042377) (b) where any application which is required to be made under this section by the guardian of an Asiatic child is not made by such guardian or where such application is refused, application for registration shall be made by such Asiatic child at the office of the Resident Magistrate of the District within which he resides within one month after he attains the age of sixteen years.
('6', 529, 5, 6, 1042760) The Resident Magistrate at whose office any application is made under this section shall cause the record of such application and all documents relating thereto to be forwarded to the Registrar, who shall if satisfied that the same is in order register the applicant and cause to be issued to him or his guardian a certificate of registration.
('6', 529, 6, 7, 1043104) APPLICATION FOR REGISTRATION BY ASIATICS ON ATTAINING AGE OF SIXTEEN
('6', 529, 7, 8, 1043173) WHOSE GUARDIANS HAVE FAILED TO SUPPLY PARTICULARS
('6', 529, 8, 9, 1043223) 7. Where particulars as to any Asiatic child under the age of eight years have not been provisionally noted on the register, as is in the last preceding section provided, by reason of the failure of his guardian to supply such particulars, application for registration shall nevertheless be made on behalf of such Asiatic child by the guardian within one year after he attains the age of eight years and if not so made shall be made by such Asiatic child within one month after he attains the age of sixteen years at the office of the Resident Magistrate of the District in which he resides and the record of such application and all documents relating thereto shall be forwarded to the Registrar, who may in his discretion register the applicant and issue to him or his guardian a certificate of registration.
('6', 530, 0, 1, 1044034) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 531
('6', 530, 1, 2, 1044078) PENALTIES FOR FAILING TO MAKE APPLICATION
('6', 530, 2, 3, 1044120) 8.(1)Any person who shall fail to make application for registration as required by this Act, either on his own behalf or as guardian on behalf of an Asiatic child, shall be liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding one hundred pounds and in default of payment to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a period not exceeding three months.
('6', 530, 3, 4, 1044468) (2) Any person who brings into this Colony an Asiatic under the age of sixteen years not lawfully resident therein and any person who shall employ suchchild in any trade or business shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on convictions to the following penalties
('6', 530, 4, 5, 1044742) (a) to the penalties mentioned in sub section (1) of this section; and,
('6', 530, 5, 6, 1044814) (b) if such person is the holder of a certificate of registration, to cancellation of such certificate by the Registrar;
('6', 530, 6, 7, 1044935) and thereupon the Colonial Secretary may issue an order directing such person to leave this Colony and such order shall be deemed to be an order issued under section six of the Peace Preservation Ordinance 1903 and sections seven and eight of the said Ordinance shall apply accordingly.
('6', 530, 7, 8, 1045222) (3) Any Asiatic over the age of sixteen years who after such date as may be notified by the Colonial Secretary in the Gazette is found within the Colony and fails upon such demand as is here in after mentioned to produce a certificate of registration of which he is the lawful holder may be arrested without warrant and brought before a Resident Magistrate and if he fails to satisfy such Magistrate that he is the lawful holder of a certificate of registration or that the time within which he is required to make application for such certificate has not expired, the Magistrate shall, save as in the next succeeding sub section provided, make an order in writing directing such Asiatic to leave this Colony within such time as may be specified in such order and such order shall be deemed to be an order made under section six of the Peace Preservation Ordinance 1903 and sections seven and eight of the said Ordinance shall apply accordingly.
('6', 530, 8, 9, 1046168) (4) If an Asiatic who has failed to make application for registration within the time prescribed by this Act shall satisfy the Magistrate before whom he is brought that such failure was due to some good and sufficient cause, the Magistrate may instead of making such order as aforesaid direct such Asiatic forthwith to make application for registration and if such Asiatic shall comply with such direction his application shall be dealt with in all respects as if it had been made within the time within which it was required to be made by this Act and all the provisions of this Act which would have
('6', 531, 0, 1, 1046769) 532 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 531, 1, 2, 1046811) applied if the application had been so made shall apply accordingly but if he shall fail to comply with such direction, the Magistrate shall make such order for removal as aforesaid in respect of such Asiatic.
('6', 531, 2, 3, 1047021) REGISTRATION CERTIFICATE TO BE PRODUCED ON DEMAND
('6', 531, 3, 4, 1047071) 9. Every Asiatic of the age of sixteen years or over entering or residing in this Colony shall upon demand made upon him by any member of a police force lawfully established in this Colony or any other person authorized thereto by the Colonial Secretary produce the certificate of registration of which he is the lawful holder and shall also on like demand supply such particulars and furnish such means of identification as may be prescribed by Regulation.
('6', 531, 4, 5, 1047529) Every guardian of an Asiatic child under the age of sixteen years shall produce on such demand as aforesaid any certificate of registration of which such child is the lawfulholder and supply any particulars and furnish any means of identification required by the Act or any Regulation in respect of such child.
('6', 531, 5, 6, 1047840) EVIDENCE OF REGISTRATION CERTIFICATES
('6', 531, 6, 7, 1047878) Every certificate of registration shall be accepted as conclusive evidence in all places that the lawful holder thereof notwithstanding anything in the Peace Preservation Ordinance 1903 contained is entitled to enter and reside in this Colony; provided always that this section shall not apply to persons who have under section ten of the Peace Preservation Ordinance 1903 been ordered to leave the Colony.
('6', 531, 7, 8, 1048285) DUTY OF PERSON FINDING LOST CERTIFICATES
('6', 531, 8, 9, 1048326) 11. Any person into whose hands shall come any certificate of registration or any permit issued under section seventeen of which he is not the lawful holder shall forthwith deliver or transmit the same by post as soon as may be to the Registrar of Asiatics, Pretoria.
('6', 531, 9, 10, 1048594) Any person who fails to comply with the requirements of this section shall be liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding fifty pounds or in default of payment to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a period not exceeding one month.
('6', 531, 10, 11, 1048837) PROVISION WHERE REGISTRATION CERTIFICATE IS LOST OR DESTROYED
('6', 531, 11, 12, 1048899) 12. If at any time any certificate of registration is lost or destroyed, the person who was the lawful holder thereof shall apply forthwith to the Registrar to have the same renewed and the Registrar shall upon compliance by such person with the Regulations relating to applications for the renewal of certificates and upon payment of a fee of five shillings renew such certificate.
('6', 531, 11, 13, 1049282) The said fee shall be denoted by means of revenue stamps to be affixed to such application by the applicant for such renewal and shall be defaced by the officer who receives such application.
('6', 532, 0, 1, 1049474) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 533
('6', 532, 1, 2, 1049518) TRADING LICENSES NOT TO BE GRANTED TO ASIATICS EXCEPT UPON PRODUCTION OF CERTIFICATES
('6', 532, 2, 3, 1049604) 13. After such date as may be notified by the Colonial Secretary in the Gazette, no Asiatic shall obtain any trading license issued under the Revenue Licenses Ordinance 1905 or any amendment thereof or under any bye law in force in a municipality unless he shall produce to the person appointed to issue such license a certificate of registration of which he is the lawful holder and supply such particulars and furnish such means of identification as may be prescribed by Regulation.
('6', 532, 3, 4, 1050089) EVIDENCE AS TO AGE OF ASIATIC
('6', 532, 4, 5, 1050119) 14. Whenever in any prosecution or other proceeding under this Act the age of any Asiatic is in question, such Asiatic shall unless and until the contrary be proved be taken to be of the age which the Registrar shall in any certificate issued under his hand certify to be in his opinion the apparent age of such Asiatic.
('6', 532, 5, 6, 1050440) EXEMPTION FROM STAMP DUTY OF AFFIDAVIT OR SWORN DECLARATION REQUIRED BY REGULATION
('6', 532, 6, 7, 1050523) 15. Any affidavit or sworn declaration which is required by Regulation to be made by any person who makes an application for registration either on his own behalf or on behalf of some other person shall be exempt from stamp duty.
('6', 532, 7, 8, 1050753) OFFENCES RELATING TO APPLICATIONS FOR REGISTRATION AND TO REGISTRATION CERTIFICATES
('6', 532, 8, 9, 1050837) 16. Any person who
('6', 532, 9, 10, 1050856) (i) for the purpose of or in connection with an application for registration or for the purpose of obtaining a certificate of registration commits any fraudulent act or makes any false statement or false pretence or incites any person to or aids or abets any person in such act, statement or pretence;
('6', 532, 10, 11, 1051158) (ii) forges any certificate of registration;
('6', 532, 11, 12, 1051203) (iii) uses or attempts to use as his certificate any certificate of registration of which he is not the lawful holder or any forged certificate of registration;
('6', 532, 12, 13, 1051364) (iv) incites any person to use or aids and abets any person in using as such person’s certificate any certificate of registration of which such person is not the lawful holder or any forged certificate of registration,
('6', 532, 13, 14, 1051583) shall be liable to a fine not exceeding five hundred pounds or in default of payment to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a term not exceeding two years or to both such fine and such imprisonment.
('6', 532, 14, 15, 1051791) POWER TO ISSUE PERMITS TO ASIATICS TO REMAIN IN COLONY FOR LIMITED PERIOD
('6', 532, 15, 16, 1051865) 17. (1) Notwithstanding anything in the Peace Preservation Ordinance 1903 contained a permit to enter this Colony may in the absolute discretion of
('6', 533, 0, 1, 1052013) 534 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 533, 1, 2, 1052055) the Colonial Secretary be issued in the form prescribed by Regulation authorising an Asiatic to enter and remain in this Colony for any period named in such permit and after the expiry of such period the person authorized by such permit to enter this Colony shall be deemed to be a person not duly authorized to be in this Colony and if found may be arrested without warrant and the provisions of sections seven and eight of the said Ordinance shall apply to such person as if he were a person who at the date of such expiry had been ordered to leave this Colony under section six of the said Ordinance and had failed to comply with such order.
('6', 533, 1, 3, 1052700) (2) The provisions of section nine of the said Ordinance shall in all cases apply to permits issued under this section.
('6', 533, 1, 4, 1052820) (3) Any permit issued before the date of the taking effect of this Act to an Asiatic under the Indemnity and Peace Preservation Ordinance 1902 or any amendment thereof and expressed to authorize such Asiatic to remain in this Colony for a limited time only shall be deemed to be a permit issued under this section.
('6', 533, 1, 5, 1053135) (4) The Colonial Secretary may in his discretion order that the person authorized by any permit issued under this section to enter and remain in this Colony shall not during the currency of such permit be deemed to be a coloured person for the purpose of the provisions of the Liquor Licensing Ordinance 1902 or any amendment thereof and such order shall be endorsed on such permit and shall be of full force and effect for such purposes.
('6', 533, 2, 6, 1053574) (5) The Colonial Secretary may issue any such order as in the last preceding sub section mentioned in respect of any person who is a member of an Asiatic race and is not subject to the provisions of this Act.
('6', 533, 3, 7, 1053783) POWER TO MAKE REGULATIONS
('6', 533, 4, 8, 1053809) 18. The Governor in Council may from time to time make, alter and repeal Regulations for any of the following purposes: (1) prescribing the form of the register to be kept under this Act; (2) prescribing the manner and form in which application shall be made for registration, the particulars to be supplied and the means of identification to be furnished by any applicant or the guardian of any applicant for the purpose of or in connection with such application; (3) prescribing the form of certificates of registration; (4) prescribing the particulars to be supplied and the means of identification to be furnished: (a) by the guardian of any Asiatic child under the age of eight years under section six of this Act; (b) by any Asiatic upon such demand as is in section nine of this Act
('6', 534, 0, 1, 1054599) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 535
('6', 534, 1, 2, 1054643) mentioned; (c) by any Asiatic applying for the renewal of any certificate of registration which has been lost or destroyed; (d) by any Asiatic applying for a trading license; (5) prescribing the form of permit to be issued under section seventeen of this Act.
('6', 534, 2, 3, 1054903) GENERAL PENALTIES
('6', 534, 3, 4, 1054921) 19. Any Asiatic or the guardian of any Asiatic failing to comply with any requirement of this Act shall except where otherwise specified be liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding one hundred pounds or in default of payment to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a period not exceeding three months.
('6', 534, 4, 5, 1055235) PROVISIONS AS TO CERTAIN ASIATICS UNDER CONTRACTS OF SERVICE
('6', 534, 5, 6, 1055296) 20. Notwithstanding anything contained in the Labour Importation Ordinance 1904, no Asiatic who is the lawful holder of a certificate of registration and no Asiatic who was lawfully resident in this Colony or allowed to enter it under a proper permit before the date of the said Ordinance shall be prohibited from entering or residing in or being introduced into this Colony by reason of the fact that he is under a contract of service and has not entered into the contract referred to in section eight of the said Ordinance.
('6', 534, 6, 7, 1055822) PROVISION AS TO HOLDING FIXED PROPERTY
('6', 534, 7, 8, 1055861) 21. Notwithstanding anything contained in sub section (b) of Article two of Law No.
('6', 534, 7, 9, 1055945) 3 of 1885 as amended by Volksraad Resolution Article 1419 of the twelfth day ofAugust 1886, any fixed property in this Colony acquired by an Asiatic before the taking effect of such Law and registered in the name of such Asiatic whether before or after the taking effect of such Law may be transmitted by such Asiatic to another Asiatic by testamentary or other inheritance.
('6', 534, 8, 10, 1056320) TITLE AND DATE OF TAKING EFFECT
('6', 534, 9, 11, 1056352) 22. This Act may be cited for all purposes as the Asiatic Law Amendment Act 1907 and shall not take effect unless and until the Governor shall proclaim in the Gazette that it is His Majesty’s pleasure not to disallow the same and thereafter it shall take effect upon such date as the Governor shall notify by Proclamation.
('6', 534, 10, 12, 1056675) PEACE PRESERVATION ORDINANCE
('6', 534, 11, 13, 1056704) The following are the sections referred to in the above Act from the Peace Preservation Ordinance No.
('6', 534, 11, 14, 1056806) 5 of 1903:
('6', 534, 12, 15, 1056817) PERSONS ARRESTED TO BE EXAMINED BY A MAGISTRATE
('6', 534, 13, 16, 1056865) 6. Every person so arrested shall with all convenient speed be brought before a
('6', 535, 0, 1, 1056945) 536 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('6', 535, 1, 2, 1056987) Magistrate and if he fails to satisfy the Magistrate that he is duly authorised to enter or reside in this Colony under the provisions of this Ordinance, the Magistrate may make an order in writing directing such person to leave this Colony within such time as may be specified in such order provided that if such person declares upon oath that he has already obtained a permit and gives satisfactory reasons for his inability to produce the same or if he declares upon oath that he can produce satisfactory evidence that he belongs to one of the classes exempted from the necessity of obtaining a permit by the provisions of section two hereof, he may be released upon entering into a recognisance with or without sureties to produce before any Magistrate named in such recognisance and within the time stated therein such permit or evidence, as the case may be.
('6', 535, 1, 3, 1057851) If such person fails to comply with the conditions of his recognisance, it shall be forfeited.
('6', 535, 2, 4, 1057946) PENALTIES FOR NOT COMPLYING WITH THE ORDER TO LEAVE THE COLONY
('6', 535, 3, 5, 1058009) 7. Any person who may be ordered to leave this Colony and fails to do so within the time specified in the order and any person whose recognizance has been forfeited under the provisions of the last preceding section may be arrested without warrant and brought before a Magistrate and shall upon conviction be sentenced to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a period of not less than one month and not more than six months and with or without a fine not exceeding five hundred pounds and in default of payment to a further term of imprisonment for a period not exceeding six months.
('6', 535, 4, 6, 1058601) FURTHER PENALTIES FOR REMAINING IN THE COLONY
('6', 535, 5, 7, 1058647) 8. If any person imprisoned under the terms of the last preceding section shall remain in the Colony for a period of more than seven days after the expiration of his term of imprisonment or any subsequent term of imprisonment imposed under this section without obtaining permission in writing from the Colonial Secretary to remain in theColony the burden of proving which shall be upon him, he may be arrested without a warrant and brought before a Magistrate and shall on conviction be sentenced to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a period of not less than six and not more than twelve months and with or without a fine not exceeding five hundred pounds and in default of payment to a further term of imprisonment for a period not exceeding six months.
('6', 535, 6, 8, 1059414) FALSE PERMITS
('6', 535, 7, 9, 1059428) 9. Any person who
('6', 535, 8, 10, 1059446) (1) obtains or attempts to obtain or incites any person to obtain or aids or abets any person in obtaining a permit by any fraud, misrepresentation, false pretence, falsehood or other improper means;
('6', 536, 0, 1, 1059646) VOL. 6 : 5 NOVEMBER, 1906 12 JUNE, 1907 537
('6', 536, 1, 2, 1059690) (2) uses or attempts to use or incites any person to use or aids or abets any person in using any permit so obtained;
('6', 536, 2, 3, 1059808) (3) enters or attempts to enter this Colony on a permit so obtained or on a permit not issued to him by proper authority shall be liable to a fine not exceeding five hundred pounds or to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a term not exceeding two years or to both such fine and such imprisonment.
('6', 536, 3, 4, 1060115) PERSONS DANGEROUS TO PEACE AND GOOD GOVERNMENT
('6', 536, 4, 5, 1060162) 10. It shall be lawful for the Lieutenant Governor on its being shown to his satisfaction that there are reasonable grounds for believing that any person within this Colony is dangerous to the peace and good government of the country to issue an order under the hand of the Colonial Secretary to such person to leave the Colony within such time after service of such order as may be stated therein.
('6', 536, 4, 6, 1060561) If on the expiration of the said period such person shall be found within the Colony, he shall be proceeded against in manner prescribed in sections seven and eight of this Ordinance and shall be subject to penalties therein provided.
